“The entry of stray cattle from MP and Rajasthan should be looked into,” he said, while responding to a query raised in the Assembly by Congress MLA and UP party state chief Ajay Kumar Lallu who sought to ask what steps the state government was taking to curtail the menace which is causing damage to crops of farmers.

Khanna said that the state government was taking various steps including setting up of cattle shelter homes. “We also need to consider the fact where these stray cattle are coming from. They are being left on the borders of MP and Rajasthan from where they enter into UP,” he said, adding: “Sarkar ko badnaam karne ke liye yahan par chhurwa rahe hain (They are letting loose their cattle here to defame the government).”

His response led to a fracas in the assembly with Congress slamming the state government of making its failure a political issue. Leader of opposition and SP MLA Ram Govind Chaudhary said that the menace of stray cattle has only grown after Yogi government came to power.

Title: Lucknow Clock Tower firing: 11 booked for rioting
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

LUCKNOW: A day after firing near Clock Tower during a clash between two groups sparked panic in the area, police booked 11 persons from both sides on charges of attempt to murder and rioting on Monday. Those booked include advocate Mirza Fazal Ali Beg, who allegedly fired in the air from his licensed pistol.

Besides Beg, FIR has been lodged against Imran Haider, Kamil, Aizaz, Akram and six unidentified men. Beg and Haider were arrested by police and while Beg got interim bail, haider was sent to jail. The FIR was lodged by police itself because no party came forward to lodge complaint. “Since there was firing and violence during the clash that endangered public life, we had to lodge an FIR,” said police commissioner Sujeet Pandey. “Two groups, one led by Kamil and the other by Aizaz, had first clashed over a petty dispute on Sunday. Beg came in support of Aizaz and allegedly fired in air to scare the rival group,” said Station House Officer, Thakurganj, Pramod Kumar.

Title: Murthal eateries operating without nod: CPCB
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Central Pollution Control Board ( CPCB ) on Monday told the National Green Tribunal ( NGT ) that restaurants and roadside eateries at Murthal in Haryana were operating without approval from the state pollution control boards and extracting groundwater without permission.

The apex pollution monitoring body, which along with Haryana state pollution control board and the municipal corporation inspected the eating outlets, told a bench headed by NGT chairperson Justice Adarsh Kumar Goel that the units need to take necessary permission from state pollution control boards for operating roadside eateries and restaurants.

“The state boards should ensure that these roadside eateries or restaurants obtain necessary permission from them as per the state policy. No unit should be allowed in areas in which such facilities are not available and should be closed down or shifted to areas where such facilities are available,” CPCB said in its report.

It also recommended that the state boards should ensure that necessary infrastructure with respect to collection and treatment of sewage and solid waste was provided prior to granting permission to such units.

“The state board must have robust mechanism to evaluate compliance with norms of such units at least twice a year,” it added.

Title: Killer spots on Bhopal roads remain dangerous, seven more added
Content:
KN Pradhan roundabout

BHOPAL: Despite decline in the number of casualties reported in road accidents in the city last year, the number of ‘black spots’ (accident-prone zones) has increased from nine to 16. After analysing the road accident data of past three years, traffic police have identified seven new black spots.Accident-prone zones, which are black spots for traffic police, are not new but rectifying the problems after identifying these zones still remains a problem with the agencies assigned to address road safety.A senior traffic police personnel, wishing anonymity, said that steps to reduce accidents in accident-prone zones are taken up by the traffic police, but negligence by ‘other agencies’ responsible for rectifying the problems in these zones leads to delay and the risk of accidents remains unchanged.In order to identify black spots, police took into account 300-500 metres of road stretches on which five or more major accidents have occurred or 10 people or more have lost their lives in the past three years —- from 2017 to 2019, he added.The seven newly identified black spots include the 400-metre stretch of road at Ratnagiri trisection in Piplani where six severe road accidents took place in the past three years, leading to the loss of four lives. Two fatal accidents were reported at the same spot this year in January in which two persons, including a 48-year-old woman central excise inspector and a 21-year-old lab assistant, lost their lives.Among the other black spots, the 500-metre stretch at KN Pradhan Square near Professor Colony has been included where four casualties were reported in six severe road accidents. The 500-metre stretch at Anna Nagar Square has also been classified as a black spot this year where four casualties were reported in five serious accidents. Another black spot identified was the ITI Trisection where five fatal accidents were reported on the 500-metre road stretch, killing three people.At the 500-metre stretch of Chanchal Square in Bairagarh, there were three casualties in five severe accidents. The 500-metre stretch of Golkheri Square in Eintkheri is also identified as a black spot where four casualties were reported in five serious accidents. Similarly, the 500-metre stretch of Hoshangabad Road at Surendra Palace main road in Bag Sewania has been identified as a new black spot, where four people lost their lives in five road accidents in the last three years.The traffic police have taken some measures at the black spots, such as installing boards of speed limits, installing stoppers, deploying police personnel and urging that traffic signals be put up. But the rectification cannot be completed fully until the road construction agencies, including Bhopal Municipal Corporation, PWD, CPA and others take required measures by constructing dividers, putting up traffic signals, resizing the rotaries and other steps.Sources in traffic police department said that police identify the black spots and temporarily make dividers using barricades. The construction agencies are expected to complete civil work for rectification, but they do nothing, he alleged. Giving an example, the traffic source said that ever since the Chetak Bridge was widened, there has been an immediate need to construct a divider. Police temporarily kept barricades to make a divider. But despite repeated letters and reminders, the divider is not being constructed. Similarly, temporary dividers were made with barricades at Bhadbhada Square, 6-Number Market, Rajbhawan Road and other places.The source said that except police control room, road construction agencies concerned did nothing to rectify the nine black spots identified last year.Speaking on the issue, DIG Irshad Wali said police have identified seven new black spots this year. The details of work needed to rectify these black spots have been forwarded to agencies concerned and appropriate action will be taken soon.

Title: Customs seize 620 grams of gold
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Jaipur: Sleuths of the customs department have seized 620 grams of gold which was smuggled by a passenger who arrived at Jaipur from Bangkok late on Sunday evening.

Officials said the gold in the form of paste was concealed by the passenger in his rectum and jeans.

According to information, the Air Asia flight reached Jaipur from Bangkok late on Sunday evening. “Acting on a specific input on a male passenger travelling with gold, the suspect was properly checked and frisked.

“While he was being checked by our team found, gold in paste form concealed in one of the pockets of the jeans and gold pellets in rubbery form were found concealed in the rectum of the passenger. After we recovered gold from his pocket, the passenger confessed that he had also concealed some in rubbery form in his rectum which, too, was recovered,” said a senior customs officer at Jaipur airport .

The total seizure from the passenger was around 620 grams which is worth about Rs 27 lakh in the Indian market.

Box

3 cases reported earlier this year

Earlier on February 5 and 12, three cases of concealed gold in the rectum were reported at the Jaipur airport. In the first case, a female passenger Mumtaz Abdul Rashid had hidden 310.94 grams of gold worth Rs 13.10 lakh in the rectum. In the second case Abdul Nazir had brought 475.99 grams of gold hidden in the rectum. In the third case a passenger identified as Bilal had brought 589.86 grams of gold hidden in his rectum, which was worth Rs 24.65 lakh.

Title: UP: Man held for raping niece’s daughter in a village of Azamgarh
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

Title: CAA Protest in Hyderabad: Anti-CAA protests reach Telangana towns, villages
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Locals protest on the streets of Sathupalli in Khammam district

HYDERABAD: Protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens have spread to smaller town in Telangana as a large population of Muslims joined a demonstration in Sathupalli on Sunday, shouting slogans.

The protest was led by Jamaat-e-Islami Hind women wing. Ruling Telangana Rashtra Samithi and Congress party functionaries extended support to them.

JIH functionary Khalida Parveen said during the protest, "Women should emulate the Shaheen Bagh protests against CAA and NRC. To create division between castes and religion is anti-constitutional. If someone asks us about our documents in NRC, we would tell them to take our DNA tests. It is an insult to ask us to prove our nationality. We will continue our protests till NRC and CAA re withdrawn."

TRS local functionary Matta Dayanand also spoke against NRC and CAA. National Christian Council local members extended support to the protest, attended by more than a thousand women.

A top intelligence official of Telangana police said that the anti-CAA protests are spreading to the towns. "The fear among the minority community is increasing. We are anticipating more serious protests," he said.

Sathupalli inspector of police Ramakanth told TOI, "Hundreds of Muslim women took part in the rally that went on peacefully. I have no information on whether they have taken permission for the rally.”

He added, "Earlier there were regular protests where locals expressed solidarity with the statewide protests.”

Title: CM inaugurates AP’s second Disha police station in VZM
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy inaugurated the state’s second Disha police station in Vizianagaram town on Monday. The police station will have a staff strength of 40 and will be headed by a DSP rank officer. The state’s first Disha police station was also inaugurated by the CM in Rajahmundry earlier this month.

Addressing a public gathering on the occasion, Jagan said the government was working on transforming all villages in the state into self-sufficient and self-administered units. “All facilities would be available for people living in the villages, with each village secretariat catering to the needs of 2,000 people,” he said, while urging the staff of the 11,158 village secretariats to serve the public sincerely and honestly.

“All government schools would be transformed into well-equipped and well-manned English medium schools under the Nadu-Nedu programme, which would allow locals to send their children to government schools and not private ones. Rythu Bharosa centres would also be set up in all village secretariats soon. Besides, the government also plans to establish village clinics to cater to the health needs of local residents at the secretariats,” Jagan added.

He also urged the ‘mahila samrakshana karyadarsis’ (women secretaries dedicated for the protection of women at village secretariats) to crack down on people running belt shops and selling arrack in their areas. Their reports would be directly sent to the DGP, home department and CM’s office, who would take a call on the action required to be taken, he said.

The CM also officially launched the Vasathi Deevena scheme at Ayodhya maidan. Under the scheme, over Rs 2,278 crore will be deposited in the accounts of parents of all deserving students across the state. While Rs 10,000 would be provided to those pursuing polytechnic, Rs 15,000 would be provided for undergraduate courses and Rs 20,000 for those pursuing higher courses. The amounts would be deposited in the accounts of parents of all deserving students.

“Poverty is one of the main reasons why many deserving students do not go for higher education. This scheme would help such students realise their dreams,” Jagan said. Pointing out that the government was spending close to Rs 6,000 crore on students alone, he said another Rs 3,000 crore would be spent on Amma Vodi scheme. He also added that the government plans to start bridge courses to help students realise their dreams.

Title: Jaipur: Two Nigerians held with 21 gm cocaine
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The accused Abbas and Ibrahim

JAIPUR: The police have arrested two Nigerians for allegedly peddling drugs from Apex Circle in Malviya Nagar area under the Clean Sweep Operation late on Monday night. Twenty one grams of cocaine have been recovered from them.

The accused have been identified as 23-year-old Abbas, a resident of Ajaro of Nigeria and 29-year-old Ibrahim, a resident of Kano state, Nigeria. Police have been keeping an eye on both for the past couple of months.

According to police, Abbas came to Jaipur for studying in 2016 from Nigeria. He got admission in a private university on Delhi Road for graduation in Geography. But, he left the city after studying for two semesters. He went to Haryana and he came back to Jaipur in 2019 and lived in a PG hostel, police said.

The police said that they investigated into the matter and found that Abbas was not studying in any college or university and he was not doing any job in the past two years. He was found frequently around the private university spending most of his time in cafes. The police said that they are investigating to find out if he was part of any drug cartel.

Ibrahim, who has also been arrested by the police, had come to Rajasthan for studying B. Pharmacy in 2015. In 2019, he managed to get a degree in B. Pharmacy. Ibrahim was illegally living in an apartment which has already been acquired by the LIC.

The police said, while investigating into the matter, they found that the cocaine which was found from their procession was provided to them by another Nigerian national. The police have launched a search for the person who provided them the drugs.

Title: Mumbai doctors remove 41-year-old man’s 12.8kg ‘giant’ kidneys
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

MUMBAI: City doctors have removed giant kidneys weighing 7kg and 5.8kg from a Goan man living with a life-threatening genetic condition. While a normal kidney weighs 120-150 gram and is 8-10cm long, 41-year-old Roman Pereira’s were nearly 26cm and 21cm in length.

Pereira suffered from kidney failure due to a genetic condition called autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), where normal kidney tissues are replaced by cysts. Though he was living with the condition since a decade, it had gradually begun to disrupt his life, often leaving him breathless and weak to walk since the past one and a half years. His haemoglobin levels, too, had begun to deplete. In November last year, though, his condition turned serious after he began to bleed.

Nephrologist Dr Bharat Shah of Parel’s Global Hospital said ADPKD was an uncommon condition seen in around 5% of patients who develop kidney failure.

Renal transplant surgeon Dr Pradeep Rao said since the kidneys were of a gigantic size, they could not take the laparoscopic approach and instead had to do an open surgery. “Through a single incision, we could remove both kidneys which weighed 12.8kg in total,” he said.

Pereira’s life could be saved through a swap transplant. While his wife Placima wanted to donate a kidney, her blood group was incompatible with him.

Doctors found a match in Amravati couple Nitin and Radha Tapar. Radha, too, could not donate to Nitin as they had incompatible tissue types. “We transplanted Pereira with Radha’s kidney and Nitin with Placima’s in December. Both are well,” said Dr Shah.

Title: Rajasthan high court dismisses plea challenging triple talaq
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A division bench of Rajasthan high court on Monday dismissed a PIL challenging triple talaq saying the petitioner had no locus standi in the case.

Petitioner Shantanu Pareek, an advocate by profession, had filed a PIL against the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019 passed in Parliament. The Act has criminalised the practice of triple talaq.

The petitioner stated that the constitutional bench of the Supreme Court in the case of ‘Shayara Bano’ had set aside the practice of triple talaq and had declared that it is also not recognised by Shariyat and thus has no legal sanctity and status. “The PIL has been filed since passing of the Act is a clear violation of Article 21of the Constitution as it also makes ‘triple talaq’ void.

The bench comprising Justice Sabina and Justice NS Dhadha dismissed the petition saying the petitioner had no locus standi in the case. The court also observed that the petitioner was not affected directly or indirectly by the law.

Title: UP: Woman tweets about harassment in bus, cops nab accused at next stop
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Rizwan and Mohammed were arrested in Rudauli

LUCKNOW: Courageous and timely action by a woman led police to nab two youths passing comments and misbehaving with her on-board a UPSRTC bus on Monday.

The youths were intercepted at Rudauli police station and nabbed by police. The 21-year-old woman thanked the police and CM for quick action.

The woman, a law student, had boarded an AC bus run by Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) from Lucknow for Basti. At Kaiserbagh, two youths—later identified as Rizwan and Mohammed of Faizabad—boarded the bus.

“On finding the woman sitting alone, the duo got seated beside her. They first asked for her phone number and then passed lewd remarks,” said Faizabad SSP Ashish Tiwari.

The woman, sensing their intentions, decided to teach them a lesson, said the officer.

“She first quietly made a video and then posted it on Twitter, tagging UP Police, UP chief minister and UPSRTC, seeking help. The CM office immediately alerted us and we swung into action,” said the SP.

The police intercepted the bus at Rudauli and after the woman identified the miscreants, police took them in custody. Rudauli SHO Vishwanath Prasad said they will be produced in front of a magistrate on Tuesday.

The woman thanked UP Police on Twitter while police replied saying, “You have shown how social media can be actively used to report emergencies.”

Title: Row over police action at guest house of vernacular; minister orders probe
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Jaipur: Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal on Monday ordered an inquiry into reported police action at a vernacular daily’s guest house for playing loud music during a birthday party. Leader of opposition Gulab Chand Kataria raised the matter during Zero Hour in the state assembly alleging that the police led by the commissioner entered the campus in Civil Lines area on Sunday night.

Kataria said two policemen could have gone to stop the music being played after 10pm and questioned the presence of the police commissioner at the guest house. He alleged that the police action followed as the venue was near the chief minister's residence and added that women guests were asked to stand in a corner but there were no women police personnel.

When contacted, Jaipur police commissioner Anand Srivastava said action was taken for playing loud music in night hours. He denied he was present at the guest house.

As per the regional paper’s news report, a birthday party of a Jaipur-based bank owner’s son was going on in the guest house and the police team misbehaved with the women guests there. It questioned why the police do not act on neighbouring marriage gardens that routinely play loud music after 10pm.

The opposition leader alleged that the Congress-led state government was annoyed with the vernacular as it was running news reports against the present dispensation.

Minister Dhariwal strongly refuted the charge. He said it was the previous BJP government that stopped advertisements to the newspaper. Dhariwal said an inquiry will be conducted into the incident by officer of a rank higher than the police commissioner.

Title: Former Prashant Kishor aide joins N Chandrababu Naidu’s team as key strategist
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

N Chandrababu Naidu

HYDERABAD: After working as an independent and full-time campaign manager for Priyanka Gandhi in Uttar Pradesh, Robbin Sharrma, a former associate of Prashant Kishor, is now assisting Nara Chandrababu Naidu’s TDP as a strategist.

TDP is facing a tough challegenge to keep its flock together while Naidu is caught in legal battles.

Sharrma has already started his work. He sits in an office on the third floor of NTR Bhavan in Banjara Hills (TDP headquarters) where he is reportedly focusing on building a social media platform for the party.

Sharrma was the co-founder of Kishor-led Citizens for Accountable Governance (CAG) - which ran a successful campaign for Narendra Modi in 2014 - and Indian Political Action Committee (IPAC). “We have no idea about his nature of work. But, we are hoping he will work wonders for the party,” a TDP leader on condition of anonymity told TOI.

Party sources said young MP from Srikakulam K Ram Mohan Naidu is working closely with Sharrma. “To begin with, it could be on establishing a social media platform for the party,” said a former party politburo member.

Some leaders said Sharrma should focus on working out strategies to beat the ruling YSRC in Andhra Pradesh in the forthcoming civic polls. “However, his prime focus will be ensuring a TDP victory in 2024 assembly elections,” a senior leader said.

For now, Sharrma leads a small team, which has started visiting some places in AP to get an idea as to where TDP stands. Party sources said it would be a huge challenge for Sharrma and his team to counter the “caste image” created around TDP by the ruling YSRC in the 2019 election campaign.

Interestingly, Kishor-led IPAC first approached TDP in last year’s election before it started working with Jagan’s YSRCP. Since IPAC is closely associated with YSRC, TDP sources said Sharrma’s team would work independently with Naidu’s party.

It is also learnt that a teaching professional Srikanth, who was a close associate of former planning board member Srinivasulu Naidu, has also started working with TDP.

Title: Smart Grid Control Centre and SGCT training prog inaugurated at IIT-K
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kanpur: A Smart Grid Control Centre, set up at IIT-Kanpur, was inaugurated by joint secretary, ministry of power, Mrityunjay Kumar Narayan along with director of IIT-Kanpur, Prof Abhay Karandikar and director, National Smart Grid Mission (Project management unit) NSGM-NPMU, AK Mishra here on Monday.

The centre has been set up as part of the smart grid pilot project titled 'Development of R&D platform for smart city pilot projects in the Indian context' which was equally funded by the ministry of power (MoP) and IIT-Kanpur.

The Control Centre has a state-of-the-art facility to monitor IIT-Kanpur's distribution substations through the SCADA system. It also has advanced metering infrastructure integrated with meter data management system, smart meters, along with home automation and rooftop solar PV integration. Using this control centre, the institute will carry out various researches, demonstrations and training activities in the Smart Grid area.

Recently, the institute had also signed MOU with National Smart Grid Mission, ministry of power, to start a series of training programmes in Smart Grid area for utility, R&D and industry professionals.

The first such training programme on 'Smart Grid Components and Technologies' is organised by Prof Saikat Chakraborty and Prof Ankush Sharma in Smart Grid Control Centre. The training programme was also inaugurated by Mrityunjay Kumar Narayan, Prof Abhay Karandikar and AK Mishra.

The main objective of the training programme is to familiarise the participants of utilities from industries and R&D organisations about different concepts and developments in Smart Grid Technology. This will help them to understand the role of modern information and communication technology (ICT) infrastructure in helping to monitor and control the power systems more effectively.

With an increase in penetration of SGT in power systems, there has been a growing demand of real-time visualization, monitoring, and control of the power system. Further, the present-day electricity sector is witnessing increased share of renewables, storage, EV charging stations, microgrids, intelligent sensors and controllers, automation, and smart metering at different levels in the network.

This leads to transmission and distribution networks requiring cyber-secure Advanced Energy Management System (AEMS) and Advanced Distribution Management System (ADMS) tools. The large penetration of renewables, being intermittent in nature, will pose system stability and power quality concerns, which will require proper compensation and controls. The above challenges faced by the power system network will be discussed in detail in this course.

Title: Separate lanes to ease traffic flow near Bank Road Crossing
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The barricades put up at Bank Road Crossing on Monday

Allahabad: Commuters in Allahabad would now won’t have to worry about heavy traffic while driving towards Bank Road Crossing, which connects Katra and Allahabad University.

Traffic police introduced separate lanes to streamline vehicular movement on the stretch. Apart from installing barricades on Monday, police also removed squatters on the footpath.

After the Magh Mela, traffic police selected 20 main crossings and intersections in the city to make streamline traffic flow around those routes. Traffic police decided to put up barricades to introduce separate lanes for easy commuting.

The separate lane system has already been introduced at UPSSC Crossing, Maharana Pratap Crossing, Traffic Chaurah and Dhobi Ghat Crossing. Besides, additional pickets of traffic police and home guards have also been deployed on these lanes.

SSP (Allahabad) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “We are focussing on improving traffic movement at important crossings and intersections. We have put up barricades to ensure that commuters are not stuck in snarls while turning left and do not have to be trapped in the rush of commuters driving straight.”

A senior traffic cop said “Commuters turning left at the crossing usually are trapped in the rush of commuters. They alos face difficulties while turning left.”

Title: Focus on Ram temple now, not Kashi, Mathura: Nritya Gopal
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Jhansi: Shri Ram Janmabhoomi Teertha Kshetra Trust chairman Mahant Nritya Gopal Das said focus is on construction of Ram temple and dismissed reports of Kashi and Mathura being on the agenda for now.

Speaking to reporters in Jhansi, Mahant said, “Let the construction of Ram temple in Ayodhya get over. Then only we can talk of Kashi and Mathura.” Mahant further announced that no money will be taken from government and Ram temple will be built with the contribution of people. He said the construction will start in next one month, and added that CM Yogi Adityanath is in power in state and PM Narendra Modi at Centre and the temple construction will start in their presence.

Title: ‘Remains of 3,500-yr-old human settlement’ found
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

VARANASI: A team of archaeologists from BHU ’s department of Ancient Indian History, Culture and Archaeology, have claimed to have found remains of a 3,500-year-old human settlement of sculptors on the city outskirts at Babhaniyav village situated along the holy Panchkoshi route.

“During the field survey of the area, we found several evidences, including a pillar with inscription in Brahmi script and a number of stole sculptures and idols of deities of Kushan and post-Gupta periods,” said project director and head of the department professor Onkar Nath Singh.

“Discovery of idols and Shivlingas, both complete and incomplete forms, suggests that there might be a settlement of sculptors. After these findings, we sent a proposal to the Archaeological Survey of India for excavation, which was accepted,” he added.

“We are going to begin the excavation from February 26 at the village,” said professor AK Dubey, a team member. “As the antiquity of the surface evidences belong to the period of around 1500BC, it could be safely said that it is contemporary to Harappan civilization,” he said.

Former additional director general of ASI, BR Mani, too, endorsed the observation of BHU archaeologists. “I visited the site in Babhaniyav village which could be at least 3,500 years old,” Mani told TOI on Monday.

The antiquity of Babhaniyav village came to notice during the survey of holy Panchkroshi route for documentation under a UGC project, said Singh. “After we found ancient stone sculptures all around in the village, we decided to go into depth to unearth something meaningful,” he said.

Title: With TA out, opinion builds up to open Sitabuldi Fort for public
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: With 118 Territorial Army (TA) having moved out, the general opinion in the city is that the Sitabuldi Fort should be opened for public daily, and developed into a tourism spot like Daulatabad Fort, Red Fort etc. City MP and Union minister Nitin Gadkari and West Nagpur MLA Vikas Thakre are likely to take up this initiative.

After TA moved out from the historical Sitabuldi Fort to Bhusawal in November 2018, the grade-I heritage fort houses the HQ Uttar Maharashtra and Gujarat Sub Area (UMANG). TA stayed at the fort for over 80 years with a huge posse of personnel and ammunition, which was the main reason for Sitabuldi Fort not being opened for the public on daily basis. TA used to permit public entry on Independence Day, Republic Day etc.

In 2018, Gadkari took up the issue with the then defence minister late Manohar Parrikar, who was in favour of opening the fort for public even when TA was occupying it. The process was started to open the fort to public on Saturdays and Sundays. Unfortunately, the process stopped after the demise of Parrikar.

Sources from Gadkari’s office told TOI correspondence with the defence ministry will begin now that TA has moved out, and the fort does not have any defence related sensitive issues.

Thakre said he had also made up his mind to approach the state’s archaeological department to take over the fort, operate, maintain and open it for public like Daulatabad Fort and other places. “Archaeological department can keep a nominal entry fee and spend it on development, operation and maintenance,” he said.

A controversy erupted recently over the fort with activists staging demonstrations at Samvidhan Square alleging UMANG was planning a club house inside the fort. However, UMANG clarified they are planning only to permit existing mess services to ex-servicemen.

BJP city president Pravin Datke said the defence ministry under Parrikar had given consent to open the fort for public on Saturdays and Sundays. “Defence ministry was positive for water fountain cum cascade proposed by Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) inside the fort facing Morris College T-point. The fort has historical significance due to battles, martyrs and stay of Mahatma Gandhi. It also is a big part of the city’s history. It is very important to open it for public so the next generation has knowledge about our history and importance of city. Also, city does not have fort related tourism spots,” he said.

Even the Heritage Conservation Committee feels the fort should be opened for the public. Member and architect Ashok Mokha said there is no significance and meaning of heritage structure if it is closed for people. “Heritage structure will lose its character and deteriorate if not in regular maintenance. It is unfortunate that we have to teach students about Sitabuldi Fort on paper despite it being situated right in the middle of the city. Even walking tracks and gardens can come up around the fort,” he said.

At the same time, retired TA personnel and some activists are demanding bringing back of 118 TA to Sitabuldi Fort instead of keeping it under UMANG.

The demand for opening fort for public had first been made in 2002. The then MP Vilas Muttemwar had raised the issue in Parliament in 2002 and 2007.

Title: Rajasthan: Tihawali villagers demand martyr status for Ratan Lal
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ratan Lal had visited his native village around a month ago

JAIPUR: Head constable Ratan Lal (42), who died during a clash over Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in Delhi on Monday, had promised his children to celebrate Holi at their native village Tihawali in Fatehpur tehsil of Sikar district.

He had visited his village around a month ago when his aunt had died. Lal had joined Delhi Police in 1998 and since then had been living in the national capital with his family in Krishna Nagar. “To celebrate Holi, his family had decided to come to Tihawali,” his cousin Prakash Singh Shekhawat said.

Lal is survived by his mother, wife and three children (two daughters and a son). “We have not informed his mother about his death. His father had passed away some 10 years ago and he was the eldest in the family,” said Shekhawat.

The villagers have demanded ‘martyr’ status for him. They also demanded that the government school in Tihawali should be named after Lal. Youths gathered at Tihawali gram panchayat after they recieved the news.

The villagers demanded that the state and the Centre should announce benefits that are given to a martyr. The villagers are also demanding that Lal should be consigned to flames with full state honours.

“Almost each and every house has a policemen or an army men in the village,” said Sunil Chaudhary, a social worker of Tihawali village.

Title: Man kills businessman over property dispute, buries him in his own field
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Allahabad: A man was arrested on Monday for allegedly murdering a property dealer and dumping his body in Bahoripur village, under the limits of Soraon police station.

The accused was identified as Vipul Patel (23) of Bahoripur village.

Police said the deceased Niraj Kumar Mishra (40) was a resident of Malak Har Har and had been missing since Saturday evening. His family last saw him leaving home to purchase medicines on Saturday. Police recovered his body on Monday morning.

“Mishra and Patel were at loggerheads over a property dispute, which eventually led to the former’s murder,” said SSP (Allahabad) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj. The accused Vipul Patel had a dispute with Mishra over a piece of property worth Rs 2 lakh. “The accused told the police that the two had entered into an agreement over an year ago. Mishra had agreed to hand over a property to Patel in exchange for Rs 2 lakh. However, Mishra had not fulfilled his end of the deal even a year after the agreement,” said the SSP.

Fed up of Mishra’s antics, Patel hatched a plan to kill him.

On Saturday evening, the accused called Mishra and told him to come to his field to have a few drinks. Patel’s field is located in Atrampur in Bahoripur village. The accused then asked the property broker to fetch an item for him. As soon as Mishra turned, Patel shot him. The accused later buried the body i his own field.

Meanwhile, when Mishra did not turn up till late night and his mobile phone was switched off, his family approached the police on Saturday evening.

The police then approached the chemist, where Mishra went to. The shop’s owner told the police that the victim had come to his shop along with an unidentified youth. Police later came to know that Mishra was last seen with Vipul. He was spotted riding pillion with the latter on his motorcycle to an unidentified location.

Police then arrested Patel and recovered Mishra’s body.

Title: Bus collides with truck on highway, 25 injured
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Allahabad: A bus collided with a speeding truck leaving at least 25 passengers injured near Harisenganj on Allahabad-Pratapgarh highway, under Mauaima police station, on Monday.

SSP (Allahabad) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said the accident occurred between 12.30am and 1am. The bus was carrying at least 45 passengers and collided with the truck while overtaking the other vehicle.

Police said most of the injured passengers were from Andhra Pradesh. The bus was on it way to Assam from Andhra Pradesh.

“Ten passengers were administered first aid at the nearby thana and the remaining 15 were sent to Swaroop Rani Nehru Hospital for treatment,” the SSP added.

Of the 15 passengers, 13 were discharged later and two others are still undergoing treatment. Their condition is stated to be stable.

The injured passengers were identified as R Omkar Raju, R Naagraje, R Nagaratnam, R Ape Amma, V Sachiwati, V Aape Amma, P Rajarao, Bhaskar Rao, Jyoti, Venkat Rao, U Arjunnama, C Apalkonda, Ramna, M Aparna, M Shriram, K Facelet, K Gangma, K Hondama, K Chantaili, M Lauchubi, J Parvati, S S Sewa Rao and Suresh.

Title: Mumbai: Elderly woman in Versova killed, body found tied up
Content:
The victim’s ransacked 1RK flat situated above Chaitanya restaurant in Andheri West

MUMBAI: A senior citizen was strangulated in a flat built on the terrace of a ground-floor space she had rented out to a restaurant near Valia College in Andheri (West) on Sunday afternoon.Gulabi Shetty (75) was killed barely 30 feet from Versova police station and the crime came to light only at 10.45pm when her niece visited the one room-kitchen flat to check in on her. The unidentified killers had tied her hands and legs and strangled her using a saree, and dumped her body in the washroom. The case is being investigated by D N Nagar police as the crime was committed in their jurisdiction.Police sources said Shetty’s husband, too, was killed in 1975. He was into the liquor business.Police suspect the accused was known to Gulabi Shetty and might have killed her to either grab her property or rob her as she earned a monthly rent of Rs 2 lakh for the approximately 3,500-square-foot restaurant space.Police said the woman was preparing food in the afternoon when she was killed. The murder reportedly occurred between 3pm and 7pm, when the restaurant, Chaitanya, was shut.The killer ransacked the flat, including her cupboard, and her belongings were strewn all over.“We suspect the prime motive was property as it is worth crores. We have learnt that the victim was in talks with some developer to sell it. Besides, she made Rs 2 lakh a month as rent. She lived alone in the 1RK flat built on the terrace of the restaurant over three decades ago. We have got some leads after scanning the closed-circuit television (CCTV) footage from three different angles of the road and the Versova police station in the vicinity,” said a D N Nagar police officer.It was Shetty’s niece Sujatha Shetty (53), a resident of Amboli in Andheri (West), who found her body.In her complaint, Sujatha said, “I had been calling my aunt since 3pm on Sunday but she would not respond. Finally, I decided to visit her. When I reached her place, I noticed the door leading to her flat on the first floor was ajar. The entire flat was ransacked and I found my aunt’s hands and legs tied, and she was lying in the washroom strangulated with her own saree.”A police source said, “The murder took place in a prime location which is close to the D N Nagar metro station and highrises. Some months ago, a developer had even approached Shetty with a Rs 25 crore deal to buy the plot. It is also learnt in the past the BMC had razed an illegal extension made on the plot. There are also allegations that the victim had herself grabbed the plot but there is no proof as of now.”Police are clueless about things that may have gone missing from the victim’s flat after she was killed.Police have called Shetty’s relatives and her daughter, who lives separately in the neighbourhood and was reportedly not in good terms with her, for questioning.Additional police commissioner (west region) Manoj Sharma said a case has been registered under Indian Penal Code Section 302 for murder against an unidentified person and the case is being probed by D N Nagar police.

Title: Two kidnap minor boy, nabbed after encounter
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Allahabad: A day after they kidnapped a minor boy from a primary school, a 21-year-old youth and his aide were arrested following an encounter with the police near Auwar Bridge Road in Pratapgarh on Monday.

The accused were identified as Anirudh and Kallo alias Suraj (20). Two of their aides are currently absconding. While Anirudh is a resident of Johlapur, Kallo is native to Sipah Maheri.

According to police, Ritesh Kumar (10) was kidnapped by four men on Sunday afternoon in Sipah Maheri village, under Kotwali police station, while he was playing cricket. The boy is a student of class III and was playing on the premises of a primary school in the village.

Police said that after kidnapping the boy, the accused sought a ransom of Rs 10 lakh from the boy’s father Ram Sundar Pal, a retired Indian Railways employee.

SP (Pratapgarh) Abhishek Singh said, “Pal approached the police and a case under sections 364 (A) of the Indian Penal Code was registered. We were able to trace the whereabouts of two of the accused and intercepted their bike near Auwar Bridge Road.”

The accused had the child with them at the time of the encounter and where moving to a different hideout when the police started chasing them.

“When the police challenged the kidnappers, they opened fire. Anirudh was injured in the exchange of fire. We were able to rescue the child safely,” said the SP.

During interrogation, Kalloo told the police that he knew Ritesh well. “The two went to the primary school and lured the child on the pretext of gifting him a new ball,” Singh said.

The accused convinced the child to accompany them and took him to a hideout on their motorcycle. They first took Ritesh to Gajehara forest and then decided to relocate to another hideout in Antoo area.

The accused used a stolen mobile phone to make the ransom call. Police said that Anirudh was shot in his left leg and is undergoing treatment at the district hospital.

Police also seized a 0.32 bore country-made pistol, two live cartridges, a motorcycle and a mobile phone from them. Police have also been looking for two of their aides — Ritik and Shiv Pujan Saroj, both residents of Raniganj.

.

Title: Pro-Pak slogans: MLA backs call for kill law
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

MADIKERI/HUBBALLI: A day after Karnataka agriculture minister BC Patil sought a law that enables authorities "to shoot at sight" those chanting pro-Pakistan slogans, Madikeri MLA Appachu Ranjan (BJP) echoed his words on Monday. After inaugurating a new building at Somwarpet Government Primary School, Ranjan said: "Shoot down people who raise pro-Pakistan slogans."

Amid these developments, fresh trouble brewed elsewhere in the state when the walls of a government higher primary school on the outskirts of Hubballi in Karnataka were on Monday morning found scribbled with 'Pakistan Zindabad' slogans. Villagers staged a protest and demanded that the miscreants be promptly arrested.

The statements by the minister and the MLA come in the wake of pro-Pakistan slogans raised by Amulya Leona Noronha , 19, during an anti-CAA event in Bengaluru last week.

Ranjan told the students: "Every citizen must protect and preserve the nation's rich culture. However, many are involved in anti-national activities. These people are using resources, including food and water, provided by our country and then raising slogans against the nation. Such people must be shot down immediately. They must be exiled and sent to Pakistan. No advocate must fight their cases in court."

Title: Youth arrested for sodomizing six-yr-old in Budaun
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Bareilly: A 23-year-old youth was arrested on Monday for allegedly sodomizing a Class I student at a village under Binawar police station of Budaun.

Police said the accused, identified as Mohit, who runs a grocery store, lured the six-year-old boy into his shop by offering him a toffee and allegedly sodomised him.

The boy’s uncle who happened to be passing by, heard the child’s screams and went into the shop to find out the cause. On seeing him, Mohit fled.

Rajiv Kumar, SHO, Binawar police station, said, “On the complaint of the boy’s family, an FIR was lodged against Mohit under IPC sections 377 (unnatural offence), 511 (attempting to commit offences punishable with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment) and provisions of the POCSO Act.”

Title: Three girl students suffer heat stroke
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Three college students suffered heat stroke and were admitted to a private hospital in Vizianagaram on their way back from the Ayodhya Maidan to the parking lot, where their buses were parked.

According to reports, the three girls, Vennela, Kvya Sree and Teja Sree of Maharajah’s Post Graduate College, were returning from the CM’s meet along with the rest of the group of students, when they had a heat stroke. Kavya Sree, a first-year Pharmacy student and Vennela and Teja Sree, second-year students, were immediately rushed to the nearest private hospital by the college authorities and the police.

K Veerabhadra Swami, the local MLA from Vizianagaram, visited the three students, who were later discharged.

According to sources, it was the distance of three to four kms between the parking lot, situated near the old bus stop and the Ayodhya Maidan, where the meet was held that was responsible for the girls suffering from a heat stroke after a long morning at the Ayodhya Maidan.

Title: LCB file offence in subsidized coal scam
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Chandrapur: Almost a week after detaining 26 trucks found unloading subsidized coal at a private depot, the local crime branch registered offence at Ghugus police station on Monday evening.

LCB team led by police inspector OG Kokate had detained the trucks at a private coal depot near Nagada village. The coal was allocated by Maharashtra State Mining Corporation (MSMC) at subsidized rate to seven different small-scale industries.

Four teams were sent to the industries for verification of records regarding lifting of subsidized coal, stock and usage. Two companies whose coal was detained were found closed.

Offence was filed against one of the closed industries, its transporter and the depot owner. Ghugus police station PI Rahul Ghangurde confirmed this.

Sources said MSMC allocates a monthly quota of thousands of tonnes of coal to around 250 private industries. Companies are supposed to lift their quota from the designated mine. It is suspected that some of these companies could be selling their quota of coal in the open market at higher rates with the help of coal mafia.

Kokate could not be reached for his comment.

Title: CAG: Mining policy causedRs 2,300-crore loss in 2012-17
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Lucknow: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) has found discrepancies in mining and execution of excise policy causing a consolidated loss of over Rs 2,300 crore to the state exchequer between 2012 and 2017.

The CAG report, which was tabled in the UP assembly on Monday, categorically took into account the period when the Samajwadi Party was in power.

According to the report, the state government erred on a payment of around Rs 698 crore on recovery of value of minerals extracted through mining. The report said that on various instances, the state government conducted mining without taking mandatory permission of the environment department causing a loss of over Rs 100 crore.

Likewise, the UP government also faltered in recovering royalty brick kilns and allowing them to operate without taking due environmental permission. The CAG noted that the state government incurred a loss of around Rs 150 crore under the two heads.

The chief auditor has also indicted the then state government for not taking license fee during a set period and not acting against the defaulters, causing a revenue loss of around Rs 1391 crore. Similarly, the state government has also been found erring on recovering of licence while allowing them to operate. This caused a loss of around Rs 38 crore to the state exchequer over a period of five years.

Similarly, the state government has also been found faltering in recovering licence fee from model shops causing a revenue loss of around Rs 10 crore.

Title: 20-yr-old girl ends life by hanging self with ceiling in hostel room
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kanpur: A 20-year-old girl, student of Dayanand Girls’ College, committed suicide by hanging herself with the ceiling in her room at MG Hostel in the Civil Lines area of the city on late Sunday night.

The deceased, identified as Ishita Mishra, was a native of Lakhimpur Kheri district. She was in B.Sc second year at Dayanand Girls’ College in Civil Lines.

Police said that they found a suicide note from the room in which she had apologised to her parents over some issue. The incident came to light when the girls staying in adjacent rooms found her room locked from inside. They later informed the warden who saw her hanging from a ventilation window of her room.

He immediately alerted the Kotwali police which rushed to the spot and broke open the door.

The incident has sent shockwaves in the hostel.

According to inspector Kotwali, Sanjiv Kant Mishra, the deceased student was alone in her hostel room.

“A friend had made a call on her mobile phone on late Sunday night. When she didn’t respond, her friend asked the other hostel inmates staying in the adjacent room to check her room. When other girls of the hostel came, they found her room bolted from inside. When repeated knocks failed to get any response, they informed the hostel warden who peeped through the ventilation window and found her hanging. Immediately, her body was brought down and after preliminary investigations by the police and forensic experts, was shifted to the mortuary for the postmortem examination,” the inspector said and added, “Her parents have been informed about the incident.”

He said the exact reason behind her taking the extreme step was yet to be ascertained. “However, we have recovered a suicide note in which she had sought an apology from her parents over some issue. She did not blame anyone for her act. We are conducting an inquiry,” he said.

Title: Builder, son arrested for assaulting mayor’s son
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kanpur: The city police, on Sunday, arrested and sent a city builder and his son for allegedly assaulting son of city Mayor Pramila Pandey in Civil Lines area on Saturday.

According to the police, builder Javed Soleja and his son Mahin and two others were booked for allegedly assaulting the mayor’s son Anurag Pandey on Saturday.

Inspector Kotwali, Sanjivkant Mishra, said that as per the complainant, Javed Soleja and his son Mahin and two others had allegedly attacked Mayor Pramila Pandey’s son Anurag Pandey when, he, on the basis of information given by locals, tried to cross check illegal grabbing and construction work underway at a plot in Civil Lines area of the city.

“The father-son duo and their two aides threatened Anurag and attacked him,” he said and added, “An FIR has been registered against builder Javed Soleja and his son Mahin and two others under relevant sections of IPC. We have procured CCTV footages and further investigations are underway in this regard. Searches are also underway to make arrest of the two aides of builder possible.”

Title: How Lord Hanuman's name created furore in Delhi assembly
Content:
AAP MLA from Greater Kailash, Saurabh Bharadwaj

भाजपा विधायकों को ऐतराज़ है कि विधानसभा में ईश्वर स्वरूप बजरंग बलि हनुमान जी की शपथ ली गई। क्या भाजपा विधायक अनिल… https://t.co/iLU5MuXILB — Saurabh Bharadwaj (@Saurabh_MLAgk) 1582532719000

NEW DELHI: After deciding to organise “Sunderkand” recitations in their constituencies on the first Tuesday of every month, two Aam Aadmi Party MLAs, Saurabh Bharadwaj and Naresh Balyan , on Monday took oath in the assembly in the name of Lord Hanuman. While Bharadwaj represents Greater Kailash, Balyan is the MLA of Uttam Nagar.Some MLAs even shouted “Jai Bajrangbali” when Bharadwaj took oath. Later he said, “It is up to an MLA to take oath in the name of the God of his choice. I decided to take oath in the name of Lord Hanuman, an incarnation of God.” He ended his oath with a “Jai Hind”.A few BJP MLAs, however, alleged that Bharadwaj’s oath was a diversion from the dignity of the House procedure. “The assembly is a place to solve the problems of the people of Delhi, it is not a religious place. That is why I objected to it,” Gandhi Nagar MLA Anil Bajpai said later.Taking a dig at BJP, Bharadwaj tweeted, “Why is BJP objecting to the name of Lord Hanuman? Does the central leadership of BJP have the same opinion? Why are they silent?”Both Bharadwaj and Balyan organised the recitation in their constituencies last week.

Title: Puducherry: Nigerian youth held for fixing PIN-capturing device at ATM
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

PUDUCHERRY: The Puducherry police arrested a Nigerian on Friday on charges of fixing a skimmer and a camera to record PIN at an ATM of a nationalized bank.

Jasher Celestine, 28, from Nigeria, has been staying at Mambakkam in Chennai for the past three years, police said. Police have launched a search for Miller Aleksandrov Hristov of Bulgaria and Milton Vladimir Cornel Zambrano of Venezuela, Jasher’s accomplices in the crime.

Senior superintendent of police (law and order) Rahul Alwal said Jasher had fixed a PIN-capturing device to the ATM and added he might have planned to install a skimmer later. “The fraudsters fixed PIN-capturing devices above the ATM keypads and skimmers near the card slots. The device has a camera and records PINs keyed in by unsuspecting customers while the skimmer collected the card details. The video and card details got stored in a memory card. They removed the devices later and made duplicate debi’, credit cards with the stolen details using a magnetic strip writer. They then siphoned money from the victims’ bank accounts,” said Alwal. He said two gangs worked together in such crimes. “One gang collects PINs and details of the cards and sells the information to other gang over the Darknet. The other gang makes bogus cards with stolen card details and steals the money,” he said.

Alwal said Jasher mainly collected card details and passed the info to Miller and Milton, who operate internationally. “The absconding suspects belong to an international gang that makes bogus cards. The two used to visit Jasher often to collect card details. We have sent their photos to the respective countries to nab them,” he said.

The issue came to the light when the ATM coordinator lodged a complaint with the cybercrime cell stating that he found a PIN-capturing device fixed above the keypad during his routine supervision.

Jasher confessed to the crime. Police have booked the three under Sections 379 and 511 of IPC and Section 66 C and D of IT Act, 2000.

Title: 37 injured after speeding private bus hits road divider, overturns in Guntur
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The bus, which overturned near Edlapadu village on Monday

GUNTUR: About 37 passengers of a private bus were injured when the speeding vehicle overturned near Edlapadu village in the early hours of Monday.

The injured were immediately rushed to the Government General Hospital (GGH), Guntur . The mishap took place when the bus going to Vijayawada from Bengaluru hit the road divider on the national highway. Police suspect that the driver tried to overtake a vehicle at high speed and lost control over the wheel before hitting the divider.

On hitting the divider, the bus flew off the highway and overturned even as the passengers started shouting for help. Police rushed to the spot and rescued the passengers trapped inside the bus. The police organised vehicles and ambulance to shift all the injured to the GGH. The hospital authorities said they have shifted at least seven people to ICU as their condition was critical by the time they were admitted to the hospital. The doctors said that the condition of a few was critical since they have head injuries with multiple fractures. GGH superintendent Dr S Babulal has constituted special teams to oversee medical aid to the injured.

The police have taken the vehicle driver into custody.

Title: Beyond the investigation: Rot in TNPSC runs deep
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Chennai: A series of scams have rocked the Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission in recent years, the latest one being alleged irregularities in the conduct of Group IV exams held in 2019. Despite a number of investigations, malpractices continue.

The rot in the TNPSC had set in decades ago, said a senior bureaucrat. "During the tenures of past chief ministers, recommendation calls used to go from the chief minister’s office to the commission’s chairman to clear certain candidates. Invariably, all of them used to get selected," said the official. Taking serious note of the malaise, MGR, when he was CM, asked his staff to suggest an upright person to be appointed as TNPSC chairman to clean up the commission. "MGR’s condition was that the person should not even heed the CM’s recommendation. People suggested his own secretary T Lakshminarayanan be made the chairman. MGR did it and till Lakshminarayanan was heading the commission, only those with calibre got selected," said a bureaucrat who worked in MGR’s core team.

It is futile to blame and take action only against candidates for tainting the system. It is the duty of the chairman, secretary and controller to ensure the selection process is fair. Even TNPSC members are powerless. The framework of the commission is such that the authority is vested with the chairman, secretary and controller. But surprisingly, no top brass of the commission has landed in the police net despite half-a-dozen investigations being carried out since 2012. "What action was taken against key officials in the past," asked the official. Former TNPSC chairman R Sellamuthu and the members of the commission during his tenure were the only ones who had to resign on charges of corruption in 2012. During vigilance searches on Sellamuthu’s premises, officials stumbled upon several documents relating to malpractices in selection.

A report sent by then member secretary of the commission T Udhayachandran to the TN chief secretary said the commission members had forced him to provide the selection list well in advance. When the secretary refused to part with the selection list, the chairman, allegedly, sent circulars to the commission staff to bypass the secretary and deal with the members directly. Based on Udhayachandran’s letter, the DVAC raided the premises of the chairman and other members.

The commission handles recruitment of four categories of government staff. Under Group I, it recruits deputy collectors, deputy superintendents of police and assistant commissioners of commercial tax. Under Group II, it recruits deputy commercial tax officer, municipal commissioners, junior employment officers, sub-registrars and assistant inspectors of labour. Under Group II-A it recruits assistants in revenue administration in various departments, personal clerks, typists in legislative assembly and accountants in treasuries. And under Group IV it recruits junior assistants, village administrative officers, clerks and typists. Government recruitment being a sensitive task, when the commission’s credibility comes under a cloud, the integrity of its officials and the candidates it has recruited also become suspect.

A retired government official said integrity of the authority and fear of punitive action are crucial for the commission to regain its stature. "Only when T N Seshan assumed office as election commissioner, did anyone take note of the commission’s existence. Till then, it was an agency at the mercy of the government. Seshan earned respect for the commission by exercising the powers vested with the commission," he said, adding that the state needs someone like him to head the TNPSC.

Though a chairman is posted for a six-year term, the upper age limit is 62 years. Since most people get the assignment post retirement from government service or closer to their retirement, most chairmen in recent years have served only for 1.5 years to 2 years. A person takes almost a year to understand the functioning of the commission. Hence, short terms for the commission’s chairman and its members hardly serve any purpose. A major cause for concern is that most people are appointed members and as chairman of the commission owing to their proximity to political executives.

So far, major malpractices have been reported in Group II-A and Group IV recruitment, for which there are only written examinations. Even in Group I selection process, there is very little scope for manipulation in the interview, because a candidate cannot be given less than 45 and more than 75 out of 100 marks for the interview. Hence, if manipulation happens it is in the written examination, said a former member of the commission.

Title: Advocates asked to bring COP, I-card on KBA polling day
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kanpur: The Elders Committee, which is conducting the annual general election of Kanpur Bar Association (KBA), has asked advocate-members to bring their certificate of place and practice (COP) and original certificate or identity card bearing COP number issued by UP Bar Council on the day of voting to be held on March 3.

The committee, at a meeting held under the chairmanship of Abdul Ghaffar Khan, advocate, decided that in the absence of a COP certificate or ID card no advocate would be allowed to cast his/her vote.

The committee has appealed to all the contesting candidates to remove their posters and banners from the court campus and follow its guidelines, said advocate Sushil Kumar Verma, special assistant to the Elders Committee.

Advocates strike: Advocates of Kanpur Nagar on Monday abstained from judicial work to lodge their protest against the negative attitude of the police towards advocates. At a joint meeting of Kanpur Bar Association and the Lawyers' Association, the members while criticising the callousness of the police, said that last night some anti-social elements had attacked an advocate but the police have not taken any action so far against the culprits.

Title: Mystery disease afflicts monkeys in Puranpur, 4 dead
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pilibhit: A mysterious disease seems to have afflicted monkeys in Puranpur tehsil in Pilibhit district. In the past fortnight, four have died and two seem to have gone completely mad. Two injured simians are being treated at Puranpur range office.,

Though the exact reason for the monkey deaths is not known, veterinary doctors have not ruled out poisoning, The monkeys’ viscera samples have been preserved for further tests.

According to the range officer of Puranpur division Ayyub Hassan, he and his team are monitoring the entire area near Puranpur railway station, where a monkey seems to have gone mad, for the last three days.

“We had found four dead monkeys in a mango orchard at Keshopur village and immediately sent their carcasses for an autopsy. Two injured monkeys had being treated at Puranpur range office,” said Hassan. He, however, did not rule out the possibility that the monkeys had been poisoned by the villagers.

“We traced one monkey that had gone mad near Puranpur railway station on Saturday. This monkey bit a forest force personnel who went to capture it. The monkey has been shifted to the range office, where its condition is improving after undergoing treatment,” said Hassan.

Dr Rajiv Mishra, deputy chief veterinary officer, told TOI that he had preserved the viscera samples of all the four dead monkeys and had sent them to the government forensic laboratory in Mathura for testing. “We are waiting for the report to reach any final conclusion about the reason behind monkeys’ death,” he added.

On the insane monkey caught from near the railway station, Mishra of the view that it could have consumed toxic water there. In reply to a question, the vet said he had not found trace of any contagious disease among the monkeys.

Title: Woman, aides booked for killing husband
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pilibhit: Following orders of the court of the chief judicial magistrate, the Madhotanda police on Sunday night booked six persons, including a woman , for allegedly murdering a 65-year-old farmer one year ago.

According to the deceased’s son, his father Jarnail Singh had married Preet Kaur, 45, two years ago. The couple lived in Bamanpur locality in Puranpur city under Puranpur Kotwali police station. Jairnal’s son, Satnam Singh, is a resident of Kalinagar under Madhotanda police station. Jairnal died on April 30.

It was while Satnam was going through his father’s papers after his death that he came across a letter written by the latter in which he accused Preet of trying to usurp his property. Her actual name was Leelawati and she hailed from Dehradun.

Satnam also learnt that Preet had married three other times. She had allegedly changed her name to Anita Sharma to marry one Prakash Sharma. She called herself Leela Khatri to marry one Vijay Khatri. Then , she married one Gurvinder Singh of Purvi village in Puranpur. She allegedly duped all the three men of their valuables before marrying his father, he claimed.

His father’s letter revealed that Preet was trying to poison him and she had forced him to sign the property papers in her name. She was helped by five others to do so, alleged Satnam.

When Satnam challenged his father’s will in court in August 2019, Preet and her accomplices -- Sajjan Singh, Soni, Rana, Gopi and an unidentified man -- barged into his house and assaulted him.

Satnam claimed that his father had been killed by Preet and her accomplices. But when he approached the concerned police station, no one paid any heed to his complaint. It was only after the court order that an FIR was registered against Preet and others.

SK Upadhyay, SHO of Madhotanda police station, said in compliance with the court order, an FIR has been lodged against Preet, four other named persons and one unidentified man under IPC sections 302 (murder), 452 (house trespass), 504 (intentional insult to provoke breach of peace) and 506 (criminal intimidation).

Title: MSEDCL wants no penalty over RE targets
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: MSEDCL has filed a petition in Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC) urging the Commission not to levy any penalty on it for failing to meet renewable energy targets, till 2022-23. The discom has claimed that despite repeated efforts by MSEDCL to procure power through renewable energy sources but was not receiving responses from the bidders.

MSEDCL had earlier Commission’s proposal to revise the solar target to 13.5% by 2024-25 from the present 2.5%. The discom contended that it was quite stiff and that despite best efforts, it would not be able to achieve it. Total solar capacity of 12,500MW would be required by 2024-25 to achieve the target against the present capacity of 4,200MW. The competitive bidding process to expand the capacity takes a lot of time and there were many other factors beyond its control, the discom had said.

Some weeks ago the company had floated tenders for buying 1,350MW with a cap of Rs3.15 per unit but got bids for only 5MW. The discom increased the maximum price to attract producers. It increased the cap to Rs3.30 per unit and floated the tender again. MSEDCL has through this petition urged MERC to revise the ceiling tariff rate for solar projects with capacity 2 to 10MW at 11 kV level. The hearing on this petition was slated to be held on February 18 put has been postponed indefinitely.

On one hand, MSEDCL is unable to meet its solar target and on the other, it is opposing solar rooftop consumers by proposing an astronomical grid support charge (GSC).

Title: Police seize 6.6kg contraband from gang, arrest seven
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Puducherry: The Puducherry police arrested seven people all aged between 20 and 28 years on charges selling ganja to tourists and locals including school students.

Police seized 6.6kg ganja and four mobile phones from their possession. The seized items worth Rs 2.25 lakh.

Senior superintendent of police (law and order) Rahul Alwal said a team from Mudaliarpet police station on receiving a tipoff that ganja peddlers were selling the contraband to students of a private school in Velrampet swung into action and raided the areas in and around the school. The team members, who functioned under the direct supervision of the superintendent of police (south) Chintha Kothandaraman, found three men selling ganja to school students and they attempted to intercept the three men.

However, the three managed to escape. The team succeeded in tracing the three in a few hours. On inspection, the team found the three men in possession of 33 sachets of ganja leaves each roughly weighing 6g. The team seized 240g ganja and two mobile phones from the possession of peddlers. The arrested were identified as V Akash alias Prasanthkumar from Nellithope, S Manikandan from Mudalliarpet and Joyal from Orleanpet.

The team based on their confessional statement arrested four more men involved in the sale of ganja. The arrested were identified as D Vinoth alias Vinothkumar from Thengaithittu, P Arunpandian and M Vijay from Theni district, Tamil Nadu and A Lourduraj from Thengaithittu. The team seized 6.36kg ganja and two mobile phones from their possession.

All the arrested men confessed to committing the crime. Inquiries revealed that they used to procure the contraband item in bulk quantities from suppliers in Theni district and sell it in small sachets to their customers including school students in Puducherry. Police booked them under different sections of NDPS act and Juvenile justice act and produced them before a local court, which remanded them in judicial custody.

Title: Bapatla MP Nandigam blames Naidu, Lokesh for orchestrating attacks on him
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Amaravati/Tirupati: YSRC leader and Bapatla MP Nandigam Suresh on Monday accused TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu of orchestrating attacks on him and called for his arrest. Stating that Naidu has a history of vindictive politics, Suresh said the TDP leadership is jittery after the state government set up a special investigation team (SIT) to probe irregularities in land pooling and insider trading.

“Naidu has been using women cadres as shield while his party workers carry out attacks on YSRC leaders. Unless Naidu and his son (Nara) Lokesh are arrested, the sponsored agitations, pre-meditated attacks would not end. It’s high time the misplaced arrogance of Naidu is brought under control,” said Suresh.

He said a 300-strong mob was at the police station by the time he reached there to lodge the complaint. “If elected representatives are stopped and attacked by mobs, chilli powder is sprayed, filthy language is used, it is clear that Naidu is the chief conspirator,” he alleged, while adding that those involved in insider trading were also sponsoring the attacks. “Naidu is concerned only about his community and their real estate business.”

Suresh also showed a video of the attack in which the mob is shouting and spraying chilli powder on the MP and his staff while shouting pro-Amaravati and pro-Naidu slogans. “I am being repeatedly targeted because I am a Dalit. Naidu might be thinking that only his community should rule the state and Dalits should serve them. Some people from the US are also calling me up late in the night and abusing me with filthy language,” he alleged.

Varla Ramaiah, TDP politburo member and Dalit leader, condemned Suresh’s allegations. “The YSRC is using Suresh as a puppet to implicate Amaravati farmers in false cases. Why is the Bapatla MP frequently touring Amaravati which is not even part of his constituency?” Ramaiah asked.

Meanwhile, Naidu accused chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy of stalling development in the state. “The situation is so grave that people are unable to raise their voice against the government which is registering fake cases against anyone opposing it,” he said at a public meeting in Kuppam, his home constituency where he reached on Monday as part of his ‘Praja Chaitanya Yatra’.

“We are not against the development of Visakhapatnam. But if the government has such an intention why is it that Adani and Lulu groups have backed away from their investment plans?” Naidu asked. He also slammed the government for setting up a SIT to probe the alleged misdeeds of TDP government. ”A SIT can be appointed to probe a particular issue, not all issues over the last five years. This decision will send wrong message to investors. The state has already lost about Rs 1.8 lakh crore in the last nine months. Now many more investors will go back.”

Title: Telangana BJP to undergo structural change
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Telangana BJP state president K Laxman

HYDERABAD: The Telangana unit of Bharatiya Janata Party ( BJP ) is all set to make some structural changes by appointing a president as well as a working president, on the lines of the Telangana Pradesh Congress Committee (TPCC). The move comes in the backdrop of party’s top brass deciding to give equal responsibilities to both old timers and juniors.

While the prime contenders for the post of working president are Jitendar Reddy and DK Aruna , the latter is expected to be made the working president with the support of national leaders. “Since Aruna had strong support from some of our national leaders and comes from the Reddy community, she may have better chances of being appointed as working president,” top sources said. They added that the proposal has come from party president JP Nadda .

For the post of the state unit chief, central observers on Monday took feedback on six names.

Two sitting MPs D Arvind and Bandi Sanjay are eyeing the post, along with current president K Laxman . Apart from these senior leaders, Perala Sekhar, a former TRS leader is also in the race.

Though Karim Nagar MP Bandi Sanjay was not keen on contesting for the post initially, he is seeking support from party bigwigs now. “The main contenders are Bandi Sanjay and current president K Laxman. Interestingly, both belong to Munnuru Kapu community,” said a top leader.

The process to take opinions of more than 40 senior leaders on the contestants began at 11 am and continued till 5 in the evening. K Laxman has reportedly received the support of many. “While Sanjay had the support of the RSS, it seems like K Laxman will be announced as the party chief,” sources said.

The final announcement is expected to be made within a week.

Title: Telangana: Mentally ill man kills wife, slits own throat
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 50-year-old man mentally ill man killed his wife and later died of suicide at Kandukur in Ranga Reddy district on Sunday night.

Jangaiah, an agriculturist, killed his wife, Krishanveni, by hitting her head with a stone. He later slit his throat.

Jangaiah had undergone treatment for his mental illness at a government hospital.

His daughter spotted the bodies of her parents after returning home and alerted the local police.

Title: 2-day National Urdu Science Congress
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Hyderabad: Centre for Promotion of Knowledge in Urdu of Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu) will organise a 2-day National Urdu Science Congress, in association with School of Sciences, Manuu. The inaugural session will be held on February 25 at 9am on Manuu campus. Dr Nakul Parashar, director Vigyan Prasar, New Delhi, will be the chief guest. Dr Mohammad Aslam Parvaiz, the vice-chancellor, will preside over the meet.

Others present at the meet are Dr Shyam Sunder Prasad, Prof Ayub Khan and Prof SM Rahmatullah. TNN

Title: Cash, jewellery worth lakhs stolen from Annapurna house
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Indore: Miscreants broke into a house at Dravid Nagar in Annapurna late on Saturday and made away with cash and jewellery worth lakhs .

Annapurna police said that the exact worth of stolen items will be ascertained once the family returns from Pune.

The incident took place at the house of 60-year-old Komal Porwal, who used to work at a shop in the cloth market.

The matter came to fore when a neighbour found his door locked from outside.

“We were suspicious that this might be done by some thief and since we knew that Porwal was not at home, we went to check and found that the lock was broken and the house was ransacked,” a neighbour Ajit Jain told TOI.

Jain and other neighbours informed police about the incident.

Annapurna police station in charge Satish Dwivedi said that they were looking at the CCTV footages of nearby areas.

Porwal had gone to Pune to stay with his son who lives there. He stays with his wife and often goes to Pune. Someone must have kept an eye on his movements, said neighbours.

Title: Woman found dead days after wedding, kin accuse hubby
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kanpur: A 21-year-old woman , who got married on Valentine Day this year (February 14), was allegedly killed by her husband after his demand of car in dowry was not met. The incident was reported from the Narwal area of the district.

Manvi, daughter of Chandrapal, a resident of Unnao, got married to Luvkush of Narwal area of Kanpur on February 14, 2020.
