“Immediately after the marriage, her husband started demanding a car, which we could not meet. We were trying to contact her since Friday but her inlaws said she was unwell. We got suspicious and reached her inlaws’ house late on Sunday night only to find her dead,” alleged her father Chandrpal.

He further alleged that his daughter was killed by her husband as he had failed to give him a car in dowry.

The postmortem report also stated that the woman died of suffocation besides severe thrashing, the police said.

“Her neck has strangulation marks. She was physically tortured and later strangulated to death. We are recording the statements of the deceased’s family and will take action on the basis of the postmortem report,” the officer incharge of Narwal police station Ram Avtar said.

“Police have detained Manvi’s husband and one other for questioning. Further investigations are on”, he added.

Title: Allahabad high court to UP DGP: Act against cops who assaulted AMU students
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

Title: Vehicles with goods jutting out having free run on city roads
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: Transporting rods, pipes, bamboo and other goods protruding out of a vehicle’s body is illegal. Yet, the traffic police allow such vehicles to ply freely. At the most a challan is issued. The vehicle is not stopped from further journey as should be the case.

On Monday morning, traffic police deployed at Japanese Garden Square caught a vehicle with iron frames and tin sheets jutting out of it. Two cops issued a challan to the driver but allowed him take his vehicle. The iron frames were jutting from both front and rear sides. As per rules, material should be confined within the body of vehicle and there should be a red sign on the back to alert other motorists. This vehicle had no such sign.

As per Motor Vehicles Act , 1988, it is a punishable offence under Section 190 (2), with a fine up to Rs2,000 and provision to detain the vehicle too. Sadar zone traffic police issued a challan for Rs200 only.

Speaking to TOI, the cop admitted vehicles transporting material should not be allowed to ply until the goods are unloaded. He could not explain why he allowed the vehicle to move on without unloading the goods. Drivers were taking advantage of this practice as the traffic police cannot fine them again the same day for the same offence.

TOI also found a cycle rickshaw carrying bamboo in similar way crossing busy Bole Petrol Pump Square on Amravati Road. The rickshaw puller also jumped the red signal.

Deputy commissioner Chinmay Pandit maintained the traffic policemen always took action against such vehicles. In 2019, they penalized 63,514 vehicles for either loading goods exceeding the height of the vehicles or having goods jutting out.

Traffic activists say this is not enough. Allowing drivers to transport goods in such an unsafe way, besides being a threat to other road users especially two-wheeler riders, is also contempt of apex court’s order.

Pandit admitted such vehicles should not be allowed to ply and assured to look into the matter.

Title: Four held for smuggling red sand boa
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Bareilly: Four persons were arrested in Bahedi area of Bareilly on Monday for trying to smuggle a red sand boa snake to Nepal. The reptile is commonly referred to as two-headed snake due to the shape of its tail.

The accused who were travelling in a sedan were arrested near Bahedi bus stand on the basis of a tip-off. The accused were planning to sell the red sand boa a dealer in Nepal who would have then smuggled it to China. This non-venomous snake is in great demand in China for preparing medicines. Its skin is used for preparing handbags, wallets and jackets. Each snake fetches a price ranging between Rs 5-25 lakh. In UP, this snake is commonly found in Dudhwa Tiger Reserve in Lakhimpur Kheri and Bahraich districts.

The accused arrested were identified as Monis Ali, Meharbaan, Inshtiaq Ahmad and Akhlaq Ahmad. Monis and Meharbaan belong to Moradabad district and had caught the snake from a forest area in terai region with the help of the other two.

Pankaj Pant, SHO of Bahedi police station, told TOI, “The forest department has been informed about the recovery of this endangered snake while an FIR has been filed against the accused under provisions of the Wildlife Protection Act and 207 Motor Vehicle Act. The rescued snake weighs nearly 1,700 gm and was expected to fetch a price not less than Rs 10 lakh in Nepal. The accused also told us that the price of the snake depends upon its age and weight.”

Title: Chitra, Anamika take charge as IWN’s chairwoman, vice-chairwoman
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Puducherry: Satya Special School director Chitra Shah and Clay & Glaze proprietress Anamika Saraogi were nominated as the chairwoman and vice- chairwoman respectively of the Confederation of Indian Industry's (CII) Indian women network (IMN), Puducherry for the year 2020-21, said CII Puducherry chapter head B Srinivas Satish.

Chitra is the founder-director of Satya Special School, a rehabilitation centre for children with special needs. The centre extends services to more than 900 children in Puducherry. Chitra is also a part of the new-born high-risk clinic in association with Jawaharlal institute of postgraduate medical education and research (Jipmer). The clinic is the first-ever early intervention program in Puducherry.

Chitra has been a co-opted member in various internal compliance committee under the Sexual harassment at workplace act, 2013. She did BSc in nutrition and dietetics from Madras University. A gold medalist in postgraduate degree in social work (1989-91) from Madras School of Social Work she specializes in family and child welfare. She was the co-convener, policy and advocacy, IWN Puducherry in the year 2018-19 and 2019-20.

Anamika is a Working partner in True Cartons, manufacturers of corrugated boxes. She is the proprietress of Clay & Glaze, a handcrafted pottery studio. Pottery is one of the several specialities of Puducherry.

BA Economics graduate from Anna Adarsh College, Chennai she is a creative artist and environmentalist. A firm believer of traditions and family values, she was the vice-chairwoman of IWN Puducherry for the year 2019-20.

Title: CAA opponents not anti-national: BJP neta
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

CHENNAI: Anti-CAA protestors cannot be called "anti-nationals" as they are exercising their democratic rights to express their views, BJP national youth wing vice-president A P Muruganandam said on Monday, in a sharp deviation from the line towed by his seniors in the party.

Muruganandam, 44, who has been a BJP member for more than two decades, told TOI , "Calling the anti-CAA protesters as anti-nationals is unfair and not right. They are exercising their democratic rights to air their views. But I will say that the persons, who are misusing the platform of anti-CAA protests to raise slogans against India are anti-nationals."

On whether Tamil Nadu - historically a Dravidian land - is a fertile land for BJP and its Hindutva politics, he said Tamil Nadu is the land of temples, but what is happening in the state is quite in contrary to that. "The Dravidian parties were defaming Hindu religion and some people were enjoying it. But, that generation is gone. People now want growth and employment."

Asked if the absence of a state president impacted the party, Muruganandam said, "The appointment [of a state president] will give momentum to the party's political activities. But the absence has not affected the party in anyway... The party is working hard and reaching out to more people. The party's popularity is growing."

Title: Take a leaf out of Indore’s clean book: KT Rama Rao to people
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: Stressing that the TRS government is committed to transforming towns, municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao said Pattana Pragati had been taken up to not only bring an awareness among people on sanitation and greenery but also on the new Municipalities Act.

Urging people to take an example out of Indore where residents keep their surroundings and roads clean, KTR said people, elected representatives and officials have equal responsibilities in this endeavour. The minister kicked off the 10-day Pattana Pragati programme in Mahbubnagar along with district minister V Srinivas Goud on Monday. KTR said segregation of wet and dry waste was important and the sanitation staff would not collect waste unless it was cleaned. Pattana Pragati is being conducted in all 141 municipalities and 3,456 wards in Telangana.

“Mahbubnagar has 1.80 lakh population and it is not possible for just 600 sanitation staff to clean the entire town. Every citizen has to do his or her bit to keep the town clean. Ward members should come up with a ward-level sanitation plan,” KTR said while addressing the people. He later interacted with people and inaugurated various developmental works.

KTR said an innovative programme ‘Parichayam’ was taken up in Hyderabad by involving residents and sanitation staff, which had yielded a good result. Talking about Sircilla experiment, the minister said MEPMA members had been earning Rs3 lakh a month by segregating wet and dry waste and compost and wanted officials to replicate it in Mahbubnagar too.

Meanwhile, chief secretary Somesh Kumar and principal secretary of municipal administration Arvind Kumar participated in Pattana Pragati at Ibrahimpatnam.

Title: Anticipatory bail pleas of Azam, his wife, son rejected
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Rampur: Additional district and sessions judge Dhirendra Kumar Kamboj on Monday rejected the anticipatory bail petitions of Samajwadi Party MP Azam Khan, his wife Tanzeen Fatimah and their son Abdullah Azam in connection with a forgery case.

The accused have been chargessheeted under sections 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property), 467 (forgery of valuable security, will), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) and 471 (using as genuine a forged document) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

On January 3, 2019, local BJP leader Akash Saxena had lodged a complaint against the trio, alleging that Azam and his wife helped their son in obtaining two fake birth certificates — one from Lucknow and another from Rampur — following which an FIR was registered at the Ganj kotwali.

Additional district government counsel (ADGC) Ram Autar Saini told TOI, “The court rejected the anticipatory bail applications of Azam, his wife and son in three separate cases related to Abdullah’s date of birth certificates, PAN cards and passport.”

“Azam was, however, granted bail in a case related to enemy property. The court, meanwhile, ordered the MP to surrender his passport to the police, but added that Azam could travel abroad after seeking its permission,” added the ADGC.

A local court had declared the trio as “absconders” and issued non-bailable warrants against them after they failed to appear before it.

Title: Banned plastic bags worth Rs1.5 lakh seized
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: In a major raid, the authorities seized banned plastic items worth Rs1.5 lakh on Monday.

Acting on a tip-off, the crime branch unit 4 of city police laid a trap at Chinchbhavan on Wardha Road, where a vehicle was transporting around 1,000 kilograms of banned polythene bags. The team led by police sub-inspector PS Mohekar intercepted the vehicle.

According to police officials, Wardha Road has turned into a hotspot for illegal transportation of banned plastic items. Interestingly, the seized vehicle and arrested accused are all from Wardha.

The two arrested are 30-year-old Ravi Adani and 32-year-old driver Girish Adani. As per the law, police also imposed a fine of Rs5,000 on them.

The police handed over the seized plastic to the Nuisance Detection Squad (NDS) of Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s Nehru Nagar zone. This is the first time that the city police have taken action against banned plastic. Earlier, such raids were carried out by the NDS and Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB).

In March last year, MPCB along with other civic authorities had seized around 3,500kg of banned plastic items. The consignment was transported to the city from Gujarat and contained very thin plastic bags below 20 microns. In October 2018, the authorities had seized 2,385kg of banned goods valued at over Rs10 lakh

MPCB has reportedly shut down all manufacturing units of the banned bags in the state.

Title: Thiruvallam traffic chaos: Police pass the bucks to NHAI
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Fed up by the traffic chaos at Thiruvallam Junction where accidents have become a daily affair, the police have sent a letter to the National Highway Authority of India ( NHAI ) to take necessary rectification measures.

The NHAI, meanwhile, is planning to direct the consultant of Kazhakkoottam–Mukkola national highway project to prepare a report suggesting measures to manage the traffic issues at Thiruvallam.

Though NHAI constructed a bridge here parallel to the old bridge to ease traffic, vehicles from Poonkulam-Venganoor Road are defying the one-way rule to take the Ambalathara route to reach East Fort easily. Also, many of the vehicles coming from Kovalam side and heading to East Fort too take the wrong way.

In the letter sent last week, DCP (law and order) R Karuppasamy has asked NHAI to take necessary measures such as erecting caution boards, traffic signs and signal system at Thiruvallam to manage the traffic situation.

But, sources in NHAI said that caution boards and signal systems are not a solution to the traffic issues in the stretch. “The consultants of the project will be asked to prepare a detailed report to resolve the issues at Thiruvallam,” said sources in NHAI.

Traffic assistant commissioner (south) S Zulfikar said that the stretch is a major headache for the department. “We have deployed two traffic police officers to manage traffic in the area. Accidents are common, though fatal accidents are rare,” he said.

Zulfikar said that the traffic police and NHAI will conduct a joint inspection to find a solution. “We think that construction of a service bridge could be a solution to the issue. A joint inspection will be held this week or after the Attukal Pongala,” he said.

When NHAI constructed an additional bridge parallel to the old Thiruvallam Bridge, a service bridge was not part of the design. As per NHAI’s design, vehicles coming from Poonkulam-Venganoor side should cross the national highway at the old Thiruvallam Junction (in front of Archana Royal Park Hotel) and proceed through the new Thiruvallam bridge to Kazhakkoottam side. Those vehicles which are heading to East Fort should take a turn at the median opening at Kumarichanta. However, the vehicles are taking the easier, but dangerous route.

Though the National Transportation Planning and Research Centre (Natpac) has submitted a report to traffic (south), the department has not reviewed it. The Natpac, in its report, has suggested construction of a 7.5-metre-wide flyover connecting main carriageway of the national highway and Ambalathara Road to avoid traffic congestion.

Title: Kerala: Makeshift godown gutted near Ernakulam South railway station
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

KOCHI: A makeshift godown near Ernakulam South railway station used for storing stationery items was gutted in a major fire on Monday. The fire started around 11.15am. Around nine firefighting units from seven stations jointly doused the fire by 12.30pm. Officials said the fire broke out on the terrace of the two-storey building that houses A3 Associates, a dealer of stationery items. This floor was illegally turned into a godown by covering its top and sides with metal sheets. A short circuit is believed to have sparked the blaze.

“The fire was a major one and its intensity could have been much worse had it gone unnoticed. There were several buildings adjacent but we could contain the fire on the terrace itself before it spread to other floors. The lane where the building is located is not wide enough for the fire tenders so we had to use connected hoses to reach the top floor,” Gogy J S, district fire officer, Ernakulam.

According to officials, the fire was first noticed by neighbouring residents even though the firm’s staffs were present on the ground floor during that time. Though they tried to douse the flames using a fire extinguisher, it proved inadequate and they alerted the fire and rescue officials who reached the spot within 15 minutes. Units from Gandhinagar , Eloor, Thrikkakara, Tripunithura, Aluva, Club Road and Mattancherry fire stations took part in the operation.

The illegal modifications using metal sheets hindered the operation as officials found it impossible to enter the floor. Thick smoke billowed as the fire gutted tonnes of papers, crayons, colour pens and pencils along with bundles of Fevicol packets making it difficult for the officials to see and breathe. They had to break the sheets to pump water into the burning goods. The building is reportedly owned by Johnson C Abraham, executive director of Chavara Matrimony.

Title: Congress launches ‘Patnam Ghosha’ to counter TRS, says government failed to give houses to poor
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Telangana Congress working president A Revanth Reddy launched ‘Patnam Ghosha from Alwal in his Malkajgiri parl... Read More

HYDERABAD: To counter the Telangana government’s ongoing ‘Pattana Pragathi’ programme, Congress on Monday launched ‘Patnam Ghosha’ (plight of urban dwellers), to “expose the ruling TRS ’ failure in delivering two-bed room houses to the homeless”.

Telangana Congress working president and Malkajgiri MP, A Revanth Reddy , who launched ‘Patnam Ghosha from Alwal in his Malkajgiri parliamentary constituency, interacted with the poor and asked them to list out the problems being faced by them.

“I will collect the list of problems being faced by the people in urban areas, and submit it to the government. I will also release money from the MPLAD funds for construction of toilets,” he told the people.

Stating that the KCR government had spent over Rs 8 lakh crore in the past five to six years (accumulated state budget of the past five years), Revanth said the CM had got a palatial building ‘Pragathi Bhavan’ constructed for himself. “However, KCR has not released funds to complete 2-BHK project because the homeless poor are not his priority.”

On distribution of government land to the poor, Revanth said a large chunk of land was available in survey number 537 in Alwal. He called tahsildar (MRO) on the phone and directed him to prepare a note for distribution of the government land to the homeless poor.

Title: Reinstall Ambedkar statue: V Hanumantha Rao to chief secretary
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

V Hanumantha Rao

HYDERABAD: A delegation of leaders led by former MP and AICC secretary V Hanumantha Rao on Monday submitted a letter to chief secretary Somesh Kumar, urging him to see that Ambedkar statue is reinstalled at Panjagutta crossroads.

In the letter, Rao said members of political parties, Ambedkar welfare associations and civil society groups would resort to dharnas and protests from March 2 if the government fails to reinstall the statue by February 29. Hanumantha Rao later told reporters that police, GHMC officials and the TRS government had insulted Ambedkar and crores of his followers by removing his statue and dumping it in a garbage yard.

He said local youth from Jai Bheem group of Panjagutta had installed the statue at Panjagutta crossroads on the night of April 12, 2019. “The statue was later removed, broken and thrown in the garbage yard at Jawahar Nagar,” he said.

The incident caused anguished followers of Ambedkar and even members of political parties held protests. The police detained protesters. “Even I was taken into police custody for staging a dharna demanding reinstallation of Ambedkar statue at the same spot,” he said.

However, officials said there was no permission to install the statue. Hence, it was removed.

Title: Anti-CAA protesters are not anti-nationals, says TN BJP leader
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

A BJP member for more than two decades and having held posts at the state and national level, A P Muruganandam, 44, is one of the front runners for the post of the party’s Tamil Nadu unit president. In an interview to TOI, the BJP national youth wing vice-president takes a different line from his seniors, who have dubbed the anti-CAA protesters anti-nationals

Q: Senior BJP leaders have described the anti-CAA protesters anti-nationals. How do you react to this?BJP leaders would have been quoted in a different context. My view is anti-CAA protesters have the right to express their views and calling them anti-nationals is not right. But using this platform to raise anti-India slogans will be not acceptable.

Q: Is TN, a Dravidian land, a fertile ground for the BJP and its Hindutva politics?

Tamil Nadu is the land of temples. But the Dravidian parties were defaming Hindu religion and its rituals and some people were enjoying it. That generation is gone. People now want growth and employment. If they (the DMK and its allies) continue their same old game, it will boomerang. The victory of our party’s candidate, who contested the panchayat councillor’s post in M Karunanidhi’s native place Tiruvarur, is a sign of the growth of the BJP in the state.

Q: Is the BJP equipped to counter protests and campaigns by the DMK and its allies against the Centre over various issues, including hydrocarbon projects?

The DMK wants a villain for their fake campaign. Hence they are portraying the BJP as the villain. We will carry out a door-to-door campaign to dispel this perception and take the BJP government’s welfare schemes to the public. For instance, the Centre had saved more than Rs27,000 crore by direct transfer of funds to beneficiaries of welfare schemes. It is equal to the fund allocated for the health sector.

Q: Has the absence of a state president impacted the political activities of the party? Why the delay in appointing a new president?

The appointment of a state president will give momentum to the party’s political activities. But absence of the state chief has not affected the party in anyway as the organisational activities are going on. If we see a duck swimming, we think it is sailing smooth, but it paddles hard underwater. Similarly, the party is working hard and reaching out to more people. The party’s popularity has also been growing after Prime Minister Modi’s Mamallapuram visit.

Q: Does the BJP have the resource and cadre base in TN to prove their strength in the coming elections?

After the demise of charismatic leaders, the DMK and other Dravidian parties are banking on their party symbols. People in several parts of the state believe they are voting for former CM Karunanidhi by choosing the ‘rising sun’ symbol. It is same with other parties too. So, we are taking up intensive campaigns to take ‘lotus’ symbol to everyone and making a point that the symbol stands for the country’s growth. In the days to come, the ‘lotus’ symbol will be seen everywhere.

Q: If Rajinikanth launches his political party and decides to go alone, will he take away the BJP’s vote bank in the state?

Actor Rajinikanth and the BJP have more or less the same Hindutva ideology. But it will not harm our prospects in any way as we have a core vote bank. Besides, we will campaign to enhance the voting percentage.

Title: Urvashi Rautela wishes herself on her birthday with an Instagram post; captions, 'My birthday should be a holiday'
Content: We will have to see how things pan out once we start shooting for films, say Gujarati filmmakers after I&B Ministry releases SOPs for film shoots

Title: Kanaka Durga temple trust board members take oath
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Vijayawada: The 16 newly-appointed members of the trust board of Sri Durga Malleswara Swamy Varla Devasthanam took oath on Monday. The members elected senior YSRC leader Paila Somi Naidu as the chairman of the board.

All the members were sworn in by the temple executive officer MV Suresh Babu. The state government on February 20 issued an order nominating 16 members to the board, which has a two-year tenure. Endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas, Brahmin corporation chairman Malladi Vishnu, and Guntur legislator Maddali Giridhar among others attended the oath-taking ceremony.

Temple chief priest Lingambotla Durga Prasad has been nominated by the government as the ex-officio member of the trust board.

Trust board chairman Somi Naidu said the board will focus on developing the temple.

Speaking to reporters after the ceremony, he said, “Providing fast and hassle-free darshan and other amenities for common devotees is our priority. We will work hard to keep up the sanctity of the temple. All our members will take decisions following the Vedic rituals”

Title: Trump said 'love it, more Americans will come here after my visit': Guide who showed Taj to US prez
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Agra: Taking US President Donald Trump and his wife Melania on a tour of the Taj Mahal was a “lifetime's dream come true", 36-year-old guide Nitin Singh told TOI on Monday.

Singh, who has spent 12 years in the profession and has a license from the department of tourism, was selected for the job after the US embassy had interviewed over 50 guides. Singh has guided several other dignitaries including prime minister of Israel Benjamin Netanyahu, Canadian premier Justin Trudeau and president of France Emmanuel Macron.

“I could have asked for nothing more than this opportunity, and I thank god for it,” Singh said, describing Trump as an extremely “kind and lively person”. He added, "I found him very friendly and jovial. He obliged everyone with selfies and photos. He did not say no to anyone.” Trump and his family spent more than an hour at the Taj Mahal. They reached the 17th century monument at about 4.40 pm, coming straight from Ahmedabad, and left around 6.04 pm.

Trump, the guide said, praised the monument's architecture, inlay and stone work, and also the double dome structure. The US president wrote on the visitor's book that “The Taj Mahal inspires awe, a timeless testament to the rich and diverse beauty of Indian culture! Thank you India”.

Trump and Melania asked Singh several questions. "They said, 'Where did all this marble come from? Where were the workers and artisans brought from? What material was used for making the royal gate?'," Singh recounted. "They also wanted to know how the monument was being kept clean and what was the procedure for doing so".

Singh said Trump was "impressed" by the story of Shahjahan and Mumtaz, "but he felt bad that the emperor was imprisoned for eight years at the Agra Quila".

Though Trump was with Melania, walking hand in hand through much part of the tour, he was joined by daughter Ivanka and son-in-law Jared Kushner when they sat down to see the sunset. "The president said he 'loved the monument' and added that after his visit many more Americans will come to see the Taj," Singh said.

Title: Sharjeel met Badruddin Ajmal to plan anti-CAA stir, says Himanta
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

GUWAHATI: Sharjeel Imam, the JNU student booked for sedition, has admitted during interrogation by Guwahati police that he met Assam Lok Sabha MP Badruddin Ajmal at his Delhi residence prior to his arrest to discuss the anti-CAA agitation, minister Himanta Biswa Sarma claimed on Monday.

“Not only Ajmal, he had been in touch with many people in Assam over phone. The police are investigating the matter. The state government is tracking developments related to his interrogation and the findings will be revealed from time to time,” Sarma said.

Ajmal is the chief of the All India United Democratic Front, which has 12 seats in the 126-member assembly. Brought to Guwahati for interrogation on February 20, Sharjeel was taken to a hospital here on Monday for a medical check-up after the court of the Kamrup chief judicial magistrate extended his police remand by another four days.

The JNU student was arrested in Bihar after several states filed complaints against him for allegedly inciting violence through his speeches. In one of several videos purportedly showing him making provocative speeches, he is heard saying that the “chicken’s neck” connecting the northeast with the rest of the country should be severed.

“Sharjeel was talking about separating Assam and the northeast from India. So, whoever was in touch with him should be investigated,” Assam BJP president Ranjeet Dass said.

Title: Economic Survey: Bihar records double-digit growth, again
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Deputy chief minister Sushil Kumar Modi releases the Bihar Economic Survey 2019-20 in Patna on Monday

PATNA: The average growth rate of the state’s economy has been in double digits in the three fiscals from 2016-17 up to 2018-19. It was also reflected in the increased per capita income commensurate with the proportionally increased gross state domestic product (GSDP) during the same period, according to the state’s Economic Survey 2019-20 released on Monday.

Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi tabled the survey report in the state assembly and water resources department (WRD) minister Sanjay Kumar Jha in the legislative council on the opening day of the month-long Budget session of the state legislature. The report dealt with the achievements and perspectives of growth with respect to the 2018-19 fiscal.

The growth rate in the state’s economy at 2011-12 constant prices was 8.9% in 2016-17, 10.5% in 2017-18 and 10.5% in 2018-19. The growth figures at current prices for the corresponding fiscals were 13.6%, 14.8%, and 15%.

Later, outside the House, Modi said that the average growth rate of the state’s economy was “higher than the overall growth of the Indian economy” and stood at 10.53% at 2011-12 constant prices and 15.01% at current prices in 2018-19. “It has been achieved despite odds like floods and drought during the three-year period,” he added.

“The per capita income in Bihar increased from Rs21,750 in 2011-12 to Rs30,617 in 2018-19,” said the Economic Survey report. It, however, noted that the “Bihar has the lowest per capita income among the states” in the country, and it was at only 33.1% of the national average (Rs92,565) in 2018-19, implying that the state needed “extra push to increase its economic activity to converge towards the national average”.

The state’s GSDP was Rs5,57,490 crore at current prices and Rs3,94,350 crore at constant prices of 2011-12.

Modi said the main growth engines contributing to the state’s economy, each registering double digit growth rate, were air transport (36%), other services (20%), trade and repair services (17.6%), road transport (14%) and financial services (13.8%). However, the “potential” of the primary sector (land, agriculture and allied activities) had remained “untapped”.

He also said the government adhered to the norms of Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) Act, maintaining fiscal deficit of 2.68% of the GSDP. During 2018-19, revenue surplus remained at 1.34% and the outstanding public debt liability of the government was 32.34% of the GSDP. He said as per the recommendations of the 15th Finance Commission for 2020-21, the state’s share in the central pool of taxes has increased from 9.67% to 10.06%.

The survey pointed out that maintaining the old trend, the revenue receipt grew by 12.2%, while the revenue expenditure increased by 21.7% in 2018-19 over the previous year. The receipt from the tax revenue at Rs1.03 lakh crore was 16.8% higher than the previous year.

Given the positive signals in the state’s revenue receipts, as well as tax and non-tax revenue receipts, the state’s capacity to repay public debt increased by 55.4% in 2018-19 over the previous year.

Accordingly, the repayment of public debt was to the tune of Rs7,230 crore in 2018-19, compared to Rs4,654 crore in 2017-18, the report noted, adding that the state’s total borrowing in 2018-19 was Rs18,668 crore, compared to Rs13,169 crore in 2017-18 and Rs21,577 crore in 2016-17.

Title: VIP darshan tickets racket busted in Tirumala, five arrested
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: Police arrested five touts for illegal sale of VIP darshan tickets in Tirumala on Monday.

Police arrested Ravi Kishore Reddy, a tout, and his accomplices identified as Damodaram, Janardhan, Jagadeeswara Reddy and Damodaram.

Seven touts identified as Nagaraju, Purushotham Reddy, Tirupati Reddy , Nagarjuna Reddy, Udaya Bhaskar Reddy , Tyagaraju and Nara Yoganand are absconding, said the police. One Town circle inspector Jaganmohan Reddy said the arrests were made after complaints about VIP break darshan tickets being sold at Rs 3,000 per ticket while the price is only Rs 500.

The touts gained access to elected representatives and TTD trust board members and obtained their recommendation letters for darshan at the temple. The police said the gang has been operating at Tirumala for eight years.

Reddy said the VIPs should verify people’s credentials before issuing recommendation letters. He asked devotees not to approach touts for darshan at the temple but avail the Srivani Trust donation linked VIP break darshan scheme launched by the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams.

Title: Former intelligence chief helped son’s firm: Andhra Pradesh to CAT
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

AB Venkateswara Rao

HYDERABAD: The Andhra Pradesh government on Monday informed the Central Administrative Tribunal ( CAT ) that former director-general (DG) (intelligence) AB Venkateswara Rao was suspended after an inquiry prima facie found him guilty of misconduct in the process to procure Aerostat and unmanned aerial vehicle or drones worth Rs 25 crore.

“The state’s action is in tune with Rule 3(1) of the All India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules,” general administration department deputy secretary J Venkata Murali, said in a counter filed before the tribunal, adding “they (Aerostat and drones) are meant for anti-extremist and security operations.”

The tribunal, hearing a petition filed by Rao challenging his suspension, had earlier sought a counter from the state. The AP government, accordingly, filed its counter informing the bench, comprising CAT chairman Justice L Narasimha Reddy and BV Sudhakar, member (administration), that Rao’s actions had constituted serious misconduct and that disciplinary proceedings were pending against him. The CAT, which resumed hearing in the case on Monday, posted the case to March 6.

The state, in its counter, refuted the allegation that it was acting against Rao with malice. A preliminary probe, conducted by AP CID, brought out evidence about the grave misconduct exhibited by Rao in his capacity as then chief of intelligence department and the irregularities he had committed, which led to release of a purchase order in favour of an Israeli firm, RT Inflatable Objects Ltd, through the State Trading Corporation (STC).

It also said that Akasam Advanced System Company, whose CEO was Rao’s son Chetan Sai Krishna , was acting as a franchisee for Israeli firm RT Inflatable Objects. “Rao acted with a mala fide intention to ensure unlawful gain to his son,” the counter stated.

Several administrative, technical and procedural irregularities were committed during the process of procurement and, on noticing them, the purchase order issued by STC was cancelled and payment withheld, the GAD official said. The DGP has informed the AP government about the irregularities and requested the state to take disciplinary action against Rao apart from ordering further probe.

The technical specifications of Aerostat and UAV were scaled down and annual maintenance (AM) conditions were dropped during the final tender on the recommendations of a committee, which included IG, SIB, at its meeting on June 26, 2018. Rao attended the meeting and signed the minutes on behalf of the IG, SIB, which was a violation. “He violated Rule 4(3) (a) of AIS (Conduct) Rules, 1968,” it said, adding, “this was done only to ensure unlawful gain to Chetan Sai Krishna.”

“No demonstration of the equipment was carried out prior to the issue of purchase order and mandatory licences from the Union home ministry, Directorate General of Civil Aviation , Directorate General of Foreign Trade, department of telecom (DoT) etc., were not obtained prior to the issue of the purchase order, it said.

On account of these irregularities, the DGP had cancelled the purchase order given to RT Inflatable Objects on December 24, 2018. “Notwithstanding the cancellation, Rao was pursuing the matter and had even written a letter on March 28, 2019,” the state contended.

The DGP ordered a CID probe into the issue and, based on its report, Rao was suspended, the state said. Rao, in his rejoinder, said there was no monetary loss to the state because STC had returned the money on cancellation of the purchase order. “I was pursuing the matter even after cancellation only to improve the intelligence department,” he said. The CAT posted the case to March 6.

Title: 350 people booked for Sunday night’s violence in Aligarh
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Agra: Aligarh police on Monday registered eight FIRs against more than 350 persons in connection with arsons and group clashes that took place in the city a day earlier.

Confirming this, Aligarh SSP Muniraj G said FIRs have been registered under various sections of IPC, including section 153 A (promoting enmity between different groups on ground of religion), 307 (attempt to murder) at Kotwali police station, where the violent clashes took place on Sunday evening. He added about 100 people have been identified and 40 of them are named in the FIR.

He further said the situation is still tense, but under control. No untoward incident was reported from any place during the day, but some women sat on a dharna at Jeevannagar area.

“We are maintaining a tight vigil in the city and things will return back to normal soon,” the SSP said, adding that the police are also initiating confidence-building measures with the help of community leaders to help restore normalcy in all the affected areas.

He told TOI that the police have so far identified 100 persons who were involved in the clashes. “CCTV footages are being screened and evidences are being collected against miscreants,” he added.

According to police, Mohamad Tariq, who received gunshot injuries during Sunday’s violence, is now stable and has been shifted to the ICU at the Trauma Centre of the Jawaharlal Nehru hospital. Doctors have performed an emergency surgery on him.

District magistrate C B Singh told TOI that anyone trying to spread rumours would be firmly dealt with and NSA would be invoked in such cases. He said that Internet services will be restored from Monday midnight.

Earlier on Sunday evening, trouble broke out at the Upper Kot locality when police were trying to evict women anti-CAA protesters who were squatting on the Mohamed Ali Road near the Kotwali police station since Saturday morning.

Some people protested, leading to a scuffle and within minutes, brick batting started from neighbouring areas.

According to eyewitness accounts, the trouble was initially limited to Upper Kot locality where the women protesters were staging the dharna, but after police action against anti-CAA protesters, tension soon spilled over to the neighbouring localities, including Babri Mandi.

Title: Wow, says Ivanka, dials relative on FaceTime to show Taj
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Agra: US President Donald Trump’s daughter Ivanka Trump made a FaceTime call to one of her relatives to let him have a glimpse of the Taj Mahal, while she made a stopover at Agra along with her parents on Monday.

This was revealed by her guide Kamalkant Gupta.

Gupta, 47, told TOI that Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner were very excited to be at the Taj.

“Ivanka even made a video call to one of her relatives to make him part of their experience,” said Gupta, who described the couple to be “humble”.

He said Ivanka was thrilled to see the Taj and her first expression on seeing the 17-century marble marvel was “wow”. “Ivanka said that it is unbelievable that someone could make such a monument for someone he loved,” said Gupta.

Gupta said that she clicked several photographs on the Lady Diana seat and was extremely impressed with architecture of the monument. She wanted to see the main mausoleum, but could not, due to protocol.

According to Gupta, Ivanka expressed the desire to visit the Taj Mahal again and her husband was particularly interested to know about the inlay work. He said that the dignitaries gave a chance to almost everyone who were present there to click photographs with them.

“The grandeur and beauty of the Taj Mahal is awe inspiring!” she posted on her Instagram page with several photographs of her with husband. Ivanka visited India to attend the Global Entrepreneurship Summit (GES) in Hyderabad in November 2017, and had dinner with global delegates at the Taj Falaknuma Palace. She praised Modi for proving that “transformational change is possible”.

Gupta had earlier shown the Taj to then US vice-president Joe Biden’s wife, Jill Biden, in August 2007.

Title: Plan B: WRD may pump water into Khandepar
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ponda:With the Dhatwada-Usgao locals continuing to oppose the water pipeline between Dhatwada and Khandepar, it is uncertain if the Khandepar river would be augmented with water from the Ganjem water scheme this summer. Work on laying the pipeline has been halted since February 1.

However, the water resources department (WRD) is ready to pour the required raw water into the Kalem River, which will flow down into the Khandepar River.

A WRD team from Pajimol, Sanguem, has recently carried out the servicing and repairs of two pumps powered by 600 HP motors, vaccum pumps and the sluice valve among other things.

With the water level in the Khandepar reducing, Opa water works had asked WRD officials to get the pumps at the Ganjem and Selaulim Dam ready, in order to rejuvenate the river. Following the commissioning of the new 27-MLD water treatment plant at Opa, the water works now draws over 160 MLD water from the Khandepar regularly.

A total of five water treatment plants at Opa ward in Khandepar village,Ponda, supplies potable water to over 95% of Ponda and Tiswadi talukas. This includes Panaji, Bambolim, Taleigao, Ribandar and the entire taluka of Ponda.

Once the water level in the Opa basin goes down, it receives water from Selaulim dam, Ganjem water scheme, a total of 18 bundharas over the Khandepar and Kalem rivers, from the mining pits in Codli village and the Opa river and its tributaries. The Ganjem bundhara has two pumps that fetch 35 MLD water and two pumps of 600 HP each at Selaulim Dam that together draw 48 MLD of water.

Title: Indian crew of quarantined cruiseliner still await release
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Margao: More than two weeks after luxury cruise liner ‘Diamond Princess’ was quarantined off the coast of Japan, the 135 crew members from India, 50 of whom are Goans, are still spending anxious days and nights aboard the vessel— well after the completion of the14-day quarantine period.

Vivian Raikar, brother of Dhanasth who is among the Goan seafarers on board the cruiseliner told TOI on Monday that the latter called him stating that the situation was getting precarious with every passing day. “Crew members from all other countries have left the ship. The Indian crew members are now feeling dejected and depressed. We appeal to the Goa government to urge the Centre to take urgent steps to ensure the safe return of the Indian seafarers ,” Vivian said.

Dhanasth had earlier told TOI from the ship, soon after the vessel was quarantined, that the passengers were prohibited from disembarking for even a few minutes. “We can’t get any fresh air here,” Dhanasth had said, suggesting that that despondency had begun to set in among the passengers and the crew.

“All the passengers have gone back home. The Filipino crew members, numbering above 500, are also going back in two flights arranged by the Phillipines government. Only the Indians are now left on the ship. All the tests for coronavirus have returned negative. Is the government waiting for us to test positive in order to rescue us?” a crew member wearing a protective mask is heard asking in a video posted on social media.

Title: Cheaper Indian device brings relief to patients with narrow aortic valve
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The Indian device is a boon for the elderly, say doctors

KOLKATA: A few weeks ago, a 79-year-old Kasba resident underwent a relatively new procedure called Tavi (transcatheter aortic valve implantation), using the India-made artificial aortic valve, at a city hospital. The procedure involves non-surgically replacing the diseased valve with a prosthetic aortic valve.

Doctors in the city said the procedure is the future for the aged patients suffering from aortic stenosis. While the exorbitant cost of the imported device was a barrier, the India-made device has cut the cost of the procedure by about 40%. Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. This narrowing prevents the valve from opening fully, reducing or blocking blood from flowing out of the heart into the main artery and to the rest of the body. If not treated, it could lead to heart failure. Aortic stenosis is related to age.

“This procedure scores over the open surgery of replacing a diseased valve in a number of ways. It is a minimally invasive surgery that takes around two hours and allows the patient quick recovery and, hence, is the best for the elderly with a host of underlying health conditions,” said interventional cardiologist Debdutta Bhattacharya.

Bhattacharya along with cardiac surgeon Atanu Saha had conducted the Tavi on the Kasba resident, a doctor himself. The septuagenarian is doing fine with the aortic valve. The patient had severe aortic stenosis and came to the hospital in a critical condition.

“The procedure has gained wide popularity in the west. Till December 2019, about 70,000 such procedures had been performed in Germany alone. But the high cost the imported prosthesis was an issue in India. Now that we have the indigenous device, which is as good as the imported ones at a more affordable cost, more people can take advantage of the procedure,” said interventional cardiologist PK Hazra who has also conducted two such procedures with the India-made device at AMRI Hospitals, Dhakuria.

The package for the procedure using the imported prosthesis is about Rs 25 in Kolkata. But now with the indigenous device, the cost has come down to about Rs 16 lakh.

Tavi is tailored specially for the elderly patients who cannot cope with an open heart surgery that requires breaking open to the breast bone. In this a minimally invasive procedure, in which the doctor inserts the catheter into a large artery in the groin. The valve is implanted in the heart via this catheter.

“This procedure is the future for the elderly. However, as a majority of the elderly people in India do not have medical insurance, the cost even after the using the Indian device could keep many away,” said Sunip Banerjee, cardiologist at SG Cardiac Care. Banerjee, too, had conducted Tavi on a Kolkatan, but at a Singapore hospital a few years ago.

Title: Robbery in Patna: Rs 31 lakh looted in Samastipur
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

SAMASTIPUR/PATNA: Three bike-borne armed criminals looted Rs31 lakh from the employees of a cement and iron bars company in Samastipur on Monday.

The incident took place around 12.45pm when the two employees of M K Traders were going on a bike to deposit the cash in the HDFC Bank branch on Gola Road. The criminals intercepted them at gunpoint near Lakhna Chowk under Town police station area and snatched the bag containing cash.

Town police station SHO Sitaram Prasad told this newspaper over phone that MK Traders’ owner Mukund Singh had given Rs31 lakh to his employees Sanjay Thakur and Kunwerjeet Singh to deposit the money in the bank, which was only a few kilometres away from the factory at Kashipur .

“Kunwerjeet was carrying the bag and Sanjay was driving the bike. When the employees tried to speed away, the miscreants scared them with a pistol and snatched the bag. According to the two employees, the miscreants escaped towards Veer Kunwar Singh Colony,” the SHO said and added: “A complaint has been registered and we are conducting raids to nab the criminals.”

The daylight robbery sent the police administration in a tizzy and a special investigation team (SIT) was formed under Sadar DSP Pritish Kumar. The DSP said police were scrutinizing the footage of CCTV cameras installed near the spot of crime. SHOs of Town and Mufassil police stations, Sitaram Prasad and Vikram Acharya, are the other members of the SIT.

Title: School asked to provide records of students caught with fake docus
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: A day after an investigating committee was set up to probe the case of 35 “students” who were caught taking the English examination of the UP Board with fake documents at Major Asharam Inter College in Meerut ’s Mawana area on Saturday, a notice has been served on the principal of PD Kanya Higher Secondary School to provide the documents and records of the students caught.

The students of PD Kanya Higher Secondary School were taking their exam at Major Asharam Inter College in Ganeshpur when 35 of them were caught with fake documents.

According to GK Chaudhary, Meerut district inspector of schools, once the documents are analysed, action will be taken accordingly. He added the result of the said students could be withheld and the service of the principal cancelled.

The matter came to the fore when it was found that the date of birth on the Aadhaar cards and admit cards of the students concerned did not match. On Friday, the students were asked to come with their Aadhaar cards for the exam. While at least 48 students skipped the exam, 35 had bogus Aadhaar cards -- the QR code of which was found to be fake. An FIR has been filed against the principal of the school for allegedly being hand in glove with the students who were caught.

All the students were taken to Hastinapur police station and during their interrogation, it was revealed that the principal of PD Kanya Higher Secondary School was involved in some irregularities with the documents.

Title: Hyderabad biker tries to dodge dog, hits footpath, dies
Content:
Police said the youth was wearing a helmet at the time of the accident

HYDERABAD: A 23-year-old student, riding a sports bike from Jubilee Hills checkpost towards KBR Park, died after he hit a footpath while trying to avoid running over a dog on Monday morning. The dog also died in the accident .Charan Yadav, resident of Ameerpet and a third-year business management student, was returning from his friend’s house in Madhapur at around 7 am when a dog came in front of his bike while crossing the road. He lost control of the vehicle while trying to save the dog, but ended up hitting it and then the edge of a footpath, Jubilee Hills police said. He suffered multiple injuries and died on the spot.Police pointed out that Charan was wearing a helmet at the time of the accident.In this mishap, another motorist also fell down after he was hit, but he escaped with minor injuries.Charan’s family was informed of the accident and the body was shifted to Osmania General Hospital for post-mortem. Police said that they are looking into the footages from CCTV cameras installed on the stretch to ascertain the exact reasons for the accident. The accident spot has also been cordoned off for further investigation.The stretch from KBR Park to Jubilee Hills checkpost is usually considered an accident-prone zone and over-speeding has been the primary reason for most of the accidents that have been reported in this area.In Video: Hyderabad: Youth riding sports bike dies while trying to save dog

Title: Kerala Dairy Expo at Kanakakunnu from today
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state-level dairy farmers’ meet titled ‘Ksheera Sangamam 2020’ will be held in the capital from Tuesday to Friday. Kerala Dairy Expo, workshops and seminars will be held as part of the event.

An open forum on ‘the future of Anand model cooperative societies in India’ to be held on Wednesday will be one of the highlights of the event. The open forum will be inaugurated by governor Arif Mohammad Khan.

Being organized by the dairy development department, Milma, regional unions, animal husbandry department, Kerala Veterinary University, Kerala Livestock Development Board, Kerala Feeds and cooperative milk societies, the four-day event will be held on the premises of the Kanakakkunnu Palace.

City mayor K Sreekumar will flag off the proclamation march at 3.30pm on Tuesday. Organizing committee chairman MLA V K Prasanth will hoist the flag at 4pm, which will be followed by inauguration of the dairy expo by industries minister E P Jayarajan at the function to be presided over by forest and dairy development minister K Raju.

Announcing the event here on Monday, dairy development director S Sreekumar said the sector was witnessing high growth, thanks to various schemes of the state government including those being initiated by the local bodies, besides the strong marketing system which is in place. “Currently, 19.11 lakh litres of milk is being procured daily through milk societies,” he said.

The event will witness workshops for employees of milk cooperative societies and for officials of local bodies, besides a technical workshop on ‘milk processing and latest technologies’. Other events include a seminar on fodder, Jwala 2020 – a confluence of women dairy farmers and the fourth edition of the Dairy Farmers’ Parliament, a forum which puts forth suggestions and recommendations before the state planning board.

The event will also have a ‘meet-the-innovators’ programme on Friday, presenting seven dairy farmers, which will be followed by the concluding ceremony during which various awards will be distributed.

The dairy expo will have around 150 stalls and will showcase cattle, pets and ornamental fish.

Title: ‘Families of Goan seafarers worried’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Margao: The commissioner for NRI affairs, Narendra Sawaikar, on Monday wrote to the ambassador of India to Japan with regards to the safety of the Indian crew members aboard the ‘Diamond Princess’ luxury cruise liner quarantined in Japan. “There is considerable anxiety gripping the families of several Goan seafarers onboard the cruise ship, Diamond Princess, which is quarantined off the coast of Japan as a preventive measure against spread of the Coronavirus as I understand that the vessel had reportedly sailed via China. The families of the Goan seafarers are extremely worried and anxious to know about the wellbeing of their family members who are onboard,” Sawaikar stated in his letter to the ambassador , urging him to apprise the Goa government of the current status of the Goan seafarers onboard the ship. TNN

Title: ‘Women will be the worst-hit by a nationwide NRC exercise’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

File photo of women protesters at Park Circus Maidan

Title: Tamil Nadu: Boards will test knowledge of students and more
Content:
16 lakh class X, XII students face finals with new textbooks that teachers too find tough

CHENNAI: The boards are here and Class X and XII students, their teachers and parents are in a tizzy. So what, you could say. This is an annual phenomenon. But there is a difference this year. These are the first boards after textbooks for the two classes were revised in Tamil Nadu.So for more than 16 lakh students, it’s like a leap into the unknown. The Class XII exam starts from March 2 and Class X exam starts from March 27. Another 8 lakh students will take the Class XI exams that start from March 4.A topper in a private school said she would have known how much she would score under the earlier system. “But, with new textbooks, even our teachers lack clarity and find it difficult to complete syllabus,” she said.Another student said it was difficult to cover the full syllabus. “Teachers are trying their best. But, the textbooks are new and difficult to understand,” said a student who scored 481 out of 500 in Class X. She expects to score more than 70% in the Class XII exams.“Our students and teachers found the new books heavier than the previous textbooks. But, the new textbooks cover more than 90% of NEET syllabus. So, we are asking students to shoulder the burden,” said B Purushothaman, senior principal of Everwin Group of Schools, Chennai.“We are waiting with bated breath to see the question papers. There is excitement and anxiety among the students and teachers,” he added.“Students are preparing well, but their confidence level is low since it is the first exam,” said G J Manohar, headmaster, MCC Higher Secondary School, Chetpet. “In the absence of a blueprint, it is challenging to prepare the students. But, if they prepare from the beginning of the academic year, they can still score above 90% marks in the revised syllabus," he said.The directorate of government examinations has released the model question papers for Class X, XI and XII board exams. But, it also cautioned that the questions could be asked from anywhere in the textbooks. “As announced students would get 30 minutes extra for all three board exams and the top sheets of regular students and private candidates and students writing under old syllabus would be different colours,” sources said.Meanwhile, officials from school education department said following the question paper leaks in half-yearly exams, the department has set up strong rooms to store question papers and answer sheets. “These strong rooms will have 24X7 CCTV monitoring and armed police guard,” they said

Title: Allahabad high court issues contempt notice to MDA for not acting against illegal marriage halls
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: The Allahabad high court on Monday issued contempt notice to Meerut Development Authority (MDA) and sought details of action taken against 124 unauthorised banquet halls in the city, almost seven months after the court gave the civic body three months to comply with the order. The court has now set March 5 as the deadline to comply with the order.

On July 12 last year, the court had directed the MDA to act against the illegal marriage halls while hearing a petition filed by Meerut resident Sachin Saini. However, the civic body failed to follow the order. The court had then observed, “Having considered all the facts stated, we deem it appropriate to direct Meerut Development Authority to take all necessary penal steps against Baratghars including the Baratghars established prior to 2008, if they are not adhering to norms.”

Reacting to the development, vice chairman of MDA Rajesh Kumar Pandey said, “We have been conducting crackdown on illegal operators. The matter is sub-judice and once we receive the formal order we will reply.”

However, the petitioner in the case, Saini, is not convinced. “A large number of illegal Baratghars (marriage/banquet halls) are still operating in the city. Most of them don’t even have adequate space to park the vehicles. The movement of the marriage procession causes huge nuisance on road and hampers traffic movement, particularly during wedding season.”

After the HC order in July, an association representing banquet halls of Meerut had sought time till November to make infrastructural changes in their establishments to adhere to parking and other norms.

The petitioner had alleged that out of the nearly 248 banquet halls in the district, a majority are running illegally without following the norms.

At present, 163 marriage halls are operational under the jurisdiction of MDA, while another 93 fall under Cantonment and Housing Development Board administration. Interestingly, out of the total 163 halls which come under the MDA, only 24 have their maps sanctioned by the development authority.

In the order issued on July 12, 2019, a bench comprising Justices Vivek Verma and Govind Mathur had observed, “It is also brought to our notice that a Baratghar must have parking space in tune of the standards given in para 16.9 of the norms. In Meerut, 163 Baratghars are operating and out of that 105 were established prior to 2008. Out of all these Baratghars, only 24 were established after getting the map sanctioned by the authority. 139 Baratghars out of 163 are in operation at places which are not having necessary approval from the MDA. These facts indicate gross violation of the norms. The MDA laid down its norms for construction and establishment of Baratghars in the year 2008. But only a few Baratghars are said to have complied with the norms so laid down.”

Title: Parents need to relax, say educators
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Chennai: The exam season is back and so is anxiety among parents. To let them breathe easy, several schools in the city are counselling parents.

“This is the first time my child is appearing for boards. I am more nervous than her,” said Ranjita Das, parent of a Class X student.

“It all starts with parents saying, ‘you have to get the highest marks’, ‘you have to stop playing’,” said Shoba Raman, principal of Vidya Mandir. “This contributes to the pressure the child is facing. “We first need to counsel the parents so that children can write the exam confidently.”

Schools like Vidya Mandir, PS Senior Secondary, Chinmaya Vidyalaya and Vael’s are helping parents on ‘exam parenting’. Schools are holding monthly and biweekly meetings, and giving access to teachers.

“Parenting during examination can be stressful and they need to be helped,” said Bharati Lakshmi, principal of Vael’s International. She said teachers regularly stay in touch with parents. “We ask them to relax. We insist that they support their children emotionally and stop doubting their capabilities,” she said.

Chinmaya Vidyalaya met parents of Class X and Class XII students. P Vijayalakshmi, the school’s principal, said she noticed that parents compared children — their marks , studying hours, playtime. “We requested them to put an end to it and focus on the child’s well being,” she said. “I do understand that exam time can be stressful, but it doesn’t mean that you stop children from doing everything they used to do. It will not improve their performance.”

Psychiatrist Dr Lakshmi Vijayakumar said parents should create a healthy environment and allow their children regular breaks besides ensuring they get eight hours of sleep and good food. “A child must take a 15-minute break after every 45 minutes of studying. And during the break, they should not be given gadgets because the switch from books to digital screen can strain the eyes and brain,” she said.

Title: Hyderabad cops on alert after CAA clashes in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar

HYDERABAD: In view of the clashes that broke out between anti and pro Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) protesters in Delhi on Monday, city police commissioner Anjani Kumar has asked all station house officers and assistant commissioners in the twin cities to be on alert.

“In the wake of stone-pelting in Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh between pro and anti CAA group, there is an urgent need to alert your field officers, please take necessary action,” read the message.

Police patrolling has been intensified across city and cops have been instructed to keep an eye on flash protests. “There is no intelligence input about CAA clashes, but we are exercising precaution,” said a senior police officer.

On Monday, tensions escalated in Delhi after protesters torched two houses and a fire engine during clashes between pro and anti-CAA groups. Two, including a head constable, were killed.

Title: Talathi acquitted of graft charges
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Colva: Principal district and sessions judge B P Deshpande on Monday acquitted a government employee Subhash Velip of corruption charges filed against him with the anti-corruption branch (ACB).

Dilip V Hegde, in his complaint to the ACB dated November 29, 2010, stated that he had sold a piece of land.

Subsequently, the buyer wanted his name to be added to the Form I and XIV through mutation. For the same, he said he had forwarded the duly filled forms to the mamlatdar’s office in Quepem, but the accused, who was the talathi then, asked for Rs 5,000 for processing the file.

On Hegde’s complaint, the ACB conducted a raid and caught the accused red-handed while he was accepting the smeared currency notes from the complainant in the presence of other witnesses.

In all, 19 witnesses were examined in support of the prosecution.

Judge Deshpande acquitted the accused by giving him the benefit of doubt.

Title: Int’l meet on environmental sustainability at Navrachana
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

One of the speakers at the conference

Vadodara: More than 15 experts and scholars from across the world and about 40 from various parts of the country are taking part in Navrachana University’s first-ever international conference being organized by the newly set up Navrachana University Centre for Environment Research and Innovation (NUCERI).

The conference that kicked off on Monday continue until February 26.

The three-day conference will deliberate on various aspects on the basic theme of ‘ecohealth and environmental sustainability’. It is being organized by NU in association with University of Calgary, Canada.

Professor A V Ramachandran, mentor of school of sciences, said, “The conference will play a vital role in the present context as all the countries are focusing on climate change and even India is playing its role for the same.”

“This conference will deliberate on recent advances in cleaner technologies to reduce pollution and health hazard-related issues. The sessions will deliberate on alternative energy resources and conservation of marine and wildlife diversity of plants and animals. The issues will find out solutions for restoring natural ecosystems,” said NU’s provost Dr Nilay Yajnik.

The conference will have 11 technical sessions and a dedicated panel discussion on ‘most challenging environmental concern from Indian perspective: identification, management, mitigation and policies’.

Title: Drug-and-rob case: Man held after 14 days
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: The watch section of the detective department on Monday claimed to have solved a case in which a man, who had gone to meet his kin at a hospital off EM Bypass, was drugged and robbed. A 34-year-old suspect has been arrested.

The incident was reported on February 10 by the victim — Pintu Sardar of Nazhat in North 24 Parganas. He went to the hospital around 8.15am. The suspect was identified as Palash Roy, a resident of Shahid Smriti Colony.

“Among the stolen items were Rs 10,000, 55 Euros, one mobile phone and some documents pertaining to the hospital. The cops have recovered Rs 4,000, the foreign currency and the phone. Roy had been arrested earlier for a similar offence,” said Murlidhar Sharma, joint CP (crime).

“Sardar said that when he went to the hospital, an unknown person came to him and struck up a conversation. He then offered Sardar some biscuits. After eating the biscuits, Sardar felt drowsy and became unconscious. When he woke up around 11.30am, he was lying on a pavement and his bag was missing. We used CCTV footage and our network to nab the suspect,” Sharma said. Roy confessed to the crime and said the biscuits had been laced with Nitrosun-10 tablet, a kind of sedative.

Title: Chennai Metro News: Uncooked meat, seafood not allowed on Chennai metro trains
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

CHENNAI: If you have just bought some fresh raw seafood from the Chintadripet fish market and have decided to board a metro train at Government Estate station to quickly go home and cook your favourite dish, you could be waiting for a long time as passengers are not allowed to carry raw meat and seafood in metro premises and in trains.

A metro rail official said uncooked meat and seafood are items banned in metro stations and trains under the Metro Railways Carriage Ticket Rules, 2014. According to the rules, officials categorise uncooked meat and fish under ‘carcasses of dead animals or of dead birds’ which fall under ‘offensive material’. “It is prohibited across all metros. You also cannot carry live animals or bird. We are simply following the rules,” an official said.

Among other ‘offensive material’ banned from metro rail services, are bones excluding bleached and cleaned bones, blood dried or coagulated or decomposed whether human or animal.

While commuters can carry packed cooked food into the stations and in trains, they are, however, not allowed to open or consume them while on commute.

Earlier this month in Bengaluru, a passenger was stopped at the entrance of a metro station for carrying uncooked fish back home. The incident came to light after the commuters tweeted about it and said the fish was in a properly sealed cover. Soon, Bangalore metro rail responded that meat is banned in the metro. However, it is allowed if it is properly packed and nothing is oozing out from the package or is emitting a foul smell.

In Chennai metro, commuters are also not allowed to carry unsealed liquor bottles. But those purchased from duty free shops and are properly sealed are allowed to pass through baggage scanners at the stations.

Among a list of items prohibited in metro, commuters cannot carry live animals or birds, gases compressed, liquefied or dissolved under pressure, petroleum and other inflammable liquids, inflammable solids, poisonous substances, acids and other corrosives, weapons, arms and ammunitions and any chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear and enhanced conventional weapons which possess risk to passengers or property.

Title: High-profile visit puts Agra on pause mode
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Agra: On Monday, Agra held its breath and went on pause mode. By 9am, shops had downed shutters. By 11am, brisk-and-businesslike cops were ordering vehicle owners to take their parked cars out of sight. A sullen cop kicked and floored two mobikes when the owner was slow to react.

It was an afternoon of edgy anticipation. Slowly cars and motorcycles thinned out of the roads. One could only see traffic police receptors, cops in various uniforms on mobikes and jeeps. Some kept watch from rooftops through binoculars. Onlookers were discouraged from peering from rooftops. Noise pollution dipped dramatically, barring the sound of siren. And all this when US President Donald Trump was still making his speech in Ahmedabad.

“Many prime ministers and presidents have visited Agra to see the Taj Mahal. But I have never seen such forceful bandobast (arrangements) before,” said hotel receptionist Faizan Khan.

By 3 pm, it was a strange sight of an empty road and crowded wayside. In a carefully calibrated show, thousands had already lined up along the road to welcome Trump. In the Tajganj area, hundreds of men and women from Brahma Kumaris, a spiritual organisation, stood by the barricades. “We will be waving out when the cavalcade passes by. It is our way of spreading positive energy,” said Manish Agarwal, who like others was dressed in all-white and wore an identification tag.

Trump arrived in Agra at 4.10 pm. Around 4.40pm, the US President’s cavalcade of 20 odd cars, hurtled past Tajganj. And it was no different when the group returned an hour later after gloating over the Taj, a poem in white marble.

To most onlookers, the experience of waiting for the US President was underwhelming. They had been anticipating the event for hours and it ended before it could register in their minds.

A bunch of Class 9 students from Holy Public Junior College, who had waited to wave flags for over five hours, were tired and disappointed. “We expected the cavalcade to pass by slowly. We hoped to wave at President Trump. Forget about seeing him, we hardly had any time to wave the flags,” said student Isha Saraswat. A Class VI student from John Milton Public School fainted briefly due to exhaustion, a fellow student said.

Tourists suffered in various ways. Those who had no inkling of the traffic restrictions had to walk for several kilometres from bus stand and railway station. James Carter, who has come with his fiancée Lesley Smith from Christchurch said, “We had planned to visit a nearby market in the afternoon. But after 2 pm, there was complete lockdown of the route. We had to spend our entire afternoon at the hotel.”

For the past few days, the city had brightened up for the US president. The makeover had continued on Monday morning. Tempo trailers scoured about for ugly spots to conceal with cut-outs of Modi and Trump. Buildings under construction were covered up with banners. Metallic horses and camels wrapped in marigold were set up overnight. Wooden barricades wrapped in saffron and white silk cloth stood as an obstacle between the road and the roadside. Roads were watered to avoid raising of dust.

Early Monday, there was air of expectation in Agra. Men on motorbikes, women in burqa and girls in shimmery dress posed and pouted before the cut-outs of Trump and Modi; the PM being the preferred choice of most. The city was in the midst of a great selfie festival.

But slowly the mood of reverie gave away. Trump left Agra for Delhi around 6.40pm. When Air Force One finally took off from Kheria Air Base, Agra exhaled.

Title: NIA raids 25 TN & K’taka sites over IS-inspired cells
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

NEW DELHI: The National Investigation Agency (NIA) on Monday conducted searches at multiple locations in Tamil Nadu and Karnataka in three cases relating to modules inspired by banned terrorist outfit Islamic State (IS). While 10 locations in Tamil Nadu — including one each in Chennai, Kanchipuram and Toothukudi, three in Salem , and four in Cuddalore — were searched, as many as 15 locations were searched in Bengaluru and Kolar in Karnataka.

The first case, registered by NIA in January this year, involved 10 people arrested and charged with conspiring with an IS member for carrying out unlawful activities and committing terrorist acts in the country by procuring illegal arms, for furthering the objectives of the proscribed terror group.

The second case — IS Khaja Moideen Module — was also registered by the NIA in January this year. Four accused and their associates were named by the NIA in an alleged conspiracy to carry out terrorist attacks in Delhi-NCR to further the objectives of IS. During searches at the houses of the arrested accused, documents, including books supporting violent jihad have been seized, the NIA said.

In Karnataka, the NIA carried out searches at 15 locations in Bengaluru and Kolar in connection with an investigation of a case relating to IS Al Hind Module. The locations include houses of the arrested and absconding accused and office of Al-Hind Trust. The case pertains to a criminal conspiracy of killing Hindu leaders, creating communal riots and to carry out “anti-national” activities by forming a terrorist gang inspired by IS.

The members of the terrorist gang conducted meetings at Bengaluru and other parts of Karnataka, Tamil Nadu and propagated IS ideology, procured arms and ammunition and other incriminating material for executing their plans, the official said.

Title: Goa: Court convicts accused in 2015 murder
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

COLVA: Additional sessions court judge Dvijpla Patkar on Monday convicted Ahit Bezbaruah for the murder of Ratan Das. Both, the accused and the deceased, were working as construction labourers.

On December 31, 2015, Curchorem police registered an offence against the accused for having stabbed the deceased in the stomach with a kitchen knife over a work-related dispute.

Das was rushed to Hospicio, Margao, with severe bleeding injuries and was declared brought dead by the medical officer. Hence, the accused was charged under Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code.

In all, 16 witnesses were examined in support of the prosecution.

Judge Patkar then heard public prosecutor Jerry Costa and defence advocate Nobert Fernandes on the point of sentence and adjourned the matter for March 6.

Title: Stray dog victims’ kin leave village, arm themselves
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Jagraon and Khanna: Pushed to the wall, many families in Jagraon and Khanna villages have been forced to take extreme safety measures to safeguard themselves from the stray dog menace. While the family of a victim has migrated to a “safer” area, another has armed itself with sticks and started a vigil to ensure safety of others. As tales of horror echo in small hamlets, some of the victims dread stepping out alone, especially at night.

In a case that sent shockwaves in Khanna, a pack of stray dogs had mauled four-year-old Viraj Kumar to death at Bahomajra village on January 26.

Viraj’s mother Sharda Devi, who worked in a rag collection unit, said the incident left them traumatised and terrorised, forcing the family to shift from Bahomajra to Kauri area. She said she took the decision as she didn’t want her differently-abled daughter Kiran Kumari, a Class V student, and son Vikas, 11, a Class IV student, to meet the same fate.

Recalling the fateful evening when her children were playing outside and she was busy with household chores, Sharda said, “I ran out on hearing Viraj’s screams. I was shocked to see canines gnawing at him. The ferocious beasts had mauled him.”

As she narrated the incident, tears flowed down the cheeks of her son Vikas, who said he will never be able to forget what happened with his brother. Shardha said the government must do something to tackle the problem that has become life threatening for small children.

Meanwhile, an area resident cited accidents on Ludhiana-Delhi highway as one of the reasons for the spike in stray dog problem.

“Vehicles hit stray cattle during night hours and then dogs feed on the carcasses. They attack humans when they fail to find food. The problem is severe in many villages, including Bahomajra, Bija, Kaddon, Daheru, Bhamaddi, Naulri and Libra,” said Raj Kapoor, an area resident.
