The family of another victim — 12-year-old Simran in Naulri Khurd area who was mauled to death by stray dogs — is living in fear. “We had heard about the Bahomajra incident wherein a boy was mauled to death, but never thought that our daughter, too, will meet the same fate,” said a shattered Utma Devi, mother of Simran.

“Since that day, we are living in fear, but we cannot shift from this place as we cannot afford rent. Now my husband Jugal and son Preetam, 14, maintain vigil and carry lathis to resist any such attack by stray dogs. My other two sons Rohan, 5, and Vijay, 4, and three daughters are too young to tackle such attacks,” Utma added.

“She was my only child who was getting educated and we had many dreams for her. The government must do something about the problem so that no child falls prey to the menace,” she said.

While the family was talking to this correspondent, Preetam and his sister picked up sticks and ran after a stray dog, which was at a distance.

In the same village, 74-year-old Malkeet Singh said the incident has caused panic and anxiety not only in the village, but also in the neighbouring areas.

“I have two grandsons, Gurjot and Dharamvir Singh, who study in Class V. After this incident, we don’t allow them to go out alone. Fear has gripped the area, especially families that have small children,” said Malkeet.

In neighbouring Badi Naulri village, 65-year-old Kewal Singh said the problem is severe in their village too.

“In our village, there are at least 50 stray dogs who have become a threat to small children. After the recent incident, there is fear in the area,” shared Kewal, a shopkeeper.

Villagers in other areas said the stray dog problem has become alarming in many villages of Jagraon, Samrala, Machhiwara, Doraha, Khanna and Payal.

Close shave

At Akhara village in Jagraon, 11-year-old Veerpal Singh shared his story of how he was almost killed by stray dogs. Following the incident, his sister and younger brother accompany him on most occasions when he goes out.

“I was dragged by stray dogs to old carcass ground. They then started feeding on my head. Hearing my cries, a villager who was passing through the area, alerted other villagers and they rescued me,” said Veerpal, showing injury marks on the left side of his head.

A villager said as the boy belonged to a poor family, villagers chipped in with funds for his treatment. The boy was lucky to survive the incident.

7,619 dog bite cases

RTI activist Rohit Sabbarwal said data obtained under RTI revealed that 7,619 dog bite cases were reported at civil hospital between January 1, 2018, and March 31, 2019. He said the number also included cases within the MC limits. Civil hospitals in Jagraon, Khanna, Samrala, Raikot too must be getting dog bite cases, he added.

Sterilization process lacks pace

Additional deputy commissioner Iqbal Singh said in city, the municipal corporation has been entrusted to address the issue, while the administration is making efforts in villages. He said sterilization of stray dogs is being carried out and villagers, too, should get stray dogs sterilized to check the problem.

However, the district administration officials admitted that the process of sterilization lacks pace. In a day, only 3-4 dogs could be sterilized and they are kept under observation for two to three days. They said besides, the government has constituted a committee to find out a strategy to deal with the menace.

Title: No NOC, Rural Oly fails to take off
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ludhiana: Kila Raipur games could not kick off on Monday, with police denying permission to organise the event.

Visitors as well as participants were left disappointed as cops did not allow the event to take off over orgainsers’ failure to obtain a no-objection certificate (NOC). Similar reasons, along with internal tiff, had put off Rural Olympics the previous year too.

Kila Raipur Sports Society Patti Sohaviya, the committee in-charge of organising the event, claimed that the permission was not given due to political interference. The police, however, said the organisers had failed to complete the required formalities.

Ludhiana Sadar SHO Jagdev Singh said, “The organisers had not obtained NOC from the police department to conduct the sports festival. The event will not be allowed on Tuesday too if NOC is not obtained and all formalities met.”

Additional deputy commissioner Jaskiranjit Singh said, “Due to internal issues of Patti Sohaviya, we have denied them permission to hold the event.”

“With more than one panel staking claim to organise the event, there was apprehension of breach of peace, too,” said a cop.

Earlier, the organisers had announced that the two-day event would kick off at Kila Raipur Sports Stadium on Monday without any animal sports.

“Police are not giving us permission due to political interference. This has happened for the second time in a row. We have completed all the formalities and had applied for NOC about 22 days ago,” said Kila Raipur Sports Society Patti Sohaviya president Col Surinder Singh Grewal (retd).

Sources said, “As Kila Raipur Sports Stadium land is owned by three committees, they keep wrangling with each other. It is apprehended that if the event is organized, it may lead to law and order problem. The three committees are Kila Raipur Sports Society Patti Sohaviya, Kila Raipur Sports and Welfare Club Patti Sohaviya, and Grewal Sports Club Patti Sohaviya.”

Tarlochan Singh, a member of Kila Raipur Sports and Welfare Club, said, “We are making every effort to ensure the event is held.”

Title: Extortionist fires in air to threaten Jagraon man
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

TNN

Ludhiana: The police on Sunday registered a case against an extortionist who fired shots in the air to threaten a villager into paying up.

Amarvir Singh, 26, a resident of Jagraon’s Dholan, said in his police complaint, “On February 18, when I had gone to Jagraon for some work, I received a call around 8.15pm. The caller asked me to ‘go home to see a trailer before the complete movie’. When I reached home, my mother, Jagpal Kaur, said she heard cracker-like sound outside. Two days later, I got another call from a different number. The caller threatened me to pay up Rs 30 lakh. I then realised that those were not crackers but shots that were fired outside my house on the night of February 18.”

Sadar Jagraon ASI Gurdeep Singh said, “The complainant says five shots were fired outside his house. We are checking the footage of CCTVs installed in the area. We have sent the phone numbers from which he received the calls to cyber cell in Chandigarh. The numbers are apparently of foreign country, but can be used in India, too.”

Police said the complainant has land in the district and had recently got a house constructed in Dholan. “We have asked Amarvir to install CCTVs at his house. The family says they have no enmity with anyone.”

A case has been registered under Section 384 (punishment for extortion) of the Indian Penal Code and under the Arms Act.

Title: Storm water drain explodes in Alkapuri
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Accumulation of gas inside the drain is believed to have led to the burst on Monday

Vadodara: A major blast took place inside a storm water drainage line on the busy R C Dutt Road in Alkapuri area of the city on Monday evening. The blast, in which a grill of the drain blew up in the air, is believed to have been caused by accumulation of gas inside the channel.

However, no one was injured in the incident that took place near the Ivory Terrace building when the road was very busy. With several offices located in the area, people were either leaving office for home or had come for shopping.

The grills of the storm water drains in the area have been covered with big nylon bags to ensure that dust and mud cannot enter them.

Sources said that sewage had been released in the storm water drains leading to formation of gases, which got accumulated over a period of time and eventually reached a stage where it burst out. Gases started gushing out of other covers in the area too.

Officials of the Vadodara Gas Ltd also rushed to the spot. Their investigations revealed that the leakage was not of piped natural gas and the gas coming out of the storm water drain had a high quantity of carbon monoxide revealing that the gas could be from sewage.

In October too, a similar incident had taken place in the evening in the same stretch. The damage and the explosion at that time was, however, much louder and cracks had appeared on the road too.

Title: Man attacked outside Shiroda police outpost
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ponda: Soon after agreeing to resolve an ongoing dispute, Shiroda-resident Subhash Tari, 56, attacked his neighbour Manohar Shirodkar, 65, with an iron pipe in front of the Shiroda police outpost on Monday morning.

While Shirodkar has been admitted to Hospicio Hospital, Margao, in a critical condition, Tari has been arrested for attempt to murder.

Ponda PI Mohan Gaude said that the accused and victim were summoned to Shiroda police outpost to settle an ongoing dispute. They had agreed to bury the hatchet before a police head constable. As they were making their way to their parked vehicles, Tari removed the iron pipe from his two-wheeler and attacked Shirodkar.

“Shirodkar suffered multiple injuries to his head, back, and legs,” the police officer said.

The pipe was wrapped in paper, indicating that the accused had intentions of assault, police said. Police seized the weapon and an offence has been registered against the accused.

Title: Goa police rules to be notified to pave way for state manual
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: The state government is in the process of finalising the Goa police rules under the Police Act 1861 to pave the way for the Goa police manual. Until now, Goa police followed the Bombay police manual as it did not have one of its own.

A manual is aimed at regulating the functioning of the department, including investigation, punishment and appeal matters.

Since there are no police rules, the state has empowered the inspector general of police to take necessary decisions under the Police Act 1861 regarding maintaining records, deciding at what rank officers would be at police stations and how many.

A senior government officer said that the home department has received suggestions from the police on the rules and after incorporating them, the file would be moved for approval. “Once the minister clears the file, the home department will issue a notification. The entire process will take another 15 days to complete,” the officer said.

The officer said that until and unless there are Goa police rules, the state government cannot notify the Goa police manual for the functioning of the force.

The draft manual was ready in November 2018, but had not received government approval.

A convict had approached the high court to challenge the Goa police decision to reopen his historysheet and put him under surveillance, along with his photograph, fingerprints and other personal information. At the hearing, the court held that there was no law covering this aspect of police authority in Goa.

The high court said they had to accede to the request of the petitioner for grant of protection and directed that surveillance on the petitioner will cease.

Title: Asaduddin Owaisi: Delhi cops pelted stones during clashes: Asaduddin Owaisi at anti-CAA meet
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: Talking tough against Delhi cops , AIMIM president Asaduddin Owaisi made a serious charge that they were pelting stones along with protestors when pro- and anti-CAA clashes took a violent turn in Delhi on Monday.

“I want to bring to the notice of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah that police were pelting stones along with those who were resorting to violence,” said Owaisi while addressing an anti-CAA, NPR and NRC rally here.

“This ( Delhi violence ) is a shame for the entire country. But, I want to emphasise that one of your (BJP) party members at a public meeting had threatened the anti-CAA protesters with an ultimatum some time back,” said the Hyderabad MP.

He said the violence on a day when US President Donald Trump had landed in Delhi was shameful.

Without naming BJP leader (Kapil Mishra), Owaisi said: “I want to tell the Prime Minister that he is growing snakes which would bite him one day.” He condemned the deaths of a cop and a civilian in the incident.

Upping the ante, he urged Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to stop the exercise on NPR. “Passing a resolution against CAA is not enough. I urge the chief minister to stop NPR,” Owaisi said.

He also took pot-shots at state home minister Mahmood Ali. “Mahmood Ali saab, if you don’t believe me, take inputs from an advocate. NPR exercise is to collect data after which people will be branded ‘doubtful’ in NCR. You are home minister of Telanaga and not home minister of TRS,” the AIMIM chief thundered.

Maulana Husamuddin Sani alias Jaffar Pasha, speaking at the rally, also took potshots at Mahmood Ali and Hyderabad police commissioner Anjani Kumar.

“Is the home minister powerful or police commissioner powerful? The police commissioner who claimed himself to be secular suddenly said Shaheen Bagh-kind of protest will not be allowed in Hyderabad. What happened to him suddenly? Did Yogi (Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath) come in his dreams? Let us all send bouquets to him,” Jaffar said.

Title: Seven-year-old girl employed as domestic help tortured by Hyderabad couple, rescued
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

Title: Pak 'violates airspace', panic in J&K village
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

JAMMU: With heightened security along the international border due to US President Donald Trump ’s visit to India, there was panic in a village in Jammu & Kashmir ’s Ranbir Singh Pura assembly constituency on Monday over alleged violation of Indian airspace by a Pakistan Air Force aircraft.

A few hours before Trump’s arrival in India, villagers living along the international border in RS Pura allegedly saw — at around 11.45 am — a Pakistani aircraft flying in Indian airspace. “Panic gripped the border residents on seeing a Pakistan aircraft on the Indian side. The villagers immediately reported the matter to the police,” sources said, adding that the aircraft immediately returned to Pakistani airspace.

There is no official confirmation of the alleged airspace violation from the BSF.

Pakistani aircraft had violated Indian airspace in Rajouri district on February 27, 2019 and the Indian Air Force pushed the Pakistani jets back.

Title: Namaste Trump: Godhra blind girl enthrals Motera
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

14-year-old Happy Desai

VADODARA: She may not have seen Prime Minister Narendra Modi or US President Donald Trump or even the mammoth gathering for the ‘ Namaste Trump ’ event at Motera Stadium in Ahmedabad, but what she experienced at the mega event will be memories for life for this 14-year-old blind girl from Godhra.

Happy Desai sang the famous song ‘Teri laadki main’ with celebrated folk music icon Kirtidan Gadhavi on the stage at the Namaste Trump event ahead of the arrival of Modi and Trump at the stadium. Happy was roped in for the performance only on Saturday.

Happy, who is blind from birth, had started learning music as a five-year-old. She sang at a major event for the first time earlier this year at the Panchmahotsav in Pavagadh here she performed with Parthiv Gohil where she had rendered ‘Teri laadki main’.

Happy’s father Vinod Kumar said that he got a call in the early hours on Saturday asking him if his daughter would perform at Motera Stadium. “I agreed and at around 8.30am, I was asked to reach Ahmedabad by 3pm on Saturday itself,” said Vinod who is a teacher at a government primary school. He added that a rehearsal took place on the same day in the night.

The girl said that she did feel nervous while performing at the event.

“I could feel the crowd. I had never expected to sing at such an event. It seemed as if I was having a dream,” said Happy.

Seeing her interest in music, her father is planning to support her and encourage her.

“I wish she does a PhD in vocal music,” he said.

Title: Hyderabad: Techie hangs self in Gachibowli flat
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 24-year-old software engineer was found dead at his residence in Gachibowli on Monday.

The deceased was identified as Antiwar Chakraborty , a native of West Bengal.

Police said that Antiwar’s flatmates returned at around 7.30 pm and found his door locked from inside. They knocked on it several times, but there was no response. They panicked and immediately called the cops who rushed to the spot and broke open the door.

Antiwar’s body was found hanging from the ceiling. The cops said that search is on to ascertain whether he has left any suicide note.

A case has been registered under Section 174 (suspicious death) of Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) and investigation has been initiated.

Title: MBA in multiple streams, BBA at workplace new courses in the offing
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: With private universities and new institutes set to start operations in the state from the 2020-21 academic year, students can now enrol in new courses on construction management, design and rural management, among others.

“We will offer MBA in four streams and the Hyderabad campus will have 800 seats,” said a representative of National Institute of Construction Management and Research (NICMAR).

Students who want to do MBA in advanced construction management, project engineering management, health, safety, and environment management, as well as quantity surveying and contracts management from NICMAR’s Shamirpet campus will have to either appear for NCAT (NICMAR Common Entrance Test) or have valid CAT, MAT, XAT, JMET, ATMA, or GATE score. The two-year course will cost around Rs 13 lakh per annum. The institute claimed that it would also provide 100% placement assistance.

Similarly, officials of Mahatma Gandhi National Council of Rural Education (MGNCRE) said that they will offer a rural management course at the undergraduate level. “From across the country, we got about 50 applications from degree colleges to start BBA in rural management. In Telangana , too, we are targeting degree colleges that have BBA programmes to offer the course,” said MGNCRE chairman WG Prasanna Kumar.

Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU), in association with Maharashtra Knowledge Corporation Limited (MKCL), will offer ‘BBA at workplace’, which gives students an option to earn a degree and get an experience certificate in three years. “We will conduct entrance tests twice a year – January and June. Those selected will be given a list of companies to appear for interviews. Instead of going to college, students can do their BBA at the workplace. They will also get a salary of Rs 8, 000 to Rs 10, 000 per month,” said Nitin Shekhar, MKCL programme manager. The students have to pay Rs 20, 000 per annum.

Title: Swine Flu in Hyderabad: Telangana woman dies of swine flu three days after childbirth
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Three days after childbirth, a 38-year-old woman died of swine flu at Gandhi Hospital on Monday. This is the third case in the state this year with two deaths reported last month.

The woman, a native of Karimnagar district , was admitted at the hospital eight days ago and had tested positive for the H1N1 virus, said hospital authorities, adding that the newborn does not have any swine flu symptoms.

The number of swine flu cases are on the upswing since the beginning of the year. While it was 42 in December last year, the number shot up to 73 in January. As many as 114 cases were reported in the first 20 days of this month.

“Despite the increase, the numbers this year are less compared to the same period last year. The death on Monday morning is the first incident at Gandhi Hospital this year,” said Dr Shravan Kumar, superintendent of Gandhi Hospital.

The state health department had sent alerts anticipating a surge in cases in January and February, but is no longer expecting any more cases. “The numbers are expected to come down once the temperature increases by 4-5 degrees. This is end of the swine flu season,” said a senior health department official.

Title: Hydera​bad: Trainee constable ends life by jumping in front of train
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A trainee constable committed suicide by jumping in front of a moving train at Sanathnagar railway tracks on Sunday night .

The deceased, identified as Sai Ram (23), was undergoing training at the police training college in Karimnagar.

Railway staff spotted the body and informed the cops. They also found a suicide note where he wrote that he took the extreme step due to pressure at the training college. However, he did not blame anyone for his decision.

Title: Khambhat riots: 45 people arrested, four FIRs lodged
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Sunday clashes had also left four policemen injured in Akbarpura area

VADODARA/ ANAND: Anand police has rounded up around 45 persons in connection with Sunday’s communal riots that broke out in communally sensitive Akbarpura area of Khambhat town and later spread to other areas.

Four separate offences have been registered in connection with the clashes that had left around 13 persons, including four policemen, injured.

In all, 95 people have been named as accused along with a mob of 1,000 persons belonging to Muslim and Chunara communities. According to the offences registered at Khambhat city police station, while a group of 33 accused along with a mob damaged a masjid and a dargah near Akbarpura, another group of seven damaged a temple in Bhavsarwad locality.

Other 45 along with a mob have been booked for rioting in Bhoibari area while 10 others were booked for rioting in Lal Darwaja area of the town.

The accused belong to Harijanvas, Sakarpur, Jagnath Mahadev chawl, Limda sheri, Madarnagar, Jahangirpura, Kadival, Lal Mahel, Chipwad, Bandra Burj and Jumma Masjid localities.

The accused have been booked for, rioting, damage to public property, intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace, criminal intimidation, outraging religious sentiments, causing hurt by using acid, endangering life among other sections of the Indian Penal Code.

It is for the first time that separate offences have been registered by the cops in connection to such communal riots which the coastal town has witnessed quite frequently.

The offences however make no mention of the reason behind Sunday’s clash in which more than 30 houses and shops were set ablaze by the rioters who had vandalized dozen-odd vehicles too.

Police had to lob around 30 tear gas shells to bring the situation under control while one company of Rapid Action Force was also deployed in the town.

The FIR regarding the rioting at Akbarpura area states that the mob had shouted slogans threatening even the cops even as the rioters had continued heavy stone pelting while the cops were performing their duty.

The riots had initially broken out in Akbarpura at around 1.30 pm when groups belonging to different communities resorted to heavy stone pelting. But later it had spread to other areas of the town.

Title: Stipends for MBBS interns hang fire as MCI drags feet
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

In many private medical colleges , MBBS students doing internship are forced to work without stipends as the Board of Governors (BoG) of the Medical Council of India failed to act on an amendment to the rules proposed in January 2019 that would have made such stipends mandatory.

After the BoG took over in October 2018, it issued a public notice stating that the MCI was considering including a provision in the Regulations on Graduate Medical Education 1997 stating that all MBBS students pursuing compulsory rotating internship shall be paid stipend on par with that of interns in government medical colleges in the same state.

The BoG sought comments and suggestions from the public on this proposal. This was in response to complaints that had been pouring in over the years from various states regarding non-payment of stipends in private colleges. However, it went silent on the issue thereafter despite several reminders from the medical community and strikes by interns in many colleges.

Talking to TOI, BoG chairperson Dr Vinod Paul said that such an amendment was difficult when there was no provision for stipend in the Indian Medical Council Act. “We are also caught in a quandary because we know that, if we make stipend mandatory, the private colleges will just increase the fees and pay the stipend from the money collected as fees. So, it could lead to an even higher increase in fees,” said Dr Paul.

He added that the BoG’s tenure was coming to an end and this issue ought to be taken up by the National Medical Commission that is taking shape.

“There is no provision for stipend for postgraduate doctors in the IMC Act either and yet the regulations for PG medical education make it mandatory. Further, it was amended in 2008 to include diploma and super-specialty students. While only Parliament can amend the IMC Act, amending regulations is done regularly,” said Dr KV Babu, who has complained repeatedly to the MCI on this issue.

After the BoG took over in October 2018, it issued a public notice that MCI was considering including a provision in the Regulations on Graduate Medical Education 1997 stating that all MBBS students pursuing compulsory rotating internship shall be paid stipend on par with that of interns in government medical colleges in the same state

Title: PE & Punjabi: Easy and balanced, say classes X, XII students
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ludhiana: On Monday, there was physical education for Class XII and Punjabi exam for Class X. Students found both the exams easy.

Raghav Kakkar, a student of Class XII medical stream of the Peace Public School, who appeared at Sacred Heart Convent School, Sarabha Nagar said “My exam was good, but lengthy. I have studied everything beforehand and it was balanced. No question was difficult.”

Rishav Kumar, a student of Class XII (humanities) from New GMT Public School, Sant Vihar, Haibowal Kalan, who appeared at GGN Public School, near Rose Garden, said, “The exam went well. It was easy as it was asked directly from the book referred. There was no question which was out of syllabus.”

Navjod Deep Kaur Sandhu, head, department of Punjabi at DAV School, said, “Punjabi paper was balanced and few of students said it was easy and they are satisfied with the exam. Last year, poetry section was really tough, almost on par with college-level Punjabi. But this time, it was easy.”

Title: PU will consider all skill-based vocational subjects for BCom
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ludhiana: In a huge initiative likely to transform the trajectory of higher education, Panjab University (PU) will consider all skill-based vocational subjects for bachelors in commerce (BCom).

Skill-based vocational subjects like financial market management offered by Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) will now be considered by various undergraduate courses like BCom and BBA offered by the affiliated colleges of PU.

Dr Ashwani Bhalla, who is part of PU council, said the decision has been taken and will be issued by the PU during admissions. Dr Ajay Sharma, principal, Sri Aurobindo College of Commerce and Management confirmed that the PU has “updated and incorporated necessary changes in the admission criteria of UG programmes”.

Bhupinder Singh, head, department of financial management at BCM Arya Model Senior Secondary School, Shastri Nagar, said. “This will boost the morale of students who opt for skill-based subject at senior secondary level. For the promotion of skill education in schools under National Skill Qualification Framework and to make the options more convenient for the students, CBSE has updated syllabus of existing skill-based courses and introduced more courses in the academic year 2018-19 after taking inputs from industries and academic organisations. For instance, financial market management merge two fields — capital market operations and derivatives market operations, which is a joint effort of CBSE and National Stock Exchange.”

BOX

Sri Aurobindo College will offer MCom

Shri Aurobindo College of Commerce and Management (will offer MCom, two-year full-time degree, from this year. Dr Sharma, principal, who joined only a week before, said, “We are planning to ofer 40 seats initially. Our commerce programmes are well received in the industry and for years had been serving the needs of managerial cadre in business and industry. Now, MCom will serve the needs of academics as well and will prepare students for research and teaching in business studies.”

Title: Road rage: One held for HR executive’s murder
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: One person was arrested on Monday for his involvement in the murder of a human resource executive a day before at Kaladarshan crossroads on Waghodiya road.

Suraj Kahar, a resident of Kishanwadi , was nabbed as police found ownership details of the car in which the six accused had fled. Kahar and five others had beaten up Keval Jadav (31) following heated arguments over overtaking their car. Jadav had left his house at Gayatrikrupa Society on New VIP Road around 5.15pm on Sunday to meet his friends.

Police said the five other accused are also residents of Kishanwadi and a team has been formed to find them. “We have booked all of them for murder, assault and rioting and efforts are on to nab the rest of the accused,” said a police official.

Meanwhile on Monday morning, Jadav’s family members refused to accept his mortal remains demanding that police arrest all the accused. However, later the body was accepted by them after postmortem.

Jadav is survived by his 28-year-old wife, who is four-month pregnant, a five-year-old son and widow mother. His father passed away 12 years ago. “We have lost the pillar of our family. It is difficult to imagine our lives without him. We just hope that we get proper justice,” said his mother Hansa Jadav.

Jadav was beaten up due to which he suffered internal injuries. After the accused fled from the spot, Jadav went to Panigate police station to lodge his complaint. But when Jadav complained of chest pain, he was taken by cops to Jamnabai Hospital which referred him to SSG Hospital. But he was declared dead before admission.

Title: Bhubaneswar: IG to probe BJD leader’s self-immolation
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

BJD woman leader Meenakshi Mishra

BHUBANESWAR: Director general of police Abhay on Monday assigned inspector general (IG) Rekha Lohani to probe the self-immolation by BJD woman leader Meenakshi Mishra on the Berhampur SP office premises recently.

Mishra had set herself on fire on February 12 protesting the alleged registration of a false case against her son Raja by Baidyanathpur police and his arrest on January 28. Mishra succumbed during treatment at a private hospital in Bhubaneswar on February 20. Mishra, 41, was a state executive member of BJD in Ganjam district . Though the BJD has been silent on her drastic step, the opposition BJP and Congress had hauled up the ruling party over Mishra’s death.

“I have ordered a high-level inquiry into Meenakshi Mishra’s death following her self-immolation attempt. IG (modernization) Rekha Lohani will conduct the probe. Lohani will find out the circumstances that led to Mishra’s death,” Abhay told TOI.

On February 12, Mishra visited the Berhampur SP’s office and wanted to meet SP Pinak Mishra. After failing to meet the SP, the woman BJD leader met another officer in the SP office and told him about the alleged registration of a false case of assault against her son. She also alleged that the police arrested her son in the false case. Police, however, rubbished her allegation and said Raja was arrested for allegedly assaulting some men during a group clash. “We also arrested five persons for attacking Raja,” another police officer said.

While returning from the SP office, she doused herself in kerosene and set herself ablaze on the office premises. Police sources said she had hidden the kerosene bottle in her bag before entering the SP office. Persons are frisked by policemen before entering SP’s chamber but no checking is conducted at a public office.

Police sources said Lohani’s investigation will focus on different aspects, including the role of Berhampur police. “She (Lohani) will investigate whether Mishra’s self-immolation could have been prevented. The IG will also probe whether or not the personnel, who were present in the Berhampur SP office, timely rescued Mishra,” an officer said.

Family members of Mishra refused to comment on the high-level probe ordered by the DGP. Mishra’s son Raja is currently on interim bail till February 25. A court in Berhampur had granted him interim bail on February 14.

Title: Our ties with Pakistan very good: Donald Trump
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

US President Donald Trump speaks during a "Namaste Trump," event at Sardar Patel Gujarat Stadium. (AP)

NEW DELHI: The loudest cheer for President Donald Trump went up when he spoke of US commitment to working with India to fight terrorists and their ideology and working to defend Indian and American citizens from radical Islamic terrorism .

While making an important point from the Indian view, Trump also said the US and Pakistan enjoyed a good relationship and added it was paying off. "Our relationship with Pakistan is a very good one. Thanks to these efforts, we are beginning to see signs of big progress with Pakistan and we are hopeful for reduced tensions, greater stability and the future of harmony for all of the nations of South Asia ,'' he said.

A part of his remarks was immediately highlighted by Pakistani media though he was quite unequivocal on Islamabad and terrorism, saying his office was working with Pakistan in a "very positive way" to crack down on terror organisations and militants that operate on the "Pakistani border''.

India would hope for an even clearer statement after official talks on Tuesday given its position that no substantive bilateral engagement can take place in view of cross-border terrorism - a stance it has has held after the Pathankot terror attack in January 2016. Trump's remarks may have a bearing on a peace deal with Taliban where Pakistani functionaries have underlined Islamabad's criticality.

Trump's remark on Pakistan also has to be seen in conjunction with comments made by a senior US administration official that the president was very much encouraging a reduction in tensions between India and Pakistan and also encouraging them to engage in bilateral dialogue to resolve differences.

While the official had said the "core foundation'' of any successful dialogue between India and Pakistan was based on continued momentum in Islamabad's efforts to crack down on terrorists on its territory, he had also said that Trump was going to urge both countries to maintain peace and stability along the Line of Control and refrain from actions or statements that could increase tensions in the region.

For India, though, the real test will be to extract an unequivocal condemnation of cross-border terrorism in the Trump-Modi joint statement on Tuesday, something which India successfully managed in their first summit in 2017. It won't be easy with the US desperate to go ahead with its emerging truce agreement with the Taliban, one in which Pakistan claims to have played a stellar role.

Title: Consumer group writes to consumer affairs ministry to reconsider complaints from allottees
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: Mumbai Grahak Panchayat, a state-based consumer group, has written to the consumer affairs ministry to reconsider complaints from allottees regarding residential properties.

The apex court recently dismissed a complaint on the ground that a body which has come into existence by the mandate of law cannot be treated as a voluntary consumer association under section 12 (1) (b) of the Consumer Protection Act (CPA), 1986, and, hence, a complaint filed under it is not maintainable.

The apex court had upheld the order of the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission in the original consumer complaint.

“The recent ruling on not recognising association of allottees and their demands relating to a developer is a setback for all pending cases in consumer courts,’’ pointed out Mumbai Grahak Panchayat chairman Shirish Deshpande in his letter to the consumer affairs minister Ram Vilas Paswan.

The group has requested the ministry to promulgate an ordinance to amend the relevant provisions in the CPA,1986, with retrospective effect and protect all the complaints pending in various consumer courts. “We have also urged similar amendment in the new Consumer Protection Act, 2019,” added Deshpande.

The group in its letter stated that as a result of the SC judgement, thousands of cases pending in consumer courts are liable to be dismissed. This will result in protecting unscrupulous builders who have wilfully delayed obtaining occupation certificates and avoided executing conveyance to the housing societies, the letter said.

Similarly, several such complaints filed by the cooperative housing societies registered under the state cooperative societies act will also be eventually dismissed as a consequence of this SC judgement, affecting individual homebuyers who cannot file complaint for seeking conveyance because the conveyance needs to be executed in favour of the society and not in favour of individual homebuyers, said the consumer group.

“The apex court judgement is thus bound to create chaotic conditions and wrongfully dent the legitimate locus of such housing societies. It may be true that the condominiums or the housing societies of the homebuyers may not be voluntary consumer associations in the strict sense. However, considering the fact that the Consumer Protection Act, 1986, was enacted with an intention to provide for better protection of interest of consumer and being a socially-beneficent legislation, as repeatedly held by the SC in several judgements in the past, such strict interpretation of law was uncalled for, unwarranted and unjustified,’’ added Deshpande in his letter to the ministry.

Title: Rise above politics to restore order: Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

NEW DELHI: Home minister Amit Shah held a meeting on Tuesday with Delhi lieutenant governor Anil Baijal, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and representatives of key political parties to take stock of the situation in wake of violence in north-east Delhi and said a professional assessment pointed to the violent protests being “spontaneous”.

At the meeting, also attended by BJP MP Manoj Tiwari, Congress representative Subhash Chopra, Delhi Police Commissioner Amulya Patnaik and senior home ministry officials, Shah suggested that the local peace committees comprising eminent citizens and elected representatives be reactivated and their meetings held to defuse the tension, quell rumours and ensure coordination with the Delhi Police.

Shah advised leaders of political parties in Delhi to exercise restraint and refrain from making any provocative speeches. He suggested that all should rise above politics to jointly work towards restoring peace and order.

Patnaik briefed the meeting on the violence witnessed on Monday in parts of Delhi as well as the current situation. Shah said professional assessment was that the violent protests were spontaneous. According to intelligence sources, the violence broke out during clashes between anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and pro-CAA groups in north-east Delhi, which is witnessing 8 of the 19 ongoing anti-CAA sit-in protests across the capital. The immediate trigger, it is believed, was the anti-CAA dharna that led to blocking of a road in Jafrabad.

A source said police personnel on the ground were heavily outnumbered by the clashing anti-CAA and pro-CAA groups, giving leeway to anti-social elements among the warring sides to indulge in stone-pelting, arson and even firing with illegal weapons. “The clashes took a communal colour. Police chose to act with restraint, mindful of the high casualties that any use of force in the densely populated ghettos would cause, and the subsequent ripple-effect this may have in other parts of the country witnessing anti-CAA protests,” said an officer. At least 13 people, including a head constable, have died and many others, including police personnel, injured.

Incidentally, the “spontaneous” assessment cited by Shah runs contrary to MoS (home) G Kishan Reddy’s claims — made to ANI on Monday and in a tweet the later — that the violent protests were a “conspiracy” to create chaos in Delhi and “show our country in poor light” at a time when US President Donald Trump was visiting.

A source told TOI there was no prior intelligence about a possible communal flare-up.

The meeting, chaired by Shah, was told that adequate police deployment in violence-prone areas was being ensured and reinforcements sent where required. Special officers would be deployed in the vulnerable areas. The roads were also being cleared.

Shah reassured the state government and political representatives of Delhi that the city police was doing its job, though while exercising restraint. He cautioned against unwarranted criticism of the Delhi Police saying it could negatively impact its morale and noted that it was adequately empowered to decide on the amount of force needed to defuse tension.

Speaking to reporters after the meeting, Kejriwal said all parties are concerned over the law and order disturbances in the capital. “We all want violence to stop. Nobody is benefiting from this violence,” he noted. Calling the meeting “very positive”, Kejriwal said everybody resolved to make all possible efforts to restore order and peace in Delhi.

Meanwhile, Shah has cancelled his visit to Kerala.

Title: First batch of Bowbazar evacuees returns home
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The Roys and the Deys of 13, Chaitan Sen Lane get ready to leave for their home from the hotel on Monday after... Read More

KOLKATA: Bowbazar resident Sunipa Roy heaved a sigh a relief as she walked into her rented rooms of 13 Chaitan Sen Lane along with her husband and son late on Monday afternoon. So did Sandhya Dey and her husband Tapan. The two families had to shift to a hotel after tunnel-borer Urvi resumed burrowing the East-West Metro tunnel last Tuesday.

TBM Urvi has bore past the area without any glitch being reported. KMRC, the implementing agency, had taken a whole lot of safety measures so that there was not a remote chance of a repeat of the tunnelling disaster, in which around 700 Bowbazar residents were evacuated after TBM Chundee punctured an aquifer, triggering large-scale subsidence.

On Monday, the Roys looked particularly relieved. They had to be evacuated twice — first, when TBM Chundee hit the aquifer, damaging their house at 10B Durga Pituri Lane beyond repair. They were shifted again last week from their rented home at 13 Chaitain Sen Lane as it fell on Urvi’s route. “Last time, we had to stay at this same hotel for three months. This time, thankfully, the stay last only for a week,” Sunipa told TOI on Monday evening.

In the second batch, around 50 residents were evacuated on Saturday from three buildings in a row at Chaitan Sen Lane. The TBM is believed have reached below the third structure. The occupants are due to return on Wednesday.

Title: Car rams into signboard, woman dies
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A woman died after the car she was travelling in rammed into a signboard on Dabhoi-Vadodara road on Sunday early morning.

Deceased Vidya Gadekar and her husband Mahesh, residents of Laxmipura had gone to Kuber Bhandari temple in Chanod on February 22 and were returning from Chanod at around 5 am in their car. At a sharp turn near Kisannagar bus stand, Mahesh lost control over the vehicle and the car went off the road to collide with a signboard.

Police said that the couple was grievously injured and was taken to a private hospital. Later they were referred to another private hospital on Waghodia road where the woman succumbed to her injuries. Mahesh fractured his left leg which had to undergo surgery, cops said. The couple had got married in 2015.

A case of rash driving and causing death due to negligence was registered at Varnama police station.

Title: Uruli Devachi, Phursungi residents stop trash trucks
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: The Uruli Devachi and Phursungi residents on Monday stopped garbage-laden vehicles from entering their villages, prompting the Pune Municipal Corporation officials claim that only “reject (from the trash) was transported there” and even that would be stopped in a couple of days.

Dnyaneshwar Molak, the head of the PMC’s solid waste management department, said, “The PMC has totally stopped garbage dumping at the depot. Only the rejected part from the garbage, which cannot be processed, was being taken to these villages. Its quantity is very small.”

The garbage rejects mostly contain plastic, dry waste or metal parts.

Vishal Harpale, a local resident, said, “We believe the civic administration is not following the court’s orders. They should not put even the reject at the dumping site. So, we prevented the entry of garbage vehicles.”

Some PMC officials claimed they had stopped dumping garbage at Uruli Devachi and Phursungi from January. Garbage was being dumped in the villages for the past 25 years.

According to the PMC officials, the processing of garbage at other areas of the city has been increased. It helped in reducing the dumping at the Uruli Phursungi depot. The capacity of the garbage processing plants at Hadapsar has been augmented.

Harpale said the residents of Uruli Devachi and Phursungi were unhappy with the PMC’s approach and had staged an agitation demanding ban on the entry of garbage vans. A group of residents from these villages formed a committee “Uruli Devachi Kachara Depot Hatao Sangharsha Samiti”. A group of residents claimed a criminal offence should be filed against those dumping garbage at the depot. A meeting to find a solution to this issue is being planned on Tuesday. The PMC officials, residents and police officers will attend the meeting at the depot.

The civic administration’s data states nearly 2,100 tonnes of garbage is generated in the city per day. Nearly 600 tonnes of it was dumped in these villages till December 2019.

Title: Rural police to procure boats to crack the whip on sand mafia
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: The Pune rural police will table a proposal to procure boats to crack the whip on sand mafia operating in the Bhima river basin in the district.

“These mafia use modified fibre boats to take the sand out during the daytime. Whenever the police or revenue officials conduct a drive, they escape via the river route and reach the adjacent Ahmednagar district. We are unable to arrest them as we do not have boats. So, we have decided to procure at least 10 boats to patrol the river and carry out drives against illegal sand mining in the district. We will table our proposal before the district administration in a meeting soon,” Sandeep Patil, superintendent of police, told TOI.

Past investigations have revealed that the boats used by the sand mafia were procured from Gujarat-based firms, a police officer said. The rural police have an anti-sand mafia squad in its Baramati division. “Sand extraction mainly occurs in the Daund and Baramati tehsils. This squad, along with revenue officials, had carried out drives in the last three months and seized sand worth Rs10 crore. But we need to intensify action to curb the menace,” Patil said.

The Bhima river originates in Khed tehsil, flows through Shirur and Daund tehsils before merging with the backwaters of Ujani dam in Indapur tehsil. “The river basin is wide in Daund tehsil, where these sand mafia have established a strong network at the village-level. They have sources in the revenue and police departments and shift their inventories to safe places before the police takes action,” a senior revenue department official said.

The rural police have even invoked the stringent Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act against seven sand mafia in the last two years. “Three proposals given for invoking the Maharashtra Prevention of Dangerous Activities Act against sand mine operators are pending with the district administration,” Patil said.

Title: Chennai man jumps to death holding girl
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Thirupathi Reddy and his daughter Harika

CHENNAI: A 35-year-old man who was being treated for psychiatric problems for a couple of months leaped off his second floor flat at Madhavaram holding his four-year-old daughter on Sunday afternoon, police said. Both died instantly.

Police, who identified the deceased as Thirupathi Reddy and T Harika, said the incident happened in full public view at 2pm at the four-storey apartment complex in Ponniamman Medu, Madhavaram. Witnesses told police that they saw Thirupathi Reddy climb the parapet in the balcony of the apartment holding his daughter and jumped down before they could realise what was happening and respond. The witnesses saw the two lying in a pool of blood and rushed them to a private hospital at Villivakkam where doctors declared that they had been brought dead. A Madhavaram police team then shifted the bodies to Government Stanley Medical College and Hospital for postmortem.

A case was registered under CrPC Section 174 (unnatural death). The bodies were handed over to the family on Monday.

An investigation officer said no suicide note was found on the dead man’s person. Preliminary inquiries revealed that Thirupathi Reddy, a cashier at a garlic godown at Parry’s who had been ailing for the past several months and was being treated at a private hospital, often skipped work and stayed at home. He is survived by his wife Sunitha, a homemaker, and five-year-old son Harish.

Title: Hyderabad firms involved in Telangana ESI fraud named in Andhra Pradesh too
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Investigation by vigilance and enforcement (V&E) sleuths of Andhra Pradesh has found that Hyderabad-based companies and their directors involved in the ESI fraud in Telangana had a role in a similar fraud perpetrated in their state too.Hyderabad-based Legend Enterprises and Omni Medi, involved in the ESI fraud in Hyderabad, have been accused of irregularities in Andhra Pradesh too.Vigilance probe in Andhra Pradesh found that lab kits worth Rs 237 crore were purchased from Legend Enterprises and Omni Medi in violation of rules on nomination basis. Insurance Medical Services (IMS) had purchased lab kits at 36 per cent excess prices than in the open market and caused Rs 85 crore loss to the government exchequer.Based on orders of minister K Achannaidu, IMS had paid the TeleHealth Services Private Limited of Hyderabad Rs 4.1 crore for the toll-free service and Rs 3.8 crore for ECG service on nomination basis. The company was paid Rs 480 per ECG whereas in other hospitals it was offered at Rs 200 per ECG.The vigilance report, a copy of which is available with TOI, stated: “The service provider claimed the bill by submitting call logs of Telangana state IPs, and the directors paid the amount without verifying the genuineness of the call logs. The service provider utilised the services of PG Diploma clinical cardiologists instead of qualified DM cardiologists by violating agreement conditions and claimed the bills.”The Vigilance officials found that three directors — Dr B Ravi Kumar, Dr CK Ramesh Kumar and G Vijaya Kumar of IMS — had in the past three years purchased Rs 975 crore worth drugs and equipment by violating rules. It was found that they had failed to form drug procurement committee and issued purchase orders without calling for open tenders.In one of the transactions, Dr B Ravi Kumar, the then director, had purchased lab equipment from Legend Enterprises worth Rs 2.5 crore on nomination basis without calling for open tenders. One Jalam Environment Private Limited of Hyderabad was given Rs 3.45 crore maintenance contract without property agreements.Prodigy Computers & Laptops, Hyderabad, had supplied 100 biometric devices on nomination basis, and they were found to be “not in working condition”.Another firm, Jercon Enterprises of Bhavanipuram in Vijayawada, owned by daughter-in-law of Central Drug Store pharmacist K Dhana Lakshmi, was issued purchase order worth over Rs 9 crore.The vigilance sleuths randomly verified purchase invoices. It was found that non-rate contract firms Raasi Pharma and Veeresh Pharma were given orders worth Rs 16 crore. According to the report, there was a difference of Rs 5.7 crore between the purchase invoice and sale invoice of Raasi and Veeresh Pharma.

Title: 3 buried alive in mudslide at Sirpur Paper Mill
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Hyderabad: Three labourers died and five others were injured when a mound of earth fell on them while they were constructing pillars at a construction site on the premises of Sirpur Paper Mill in Kumram Bheem-Asifabad district on Saturday night.

The incident happened at around 11pm on Saturday when 12 labourers were constructing the pillars for a boiler at the unit, police said.

The deceased have been identified as 38-year-old Raghunath Ram and 25-year-old C Bahniya from Jharkhand and 30-year-old Ranjith from Lucknow. The injured persons have been identified as M Rani Das, Santosh Ram, Parikhan Ram, Ram Praneeth and Sanjay Ram.

The injured were shifted to a hospital in Mancherial for treatment.

After being alerted by other construction workers present at the mishap spot, the police rushed to the spot and began rescue operations with the help of an earth mover. It took more than three hours to recover the bodies of the deceased, which were buried under the mud.

“A boiler was being constructed at the site and for that purpose pits that were around 15 feet deep and quite wide were made. The workers were erecting the pillars when the mud fell on them,” said officials from the fire department.

Police said that a company had given the project to a civil contractor and a case was registered under Section 304 a (negligence causing death) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
