Title: Outreach programmes to address concerns about NPR drive
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: Officials in all the states have been advised to hold outreach and awareness campaigns about the Census and the National Population Register drive because people’s misgivings about them could hurt the population enumeration exercise.

The authorities believe widespread awareness drives would help address concerns of people about the NPR (National Population Register) data gathering process, prompting them to cooperate with enumerators when they visit homes.

An official in the know of things said, “For sensing the kind of questions that enumerators may face during house visits, the Census officials will have to establish contact with local representatives. An outreach programme has been proposed to ensure that people’s doubts are resolved before the information gathering work begins.”

The house-listing phase of the Census and updating of the NPR in the country would be rolled out simultaneously by mid-April and continue till September. Over 2.5 lakh enumerators would handle the massive exercise in Maharashtra. Senior government officials associated with the Census said once the notification was issued, awareness programmes would be conducted.

The Census authorities in Karnataka recently requested deputy commissioners in the districts to hold outreach and awareness campaigns about the NPR, as they fear misgivings about the exercise could hurt the forthcoming enumeration of population.

Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray has appointed a panel to look into the problems that might arise during the NPR drive.

The general administration department and the home ministry handle the Census operations. Several district officials are said to have raised concerns about the possibility of people refusing to share information when the work on the Census and NPR begins. This would affect the quality of the Census work, they stressed.

There is a fear that many people may decline to share personal information with the officials visiting households in connection with government programmes suspecting them of gathering data for the yet-to-be unveiled National Register of Citizens (NRC), following the enactment of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

The district authorities have been told to train and sensitise enumerators to tread carefully while gathering information. Enumerators will be told not to demand information by force. For instance, if a person does not know his exact date or place of birth, the enumerator may engage in a conversation with the person that may elicit some anecdotes and roughly establish the year and the place of birth. This is part of the Census manual,” a Census official said.

Another challenge before the officials would be to convince people that the Census/NPR data would remain safe because the information would be gathered and stored digitally.

Title: February salary to be delayed, cash-strapped V-B informs staff
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Santiniketan: Visva-Bharati has informed its employees that their February salary may be delayed “due to paucity of funds”. A formal notice signed by the acting registrar was issued on Monday.

“We had requisitioned for fund (to UGC) in time. This is not only about Visva-Bharati, but several universities are facing the same situation. Our VC is in Delhi and is in constant touch with UGC and MHRD to expedite the disbursement of funds,” VB PRO Anirban Sarkar said. According to university sources, around Rs 22 crore is required for the monthly salary and pension of employees and as on Monday, Rs 7 crore has been disbursed by UGC to VB for this purpose.

According to sources, UGC has been repeatedly flagging its “objections” on excess payment to certain Visva-Bharati employees. UGC, first in October 2019 and again in November 2019, had asked the university to recover this excess payment paid over the last decade. The November reminder by UGC had a three-week deadline. In December, Visva-Bharati issued orders and started to dock excess payments to certain employees. This, however, has hit a legal roadblock with three teachers moving court.

Title: Ahmedabad: Flyers at SVPI experience some Trump traffic turbulence
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Cars headed to the airport queue up at Sardar Chowk

AHMEDABAD: The VVIP visit posed some expected inconvenience for many passengers travelling out of the city airport on Monday. While most flights operated as per schedule, passengers faced troubles finding cabs or reaching the airport due to road closure.

“Our flight to Goa was scheduled around 1pm but we reached the airport before 8am. We were not allowed inside the terminal building and had to wait outside,” said Bhavesh Shah, a Satellite resident.

Road closure also led to several passengers getting stranded en route to the airport. Especially after 10.30am, there was utter chaos at Sardar Patel Chowk.

“We got stuck in traffic for about an hour. I had to request the cops to let our car go as the flight would be delayed otherwise. After due verification, cops allowed the car to pass through the barricaded road,” said Ashok Panchal, a cab driver who was ferrying a pilot of a private airline.

A Mumbai-bound passenger, Richa Taneja, barely made it to catch her flight. “Thankfully, some senior cops communicated to the police to verify air tickets and allow passengers to move towards the airport,” she said.

Ankur Patel, a flyer said, “I have to reach Mumbai by the 2.20pm flight and have a connecting international flight from there. There is no chance I can afford to miss this flight otherwise, my journey will be jeopardised.”

Many passengers who arrived at the airport also struggled to find cabs. “I’ve come here for a vendor meeting and need to reach in time but I’ve only been waiting to find a cab,” said Gaurav Sharma, who flew from Delhi.

“I doubt if I will make it to the court hearing in the morning because my flight landed at 9am and till 10am, I was only struggling to get out of the airport,” said Alpesh Purohit, an advocate.

Similar was the case of Rajesh Raman, who is in Ahmedabad, with his wife and daughter for a wedding. “Our flight landed late by 30 minutes. We didn’t find any cabs because of the road closure.”

During the afternoon, the roads to the airport were briefly closed again, due to which a number of passengers ended up waiting in a traffic jam. “I am going to Delhi to take an international flight. Thankfully, I had kept enough time margin for reporting to the airport but somehow it didn’t work,” said Chandrika Patel, who was stuck in traffic near Dafnala junction around 3pm.

Title: CBSE exams held smoothly
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) exams of class X and XII were conducted smoothly amidst all security arrangements made for the visit of US President Donald Trump on Monday.

A large area was cordoned off due to security reasons for the US president’s visit. This area included four schools — Podar International School, Rachana School, KV Shahibaug and KV Cantonment. Around 400 regular and 17 private students sat for their exams in these four centres. Class X students appeared for Gujarati paper, while class XII students had physical education exam.

All students reported early to their respective exam centres and were provided breakfast. They left the exam centres immediately after exams. The biggest challenge was for students who were appearing for exam at KV Cantonment, but this was sorted out by the CBSE. They took permission from army cantonment to use internal roads. Kapil Shah, a class X student said, “The smart move by the board ensured that we left immediately after the exam.” Talking to TOI, Mrugen Shah, said, “CBSE chairwoman Anita Karwal’s telephonic talk with the police commissioner to ensure that students are not stopped on their way to exam centres helped all students in reaching their exam centres on time.”

Title: Activists decry riverbed dumping near Sangamwadi
Content: Pune: Environmentalists have called for urgent steps to check dumping of debris on the riverbed near Sangamwadi .They have demanded that the riverbeds be restored to their natural state.The environmentalists said that the local residents have observed outsiders dumping debris on the riverbed and added that the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) needed to vigilant to stop such activities. The civic officials said that they have decided to carry out a drive this week.“Dumping takes place behind the SSPMS college, around Sangamwadi areas. The flood level of Mula and Mutha river may rise due to the dumping of debris. The Naik island’s biodiversity will be destroyed,” Sarang Yadwadkar, an environmentalist, told reporters.He said that the flora and fauna at Naik island and the nearby areas were getting adversely affected due to the dumping. The National Green Tribunal (NGT) had given directives that no dumping should take place on the riverbed. Even then such activities go on unchecked. The source of the dumps should be found out and the responsibility fixed. PMC commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad said that he along with a delegation of environmentalists had visited the spot. “The officials concerned has been directed to take action. They will chalk out a plan and act accordingly,” he said.Raj Nikam, a local resident and landowner, said that the dumping was going on for years. “The local citizens have supported the PMC on infrastructure development work in these areas. We have given our land for the projects a decade ago. Blaming us for the dumping is wrong,” he said.Nikam added that they have lodged complaints with the PMC. The environmentalists have also demanded CCTV surveillance in these areas, but their demands have not been met. Madhav Jagtap, head of the PMC’s anti-encroachment department, said that the staff members had gone to the spot, but faced opposition from the locals.“The next course of action will be taken with the help of police. More manpower and equipment will be provided to the team,” he said.In Video: Activists decry riverbed dumping near Sangamwadi

Title: AIT’s cybersecurity lab unveiled, to foster interest in research among students
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: Engineering students at the Army Institute of Technology (AIT), Dighi, can look forward to actively engage in research on the latest trends in cybersecurity, besides working on industrial projects, at the institute’s newly developed laboratory.

Southern Army Commander Lt Gen CP Mohanty on Monday inaugurated the Information Security and Digital Forensic Laboratory on the occasion of the 26th foundation day of the AIT.

The institute has hired a private data security firm for training students. “The laboratory aims at fostering interest among students about cybersecurity and preparing them for the job opportunities in this fast-emerging field,” Sunil Dhore, head of AIT’s computer engineering department, said.

Over 70 students from across the engineering streams have enrolled their names for the co-curricular activity, which will be run by industrial experts on the campus. “Topics like ethical hacking, cybersecurity, cyber forensics cannot be taught officially in the college. But through this activity, the students can develop expertise in niche fields of security domain,” AIT director Brig Abhay Bhat (retired) said.

A one classroom-sized facility can accommodate about 20 students at a time. “Our plan is to prepare them for future challenges. We have a pool of listed firms who can give their projects to us. Secondly, our students can go through their internal security system and find out loopholes and provide apt solutions,” Dhore said.

On the institute’s future plans, Brig Bhat said they were moving towards transforming the AIT into a ‘Centre of Excellence’ in cybersecurity. “Our aim is to start certificate, basic and advance courses,” Bhat said.

Lt Gen Mohanty also presented the successful entrepreneur award to Hanumant Gaikwad, chairman and managing director of Bharat Vikas Group (BVG), and young entrepreneur award to Ravi Kumar, cofounder of ‘udChalo’, an air ticketing portal for defence persons.

Title: Petrol dealers to sell green fuel soon in Maharashtra
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: Petrol dealers in the state, including those in the city, would soon start selling compressed biogas (CBG) to boost its usage, oil marketing companies stated on Monday.

CBG, produced naturally through anaerobic decomposition from waste or biomass sources, is an environment-friendly alternative to compressed natural gas (CNG) used in vehicles. Sources from oil marketing firms stated that they were inviting applications from entrepreneurs to set up CBG plants.

“The government had envisaged setting up 5,000 CBG plants across the country by 2023. In line with that plan, the Centre has roped in oil marketing companies to market the green fuel produced by the interested parties. Once an entrepreneur gets his CBG plant commissioned and starts the production, we would allot the nearest petrol pump for its dispensation,” an oil marketing company official told TOI.

The official said CBG would be sold to customers for Rs55.25 per kg, close to the CNG price of Rs55.5 per kg in the city.

All India Petrol Dealers Association (AIPDA) president Ajay Bansal said they had so far received nearly 79 applications for setting up of CBG plants in Maharashtra. “The government has plans to provide heavy subsidies for such set-ups,” he said.

Bansal said since Maharashtra had many sugar factories, press mud from the factories could be used for manufacturing CBG. “The ministry of petroleum and natural gas has issued 500 letters of intent to the interested parties across the country,” Bansal said.

“In a recent executive committee member meeting with Indian Oil Corporation, further modalities of this project were discussed,” AIPDA spokesperson and petrol dealer Ali Daruwalla said.

Title: US first family gets a euphoric welcome
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Us President Donald Trump greets PM Narendra Modi as he arrives at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International airp... Read More

AHMEDABAD: It was a momentous occasion at the Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport on Monday morning as the flying fortress – the Air Force One – touched down at around 11.35am. The visit of the US president, Donald Trump, is the first for an American president to visit Ahmedabad. As the US president, along with the US first lady, Melania Trump , descended from the airport, Prime Minister, Narendra Modi welcomed him with a warm hug, while professional dancers performed the Hudo dance – a well-known folk dance of Gujarat .

The Indian Air Force, Navy and Army — all three defence wings accorded a tri-service guard of honour to the US president at the airport. The guard of honour was commanded by Major Subhash of Maratha Light Infantry.

Soon after, as the US presidential motorcade, including the luxurious ‘Beast’ – a specially configured limousine, passed the city roads, cheers went up from the crowds outside the airport and waiting on the route all the way till Sabarmati Ashram . Some 28 stages were set up by the civic authorities along the road where troupes performed folk dances.

Title: Indo-Bangla car rally to mark Mujibur Rehman birthday
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

KOLKATA: A convoy of cars will rally from Kolkata to several places in Bangladesh for a week, starting this weekend, to celebrate the centenary of Bangabandhu Mujibur Rehman, the first Prime Minister of Bangladesh. This is also being touted as the first-ever motor rally between Kolkata and Dhaka and has been christened ‘Moitree’.

Starting from Kolkata, the rally, which is being organised by the Automobile Association of Eastern India (AAEI), will touch Dhaka, Cox’s Bazar, Chittagong, Mymensingh, Rangpur before re-entering West Bengal through Siliguri. More than 30 cars have already signed up for the rally. The registrations will remain open till February 28, when the rally will be officially announced from the precincts of the Calcutta Club. Almost all the heritage clubs of the city have joined hands with the AAEI in the initiative.

On the Bangladesh side, the deputy high commission here, Dhaka Bank and Dhaka Club are partnering the initiative. Elaborate cultural exchanges have been planned at every place where the rally will stop. “This should have happened long back. We are part of the same cultural skein and still it took us so long to plan this. But better late than never,” said Kaushik Roy, veteran rallyist who has driven across 32 countries already and will lead the rally.

For some participants, it would be a nostalgic trip to the country that their parents belonged to. Take the case of former banker Iman Bhattacharya and his wife Meghmala, who trace back their ancestry to different parts of Bangladesh. “Though I have driven across India and to other countries as well, it is quite another thing to drive to Bangladesh. No boundary can divide the heart, can it? We hope that after this debut rally between the city and Bangladesh becomes a popular route for rallyists,” Bhattacharya said.

The rallyists will also carry the message of Sunderbans conservation with them. Special posters have been designed for this and many interactions between rallyists and conservation experts in Bangladesh have been organised. “Sunderbans is common to both West Bengal and Bangladesh and we will see if some collaborative projects can be drawn up,” said Milan Mukherjee, senior lawyer and chairperson of AAEI.

Title: Cong’s urban plight prog to counter TRS’s devpt prog
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Hyderabad: The Congress has come out with ‘patnam gosa’ (urban plight) programme to counter TRS government’s pattana pragathi (urban development) programme. Both the programmes will start from Monday.

Telangana Congress working president A Revanth Reddy will launch the programme from Malkajgiri Lok Sabha constituency. “This is an effort to bring to the notice of the TRS government the problems being faced by the people in urban areas. With an eye on GHMC polls, the state government is trying to paint a rosy picture with pattana pragathi programme . Whenever KCR launches any programme, it is connected with upcoming election,” Revanth said on Sunday.

Revanth charged the state government of not completing the 2-BHK project and diverting Central funds given for housing sector. “There are 10 lakh families in Greater Hyderabad alone who are waiting for 2-BHK units, and another 30 lakh in Telangana. KCR had promised to complete 2-BHK houses in a year or else they would not seek votes,” he said.

Releasing a copy of the answer given in Telangana State Legislative Council about Central government sanctioning houses under Indira Awas Yojana (IAY) and Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY), Revanth said 65,149 houses were sanctioned under IAY in 2014-15 and 56,748 in 2015-16. “IAY was discontinued and the Centre launched PMAY-rural and urban in 2016-17. The funds allotted for housing under IAY and PMAY have been diverted by the TRS government,” he alleged.

He also questioned Union minister of state for home G Kishan Reddy’s silence even after PMAY funds have been diverted by TRS government. “Kishan Reddy should raise the issue in the Parliament or else it can be assumed that TRS-BJP are two sides of a coin.

Revanth further slammed Kishan Reddy for his comment that the people of Telangana were not aware of trains till recent years and it was only after Narendra Modi became the Prime Minister that new trains were introduced. “There were railway stations in Telangana even before Narendra Modi was born. Kishan Reddy should verify facts before speaking,” Revanth said.

Title: Big research institutes expect max footfall on Science Day this Friday
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: Research centres in the city will open their facilities to citizens on the occasion of ‘Science Day’ on Friday.

Science Day is celebrated to commemorate the discovery of the ‘Raman effect’ by physicist CV Raman.

Agharkar Research Institute will host an open house with an exhibition for the audience. Visitors will be informed of fossils, medicinal plants, diatoms, lichens, fungi, zebra fish, hydra, drosophila, bioenergy, nanotechnology and bioprospecting.

Inter-University Centre for Astronomy & Astrophysics (Iucaa) will host an open day for the public on Friday and Saturday from 10am to 5pm. Public science talks will also be held in the evenings till 7pm.

The National Centre for Cell Science will organize an open day on Friday from 10am to 5pm. Visitors will get a chance to see animal cells, bacteria, fungi, fruit flies and also learn about the various scientific processes such as Flow Cytometry, Bioimaging tools, Proteomics tools, among others.

Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (GMRT) in Khodad will host a two-day event on Friday and Saturday. GMRT, operated by the National Centre for Radio Astrophysics, is a part of the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai. “There will be special state transport buses from Shivajinagar to Narayangaon and shuttle bus services from Narayangaon to GMRT facility,” JS Solanki from GMRT said.

Solanki said all GMRT systems will be put on display. “There will be a stall where about 200 selected schools will showcase their science projects. Science is about ease of doing things and we have selected projects that will make living easier in one way or the other. There will be a separate stall ‘ask an astronaut’, where students will be able to talk to various astronauts and get their doubts cleared,” Solanki said.

Title: Gangrape of girl: Boy, 16, held, hunt on for 2
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Krishnagiri: The Krishnagiri town all-women police on Monday arrested a 16-year-old boy who, along with two others, had gangraped a Class XI girl near Veppanhahalli on February 22.

A search is on for the other two accused.

P Karpagam, inspector (in-charge) of Krishnagiri town all-women police, said that on the morning of February 22, the girl was chatting with her boyfriend, who is also her classmate, near a bus stop.

V Raja, 26, of Jodukothur and his friend C Manju alias Manjunath, 22, of Thimmasandram, joined them and offered her a soft drink. After consuming it the girl fell unconscious.

The trio took her to a hideout, raped her and left the spot.

After she regained consciousness, the girl realised that she had been gangraped and managed to reach home. She informed her parents about the incident and they lodged a complaint with the Krishnagiri town all-women police.

“We have registered a case . We have medical records confirming gangrape . The accused had mixed coconut toddy with the soft drink which they gave the girl,” the inspector said.

The boy has been arrested under the Pocso Act. “We have launched a search for Raja and Manju,” she added.

The boy was produced before the judicial magistrate of Krishnagiri district court and later lodged in the borstal cell in the city the same evening.

Title: Ravi Pujari Latest News: Gangster Ravi Pujari lived in 5 nations, donned 4 identities in 26 years
Content:
Gangster Ravi Pujari (white cap) was nabbed in South Africa in a joint operation by the SA police and Senegal ... Read More

BENGALURU: On the run for nearly three decades, fugitive gangster Ravi Pujari fled the country in 1994, and is suspected to have lived in at least five countries under at least four names, Karnataka police said.“Pujari was first involved in many heinous cases in Mumbai. Police had identified him as a staunch associate of gangster Chhota Rajan. In 1994, he flew to Nepal and then to Bangkok,” said additional director general of police (ADGP) Amar Kumar Pandey.Investigations revealed between 1994 and 1998, Pujari operated from Nepal. “By the end of 1999 or early 2000, he was forced to leave the country after learning that police had tracked him down. He flew to Bangkok, where he lived till 2003. Pujari had invested huge money in the casino business and financed dance bars. In no time, local mafia gangsters developed differences with him. Knowing Bangkok was no more safe for him, Pujari flew to Sudan by mid-2003,” police officer said.In Sudan, Pujari invested in the garment business. Initially, he earned small profits but later started losing money and shifted to Burkina Faso. Meanwhile, Pujari continued his alleged underworld activities like extortion and murder.“Film personalities, Bollywood actors in particular, well-known builders in metro cities, popular industrialists and businessmen were his main targets. He laid his hands on politicians too. He would make threat calls to them,” police said, adding: “In Burkina Faso, he purchased a garment factory and invested in hotels. In mid 2015, he moved to Senegal.”In Senegal, Pujari opened Maharaja Indian restaurant. He hired Indian cooks and soon the restaurant became popular for its Indian food.Pujari is suspected to have operated under four names, police said. “Ravi Prakash Pujari was his name at birth. His underworld guru, Chhota Rajan christened him Antony Fernandes. Pujari later called himself Tony Fernandes and lived under the name in Nepal, Bangkok and Sudan.“After entering Burkina Faso, he called himself Rocky Fernandes and obtained another passport under the name in that nation,” police said.However, Pujari’s luck ran out when Senegal police, based on inputs provided by their Karnataka counterparts, arrested him on January 19, 2019. He was lodged in Senegal jail and was handed over to Karnataka police on February 20. “Pujari filed a petition claiming there was a security threat to him in India and his health condition was poor. But the Senegalese court considered his criminal history and activities and extradited him,” Pandey said.

Title: This Bengaluru boy can recall every detail about elevators at 5k sites
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Aaryan Sachin Kashyap

BENGALURU: Aaryan Sachin Kashyap, 12, is not just any other sixth grader. With an exceptional photographic memory , he can not only remember specifics about elevators — if they are service or passenger — from over 5,000 sites that he’s visited, but can also recall all the details within five seconds.

Aaryan’s love for elevators began when he was two and a half years’ old. His father, Sachin Ramesh Shimoga, a lead information architect in a city-based firm, told TOI the boy would stand near elevators for hours and still not get bored. “Initially, we thought like any other child, he likes going up and down elevators, but only when he started recalling specifications of lifts he’d seen long ago in some other building did I realise it’s something special,” Shimoga said.

He said they found out about Aaryan’s photographic memory through Chhota Bheem books, for which he holds a Limca World Record. “We got him 95 volumes of the books with 35 pages each. At the age of two and a half, he wouldn’t read but glance through the pages full of excitement,” Shimoga said.

One incident left the elders awestruck. “I showed Aaryan a picture from one of those books and asked him which volume it was from. He recalled the volume correctly in a second. I wanted to be sure so I picked random pages. Even then, he was correct,” said the father.

After getting a certificate and clearance from his then school, Indus International School, Aaryan’s family was able to get him a place in the Limca Book of World Records.

Four years after that, Shimoga and his wife Smitha Sachin started supporting Aaryan in his love for elevators. They documented all the lifts he had identified and recalled. They are from across the globe — Bengaluru (654) Chennai

(67), Coimbatore (37), Germany (1), Mysuru (66) and Singapore (260), among others.

In August 2019, the family shifted to Mysuru, where Aaryan is now studying at Pramati Hillview Academy School. To test Aaryan’s memory, all one needs to do is ask him about elevators. For instance, if asked about lifts at Forum Mall, Koramangala, Bengaluru, he will respond in jiffy: “Otis, 3 passenger elevators, goes from -1 to 4; Otis, 3 service elevators, goes from -1 to 4.”

It’s not just details of elevators Aaryan can remember. “He can recall the vehicle registration codes of all Indian cities within seconds and has lately started showing interest in cookery videos,” Shimoga said, adding that his son looks up all the information he needs online to get the details.

“From building plans to RTO websites and even YouTube videos, Aaryan always knows where to find what,” Shimoga said. The boy chipped in: “In two years, I will start cooking.” He, however, wants to be an elevator engineer. “I also love sports, especially swimming,” said Aaryan.

Title: How Karnataka cops ended fugitive gangster Ravi Pujari’s 26-year run
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Gangster Ravi Pujari (in white cap) at Bengaluru airport

BENGALURU: The long chase for a phantom-like figure has finally ended, additional director general of police Amar Kumar Pandey said on Monday with a sense of pride as well as relief, hours after bringing fugitive gangster Ravi Pujari back to Karnataka.

After all, Karnataka police have in their custody a man who’s an accused in 97 cases of murder, attempt to murder and extortion across the state, including 46 in Bengaluru alone, over the past 26 years. But for long, police had no clue where Pujari was. All they had was an old photograph that they photoshopped to know what he would look like in future.

In 2017 and early 2018, there was a spike in the number of cases where threat calls were made in Pujari’s name to extort money from businessmen and others. Some of these calls achieved their objective too.

Among those who received the calls was MP DK Suresh (August 2017). Incidentally, Interpol had issued a red corner notice against Pujari on March 8, 2017 in the Shabnam Developers double murder case of 2007. However, in the Interpol notice, it was suspected that Pujari was in Canada, Australia or New Zealand, where the threat calls had originated.

In 2018, then chief minister HD Kumaraswamy issued an ultimatum to state police — arrest him and get him here, never mind which corner of the world he is holed up in. The responsibility was assigned to Amar Kumar Pandey, who was intelligence ADGP at the time. While cases before Central Crime Branch (CCB) had already piled up, cops collected details about Pujari’s movements. Within days, they got to know he was living as a successful businessman and philanthropist in Senegal.

Between June and December 2018, the team worked hard to collect details and was able to get one crucial video of Pujari dancing during Navaratri festivities at Maharaja Hotel in Senegal’s capital Dakar. The video proved a breakthrough. Inquiries revealed Pujari was living by the name of Rocky Fernandes alias Antony Fernandez.

A police informer based out of Mangaluru and living in Dubai sent cops a set of photos showing Pujari watching a cricket match with a few others. In one of the pictures, a man was seen wearing a white shirt bearing the words ‘Indian Senegal Cricket Club’ and it was confirmed that Pujari was in Senegal. Police officers sought help from locals and found the photo was of Antony Fernandez.

In the third week of December, Karnataka police through diplomatic channels alerted the Senegal government about Pujari and after checking the veracity of the information, Senegal police arrested him on January 19, 2019 when he had gone to get his hair coloured at a salon. Since then, he tried everything under the law to get released but to no avail.

Title: Third suspect held in shoe shop owner murder case
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: The third suspect in the kidnapping and murder of Laxmi Road shoe shop owner Chandan Krupadas Shewani was arrested early on Monday morning from a spot near Swargate.

The city crime branch identified him as Ajinkya Hanumant Dhumal (21), a resident of Saswad. Acting on a tip-off about his movement at Swargate, a team headed by assistant commissioner of police (crime) Shivaji Pawar and inspector Mahendra Jagtap rushed to the spot and took Dhumal into custody.

The investigators have not been able to establish the motive behind the murder of Shewani even after Dhumal’s arrest. “The main suspects who plotted the crime are still at large and the arrested trio were fringe players, hired for assistance at nominal payout,” Jagtap told TOI.

Shewani (48) was on way back to home from his shop in his car on the night of January 4 when a group of men intercepted his vehicle near Maldhakka Chowk and kidnapped him. His body with a couple of bullet wounds was found near Lonand in Satara district the next day. The Satara police found a note, purportedly written by the assailants, near Shewani’s body stating that he did not give them Rs2 crore and hence, they had to eliminate him.

The city police arrested Afridi Rauf Khan (23) of Nana Peth on January 7 and Sunil Gaikwad (25) of Katraj on January 10 for their alleged role in the kidnapping and murder of Shewani. Both, Khan and Gaikwad, are since lodged in the Yerawada central jail under magisterial custody.

Inspector Jagtap said, “Prima facie, the investigators are continuing to work on the extortion angle although they have not come across any evidence of extortion calls made to the victim’s family members. The suspects may have demanded a large sum of money from Shewani while he was being taken to Padegaon from the kidnap spot. The victim may have refused to fulfil their demand, which prompted the assailants to kill him.”

Jagtap said, “Shewani had no rivalry with anyone.”

Regarding Dhumal’s role, Jagtap cited the investigation and said, “Dhumal kept an eye on Shewani’s movement on the day of the crime and was in touch with the prime suspects, who plotted the kidnapping and murder. Dhumal followed Shewani on his two-wheeler and kept updating the suspects using his cellphone.”

As soon as Shewani reached Maldhakka Chowk, Dhumal and the other suspects, travelling in a car, intercepted Shewani’s vehicle and forced him into their car before speeding away, police said.

Title: Eye on US elections, Gujarati diaspora wooed
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Bhupendra Patel, a septuagenarian NRG, was seen near the Sabarmati Ashram ahead of the visit of PM Modi and US... Read More

AHMEDABAD: US President Donald Trump’s bonhomie with Gujarat-origin Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi was palpable on Monday. In his speech, Trump said that the 4 million strong Indian diaspora has contributed immensely to the development of the US. He also acknowledged the Gujarati diaspora by saying that one in four NRIs has roots in Gujarat.

NRGs in particular and NRIs in general are known to lean towards Democrats. But Trump’s stance on India and his support for the country in the global arena might swing the votes in his favour, believe a few diaspora members.

However, NRGs who were part of ‘Namaste Trump’ on Monday, saw the event as a reciprocation of the love which was on display during the ‘Howdy Modi’ programme last year in Texas. “I am sure the ‘Namaste Trump’ event will leave a deep impression on the US president who has called himself a friend of India and Indians,” said Haribhai Patel, a resident of Chicago and the vice-president of Republican Hindu Coalition.

Patel said that 50-odd NRGs had come on their own to the event as there was no official contingent of NRIs with Trump on his two-day India visit.

Title: done Bikers again at risk now on wet Shivajinagar underpass
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: After the Swargate grade separator, the vehicle underpass at Netaji Subhashchandra Bose Chowk has become a risky spot after it developed water seepage. Motorcyclists are not able to use the extreme left lane because of the collected water.

Though the quantum of water accumulated on the carriageway of Shivajinagar facility is much less, the volume of traffic is regular users say that it still poses a challenge to motorists as chances of vehicles skidding cannot be ruled out because of the gradient and has to be repaired at the earliest.

Hundreds of vehicles coming via University Road use this grade separator to go towards Civil Court and Pune station. The grade separator, which handles one-way traffic, was constructed to eliminate vehicles halting at the chowk.

Autorickshaw driver Kiran Paidgude said the water seepage is near the extreme left lane. “The quantity of water that gushes out varies every day. On some days, the entire lane gets wet because of excessive seepage. A wet road is always risky and may cause hardships to motorists. It will damage the road surface,” Paidgude added.

Since the flow of traffic in the grade separator is unidirectional, vehicles travel at high speed. Sunil Hegde, who often uses the the underpass to go towards Pune station, said two-wheeler riders often face difficulties while controlling the speed of their bikes and balance when they suddenly get into the wet patch of the carriageway.

“When one is travelling at speed, changing the lane becomes difficult. If not repaired, the problem may lead to serious accidents. The civic body should repair and maintain the facility at regular intervals to avoid such leaks,” Hegde said.

Regular travellers have complained about the loosened lid of the drainage lane which moves when a vehicle passes over it.

The authorities in PMC said they will inspect the entire patch and chalk out a plan to plug the seepage. “We will check the origin of the seepage and why water is on the road though there is a stormwater channel,” civic officials said.

Even when the underpass was being constructed, it ran into several delays-from removal of water lines to uprooting of trees and even the court’s permission.

Permissions from the water supply department to shift the old water lines and place the new ones took time and felling of trees needed the court’s permission.

Four arterial roads --University Road and Wellesley Road going towards the district court and Jangli Maharaj Road and Sancheti Bridge Road that join Boat Club Road and the Pune Regional Transport Office near Sangam bridge—converge here.

Title: Ravi Pujari extradition: There were failures, but we persisted, says Karnataka IPS officer
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

IPS officer Amar Kumar Pandey shows the passport of gangster Ravi Pujari

Title: Airport director says cargo export short of expectation
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: International cargo exports from the city airport had not been impressive and far short of expectation, said airport director Kuldeep Singh on Monday, citing non-availability of land for shifting the current cargo complex as one of the major hindrances.

“We have 10 international flights per week. If we take optimum load of 2 tonnes per flight, our monthly international cargo handling should be in the range of 70 to 100 tonnes. We are far short of that figure. The constraints are the weather during summer, and the runway length,” he said.

Currently, the airport handles around 20-30 tonnes of international cargo per month, said officials. As the international cargo mostly comprises perishable goods, it poses a problem during summer as the airport does not have a cold storage facility. Though there has been some improvement in figures as per the data of the Airports Authority of India (AAI), constraints related to land availability and runway length are major roadblocks, he said.

Close to 260 tonnes of international cargo were handled by Pune airport in 2019 compared to 68 tonnes in 2018. “The present cargo complex will have to be demolished to pave way for the new terminal building. I am sure our operations will record a huge surge once we get a new cargo complex,” he said.

SpiceJet operates a daily flight from Pune to Dubai and Air India Express operates a flight on the same route three days a week.

“The present cargo complex is not up to the mark and has major space and storage issues. There were talks of it being shifted to an Indian Air Force (IAF) plot, but nothing happened. Moreover, the complex will have to shift from its current location as the new building will come up,” a source at the airport told TOI.

Anant Sardeshmukh, former director general of the Mahratta Chamber of Commerce, Industries and Agriculture, told TOI that exporters would come to Pune if the facilities were good. “A trader who has a setup in Mumbai will not consider switching to Pune unless he or she is convinced that the city has got proper infrastructure,” he said.

Title: Pune: Parking fine without sign on FC Road stuns citizens
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The traffic police had banned parking of any vehicle outside popular restaurants in the city, including Hotel ... Read More

PUNE: Road users and regular visitors to Hotel Vaishali on Fergusson College Road are crying foul after being penalized by the traffic branch of the Pune police for parking their vehicles in a bay right outside the restaurant.

The traffic police had banned parking of any vehicle outside popular restaurants in the city, including Hotel Vaishali, following the German Bakery blast in 2010.

The stretch of the road initially had a wide footpath with two no-parking signs and a no-stopping sign.

However, as part of smart footpaths, the Pune Municipal Corporation has constructed a bay, which resembles parking bays on the rest of the road, creating confusion among citizens.

According to Gaurav Shah, an urban designer and a regular visitor, the traffic police have been taking action against vehicles found halting or parked in the bay.

“There is no board outside the hotel which says that the bay is a no-parking zone. There is one board with a cross on it which only says no stopping. All similar bays along FC Road are being used for parking and it is obvious that people will park outside Hotel Vaishali as well. If the parking restrictions have not been lifted, what is the need for such a bay?” he said.

Sayali Jadhav, another regular visitor to the area, said, “My friend’s vehicle was parked outside Hotel Vaishali and she was fined. Even when the old footpath had not been broken and there were no parking boards, many four-wheelers could be seen parked outside the restaurant. Now, a bay has been created and the traffic police are taking action. There is no board or sign saying that the area is a no-parking zone. Instead of taking action, the department should inform people that it is a no-parking zone. This should be done till proper sign boards are installed. Once these are installed, they can take action against anyone flouting the rules.”

On the construction of the bay, executive engineer from PMC’s road department, Dinkar Gojare, said, “After the German Bakery blast, the Pune police had notified the areas outside some restaurants in Koregaon Park and Hotel Vaishali and Hotel Roopali on FC Road as no-parking zones. I had coordinated with the traffic police to know whether they want to have parking space as once the construction for the new footpath is done, it cannot be rolled back. I had initially designed a kerb outside Hotel Vaishali. However, together we decided to provide a bay which could be used as a drop-off location thus keeping the carriageway free.”

Police sub-inspector of Deccan traffic division Ramesh Bhote said the bay has been constructed to ensure that the carriageway does not get blocked by vehicles dropping off passengers.

“We have been taking action against vehicles parked here but we only request drivers of vehicles that have halted to move away. Action against vehicles that have halted is taken only if the driver engages in arguments or fights instead of moving away. We have requested the PMC to install no-parking sign boards at the spot to prevent confusion. The sign boards should be installed in two days,” Bhote added.

Title: Panel to draft rules for setting up skill varsities
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: The department of skill development and entrepreneurship has set up a committee to assess the process of setting up skill-development universities in the state.

The seven-member committee headed by commissioner of the department would look into how such universities could impart holistic skill education to the students, a government resolution issued in this regard stated. The panel would have representatives from the state higher education department, law and judiciary department, and experts from the academic field, among others.

“The committee will make draft rules to set up financed and self-financed skill universities. It will also provide a framework for providing approval and recognition in terms of certificates, diplomas and degrees for the courses in these institutes. Universities could send their proposal for deemed status to the University Grants Commission,” joint secretary of the department of skill development and entrepreneurship and a member of the panel, Suvarna Kharat, said.

Title: Pune: Four youths in cop net for stealing 25 two-wheelers
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The four youths used duplicate keys to steal the vehicles

PUNE: Four youths, including a criminal on record and a professional dancer, had stolen 25 two-wheelers and kept them at secluded places to look for prospective customers but they ran out of luck when a patrol team from the Hadapsar police zeroed in on them on Sunday evening.

The arrested persons are Sanjay Bhosale alias Sonya (20) from Osmanabad, Hrishikesh Babasaheb Dongre alias Bittu (19) and professional dancer Abhishek Anil Bhadange alias Monu (19) from Latur, and Ajit Kailash Kamble alias Vitthal (21) from Hadapsar. Bhosale is a criminal on police records.

The foursome was checking expensive vehicles in a parking lot at Magarpatta Chowk suspiciously on Sunday evening when the police team led by assistant inspector Sanjay Chavan, under assistant commissioner of police Kalyanrao Vidhate (Hadapsar division) and senior inspector Ramesh Sathe, also the Hadapsar police station in-charge, arrested them.

Deputy commissioner of police (Zone V) Suhas Bawache said, “We have seized 25 bikes and scooters from the youths. They used duplicate keys for stealing the two-wheelers parked for a long time at parking lots. Investigations revealed that the youths also broke some vehicles’ locks and pulled the ignition wire for starting them.”

He said, “The suspects are close friends. They are not well educated. They came together and stole vehicles for making fast bucks.”

Assistant inspector Sanjay Chavan said, “Of the 25 two-wheelers seized from the youths concealed at Manjri and Hadapsar areas, we have identified the owners of 22. The process of tracing the three other bike owners is in progress. Investigations have revealed that the vehicles were stolen from Pune city and Pune rural areas in 2019-20. The youths will remain in police custody till February 26 because we suspect their involvement in a few more cases.”

The policemen responsible for the action include Pratap Gaikwad, Nitin Munde, Vinod Shivle, Akbar Shaikh and Shahid Shaikh.

Title: Pune: Seven wrestlers among 8 booked on assault charge
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Dispute over selling vegetables near a housing society at Dattanagar in Ambegaon Pathar took a violent turn on Sunday night after seven wrestlers and a vegetable vendor entered the society and assaulted two people, besides, ransacking a shop.The Bharati Vidyapeeth police have booked the vegetable vendor and his seven wrestler aides for assaulting the residents of the Amrut City society in Dattanagar. One of the residents, Subhash Vishnu Shinde (64), who also operates a shop in the society has lodged an FIR in the case.The society has a few shops facing the road and has an entry for residents from one of the side alleys. “After beating up the residents, the vegetable vendor and the wrestlers fled the spot. We are looking for them. Our teams have visited many ‘Kushti Talims’ (wrestling facilities) to trace them,” inspector Vishnu Tamhane said.Complainant Shinde told TOI, “I sell vegetables, milk and other small articles from my shop on the society premises, where outsiders are not allowed to set up shops. However, over the last few days, a man started selling vegetables on the society premises by parking his three-wheeler tempo.”After Shinde raised an objection to the activity, other society members joined him too and requested the tempo driver to move away from the society premises. “This resulted in arguments between the vendor and the society members on Sunday evening, following which he left the spot,” he said.Inspector Tamhane said the assault took place around 10.15pm. “The vegetable vendor and his seven aides, who were armed with sharp weapons and sticks, entered the society premises and started hurling abuses randomly at the residents. They can called out Shinde, after which the society residents, including Shinde, came out of their flats.”The police said after spotting the local residents, the wrestlers charged at them and beat up one of them. Hearing their cries, a man from the adjoining society, Prakash Mahadu Marne, attempted to intervene. “But one of the wrestlers hit him hard. Marne’s arm was fractured in the incident. After issuing warning to the local residents, the vendor and the wrestlers fled the spot,” the police added.

Title: Pune: 20-year-old torches five bikes of mechanic’s customers
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 20-year-old youth was arrested on Sunday on the charge of setting five two-wheelers parked in front of a mechanic’s shop on fire in Pimple Nilakh.

The incident occurred in the early hours of Sunday. A 36-year-old man Raju Telangi, a mechanic, has lodged an FIR with the Sangvi police. The vehicles that were damaged in the fire were owned by Telangi’s customers.

Sub-inspector Yashwant Salunkhe of the Sangvi police told TOI that the incident was a fallout of old dispute between the youth and Telangi.

“Telangi and the youngster had entered into a brawl over some petty issue a few days ago. In a fit of rage, the suspect poured petrol on the five two-wheelers that were parked in front of Telangi’s shop before setting them on fire,” the officer said.

Salunkhe said while lodging the complaint, Telangi had suspected the involvement of the youngster. “When we brought the youth in for questioning, he admitted to his involvement in the incident. Though further investigation is still under way,” he said.

The youth was produced before the court and released on bail, Salunkhe said.

Title: Maharashtra: RTE applications exceed intake before February 28 deadline
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The deadline for parents to fill applications for admissions for their wards under 25% quota of Right to Education Act (RTE) will end in four days, but the number of applications has already exceeded the intake capacity.For over 1.15 lakh seats in Maharashtra , there are 1.81 lakh applications. In Pune district, the applications have reached a record high of over 42,000 this year for the 17,000 available seats.The online admission system is being run in some districts including Pune, Mumbai and Nashik. Students from economically and socially backward backgrounds are allowed admissions to private, unaided schools under the provisions of the act. As many as 9,328 schools across Maharashtra are eligible under the RTE Act to admit them.In charge of RTE admissions in state and joint director of education, Dinkar Temkar, said initially, the admissions were very slow, but since the past few days it has picked up and the applications have exceeded the intake.“The admitted students will be able to start school from the new academic year in June,” he added.A separate portal for admissions under RTE has been created by the education department and parents had begun applying since February 12. The last date of application is February 29.Temkar said there were some changes in the admission process this year. “Only one round of allotments will be conducted instead of the several rounds that were held till the last applicant got admission in schools. This year onwards, we will be creating a waiting list of those who will be admitted against unconfirmed admissions,” Temkar said.After document scrutiny and verification, the lottery will be announced by March and admission confirmation will end by May-end, he added.

Title: Bicholim dairy farmers renew demand to solve their issues
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Bicholim: Dairy farmers from Bicholim have demanded that authorities from Goa Dairy hold a monthly meeting to discuss grievances of farmers.

Speaking at a press conference in Bicholim, president of Shri Bhumika Dairy Farmers’ Association , Sal, Adinath Parab said that 49 farmers from the taluka have submitted a memorandum to the authorities to meet regularly to discuss farmers' problems; like the increase in fodder cost by Rs 4 and other issues that he said had resulted in farmers and dairy societies facing losses.

Parab said that despite repeated requests, Goa Dairy is not ready to roll back the raise in fodder cost. He also said that after a protest by farmers, chief minister Pramod Sawant had promised to reduce the price of fodder cost, but no action has been initiated.

“Once again, we are requesting the chief minister to personally look into the matter on a priority basis and solve the grievances of dairy farmers,” said Vaibhav Parab, a dairy farmer from Amthane in Bicholim.

Title: Asia Economic Dialogue to focus on Asia’s rise as an economic powerhouse
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pune: The city will play host to the three-day Asia Economic Dialogue beginning February 28, which will see decision-makers and influencers contemplate on the global trade rules and Asia’s role in the same.

The Asia Economic Dialogue (AED) is one of the three main national dialogues organised/supported by the ministry of external affairs. It focuses on India and Asia’s rise as an economic powerhouse and also the region’s aspirations to get a proportionate share in leading world forums.

“The global economic landscape has changed dramatically. Over 60% of the world’s GDP is coming from Asia, but the global trading system dates back to the 19th or 20th century, and is dominated by OECD (Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development) thinking,” said Raghunath Mashelkar, the president of Pune International Centre (PIC), which is organising the event.

The AED hopes to use the dialogue to also tell the India narrative, which is reflective of its position as the world’s fifth largest economy.

On hosting the AED in Pune, Mashelkar said, “Davos-like dialogues have been generally focused in Delhi. So we thought, why not Pune? Because this city is an educational and cultural hub, the ministry of external affairs and the PIC have come together to create the AED.”

The sessions will focus on World Trade Organisation reforms, global value chain, agriculture trade and tariffs, greater participation of developing countries, financial innovations from Asia and Africa, among other important topics.

“Some of these discussions will bring many key stakeholders together in shaping deliberations that will eventually lead to a futuristic governance architecture on international trade,” Prashant Girbane, director, PIC, said.

The organisers are looking to position the AED as one of the main conferences in Asia to look out for.

“This is a geo-economics conference and the theme this year is “Asia and the Emerging International Trading System“. Ministers from the Maldives and Sri Lanka, besides businesspersons from all over Asia and the world will attend it. This will become an annual event, which we hope to develop as an Asian Davos,” Gautam Bambawale, AED convenor and former Indian Ambassador to Bhutan, Pakistan & China, said.

Title: Security guard puts out fire
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: An alert security guard at River Residency in Chikhali doused a fire that broke out in a flat before the fire brigade arrived on Monday morning.

Fireman Rushikant Chipade said the fire was spotted in a closed flat belonging to Renita Gurundapalli on the first floor of a building in Jadhavwadi area of Chikhali around 11.36am.

A short circuit inside the flat gutted a television set and the adjacent furniture. The firemen from Chikhali sub-office of the fire briagde rushed to the spot and found that the security guard had used the fire hose and averted a mishap.

The fixed fire installation in a high rise was put to use.

Title: Gated communities warm up to waste recycling
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Trichy: Gated communities in the city are gradually adapting independent solid waste recycling within their compounds as a section of gated communities here are producing manure from the waste to use in gardens and for trees.

The most recent to join the list of zero-waste apartments is Rohini Nakshatra apartment in Sangliyandapuram. With 62 housing units, the apartment generates around 12-15 kg of biodegradable waste, mostly food and kitchen waste per day, coming under Ariyamangalam zone.

Based on suggestion from the civic body, the builder installed a couple of green bins at a cost of Rs 1.5 lakh with a capacity of 850kg, that can decompose biodegradable waste into manure. “Maids will collect the waste from houses and shred the degradable waste before dumping them into the green bin. Microbe powder will be sprayed to quicken the decomposition process,” said L M Raj, in-charge of Rohini Nakshatra apartment.

The gated community is processing 12 kg of biodegradable waste each day, while the corporation collects the recyclable non-biodegradable waste such as plastic from the residents.

The bins can decompose the waste without emitting a foul odour. After one of the green bin is filled, support staff will fill the waste in another green bin. In the meantime, the bin completely dumped with waste will produce manure within 45 days.

“The gated community is using the manure for growing garden. If required, we will also help them find buyers for the surplus manure generated. More such apartments will be encouraged to follow suit,” said S Karthikeyan, sanitary officer of Ariyamangalam zone. Similarly, the number of apartments recycling their own waste has increased in Srirangam zone. Officials said that apartments treated as bulk waste generator will have to achieve self-sufficiency in managing their waste.

SELF SUFFICIENCY IN WASTE MANAGEMENT:

Options available:

1) Green bin: Rs4,000 to Rs2 lakh

2) Automatic composter: Rs2 lakh to Rs20 lakh

3) Biogas plant: Rs10,000 to Rs2 lakh

Total apartment buildings/gated communities: 400-450
