Title: LPG cylinder explodes, house gutted
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Valpoi: An LPG cylinder exploded at the home of an elderly woman at Dhamshe ,Sattari taluka, late Monday evening. No casualties were reported.

A loss of around Rs 1 lakh has been estimated due to the explosion, that took place at the home of Satyawati Deoli, who lives alone.

Satyawati escaped unhurt as she was visiting her neighbour at the time of the blast . Though personnel from the Valpoi fore station tried to douse the fire, a major part of the house , including the roof, was gutted .

Title: Two girls run away from their homes, traced within 2 hours
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nashik: Two friends, both girls aged 16, left their homes in the Indiranagar area on Sunday evening over domestic reasons, but were traced within the next couple of hours. They were counselled and handed back to their parents.

Senior inspector Nilesh Mainkar of the Indiranagar police station said, “The parents came to the police station at around 5.30 pm stating that their daughters had left their homes over domestic reasons. The girls had also left a note behind to their parents saying they were leaving.”

Taking serious cognizance of the matter, the police prepared a team to trace the teenage girls.

They also alerted the Nashik Road police station, the railway police at Igatpuri and Kasara stations to keep a vigil on trains arriving at these key junctions.

Mainkar said they got a tip-off from one of their informers regarding spotting girls matching the description at Kalika temple area of Nashik. “At around 7.30pm, we had found the girls. They were then counselled and handed over to their parents,” said Mainkar.

The entire operation of tracing the girls and handing them back safely to their parents was conducted under the guidance of police commissioner Vishwas Nangare-Patil, deputy police commissioner Vijay Kharat and other senior officials of the city.

Title: Tirupur: Burglars strike gold at SBI branch in second attempt
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

TIRUPUR: Burglars broke into the State Bank of India’s branch on the Palladam – Tirupur Road to decamp with cash and jewellery worth several lakhs, just three months after a failed attempt.

The heist came to light on Monday morning when the staff of the branch, at Kallipalayam, returned after the holiday weekend. They informed senior bank officials, who informed police .

The news was kept under wraps till afternoon to prevent a public scare. But rumours began spreading by afternoon and depositors gathered at the branch in the evening. Police officers pacified them and ensured that the burglars would be arrested soon, and the stolen items would be recovered.

Bank authorities have not ascertained the quantum of money and jewellery stolen, a police officer said. “The burglars had drilled holes and forced open some safety lockers. In that process, locks of other lockers got jammed. So, a technical team from the bank’s Coimbatore office will arrive to open those lockers. Only then the exact value of cash and gold can be calculated,” a police officer said.

A special team has been formed to nab the gang, said superintendent of police Disha Mittal, who inspected the spot.

Police believe the incident could have happened on Sunday night. The miscreants had smashed the glass windows and bent the window grill to enter the building.

The incident has brought to light the lack of safety features at the bank branch. It lacks security guards for night duty and burglar alarms, despite the earlier bid to loot it last October. “The burglars also took away a CCTV camera installed in front of the branch,” the officer added.

Title: Kanaka’s rendition of 55 songs steals the show, wins hearts
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: The Scientific Society Hall in Laxmi Nagar turned musical on Sunday as ‘ Sur Aur Noor 2’ paid tuneful tributes to Bollywood’s 57 divas through 55 songs that touched the souls and captured the hearts of the audience .

Though Kanak Sur Mandir set the stage for the grand show, the spotlight was however on Kanaka Gadkari who regaled the gathering with her mesmerizing voice on all the 55 counts.

The audience was taken on a Bollywood journey which began with songs picturised on the majestic Madhubala and ended with the amazing Alia Bhatt.

With a display of various genres like semi-classical, devotional, patriotic and much more, Kanaka was a picture of versatility at its very best.

Anchor Shweta Shelgaonkar made the entertainment wholesome by adding a heady dash which included a brief introduction coupled with anecdotes of every star before every song.

‘Aaiye meherbaan’, in remembrance of Madhubala, left the audience spellbound. Mumtaz, the epitome of beauty, was brought alive with the song ‘Bindiya chamkegi’.

Ravishing Rekha’s ‘Piya baawri’ gave a classy account of the timeless beauty. ‘Pyar karne wale pyar karte hain’, picturised on another diva, Parveen Babi, was another tribute by Kanaka.

The other popular songs which left the audience glued to their seats included ‘Panchhi banoo udti phiru’, ‘Barsat mein’, ‘Jaa jaa bewafa’, ‘Gore gore baanke chore’, ‘Tadbeer se bigdi hui taqdeer bana le’, ‘Tora mann darpan kehlaye’, ‘Yeh zindagi usi ki’ and ‘Ghadi ghadi mora’.

‘Yeh ishq haaye baithe bithaye’, filmed on the scintillating Kareena Kapoor Khan and ‘Pinga’, picturised on damsels Deepika Padukone and Priyanka Chopra, amazed the audience.

Kanaka sounded melodious with ‘Saawar lun’, picturised on the starry Sonakshi Sinha.

While ‘Ae qatan’ saw the flow of patriotism, ‘Hungama ho gaya’, ‘Ainvayi ainvayi , ‘Piyu bole’ and ‘Beedi jalaile’ entertained the audience to the hilt.

The event would have been incomplete had it not been for musicians Govind Gadhikar, Moreshwar Dahasahastra, Vishvajeet Paserkar, Gaurav Tanksale and Sourabh Killedar.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Despite huddle, Cong struggles
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Chandigarh: In the absence of chief minister Amarinder Singh in the Punjab assembly, Congress MLAs struggled to launch a counter-offensive at the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) MLAs who cornered the treasury benches during the budget session. The incumbent party legislators went into a huddle to strategise how to blunt the opposition’s frontal attack on the sensitive issue of DGP’s references to Kartarpur corridor.

However, lack of proper coordination was visible as the Congress MLAs tried to go on the offensive after some SAD legislators referred to the Congress leadership while raising slogans against the government. Led by cabinet minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa and MLA Amrinder Singh Raja Warring, the Congress MLAs too raised slogans against the Akali leadership when the House resumed after the first adjournment of half hour.

The senior Congress MLAs, including Randhawa, were apparently upset at their party colleagues not taking on the opposition parties even as it tried to drag the party leaders into the local issues raised in the House.

Most Congress MLAs gathered around parliamentary affairs minister Brahm Mohindra and finance minister Manpreet Singh Badal as Warring took the lead in planning the party’s strategy in consultation with others. Later, the Congress MLAs too flashed pictures and raised slogans against the Akali leaders.

The opposition parties had already announced that they would raise the issue of the DGP on the floor of the House even though the police chief had clarified his statement on the Kartarpur corridor. Later, when some of the Congress MLAs left their seats to take on the opposition, cabinet minister Charanjit Singh Channi had to signal them to go back

Title: Women members of Cong claim cheap liquor will increase domestic violence, stage protest
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Dehradun/Pithoragarh: Women members of the state Congress on Monday staged a protest against the Trivendra Singh Rawat government’s decision to cut liquor prices in the state. The protesters burnt an effigy of the state government in the city’s Astley hall area. Similar protests took place in Haldwani and Pithoragarh as well.

The protesters claimed that the hill state’s women will be the worst hit by the decision to make liquor cheaper. Kamlesh Raman, head of Congress’s women wing, told TOI that the party will "mobilise women from each house -- be it in hills or plains, urban or rural areas, to raise their voices against the anti-people policies of the BJP government in the state."

“Women will be the worst victims of the policy to make liquor cheaper, even as items of daily use continue to be steep. Easy access to liquor will only give rise to increased domestic violence. All of this is being done for revenue,” said Raman.

Meanwhile in Pithoragarh, Congress staged a demonstration at the district magistrate’s office. The protesters also submitted a memorandum to roll back the new excise policy.

Congress state spokesperson MD Joshi said, “The BJP government has an anti-people attitude, which is why it keeps increasing rates of transport, electricity, house tax and other basic facilities but cuts the rates of alcohol. This decision shows that the government has surrendered to the liquor mafia and is promoting alcohol consumption in the state.”

To recall, the state cabinet, in a meeting on Saturday, gave its approval to the excise policy for the fiscal year of 2020-21. This policy sets the overall revenue target at Rs 3,500 crore, about 15% more than the last fiscal. Liquor prices are likely to decrease by almost 20% after the new excise policy comes into effect. This dip will make liquor in Uttarakhand cheaper than what it costs in neighbouring Uttar Pradesh. The new policy alsi gives power to issue bar licenses to district magistrates.

Title: Trichy rly junction gets clean & green campus award
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Trichy: Tiruchirapalli district Exnora celebrated their silver jubilee celebration (1994-2019) here on Monday evening. On the occasion, offices and educational institutes were recognised for their contribution in promoting awareness on sustainable growth.

Trichy railway junction had received the clean and green union government campus award while RSK higher secondary school in Bhel township received clean and green school award, Jamal Mohamed college receive clean and green college award.

Trichy city police commissioner V Varadharaju, who was the chief guest of the event, urged the public and representatives of NGOs present to take up corrective measures for tackling the threats of global warming.

“Service provided by Exnora has played a pivotal role in Trichy becoming and sustaining the cleanest city status. The ownership attitude induced by Exnora among people should continue,” Varadharaju said.

The commissioner launched the silver jubilee souvenir of Trichy district Exnora highlighting the environmental-friendly activities of Exnora such as solid waste management, plastic awareness and promoting rainwater harvesting structures since 1994.

Later the award of excellence was awarded to A P Sivakumar, district library officer, Trichy, recognising the efforts of in promoting reading habit among youngsters,. The best innovator award was handed over to T Francis Xavier, assistant professor in St Joseph’s college for developing eco-friendly sanitary napkin.

Environmental development award was handed over Bhel township for planting more number of trees and banning the usage of single-use plastic products in their campus a few years back. “Trichy people are known to be cooperative and civilised people which helped Exnora to achieve on cleanliness front. Past records are fine, more youngsters should come forward to continue such initiatives,” M B Nirmal Kumar, founder, Exnora said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Stop levying SWM charge, residents tell corporation
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

TRICHY: As the corporation has indirectly hinted at stopping waste collection from buildings in a month or two, residents have urged the civic body to stop levying solid waste management (SWM) user charge for collecting waste. Residents said that the corporation should not charge residents who recycle their own waste.

“Encouraging apartments to recycle waste is fine, but will Trichy Corporation stop collecting the SWM user fee alongside property tax for properties that recycle their own waste?” said H Ghouse Baig, a resident of Khajamalai. At present, the corporation collects Rs150 to Rs1,000 from buildings as user fee.

“Residents have been asking us to stop collecting SWM user fee. The decision has to be taken by the state-level authorities,” an official source said. The civic body, however, justified the collection of SWM charge by stating that residents will depend on the civic body during disasters and major events.

Lack of space is other reason cited by apartment buildings for opposing the ‘recycle your own waste’ move. While new apartment buildings have space to process and recycle waste, old ones in the city without open space are in a fix.

Title: SAD makes its 6 functionaries take back resignations
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Patiala: SAD MLAs Bikram Singh Majithia and Daljit Singh Cheema on Monday met the party’s six disgruntled functionaries who had offered to quit party posts on Saturday, and convinced them to take back their resignations.

Majithia and Cheema, during the meeting with the functionaries here, said they were rejecting the resignations. The six functionaries who had put in their papers on Saturday include SAD national vice-president Randhir Singh Rakhra, national political adviser to Sukhbir Singh Badal and party spokesperson Ajay Thapar, SAD senior vice-president of Patiala (rural) Sarabjit Singh, general secretaries Major Singh and Joginder Singh, and Malwa Zone II general secretary Jasvir Singh Jassi.

In a statement issued on Monday, Thapar said both the leaders gave a patient hearing to them and assured them of taking all steps to redress the issues raised by them. While Rakhra claimed that the party drifted away from the ideology based on which it was formed in 1920 and this had provoked widespread unrest among workers, Thapar said Dhindsas were dismissed in an ‘undemocratic manner’ and everyone should have the right to raise their voice on issues concerning the party. Majitha and Cheema said they had an elaborate meeting with the disgruntled functionaries. He said leadership had promised the office-bearers that they would be given more say in the functioning of the party and their concerns would be addressed soon.

Title: Remove encroachments along waterbodies, say farmers
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Coimbatore: More than 100 farmers went on a day-long hunger strike on Monday pressing for their charter of 19 demands, in front of the office of block development officer (BDO) in Madukkarai on the outskirts of the city.

P Kandasamy, one of the protesters, said, “We have been demanding the district administration to remove encroachments along the waterbodies for a long time. To one of our petitions, the tahsildar had replied that they had cleared all the encroachments. But the encroachments were not removed. The tahsildar had sent a copy of the reply to the district collector as well. We demand action against the official for providing false information.”

Some of the revenue villages, including Sundakkamuthur in the corporation limit, falls under the Hill Area Conservation Authority (HACA) category. It has become difficult to sell land in villages that come under HACA as it involves getting approval from the authority, he said.

“It has been one of our long-pending demands to limit the area that falls under HACA and remove the villages off the list. But, it was not considered while making amendments in the Town and Country Planning Act,” he added.

He also demanded the state government to take steps to find a solution to curtail human-animal conflict in the district. About seven months ago, the district collector had assured to take steps to find a solution to reduce the conflict and nothing has changed on the ground so far, he added.

He also requested the state government to consider providing compensation on par with market value while acquiring land for western bypass and ring road project.

Title: SAD-BJP, AAP MLAs tamper with speakers
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Chandigarh: Speaker Rana K P Singh had to direct marshals to take out AAP, SAD and BJP legislators from the House as they broke speakers of Vidhan Sabha reporters during the second day of the budget session.

The speaker said, “I have been told that you have closed reporters’ speakers. It is not acceptable.” MLAs of AAP and SAD-BJP had tampered with speakers during protest and sloganeering in the well of the House. As soon as the marshals approached AAP MLAs asking them to move out, they refused to move and entered into heated arguments with marshals. Soon, SAD MLAs Pawan Kumar Tinu and Bikram Singh Majithia also entered into arguments with the marshals.

After the session resumed, technical education minister Charanjit Singh Channi urged the legislative assembly speaker to take back his decision of directing marshals to remove AAP and SAD-BJP MLAs from the House so that the session could run smoothly. tnn

Title: Coimbatore: Man arrested for assaulting sub-inspector
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

COIMBATORE: A 33-year-old man was arrested for assaulting a sub-inspector at the Valparai police station on Sunday.

Police said sub-inspector N Udhayasuriyan was investigating a case against the accused, V Prabhu, of Valparai, following a complaint filed by J Vellaisamy , 42. Both of them work in meat stalls in the municipality market. “Vellaisamy submitted a written complaint that Prabhu and his friend Senthil Kumar were abusing him in foul language and threatening to murder him following a quarrel over a business dispute,” a police officer said.

The sub-inspector filed an FIR under Section 294 (b) (using obscene words) and Section 506 (ii) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and subsequently went to the municipality market for the preliminary investigation.

“When the sub-inspector came back to the station, Prabhu and Senthil Kumar were waiting for him. The officer started questioning them and it gradually led to an argument. Prabhu lost his cool and started verbally abusing the officer. HE grabbed the officer by his uniform and started hitting him,” the officer said.

Other police personnel at the spot separated the duo. “However, Prabhu threatened to kill the sub-inspector and fled from the spot with his friend, ignoring the warnings,” the officer said.

Police registered a case against Prabhu under sections 294 (b), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 353(assaulting the public servant in execution of his duty) and 506 (i) of the IPC and arrested him.

Title: ‘Dhindsas involved in all decisions’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Patiala: A day after expelled SAD leaders Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa and son Parminder Singh Dhindsa attacked party chief Sukhbir Singh Badal over what they described as his “dictatorial” atttude, the political outfit hit back at the duo on Monday, saying that both of them were very much a part of the decision-making process.

Before being dismissed, Parminder was SAD’s legislature party leader in the Punjab assembly and was the finance minister in the previous SAD-BJP government.

Calling the campaign launched by the Dhindsas as malicious, SAD general secretary Bikram Singh Majithia said Dhindsa and son Parminder were involved in every decision taken by the SAD government and the party. Interacting with media at the residence of SAD former district unit chief Randhir Singh Rakhra, Majithia said Parminder was a colleague in cabinet whereas his father was a decision-maker in the party. He said all decisions were now being condemned by the two, even as these had been taken by them and the rest of the party.

He said the Sunday gathering at Sangrur was organised by a number of splinter groups who are supported by the Congress government.

Title: Srirangam veg traders protest against corpn
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Trichy: Retail vegetable traders in Srirangam who function from the space allotted to them by the Trichy Corporation staged a protest during the weekly grievance meeting at the collectorate on Monday. The traders alleged that corporation was not taking action against the makeshift daily retail vegetable markets in Srirangam which play a spoilsport to their revenue.

The protesting retail vegetable traders from the Srirangam Town Vegetable Seller Association said around 150 traders were paying rent and occupying the shops allotted to them by the corporation in Chithirai Street.

However, some other traders were conducting daily makeshift vegetable markets at Geethapuram and Teppakulam Street in the past few weeks.

The association said these traders were jeopardising the business of the association members by selling the vegetables at a lower price.

“We are paying rent to the civic body to occupy their space. But a section of traders from other parts of the district are hosting daily vegetable market in the vacant space without paying any rent. Though we petitioned the civic body to stop the daily markets, it didn’t act. The local body should support us,” R Govindaraj, president of Srirangam town vegetable seller association, said.

Following the protest, the district administration instructed the revenue department and the local body to hold a peace talk with traders.

Title: Collector petitioned to set up zoological park in Pudukottai
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Trichy: Members of Tamizhaga Vazhvurimai Katchi staged protest demanding a zoological park to accommodate wild animals that have been invading into residential localities, in Pudukottai district on Monday.

Submitting a petition to the district collector in the grievance meeting, they said that reduction of green cover due to urbanization and vast landscape under eucalyptus plantation has robbed the wild animals of their habitat.

S Niyaz Ahmed, district secretary of the party, said that death of monkeys, peacock and spotted deer in road accidents have become usual in Pudukottai.

This is primarily because they lost their home as Pudukottai has lost significant green cover in the recent years.

Roughly 40,000 hectares of land in Pudukottai district is under eucalyptus cultivation. Majority of the cultivation is carried out by forest department for their commercial gain, this has been affecting wildlife, he said.

These animals meeting with road accidents have also been fatal for people , therefore, the administration must establish a zoological park in the district to accommodate animals that have lost their homes, he urged.Collector petitioned to set up zoological park in Pudukottai

Title: With no night parking at airport, Goa loses out on charters: Report
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: With the footfall of charter tourists decreasing, tourism stakeholders are now looking into probable reasons for the fall in numbers. The ‘Export Strategy of Goa’ document prepared by the department of industries stated the lack of provision of night parking at Goa International Airport results in fewer charter flights arriving in the state.

Goa witnessed a decline in tourist footfalls from the UK in the last two months of 2019. The November-December period in 2018 saw 69 charters from UK bringing in 19,956 tourists, while the same period last year saw just 9,723 tourists arriving on 36 charters.

As a result of infrastructural constraints, though charter flights land at Dabolim , they have to return to their point of origin and come back to pick up passengers on a scheduled date.

Only after the night parking facility is created, will charter flights be able to land late at night. The document suggests that Goa has to expand its connectivity to European and Asian countries, including Indonesia and Malaysia.

It is also suggested that the tourism department introduce floating bays by putting to use unutilised barges for weddings and other events. Further, tourist zones may be earmarked by relaxing noise pollution norms.

Pointing out that there is no online mechanism, the document suggested that the tourism ministry should have a single-window clearance to grant approvals and permissions. “Making it online and specifying time delivery norms will increase the number of events,” stated the document.

The state should consider promoting Goa tourism as cruise tourism, the document suggested. For this, outbound immigration processing facility must be created. “Introduce e-visas and landing cards,” the document stated. Currently, identity cards are not accepted at ports.

Stating that tourists do not like the idea of having to stand in queue, it suggested that international ports have special processes for cruise tourists which exempt them from the exasperating exercise.

“The tourism department will also have to put its infrastructure in place before it aggressively promotes cruise tourism,” the document said, adding, “More berths have to be added so that ships are not made to wait till a berth gets empty.”

There is also a suggestion that an ombudsman be appointed for quick dispute settlement and ease e-visa processes. The immigration officer can go to the ship, complete all the formalities and the get e-visa done, a system that is followed in Gulf countries.

Title: 40-year-old woman killed in tiger attack in TATR buffer
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Chandrapur: Yet another human life was lost in tiger attack in buffer zone of Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) on Monday evening.

Victim Rasika Magre (40) was working in the fields near Petgaon village when the tiger attacked and killed her.

This is fifth human kill in Chandrapur this year and second in buffer zone. Predators had killed 23 people in Chandrapur district last year.

Sources informed that Raskia was alone in the farm near Andhari river, which flows close to Petgaon village, when the incident took place at around 4.15pm. Villagers later discovered Rasika’s mutilated body in the farm.

A team led by RFO, Shivni (buffer) range, rushed to the spot. The woman ’s death in tiger attack had angered the villagers forcing the forest officials to summon cops for help. The irked villagers opposed shifting of the body for post mortem. However, police and forest officials pacified them and removed the body to Mul sub-district hospital.

Officers claimed that they have provided ex gratia aid of Rs25,000 to the kin of the victim.

Title: ‘Military shotgun champ, dad killed 2 hockey players’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Hockey players Amrik Singh and Simranjit Singh

PATIALA: Police on Monday booked military shotgun champion Manraj Singh Sarao and his father Amandeep Singh for the murder of two hockey players Amrik Singh and Simranjit Singh at a local dhaba on February 19 night.

Patiala senior superintendent of police M S Sidhu said police investigators picked up electronic and other evidence to identify the two accused, following which special teams carried out raids at Mohali, Sangrur and Mansa as the accused are suspected to be hiding there.

Manraj, 20, had recently won a gold and a bronze medal at Military Shotgun Championship. He was undergoing training here and staying with his father at a PG accommodation near Partap Nagar, where the murders took place. Sidhu said Amandeep, 45, who originally hails from Duggal village in Patran block of Patiala district, was now settled in Sector 66 of Mohali. Manraj, a known trapshooting champion, owned a licensed .12 bore gun, which is suspected to have been used to kill the two players. According to police, Amandeep has a marital dispute with his wife and lives separately while Manraj lives with him.

Amrik and Simranjit, both employed with the Punjab State Power Corporation Limited, were shot following an argument with the father-son duo over a trivial issue. Amrik, a resident of Majithia Enclave, and Simranjit alias Happy, resident of Partap Nagar, were shot at from close range with a double-barrel gun around 11 pm.

Police had registered a case t at the Patiala Civil Lines police station against unidentified persons.

Title: PU will consider vocational subjects for BCom
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ludhiana: In a huge initiative likely to transform the trajectory of higher education, especially the commerce stream, Panjab University (PU) will consider all skill-based vocational subjects for bachelors in commerce (BCom) programme.

Courses like financial market management, offered by Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), will now be eligible to apply for admission in various undergraduate courses like BCom and BBA offered by the affiliated colleges of PU.

Dr Ashwani Bhalla, who is part of PU council, said the decision has been taken and will be issued by the PU during admissions. Dr Ajay Sharma, principal, Sri Aurobindo College of Commerce and Management confirmed that the PU has “updated and incorporated necessary changes in the admission criteria of UG programmes”.

Bhupinder Singh, head, department of financial management at BCM Arya Model Senior Secondary School, Shastri Nagar, said. “This will boost the morale of students who opt for skill-based subject at senior secondary level. For the promotion of skill education in schools under National Skill Qualification Framework and to make the options more convenient for the students, CBSE has updated syllabus of existing skill-based courses and introduced more courses in the academic year 2018-19 after taking inputs from industries and academic organisations. For instance, financial market management merge two fields — capital market operations and derivatives market operations, which is a joint effort of CBSE and National Stock Exchange.”

Title: Romantic elders woo partners, once again
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: ‘Bekhudi Mein Sanam’ provided elders with the opportunity to exercise their vocal chords. They did that with aplomb, albeit with their limited talent, by singing romantic singles and duets and dedicating them to their partners who were in the audience at the musical do organized by Jyeshtha Gandharva Swara Mandal at Vikas Nagar Sabhagruh, behind Sai Mandir, recently.

After every performance, innovative anchor Snehal Tambekar ‘emotionally grilled’ the shy singers and made them talk about their journey of love with their partners.

The programme started with the song ‘Jaoon kahan bata aye dil’ sung by Arvind Raje but when Anant Naik crooned ‘Laakhon hain nigaah mein’ in an energetic and stylish manner, he didn’t give the impression that he was a retired soul. The audience saluted Naik’s performance with a huge round of applause.

While Deepak Tambekar came up with ‘Hum bewafa hargiz na the’, Vivek Sakdeo chipped in with ‘Kisi ki muskurahat’.

After Sanjay Kulkarni impressed with ‘Tum bin jaoon kahan’, he was requested for another one and he willingly obliged. ‘Tumhe ho na ho’ by Deepali Sapre, ‘Chashm-e-baddoor’ by Prakash Pande, ‘Hum pyar mein jalanewalon ko’ by Nayana Gathoo and ‘Zulmi sang aankh ladi’ by Nilima Mohite were the other highlights of the events.

Prakash Pande and Nilima Mohite sprang a surprise with a duet ‘Bekhudi mein sanam’.

The other numbers, ‘Tumko dekha toh yeh khayal aya’, ‘Khullam khulla pyar karenge’, ‘Rangeela re’, ‘Ye raatein ye mausam’ and ‘Hum toh tere aashiq hain’ by Dilip Rapate, Sanjay Kurlarni and Deepali Sapre, Rupa Meshram, Nilima Mohite and Deepak Tambekar, Rapate and Mohite were impressive.

The show was conceptualized by Vivek Sakdeo, Nayana Gathoo, Deepali Sapre and Deepak Tambekar.

(Reporting by Rushabh Rathod)

Title: Punjabi arrested in connection with Ilford triple murder refuses to leave cell
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

LONDON: A Punjabi man charged by detectives investigating the death of three Punjabi men in east London on January 19 refused to leave his prison cell and attend his plea and trial preparation hearing on Monday morning.

Sandeep Singh, 29, who lives in Romford, east London, on January 27 was charged with conspiracy to cause grievous bodily harm and causing grievous bodily harm with intent and remanded in custody at Redbridge Magistrates’ Court the next day.

Judge Martyn Zeidman QC, said, “I received a note from prison that the defendant does not agree he needs to attend court and the prison marks he is fit to attend court but doesn’t agree he needs to come. If that is correct that would be a real cheek by this defendant because he does need to be here.”

Zeidman said: “This is obviously a very serious matter. This is very sensitive case for a number of reasons not least a number of people are dead.”

The judge has set July 27 as the provisional start date for a 10-day trial for Sandeep, if a trial is needed, and March 9 for him to appear to enter his plea. “It is absolutely clear, he must be here on the next occasion as this is not suitable for a prison hearing,” he said.

Narinder Singh Lubhaya, 29, from Hoshiarpur , Malkit Singh Dhillon alias Baljinder Singh, 37, from Sultanpur Lodhi, and Harinder Kumar alias Honey, 30, from Patiala, were found dead on the road in Seven Kings. Harinder’s funeral was held on Monday in Hainault, Redbridge. His family, who flew to London for it, will carry his ashes back to India. Bodies of Narinder and Baljinder are expected to be flown to Punjab this week. The Seven Kings Gurdwara has been raising money for the three families to cover funeral costs and help them.

Title: Coimbatore: Food safety awareness drives held
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Represenattive Image

COIMBATORE: The food safety department conducted a rally on Monday to create awareness on adulterated food products, importance of consuming nutritious food and banned products like tobacco.

Collector K Rajamani flagged off the rally.

Officials of the department visited a city-based engineering college and addressed students to create awareness on adulterated tea, coloured eggs and adulterated ghee, and explained about the ways to trace adulteration. The team requested them to report adulteration on the department’s WhatsApp helpline 9444042322.

As many as 2,500 people, including college students, members of self-help groups, anganwadi workers and government employees learnt food safety lessons at the awareness session conducted by the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India at Sri Krishna College of Arts and Science.TNN

Title: Physical edu, Punjabi easy & balanced: Std X, XII students
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ludhiana: On Monday, there was physical education for Class XII and Punjabi exam for Class X. Students found both the exams easy.

Raghav Kakkar, a student of Class XII medical stream of the Peace Public School, who appeared at Sacred Heart Convent School, Sarabha Nagar said “My exam was good, but lengthy. I have studied everything beforehand and it was balanced. No question was difficult.”

Rishav Kumar, a student of Class XII (humanities) from New GMT Public School, Sant Vihar, Haibowal Kalan, who appeared at GGN Public School, near Rose Garden, said, “The exam went well. It was easy as it was asked directly from the book referred. There was no question which was out of syllabus.”

Navjod Deep Kaur Sandhu, head, department of Punjabi at DAV School, said, “Punjabi paper was balanced and few of students said it was easy and they are satisfied with the exam. Last year, poetry section was really tough, almost on par with college-level Punjabi. But this time, it was easy.”

Title: ‘Pay 100% attention in class, exams are a cakewalk’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ludhiana: Ishroop Kaur Brar is pursuing Class XI (humanities) in Sacred Heart Convent School, Sarabha Nagar. She scored 97.4% in her Class X. She said, “On the whole, I had an enriching experience while giving my CBSE board exams for the first time. After all, it is self confidence and hard work that pay off. And leave the rest to god.” Here, she shares the routine followed by her while preparing for the board exams.

How did manage to get high scores?

Simple, by paying 100% attention during class lectures. It helped me grasp concepts easily. Secondly, i worked consistently and, to be honest, smartly too. I never hesitated in seeking help or clarification from my school teachers.

What tips and tricks do you have for current batch of students?

Work hard with dedication and sincerity and be attentive in the class. Have a balanced study schedule. Do not take any stress or pressure whatsoever. Have faith in yourself, and in God.

What kind of routine did you follow before and during exams?

I was consistent. I studied for 5-6 hours every day. I also made sure to get adequate sleep — for atleast seven hours, I didn’t skimp on that. To keep my attention from sagging, I took short naps of 15 to 20 minutes. I also studied NCERT books throughly. My success mantra was to study with devotion, focus and determination. The rest, I left it to the God.

How was your experience in exams?

I was both apprehensive and excited. The constant support of my parents, teachers and the regular prayers to the Almighty encouraged me and made me realise my inner strength. Also, exams are stimulating and provide an opportunity for intellectual expression. Needless to say, there is always that tingly anxiety.

Who was your inspiration?

My elder sister

What did you do to relax?

I meditated, went for evening walks, listening to music and painted in my free time.

Title: Demand to include 3 dists under protected agri zone
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Trichy: DMK has demanded the government to include Trichy , Karur and Ariyalur districts in the protected special agriculture zone (PSAZ) in the recently introduced bill in Tami Nadu assembly. A resolution to this effect was passed in the DMK cadre meeting in the district on Monday.

Chief minister Edappadi K Palanisami had introduced the bill in the assembly on February 20 announcing Thanjavur, Tiruvarur, Nagapattinam, five blocks each of Cuddalore and Pudukottai districts as protected special agriculture zone. The bill came in the wake of relentless opposition from people and political parties against hydrocarbon projects in the delta region.

The bill also termed industries like copper smelter, zinc smelter, aluminium smelter; iron ore process plants, tannery and few others to be adversely affecting the agriculture sector.

The issue was also reflected in the weekly grievance day meeting at the Trichy collectorate on Monday. Tamilaga Eri Matrum Aatrupaasana Vivasayigal Sangam members staged a protest by wearing ‘naamam’ on their forehead and rolling on the ground before handing a petition to the officials. State president of the association P Viswanathan raised his apprehension that Trichy, Karur, Ariyalur may have been excluded with deliberate intention. “We fear that the government may start research in the area for (mineral) reserves. So, we strongly demand inclusion of the three districts under the protected special agriculture zone,” he said.

Title: State govt adopts Centre’s witness protection scheme
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: The state government has adopted the Centre ’s witness protection scheme, 2018, notified last week. The scheme involves providing a police escort to the witness up to the courtroom or using technology for recording testimonies.

Its scope includes providing protection to witnesses in complex cases involving organised crime group and may require to take-up extraordinary measures. Director of prosecution T S Sardinha said the scheme will primarily benefit minor victims and in the cases of crime against women.

The scheme defines categories of witness as per threat perception – A, B and C. The category A is defined as where the threat extends to life of witness or his family members during investigation/trial or thereafter. Under category B, the threat extends to safety, reputation or property of the witness or his family members during the investigation or trial.

Category C witness is the one where the threat is moderate and extends to harassment or intimidation of the witness or his family member’s, reputation or property during the investigation or trial.

There is also a provision to create state witness protection fund under the scheme. Expenses incurred during the implementation of witness protection order passed by the competent authority and other related expenditure are to be drawn from a witness protection fund.

To avail benefits under the scheme, an applicant will have to make an application before the competent authority. Depending on the urgency in the matter owing to imminent threat, the competent authority can pass orders for interim protection of the witness or his family members during the pendency of the application, stated in the scheme.

It is also stated that the threat analysis report shall be prepared expeditiously while maintaining full confidentiality and it shall reach the competent authority within five working days.

It is mandated in the scheme that all the hearing on witness protection application shall be held in camera by the competent authority while maintaining full confidentiality.

The responsibility of implementation of all witness protection orders passed by the competent authority for change of identity or change of relocation shall be implemented by the department of home.

Title: Nashik: Nirbhaya squad books over 50 in 2 days
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nirbhaya squad has booked 23 people and issued a strict warning to 25 others in the Deolali Camp area on Sunday evening. Meanwhile, another 30 people were booked by the other unit of the same the squad at the Golf Club Ground on Monday.

The ones who were booked were found consuming alcohol in public, making lewd remarks on girls and women in the Temple Hill area of Deolali Camp. Officials of the Nirbhaya squad said that they also took action against harassers in the Bhagur bus stand area.

PSI Vaishali Mukane of Nirbhaya squad 4 said that the action in Deolali Camp was taken on Sunday evening.

The people were taken to the police station, said PSI Mukane. While 23 of them were booked under Section 112/117 of the Bombay Police Act, a strict warning was issued to the 25 others.

Mukane said that some youngsters pass lewd remarks on girls at the Bhagur bus stand. Strict action was also taken against them.

The Temple Hill, commonly known as Khandoba Tekdi is crowded due to the presence of the temple and the scenic beauty around it. The other side of the temple hill has dense plantation where the people consume alcohol in public, indulge in objectionable activities.

She said that since the residents have the number of Nirbhaya squad, they alert the police after which action is taken.

Meanwhile, the Nirbhaya squad 2 booked 30 people under Section 112/117 of the Bombay Police Act at the Golf Club Ground on Monday morning.

Title: KGMCH sets up special work arrangement at casualty wing
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kozhikode: Kozhikode Government Medical College hospital (KGMCH) authorities have put necessary efforts in place to ensure a swift response mechanism at the casualty wing. The medical college authorities have decided to deploy volunteers to help the on-duty staff to attend patients without any delay.

A four-member medical team headed by KGMCH superintendent Dr K G Sajeeth Kumar as chairman, has been formed exclusively to ensure the smooth functioning of the casualty. The team will ensure sufficient strength of staff and volunteers at the casualty to attend the patients brought to the casualty.

The medical college hospital authorities took measures to improve the functioning of the casualty considering the growing number of patients arriving at the hospital to avail treatment. It has already set up triage facility at the casualty for the quick screening of patients to avoid hospital level transmission of diseases.

According to the Kozhikode government medical college hospital authorities, on an average, 3 ,500 patients visit the hospital daily from six districts of North Malabar. Out of this, 500 to 700 patients arrive at the casualty. The medical college hospital has already commenced the deployment of trained volunteers to help the staff on duty to provide emergency treatment to patients arriving at the casualty on need basis. Doctors of emergency medicine department of the Kozhikode Government Medical college imparted training to 94 volunteers who have come forward to render voluntary service to the patients. The medical college has also decided to provide uniform to the volunteers attending patients at the casualty. The formed committee will deploy the volunteers each day. The medical college has already deployed eight nurses trained in emergency medicine at the casualty to meet the requirements of patients.

The medical college hospital authorities have also deployed a total of 10 Kudumbashree members to ensure cleanliness at the casualty. The members were deployed on contract basis to carry out round-the-clock cleaning work at the casualty.

Dr K G Sajeeth Kumar, KGMCH superintendent said that they took steps to improve the facilities at the emergency care and to ensure patient friendly measures .

Title: Free run for private buses as PMC has no big jammers
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The civic body had planned to act against illegaly parked buses from the first week of February

PUNE: The civic body is finding it tough to take action against illegally parked private buses because of non-availability of big jammers , an official said.

The Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ) had planned to take action against such buses with the help of the traffic police from the first week of February. But, the big jammers required for the same were not available with the civic body, which put a brake on the drive against illegal parking. The operators of these buses are now fined on the spot.

“The action is jointly being taken by the PMC and the traffic department. A few drives have already been carried out. The buses are parked on the road during the day as well as night. It not only causes traffic problems, but also leads to accident threats,” a senior PMC official said, adding that the drive had been suspended temporarily, and would begin again soon.

“The civic administration will procure jammers for this drive and hand it over to the traffic department. Around 100 jammers will be bought,” Madhav Jagtap, head of PMC’s anti-encroachment department, said.

Designated parking bays have been set up for private bus operators. But, many of them do not park their vehicles there, an official said. The areas where the buses are mostly found parked include JM Road, Deccan, Shivajinagar , Satara Road, Nagar Road and Sinhagad Road. The PMC in association with the police department and private land owners has given operators space at Sangamwadi . Inter-state and intra-state private travel companies use this space for parking.

The civic body had given notices to those violating parking norms. Those who were not adhering to the notices were facing action. No new notices are being issued now and the civic administration has been directly taking action against them, an official said.

The private tour operators in the city take around 5,000 trips a day. Over 1,000 operators have their buses visit Pune for the tours. Different buses are used for these services ranging from mini buses to sleeper coaches.

Title: Coimbatore: Develop open space reserve land, residents tell corporation
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

COIMBATORE: As many as 50 residents of Kamarajapuram in Ganapathy on Monday requested the collector to ensure that the adjacent open space reserve (OSR) land is not encroached.

The city corporation had recently evicted a group that had encroached on the 2.25-acre plot, said Prakash , a resident. “We have been staying at Kamarajapuram from 1961, when the layout was launched. The corporation did not do anything to develop the common space, which was earlier a part of ward 45 but is now ward 32. Gradually, some people began encroaching the space and stayed there. But a few months ago, the corporation evicted them after giving them houses at Keeranatham,” he said.

After the encroachers were shifted, the residents expected the civic body to develop the land by setting up a park, playground, anganwadi or a primary health centre. “But a new set of encroachers seem to be moving in,” said Pattiammal. “Most of us belong to the SC community and other economically-backward sections. We would benefit from a community hall, a primary health centre offering free medical care and playground for our children.”

A new slum may come up in the residential area, the petition said. “There are rumours that some people want to construct a church or a temple on the land,” said another resident.

“The corporation should develop the land. Only then it will be useful to us,” said Jothimani , another resident.

Title: All’s well, says Madhya Pradesh Congress, after Scindia-Digvijaya surprise meet
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Congress leaders Digvijaya Singh and Jyotiraditya Scindia greet each other during a roadshow in Guna

Title: Forest dept struggles to curtail poaching in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Trichy: The Trichy forest department is unable to curtail poaching as many cases go unnoticed. And, even the few cases that are reported and where the guilty are arrested, all of them walk free by paying a petty penalty.

Experts say that increasing activity of poaching reflect on the poor awareness among people and meagre effort from forest department to curtail such incidents.

Few days ago, about 50 villagers in Manapparai picketed the taluk office seeking permission to hunt wild animals inside the reserve forest.

However, the forest department denied them permission and warned of strict action under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 if anyone is found indulging in poaching activities.

In another incident, more than 40 people were detained by the forest personnel on Saturday for trespassing into the reserve forest in Thatchankurichi. Sources said a state minister intervened to release the detained people. Subsequently, they were released by the officials after collecting fine.

While in such attempted poaching incidents, offenders are usually sent to jail.

However, bowing to pressure from local leaders, the guilty often get away with a meagre fine.

R Chandrasekar MLA of Manapparai, who had contacted the forest personnel on behalf of the Manapparai villagers for permission, said that those seeking permission aren’t poachers.

“It has been a traditional practice to hunt rabbits during Mahashivrathri and people strongly believe that their prayers are incomplete without hunting,” he said.

A forest department official said that they cannot allow such activities as there is a possibility that protected wildlife species could be harmed along with other small animals. There was no significant step towards preventing poaching incidents by the forest department which has largely contributed to such incidents, says A Kumaraguru, conservation scientist from biodiversity conservation foundation (BCF).

Title: Protesters burn UP CM’s effigy at city’s ‘Shaheen Bagh’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Ludhiana: Protesters at the Ludhiana’s “Shaheen Bagh” on Monday burnt the effigy of Uttar Pradesh (UP) chief minister Yogi Adiyanath to protest against the alleged police atrocities in Aligarh on Sunday.

Addressing the protesters, president of Majlis-e-Ahrar Maulana Habib-ur-Rehman Saani Ludhianvi, who is Shahi Imam Punjab, said police’s atrocities in Aligarh will only be considered as murder of democracy. He added that the UP administration on directions of their political masters is walking on the road once tread by General Dyer.

Shahi Imam said those men in uniform should understand that there is rule of law in the country and a time will come when those committing atrocities will have to go to jail. He added that the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) agitation is to save the constitution of the country and it cannot be muzzled.

Maulana Habib-ur-Rehman said those threatening to turn Shaheen Bagh into Jallianwala Bagh should listen with open ears that such threats will not be heard in independent India and no one will be allowed to resort to ‘goondaism’.

Personal secretary to Shahi Imam said the protests at the Ludhiana’s Shaheen Bagh have entered 12th day and people of various faiths are coming there to voice their anger against CAA and National Register of Citizenship. He added that to promote national unity and against CAA and NRC, a kavi sammelan (poetry evening) was organised at the protest site.

During the session, poet Ghulam Hassan Qaisar recited his poem ‘Na Tan Ki Baat Karo, Na Dhan Ki Baat Karo, Jahaan Khaloos Mile Uss Watan Ki Baat Karo’. Also poets Rajinder Rajan, Manohar Vijay, Dalip Aodhi, Sukhwinder Andoh, Aalima Khaton, Niyam Jigar, Mustkeem Karimi, Johar Wastawi, and Salman Rehbar recited their poems.

Title: Meet Komal, the first woman doc from Madia tribe
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: Neither the rattling guns of Maoists and police nor the acute backwardness of her native village, nestling deep in forest on border of Maharashtra-Chhattisgarh border, could sway the determined steps of Komal Madavi.

Daughter of a farmer father and mother, who is a nurse at a primary health centre (PHC) in Maoist-affected Gadchiroli district, 22-year-old Komal became the first woman doctor from Madia tribe, one of the three tribal groups classified as particularly vulnerable in the state.

Komal, a student of Shri Vasantrao Naik Government Medical College and Hospital, Yavatmal, attained that distinction when her final year’s results were declared earlier this month. Her younger sister, Payal, studying at GMCH Nagpur, is likely to follow her feat in another two years.

Komal’s dream now is to open a hospital in her village which suffers from backwardness due to Maoist-related issues. “I have seen how my own people suffer to get even basic medical facilities which always pushed me to become a doctor. My mother’s being a nurse was another motivation. I used to always write an essay or prepare speech in my early days in schools on my aim of becoming a doctor. Soon, it had started to run in my blood,” said an elated Komal aims to be a surgeon.

The siblings come from a village where people are still struggling for basic amenities and poor infrastructure. There is a solitary bus service and the nearest railway station is more than 100-km away in Telangana state. It has a small PHC to cater to the medical needs of the local population. The closest town Sironcha is more than 45 km and district headquarters 230km away. During 2019 national and state elections, the place had to be transformed into a fortress so polling could take place.

Komal, who studied till Standard IV at her village’s ZP school, would speak only Madia language when she took admission at Dharmarao High School at Sironcha in the Standard V as her mother got transferred out of Zinganur to the new place. Learning Marathi was first of the many challenges she faced. Despite the odds, she scored 84% in her board examination.

Komal’s father Kasa, a school dropout after Standard VII, may not have an academic background but he nurtured a dream for his elder daughter. His decision to send Komal to Nagpur for her higher secondary education meant another struggle for her. The girl had to adapt to city life and also fight home-sickness. It took a toll on result of her board examination.

It also reflected in her performance in National Eligibility-cum-Entrance Test (NEET) which she could not clear in 2013. “I wanted to quit but father egged me on. In 2014, I managed to crack it comfortably,” recalled Komal.

Komal’s take on Maoist movement of her district is positive. “They may have been present around me but they never came in my way even once nor bothered my family. One must come here to see and feel the serene nature, the beautiful villages and forests unlike anywhere else. There is more to Gadchiroli than just Maoists,” she said.

Title: Farmer draws attention at banana expo
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Trichy: On the third day of the international conference of National Research centre for Banana (NRCB), a farmer drew the attention of everyone by visiting all the stalls put up in the exhibition and insisted on keeping the names of the stalls in Tamil besides having names in English.

The farmer was of the view that the farmers knowing only Tamil could not make use of the exhibition organised by the government by spending huge money.

When farmers are visiting the stalls and listening to the staff telling about their product, a 68-year old man visiting all the stalls starting from one and appealed to the representatives of each stall to write their company or agency’s name in Tamil with folded hands.

He has been identified as S Natarajan, a resident of Raja Colony in the city. He identified himself as a farmer visited each and every stall established at around 75 and questioned them how farmers who have arrived from rural areas could understand what was going on that particular stall.

Title: Alarmed cops on alert after intel report
Content:
Delhi Police personnel at a spot where demonstrators of the two groups pelted stones during a protest at Maujp... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police will be on very high alert in the next 24 hours as intelligence agencies have received inputs that the riots in the city could intensify in order to put the international spotlight on Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) with President Donald Trump in the capital.The intelligence branch and Special Cell are keeping a close tab on the developments and coordinating with the intelligence bureau with regular updates which are being further shared with secret service officials who are in charge of Trump’s security. The security on routes leading to Rajghat was reviewed on Monday evening and additional forces will be deployed to keep it out of bounds for people.The agencies are also learnt to be probing the role of at least three organisations, including Popular Front of India (PFI), in fanning Monday’s violence which spiralled out of control. The outfit is already under probe on allegations of funding anti-CAA protests in UP and Delhi.After the death of one of its cops and injuries to four dozen others, the police brass is reworking its strategy to tackle the riots. A meeting was called late on Monday to review the situation and decide the plan of action for Tuesday.The plan to whip up frenzy in north-east Delhi seems to have been set in motion days in advance and only intensified on Sunday night. Stones and Molotov cocktails were piled up at strategic locations like houses, rooftops, balconies and corners of lanes inside colonies. It is disturbing that the police did not anticipate this or failed to crack down.Perhaps because of the impending visit of the US President or lack of leadership and clear orders from the police brass, the force was evidently ill-prepared and hesitant in nipping the trouble in the bud. They were inadequately deployed in such a volatile area and reinforcements had to be rushed in and later additional forces deployed when much of the damage was done.Many cops agreed that there seemed to have been a lack of preventive measures too compared with the past scenarios where Delhi Police even moved to restrict internet services in several areas of Delhi during the anti-CAA protests in mid-December.TOI spoke to several policemen who have watched over law and order in the capital for over two decades and many of them agreed that the police did not seem to be on the front foot this time. “Alarm bells should have rang after Sunday evening’s stone-pelting in Maujpur and incidents of arson at Karawal Nagar late at night but the police brass, it appears, chose to remain in wait-and-watch mode and started reacting in haste when things spun out of control on Monday noon,” he said. In fact, TOI was witness to multiple instances where rioters beat up people after asking for their names and set a shop and a house on fire in the presence of the police.Delhi Police, however, denied being lax and said they took appropriate measures. In a statement issued around 4.30pm on Monday, the department casually said that “some incidents of violence and arson had been reported in the areas of north-east district, particularly Maujpur, Kardampuri, Chand Bagh and Dayalpur...strict action will be taken against miscreants and anti social elements”.Delhi Police has also compiled a detailed report on Monday’s violence and it will be submitted to the ministry of home affairs late on Monday night or Tuesday, said an officer.

Title: Stalker slashes 19-yr-old college girl, arrested
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Coimbatore: The Thudiyalur police on Sunday arrested a 21-year-old man, who injured a college girl using a blade at Vellakinar on the city outskirts.

Police identified him as M Muthukaruppan of Gandhipuram. “He was a senior student in the private college attended by the 19-year-old victim and was besotted with her. But the girl had rejected his unwelcome advances several times. Even after completing his study, he used to follow her when she was on the way to the college. But the girl never reciprocated his feelings,” a police officer said.

A frustrated Muthukaruppan met the girl at her house in Vellakinar on Thursday when she was alone. “When the girl rejected his proposal again, he grew angry and verbally abused her. He slashed her throat, hands and legs using a blade he had carried with him. As the girl started to scream in pain, he ran away from the house,” the officer added.

Alerted by her screams, the girl’s neighbours rushed to her help and took her to a private hospital. She has sustained injuries in neck, legs and hands, and is undergoing treatment.

Based on a complaint from the girl’s mother, police have filed an FIR under Section 294 (b) (for using obscene words), 448 (punishment for trespassing into a house), 324 (voluntarily causing hurt with dangerous weapons) and 506 (ii) (criminal intimidation) and arrested Muthukaruppan. He was remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Disabled tea vendor attempts suicide over anti-encroachment drive
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: A day after Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) anti-encroachment squad removed his tea stall near Dawa Bazaar in Gandhibagh area, differently-abled vendor Chandrashekhar Kumbhare allegedly attempted to commit suicide by setting himself ablaze at NMC headquarters on Monday afternoon. Alert security guards and Sadar police station personnel foiled his attempt.

NMC’s anti-encroachment drive intensified against vendors encroaching on roads and footpaths after Tukaram Mundhe took over as municipal commissioner on January 28. NMC’s anti-encroachment squad has started conducting the drive even on Sundays.

On February 23, the NMC anti-encroachment squad carried out a drive against vendors who had encroached on roads and footpaths in Gandhibagh zone area. During the drive, NMC enforcement team seized Kumbhare’s tea stall in front of Dawa Bazaar. Despite requests, the team did not return his belongings.

“Kumbhare’s tea stall was situated next to a public toilet constructed on a portion of footpath in the commercial area. It never disrupted the movement of vehicles or pedestrians,” claimed Giridhar Bhajbujhe, another differently-abled vendor, during a meeting with additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi and deputy municipal commissioner Mahesh Morone. They demanded that NMC should not act against differently-abled vendors.

The delegation said there are around 100 differently-abled people earning a livelihood through hawking. They also showed some government resolution issued a decade ago regarding rehabilitation of differently-abled by setting up shops. “But nothing has happened so far,” said another differently-abled vendor Sukhdeo Dudhalkar.

To justify their demand, they also pointed out that when Mother’s Dairy and cobblers’ kiosks were constructed on footpaths, why were their shops facing anti-encroachment drive?

Joshi rejected their demand and clarified that the civic body is already facing contempt petition for inaction against encroachments on roads and footpaths. “So no leniency will be show while taking action against vendors on roads and footpaths,” he said.

He also informed them that NMC has already formed a town vending committee. “The committee will soon start functioning by identifying hawking zones,” he explained.

The delegation also sought directives to enforcement department to return Kumbhare’s seized material, which too was refused by Joshi. “Inquiry will be conducted in his case and if we find his encroachment was not disrupting vehicles and pedestrian movement, only then we will think about your demand,” Joshi said. Kumbhare told TOI he has been selling tea there for the last 25 years and it is the only source of income for his family of four members.

They also pointed out that they could neither run nor save their material during the anti-encroachment drive. So, they demanded NMC should give a warning before taking any action against differently-abled vendors, and the additional municipal commissioner assured to look into it.

“The Sadar police booked the differently-abled vendors for unlawful assembly but has not registered any case against the vendor who attempted to commit suicide by pouring kerosene on himself,” said senior police inspector Mahesh Bansode.

BOX

Sitabuldi Main Rd cleared of hawkers

Sitabuldi traffic police zone along with anti-encroachment squad of Nagpur Municipal Corporation on Monday cleared vendors from the busy Sitabuldi Main Road. The drive led by senior PI Jayesh Bhandarkar and assistant municipal commissioner Ashok Patil acted against over 60 hawkers. In the past too similar anti-encroachment drives had been taken out on this road, but in vain.
