Title: Trichy: Man pedals to save disappearing farmlands
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

TRICHY: A 26-year-old man from Mannanchanallur in Trichy, who has undertaken a cycle rally from Kanyakumari to Chennai to highlight the sorry state of agriculture due to conversion of farmlands into housing plots reached Trichy on Monday.

T Balamurugan of Vadakkipatti near Mannachanallur, hails from a family whose occupation has been primarily agriculture. Mannachanallur being a rain-fed area, the agriculture work of his family gradually came to a standstill after water scarcity loomed large and the wells turned dry a decade ago. “After completing my Class XII, my family was unable to provide me higher studies as they could not earn from the farming following which I chose construction work. In the past two decades, most farmlands were converted into housing plots which disturbed me a lot and forced me to take up a rally to create awareness,” Balamurugan told TOI on the way to Perambalur.

The objective of the cycle rally that commenced from Kanyakumari on February 18 is to sensitise the public about the ill-effects of converting farmlands into real estate. “If the situation continues at this pace, our future generation will have to bear the brunt of shortage of food. It is high time we raise the pitch against the alarming trend. So, i am on a mission to disseminate the message and insist the state government on passing a law to prevent the conversion of farmlands,” he said.

His journey covered Kanyakumari, Tirunelveli, Virudhunagar, Madurai and Trichy. He plans to reach Chennai after covering Perambalur, Villupuram, Tindivanam, and Chengalpattu to petition the chief minister Edappadi K Palanisami.

Pedalling for 80km a day, Balamurugan was upset over the reaction of the public in urban areas to his rally. “Urban people are not bothered about the issue but those in rural areas show interest to take home the message from my rally,” he said.

Title: Reluctance to absorb surplus teachers affects recruitment to aided schools
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

TRICHY: The recruitment of teachers to vacant posts have been hit greatly after a few government-aided refused to absorb the surplus teachers from other schools

As many as 350 government aided schools, including 108 high and higher secondary schools, are functioning in the Trichy district. Salary of regular teachers in these private management-run government aided schools are borne by the state government.

Number of regular teachers in these schools have become excess over the recent years because of fall in the student strength. The state has prevented these schools from filling vacant posts so that the posts could be filled with excess teachers found in many schools.

But many schools seem to be reluctant to fill posts by absorbing excess teachers from other schools. This has delayed filling up of teachers posts in many schools.

Speaking to ToI, S Santhi, Trichy district chief education officer said that there has not been any delay in giving permission to make appointments in government aided schools in Trichy.

She said that five postgraduate teachers in as many government aided schools are found surplus in the city. One teacher each in subjects like Tamil, English, Physics, Chemistry and Mathematics have been found surplus.

“Though we called for a meeting of aided schools management to absorb these teachers when there is a vacancy in their schools. But not many are showing interest in absorbing excess teachers,” she said.

“For instance, if seven schools have vacant teacher post in one of the five subjects, any one of the school should absorb the teachers. If one of the school could come forward to take this one teacher, we can give permission to rest of the six schools to go ahead with the appointment . But none of the school is agreeing to take these five teachers which is resulting in the delay,” she said.

Title: Salem: EPS challenges Stalin to list out faults, drawbacks of his govt
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

SALEM: Detailing about the achievements of his government, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami challenged DMK party chief MK Stalin to list out the faults and drawbacks of his government, if any, as his party had fulfilled all the promises made in its manifesto before the 2016 assembly .

Citing 2006 assembly election manifesto of DMK, the chief minister asked why former chief minister and DMK leader M Karunanidhi failed to give two acres to landless farmers as promised in the manifesto.

“At the same time, DMK functionaries had grabbed lands from many people across the state,” he said. “The AIADMK government took action and returned the land to original owners,” he added.

The AIADMK government has given 11 medical colleges in the state besides created five new districts.

Slamming the DMK for winning in the Lok Sabha election by giving false promises, the chief minister appealed to the public to vote for AIADMK in the municipal election to give good governance.

He said Rs 3 lakh crore worth of projects have been brought to the state in the investors meet held last year. Nearly 304 MoUs were signed in the meeting, he added.

“We have saved the delta districts by announcing it as agricultural zone,” he said.

On releasing convicts in the Rajiv Gandhi assassination case, Palaniswami said his government had sent a letter to the governor to release six people including Nalini and Murugan . “At the same time, DMK did not take any step to release them,” he said.

Meanwhile, the district administration celebrated former chief minister Jayalalithaa’s 72 birth anniversary. District collector S A Raman, officials and MLAs participated in the event and garlanded the statue of Jayalalithaa at the memorial hall, belonging to the public relations and information department.

Title: Transgender identity is for my soul, not sympathy: Narthaki Nataraj
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Narthaki Nataraj performs at Khajuraho festival

BHOPAL: Day five of ongoing Khajuraho Festival radiated with extra sparkle, as the first Padma awardee transwoman, Narthaki Natraj, presented some of the oldest compositions of her guru - Kittappa Pillai- direct descendant of the Thanjavore auartet, known as father of Bharatanatyam.

Admitting that performing at Khajuraho is a momentous occasion, she said, "I read the history of Khajuraho temples and decided to stick to my traditional repertoire. Performing on Vishwanathashtakam bhajans was an ode to my guru."

Originally from Madurai, today she travels across the globe for her solo concerts, but not many know that she was thrown out of her home at 11. That didn't stop Narthaki from dedicating her life to classical dance, with her childhood 'soul mate' Sakthi Bhaskar standing by her, throughout. "My struggle egged me on to focus all my energy in the pursuit of dance. My siblings and extended family have accepted me now and I love them too, holding no grudges," said she.

For her, dance is the only way to drive the demons away. Admitting that her art is indeed cathartic, she said, "When I'm dancing, I feel like a queen. On stage, it seems as if I'm flying like a honey bee. I can't express my happiness in words ; dance has definitely helped me forget all the fears and anguish of my past."

These days a lot of LGBTQA youngsters are participating and excelling in dance reality shows and competitions, but most of them still prefer Bollywood or western genres to classical formats. When asked if it saddens her, the danseuse said, "Classical forms, whether Hindustani music, Carnatic music or dances, require a lot of hard work. You can't pursue this genre as a hobby. You can reach your goals only if you surrender yourself to the art. Not only the community youngsters, but most of the youngsters today want to strike it rich, overnight."

It's been over five years that transgender community got the third sex status, but even now those thin lines that marginalise the community, remain. A vocal leader, Narthaki suggested a way forward. " I tell the community youngsters, come out of the closet and serve the society selflessly. Seeking sympathy is not advisable. Whatever I got in life, is purely on merit. Transgender identity is for my soul; it is not for sympathy. To get love, we have to give love. We are known as god's people, so if we work for people without expectations, it will eventually be recognised. My friend Shakthi and I practise this mantra and both of us are the happiest people in the world. We indulge in thanksgiving every day," said she.

Earlier, Aswathy and N Srikanth presented the finer nuances of Bharatanatyam on stage, Nair sisters' Mohiniattam presentation was also appreciated a lot.

Title: Stringent new norms for Tadoba guides, drivers
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Guides and drivers are yet to respond to the directive

Nagpur: No involvement in any forest or wildlife offences, good communication skills in Marathi, Hindi and English, and termination of service after three complaints are some of the conditions part of fresh rules framed by Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) for new guides and Gypsy drivers.

Stung by sharp criticism from all quarters — including the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) — over a viral video of a tourist vehicle blocking the way of a tiger on February 9, the TATR management issued stringent guidelines on February 18 for guides and drivers.

The existing guides and safari vehicle drivers/owners have also been asked to submit a notarized affidavit on a Rs200 stamp paper by February 25, stating that they are not involved in any kind of forest offences, and that they are ready to clear encroachments on forest land, if any. Sources said guides and drivers are yet to respond to the directive.

Anil Tiwade, the president of Maharashtra Guides Union said, “Guides are opposed to giving an affidavit. A meeting has been called on Monday to take a final decision.”

TATR conservator of forest (CF) and field director NR Praveen said, “For the first time, rules have been formulated for guides and drivers. We need 25% more guides than the existing carrying capacity of the entry gates, and there is demand to recruit guides from gates like Kolara.”

Currently, there are 225 guides for TATR’s core and buffer zone. Around 125 vehicles (including canters) enter Tadoba in two shifts, and another 100 vehicles enter the buffer ranges of the park.

“The rules have been framed with the consent of the guides and registered vehicle owners. The new rules for recruitment of drivers will be applicable from the next tourism season,” Praveen added.

The rules make it compulsory for new guides and drivers to have proficiency in Marathi, Hindi as well as English. A guide or driver will be terminated if three complaints of any violations are received against them.

“The educational qualification for new guides will be at least SSC, while for drivers it will be Std V. We have also fixed 58 as the age of retirement for drivers, while for guides it will be 65. The minimum age for recruitment will be 22,” said Praveen.

To curb dual employment from tourism sources, the guides and drivers will be asked to submit an affidavit.

Guides and drivers had recently blocked the entry of tourists from Kolara gate, after park management asked them to clear encroachments on forest land in Kolara.

Young naturalist Himanshu Bagde welcomed TATR’s move. “Till now, there were no curbs on guides, drivers or vehicle owners because of the park’s requirement. Only the tourists were taxed for any set of rules. I hope the new set of rules bring discipline. If good candidates are identified at the recruitment stage, the park management will face fewer problems.”

Radical Rules

Guides’ retirement age to be 65, drivers 58

Guides should have cleared SSC, drivers Std V

Character certificate from police must

No record of forest or wildlife offences

No dual employment from tourism sources

Proficiency in Marathi, Hindi & English mandatory

Termination after 3 complaints

Title: Pune: Railway authority warns people against fake job advertisement for RPF constables
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The fake job advertisement highlights vacancies for nearly 20,000 constables in the Railway Protection Force

PUNE: The railway authority has warned people against a widely-circulated advertisement on social media and several websites, which highlights vacancies for nearly 20,000 constables in the Railway Protection Force (RPF).

The Ministry of Railways wrote a letter to all the railway zones on February 20, instructing them to alert job seekers about the false advertisement through different mediums, senior officials at the Central Railway said.

Sources said the advertisement appeared on a website www.placementstore.com, which was further circulated on different social media platforms, via WhatsApp groups and messages.

The website claims that “RPF has issued a latest notification for the recruitment of constable vacancy at 19,952 posts. Interested candidates can apply by April 30, 2020.”

“There are some unofficial websites spreading advertisements for the recruitment of 19,952 constables by the RPF. The railway board has not issued any advertisement regarding vacancies in the RPF,” a senior official with the railways said.

Deputy Inspector General (DIG) of the RPF in the railway board, said in a letter, “Fake advertisements regarding the recruitment of the constables of RPF is being spread by some unofficial websites and social media platforms. Any advertisement related to RPF jobs will be published on the official website of the Ministry of Railway, indianrailways.gov.in.”

A senior RPF official told TOI that they were investigating the issue. “The advertisement is fake and action will be taken. The cyber cell of the RPF is investigating the matter and a complaint has also been lodged with the Delhi cyber cell,” the official said.

Job aspirants should know that any job vacancy related to the railways comes out in the official website only and not anywhere else, the official added.

“The RPF and railway board will not be responsible if anyone is trapped into the net. We always publish advertisements on our official website. These websites are to dupe people. People are requested not to give any details related to bank accounts, date of birth, insurance policy or Aadhaar numbers to such websites,” the officer pointed out.

Title: Gazebos erected at Colva and Sernabatim beaches
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Colva: Even as development of Colva beach has come to a standstill due to paucity of funds, six gazebos have been installed at the beach. One gazebo meanwhile has come up on the adjoining Sernabatim beach.

Gazebos are free-standing roofed shades which are open on all sides. Apart from adding ornamental features to the beach, they also provide a shady respite to beach visitors.

The Union tourism ministry had announced Rs 100 crore to the state in July 2017, under the Swadesh Darshan scheme, to augment tourism infrastructure. In the first phase, inaugurated last September, projects under this scheme were unveiled at Anjuna, Candolim and Morjim.

In the second phase, GTDC has taken up Colva, Sernabatim, Benaulim and Palolem, Miramar and Dona Paula beaches .

Goa Tourism Development Corporation, managing director, Nikhil Desai, said that while the gazebos are placed for providing shade to visitors, they could also be used by lifeguards, night patrol staff, tourist wardens and tourist police while on duty.

He also said that the gazebos, made of steel and fibre reinforced plastic (FRP), are approved under the Swadesh Darshan scheme.

Title: Malayora Samrakshana Samithi begins strike
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Thrissur: Thrissur Malayora Samrakshana Samithi , a farmer’s movement began an indefinite hunger strike in front of the Thrissur collectorate from Monday onwards demanding to distribute title deeds to all eligible farmers under the Ollur assembly constituency. The farmers movement leaders allege that the district administration failed to distribute the titles to the farmers on time.

Malayora Samrakshana Samithyi convenor K K George Kakkasery said, “Thousands of farmers from Pananchery, Nadathara, Puthoor and Madakkathara areas have been waiting to get title deeds for the last 40 to 50 years. But the district administration officials failed to distribute the it.”

“It was in last November that the district collector said they will distribute title deeds to the farmers before December. But they changed the dates and the title deed distribution was left in limbo. But as per the recent statement by the collector said that they would distribute only 1,300 forest land title deeds,” said George.

“Our demand is that the government should appoint a special officer for the title deed distribution process. A special officer can easily complete the verification process of the forest and title deed applications and distribute the title deeds on time,” he said. “Whenever the farmers movement announces a protest the district administration will announce the date of a title deed distribution fest. But after we withdraw the protest the district administration cancels the title deed distribution related works,” alleged George.

“We will continue the indefinite hunger protest till we get a favourable reply from the government,” he said.

Two days ago, district collector S Shanavas announced that the district administration will distribute 1,300 forest land title deeds to the farmers.

Title: ‘Mountaineering summit’ workshop begins in Uttarkashi
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Uttarkashi: A ‘ Mountaineering Summit ’ workshop organised by district administration commenced at the Nehru Institute of Mountaineering (NIM) on Monday, on the occasion of 60th foundation day of Uttarkashi district. Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat inaugurated the two-day workshop, which focuses on various aspects of mountaineering and trekking-based tourism in the Himalayan region.

During the event, Gopal Singh Rawat, MLA Gangotri constituency, put forth the demand to open trekking routes situated in inner line region of India-China border for foreign tourists too. Besides, he also demanded to give relaxation in the number of mountaineers visiting Gangotri National Park, as only 150 tourists per day are allowed to enter the park.

President of Adventure Tour Operators Association of India, Swadesh Kumar, said that Gangotri National Park should be open throughout the year for mountaineers and trekkers. He also pressed for opening of Nanda Devi National Park for tourists, to open adventure sports rescue centres all over the hill state, to provide marketing grants to tour operators and not to take any extra charges from foreign mountaineers.

CM Rawat assured to take positive action over the demands. He said, “We are soon going to conduct a meeting with the ministry of home affairs over inner line issue and will try to remove the restrictions from foreign tourists. We will also try to pass the budget for marketing grants to tour operators in upcoming assembly session. Besides, we will also conduct a meeting with forest department for opening of new trek routes in hill districts.”

“Government is taking all possible steps to boost tourism in the state. Looking at the increasing possibilities of adventure sports and tourism in the state, we are planning to set up a separate department for adventure activities so that we can develop proper infrastructure in this genre which boost the economy of local people,” the CM added.

Title: Officials get trained to carry out NPR exercise from May 1 in Nashik
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Training for officers of the rank of tahsildars and above — designated as ‘charge officers’ — was conducted at... Read More

NASHIK: The Nashik district administration on Monday started the process of imparting training to officials who would oversee the National Population Register (NPR) exercise across the district.

“The process of NPR is to start across the country from May 1. The process will, in no way, affect the valid citizenship rights. Any miscreant trying to create trouble will be dealt with the proper procedure of law,” Nashik collector Suraj Mandhare said sounding a warning to those opposing the exercise.

Ever since the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) was passed by Parliament, there have been protests in pockets across the country. Some organisations have also appealed to the people to oppose the CAA and not cooperate with the NPR enumerators.

Earlier, in Malegoan, some people opposed the electors’ verification programme (EVP) started by the Election Commission of India. Local elected leaders, including MLAs and corporators, had to intervene to ensure that the process went on smoothly.

The administration has pointed out that the NPR and the census had nothing to do with the CAA. The officials said that the issues coming up at the time of enumeration will be dealt with appropriately.

Training for officers of the rank of tahsildars and above — designated as ‘charge officers’ — was conducted at the Niyojan Bhawan. The training was chaired by resident deputy district collector Bhagwat Doifode.

The enumerators will be going house to house between May 1 and June 15 to complete the NPR exercise. The enumerators will have to complete the process on the special application, which they have to download on their cellphones and complete the formalities. Only authorised personnel have access to the software. The application works online as well as offline, thereby ensuring that every house, even in the remotest location, is covered. The enumerators will be derived from the rank of teachers, clerks and others.

Title: Two Additional flights will push up cargo volume: Exporters
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

TRICHY: Exporters in Trichy airport exuded confidence that the introduction of two more flight services to Abu Dhabi and Doha will help them handle more volume of cargo. The old terminal at the airport was converted into an international cargo complex and was commissioned for operations on November 21, 2011.

The Central Board of Excise and Customs approved and notified the airport as an air cargo complex. Ever since the airport started to handle cargo, the terminal has been witnessing increase in handling cargo consignment when compared the previous year.

Export of perishables commodities like vegetables, fruits, flowers constitute 90% of the total volume of consignments handled here. Singapore, Dubai, Sharjah, Kuala Lumpur and Colombo are the main destinations. The remaining 10% of export included are non-perishables like garments, leather etc.

Air India Express, Air Asia, Scoot Air, Malindo Air, Sri Lankan Airlines and IndiGo Air have been providing 91 services per week to Dubai, Sharjah, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore and Colombo. The total volume of cargo handled in 2009-10 was 1,349 and it started going upward year by year. In 2018-19, the total volume of cargo handled registered as 6,932 tonnes. It was 6,787 tonne till January 2020. As two months are remaining to complete the financial year 2019-20, the terminal is likely to touch a volume of 8000 tonne, airport authorities said. It will be a reality when the newly launched flights - Abu Dhabi and Doha - accommodate significant volume of cargo, they said.

“So far, exporters sending their consignments via Colombo to Abu Dhabi and Doha by Sri Lankan Airlines, taking circuitous route are wasting money and time. This means that there is no more ordeal for the exporters. Volume of cargo would go up. Each flight can accommodate cargo to their belly ranging from 1 tonne to 2.5 tonne, based on various factors. On an average, these two new flights would fetch 75 tonne a month,” managing director of MB Cargo R Muralidharan said.

As Doha is a transship destination to various Europe countries, the new service would attract more number of exporters, airport sources said. It is noted that Air India Express will commence new services from March 29.

Title: Two neighbours stab each other after quarrel
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: Two persons were injured after they stabbed each other in broad daylight at Bajaj Nagar Square on Sunday. Bajaj Nagar police have registered two separate offences of serious assaults and attempt to murder against three persons including the injured.

It’s learnt that Shrikant Raut and Prashant Koparde were purchasing liquor from an outlet at Bajaj Nagar when one Sachin Mandalwar attacked them from behind with a knife. Mandalwar and Raut, who are neighbours, had a verbal duel around couple of days ago. Following the spat, they had vowed to teach each other lesson.

After Mandalwar stabbed Raut twice on his lower back, the victim and his friend Koparde fought back. In the scuffle, Mandalwar lost possession of the knife which was picked up by Raut. Subsequently, Raut and his aide took turns to stab Mandalwar in his stomach, chest and other parts of the body.

As the cops arrived at the spot, the injured were rushed to the Mayo hospital for treatment and offences were registered.

Title: Goverment switches off Pipili power to protect tusker, upsets matric students instead
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

BHUBANESWAR: The effort to drive away the wild tusker that killed four persons in Puri’s Pipili on Sunday seems to have had unintended consequences.

Students of the area who are appearing for the matric examination alleged that the presence of the uninvited guest had affected their studies. The reason? All power distribution companies in the area had been instructed to shut off electricity supply to prevent the animal from accidentally getting electrocuted.

The elephant strayed into Pipili on Saturday, prompting the state government to ask all power distribution companies to shut off supply in villages like Matighara, Rajatei, Mangalpur, Jamalpur, Gopinathpur, Balanga and Sankari Sahi. Power was restored only on Monday morning, while the matric Sanskrit exam began at 10 am on the same day.

“We had no electricity for almost two days and two nights. My exams are on. I could not study at all for Monday’s paper. We don’t have inverters. How long can we study using candles? This is really unfair,” said Subas Nayak, a student.

The Central Electricity Supply Unit (Cesu) pleaded helplessness and said it had standing instructions from the government to ensure the safety of the tusker. “The government asked us to disconnect power supply in areas the elephant passed through. Elephants often fall victim to low-tension wires in villages,” said Subrat Mishra, spokesperson of Cesu.

This failed to calm down angry parents, who demanded that the school and mass education department ensure that the students received grace marks in Sanskrit. “We are not asking for any favour. The government must make sure that our children pass in Sanskrit,” said Anadi Charan Sahu, a parent and resident of Gopinathpur village.

Officers in the school and mass education department, however, said there was no precedent for granting grace marks to students because of elephant intrusion.

Meanwhile, the tusker at the centre of it all safely entered Chandaka sanctuary, after spending some time at Ghatikia on the outskirts of Bhubaneswar.

Title: Arvind Kejriwal: CM condoles death of cop, urges Baijal, Shah to act
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

New Delhi: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal condoled the death of the Delhi Police head constable who died in the line of duty in the clashes at Gokulpuri on Monday. Along with him, different AAP functionaries also made appeals for peace.

In a series of tweets, Kejriwal said, “The death of the head constable is very sad. He was also among one of us. Please abstain from violence. It will benefit none. All problems will be solved with peace.”

The CM also urged Union home minister Amit Shah and LG Anil Baijal to maintain law and order. “Very distressing news regarding disturbance of peace and harmony in parts of Delhi coming in. I sincerely urge LG and home minister to restore law and order and ensure that peace and harmony is maintained. Nobody should be allowed to orchestrate flagrations (sic),” he tweeted.

Baijal instructed Delhi Police to maintain law and order in northeast Delhi and asked people to remain calm.

Meanwhile, Gopal Rai, AAP MLA from Babarpur, one of the points where the clashes erupted, appealed through a video posted on social media to maintain peace. “I request everyone with folded hands to maintain peace. Some people are intentionally trying to aggravate the situation by creating an atmosphere of fear,” he said.

“The LG has assured me that additional security forces are being deployed to maintain peace in the affected areas,” he added.

Deputy CM Manish Sisodia also condemned the violence. “The flames of violence cause irreparable damage to everyone,” he said. Later, he tweeted, “I am living in Delhi for three decades. Never felt so terrified in my own city. What has happened? Who are the people burning Delhi? I am very sad and ashamed today.”

AAP Rajya Sabha member Sanjay Singh alleged on Twitter that Shah was not taking any steps to stop the violence. Singh and Rai added that police were not taking their calls.

Rai and Burari MLA Sanjeev Jha arrived at the LG House around 11.45pm to demand police action against the rioters. “We are getting distress calls from different areas. We want police presence to be increased,” Jha told TOI. Till the filing of the news they were camping outside LG House.

Title: Forest dept to take public opinion on Kanhargaon reserve
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: Over a year after the state board for wildlife (SBWL) gave in-principle approval to declare Kanhargaon in Gondpipri tehsil a wildlife sanctuary, the first process has been initiated by taking locals’ views on the proposal.

“The in-principle approval to the proposed sanctuary was subject to the condition to seek ‘janmat’ (public opinion) and accordingly, the process has been initiated,” said Nitin H Kakodkar, principal chief conservator of forests (wildlife), Maharashtra.

SV Ramarao, chief conservator of forests (CCF), Chandrapur, said, “FDCM and regular forest officials have been asked to hold joint meetings with locals to seek their views on the issue.”

This may be the first occasion when public hearings will be held to notify any forest area a sanctuary. On December 5, 2018, the decision to notify Kanhargaon as a sanctuary was taken at the 14th SBWL meeting led by the then chief minister Devendra Fadnavis. Former forest minister Sudhir Mungantiwar was also present.

The Kanhargaon sanctuary proposal was first mooted in 2014. Since then, it is hanging by the fire owing to political differences and basically, opposition from Forest Development Corporation of Maharashtra (FDCM), which has large-scale logging operations.

“The corporation generates a revenue of at least Rs20-22 crore annually from commercial extraction of timber from Kanhargaon. It is in possession of 28,000 (280sqkm) hectare area,” officials said.

The Kanhargaon proposal includes 24,862-hectare (248.62sqkm) area of FDCM and 1,638 (16.38sqkm) hectare area of territorial forest under the Central Chanda division. Both combined makes it a 265sqkm sanctuary with no villages inside.

Even as the FDCM was opposed to it earlier, things have changed in the last six years. Sources said that now, the FDCM is willing to part with the Kanhargaon area provided it is compensated with an equal amount of forest in the Allapalii division in Gadchiroli Circle.

A proposal in this regard is already pending. Earlier, FDCM was compensated with forest land in Allapalli for handing over its area for the Koka wildlife sanctuary in Bhandara.

“Another reason why Kanhargaon needs to be declared a sanctuary is the flared up man-animal conflict with tigers crying for space. The tiger numbers in Maharashtra has grown from 190 in 2014 to 312 in 2018,” says Gadchiroli honorary wildlife warden Uday Patel.

As per the survey conducted in 2015 by the Wildlife Conservation Trust (WCT), there were 10 tigers and 23 leopards in Kanhargaon.

“The lush green forest of Kanhargaon forms the key southern corridor for the spill over tiger population moving to the Kawal tiger reserve in Telangana and Indravati reserve in Chhattisgarh through Chaprala and Pranhita sanctuaries in Gadchiroli,” says wildlife conservationist Prafulla Bhamburkar.

Chandrapur honorary wildlife warden Bandu Dhotre said, “Notifying the sanctuary is in the interest of locals as they will reap benefits of ecotourism besides the Dr Shyamaprasad Mukherjee Jan-Van Yojana.”

“I have visited villages around Kanhargaon and found that people were being misguided on the issue by being told that they will be relocated if the sanctuary is notified. This is completely false,” said Dhotre.

“Kanhargaon encompasses pristine forest patches which were once shooting blocks during the British era. With TATR emerging as the top tiger tourism destination in the country, tourists flow can be diverted to the proposed sanctuary bringing local employment,” Dhotre adds.

WHY KANHARGAON?

* Tigers need space as number in Maharashtra up from 190 in 2014 to 312 in 2018.

* Kanhargaon is a strategic link between Tadoba-Kawal in Telangana and needs to be made inviolate.

* The new PA can accommodate surplus spill over population of tigers reducing man-animal conflict and ensure safe future of tigers.

* The new sanctuary can boost employment generation for locals.

* While denotifying GIB sanctuary in Solapur, state has committed to Supreme Court to declare more PAs. This promise has not been fulfilled yet.

ENDS

Title: Arterial road dug up in Thanjavur to erect arches to greet Tamil Nadu CM Edappadi K Palaniswami
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Pole erected on the middle of a road in Thanjavur

THANJAVUR: Despite there being a ban on erecting arches and flex boards on roads obstructing public movement and vehicular traffic, AIADMK workers have damaged arterial roads in Thanjavur to erect arches and banners to welcome the chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam , who are scheduled to attend Rajya Sabha MP and deputy coordinator of AIADMK R Vaithilingam’s son’s wedding on February 26.

Some workers were seen digging holes and erecting bamboo poles almost in the middle of the state highway roads in and around Thanjavur on Monday morning. This has raised questions about effectiveness of the ban.

“Workers said they were doing it for a wedding that was scheduled for Wednesday. The arches would be a huge threat and hinderance for motorists,” said a roadside vendor near New Bus Stand, where the wedding is to take place in a hall.

When contacted, superintendent of police, Thanjavur, S S Mageshwaran told TOI that while court orders said no one must erect flex banners in public places affecting people, there were no such restrictions in case of arches, if they are erected in a way that public movement and vehicular traffic are not affected.

Title: Uttarakhand: Four arrested by Jhabrera cops for shooting at man
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

ROORKEE: Four persons, including three contract killers, were arrested by Jhabreda police in Haridwar district on Monday for trying to allegedly eliminate a 19-year-old man of a village near Jhabreda.

Police said that he victim's father Subhash worked as a labourer in the house of a farmer Suresh Pal of Miragpur village. He had allegedly taken some money on interest from Pal which amounted to Rs 4 lakh.

When 55-year-old Pal, a bachelor, realised that Subhash was unable to repay the debt, he proposed his marriage with Subhash’s 17-year-old daughter. But, Subhash's son Satendra was opposed to his sister’s marriage with Pal.

Police claimed that Pal hired three criminals for Rs 35,000 from Rajjupur village near Deoband to eliminate Satendra.

Haridwar SSP Senthil Avoodai K Raj said, “Since the victim is from the Dalit community, we have now slapped a section of SC/ST Act along with other sections of IPC 307(death causing act), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 452 (house-trespass for assault) on the accused.”

Title: Erode: Tusker suffering from intestinal worms dies near Bhavanisagar
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

ERODE: A 20-year-old tusker suffering from intestinal worms died near Bhavanisagar in Erode district on Monday.

After being informed that an elephant was lying on a village road that connects Dengumarahada and Bhavanisagar, forest officials went there and found the tusker battling for its life.

Using an earthmover, officials moved the jumbo off the road. Veterinary doctors tried to save the elephant, but in vain. “Due to intestinal worms, it did not eat for at least a week,” a forest officer said.

The veterinarians performed an autopsy on the spot and buried the carcass in a nearby forest.

The tusks of the elephant were cut and kept in the Bhavanisagar forest office, the officer added.

Traffic in the stretch was halted for a few hours due to the incident.

Title: PWD replacing defective concrete panels on Inner Ring Road
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: With the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court taking cognisance of criminal PIL filed by activist Suraj Lolage, the state’s public works department (PWD), through controversial contractor RPS Infraproject Private Ltd, has started removing defective cement concrete panels and laying new ones on Inner Ring Road (IRR).

The PWD has also started the process to appoint a private agency for checking quality of work done under IRR Widening and Cement Concrete Project.

HC on November 6, 2019, had asked the petitioner to carry out survey of the already executed work and file affidavit supported by authenticated material.

The PWD, through RPS, then removed defective panels between Trimurti Nagar Square and Pratap Nagar Square. Instead of concretizing the patch again, the contractor laid paver blocks in place of the panels. TOI on November 25, 2019, highlighted the irregularity.

The PWD through RPS has now started removing two defective panels at Kharbi from the last few days. Each panel of 40 metric tonne is around 4.5 metre wide and 3.5 metre long. The cement concrete panel was dumped on the road divider and the contractor laid a new panel.

Lolage told TOI that PWD and RPS did not replace defective panels between Hingna T-point and Chhatrapati Square. “Even, those between Chhatrapati Square and Kharbi were not replaced. The work directly started at Kharbi. PWD should ensure all defective panels on IRR are removed like at Kharbi. Also, PWD engineers should monitor work at the site,” he said.

The activist said that huge quantum of cement, concrete, sand, iron rods, time, manpower and funds have gone waste due to nexus between PWD officials and contractor. “Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation had blacklisted RPS for inferior quality of road works. PWD should have verified it and avoided tender,” he said.

PWD has also floated a tender for appointment of private agency that will conduct falling weight deflectometer test at 50 locations on IRR to evaluate effectiveness of dowel bar at joints and assess effectiveness of cement concrete panels.

Lolage said PWD is wasting public money. “PWD had appointed a third party agency to check quality and paid it in crores. Inspection was also done through Central Road Research Institute (CRRI),” he said.

TOI from the last three years has been reporting about cracks on IRR and deterioration of surface layer. Lolage had lodged a series of complaints with PWD. When PWD did not take any action against contractor and its engineers, Lolage filed a criminal writ petition.

A PWD engineer told TOI that all defective panels will be replaced. “We will repair surface layer by removing entire panels as per suggestions of CRRI. Lot of initiatives have been taken to ensure proper quality and completion of project,” he said.

RPS was given the work on September 24, 2015. It was supposed to complete the project within two years. Till date, it is 89.3% completed, as per PWD.

After HC took cognisance of criminal PIL, PWD started levying a fine of Rs5,000 per day on RPS.

Title: HC says no to announcing Jaya’s b’day as govt function
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has dismissed a plea which sought to declare the birth anniversary of former chief minister J Jayalalithaa as a government function.

M Manimaran, an AIADMK functionary, and resident of Sivaganga district, in his petition stated that Jayalalithaa served as the chief minister of Tamil Nadu for more than 14 years. Because of schemes implemented for the welfare of the people, she became a renowned political leader. Following her demise, the state government had announced that February 24, her birth anniversary would be declared as a government function, however, nothing has been done so far. He said that he had submitted a representation in this regard to the government, but no steps were taken.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench. When the petition was taken up for hearing on Monday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran observed that since the petitioner had stated that he had filed this petition only on the ground that her birth anniversary is celebrated on Monday, the court is not inclined to entertain this petition.

Title: New library and constitutional park at Rajasthan University
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The new library at the university will have a digitalised system to reduce manpower

JAIPUR: A constitutional park and a new library in the name of Bhimrao Amedkar will soon be additional features of Rajasthan University .

While library construction has been completed, furnishings will begin soon and the university will invite tenders in two days.

Vice-chancellor R.K.Kothari said, “We will finalise the tender within a few days after furnishing work will start. We are expecting the work to be completed in three months. It will be named after Bhimrao Ambedkar. Right in front of the library, a constitutional park will be created as per the orders of the governor. Preamble of the Constitution, fundamental rights, directive principles of state policy and other provisions of the Constitution will be inscribed on a stone in the park. This will spread positive message amongst students.”

The new library will have a digitalised system to reduce dependency on manpower. Professor S.L.Sharma, in-charge of library, said it will be digitalised and there will be special chip in the books to keep a track. “Students will have to punch their smart library cards to get a book issued. Library cards will have information of all books issued in the past as well. At the entry gates, sensors will be installed that will start beeping if any book is taken out without being issued. This will help in preventing book theft as well,” said Sharma.

A Rs 4.85-crore new humanities hall is under construction in the university. A human resource and development centre is also almost ready near Government Poddar College which is currently running at the university.

Title: Raut’s free power plan will cost 8,000cr per year, is unfeasible, say discom officials
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: Energy minister Nitin Raut may have made big headlines by proposing to provide free power to domestic consumers using less than 100 units per month, but MSEDCL top officials say the plan is unfeasible.

Raut in fact wants to provide free power to consumers of all four discoms in the state – Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL), Brihanmumbai Electric Supply and Transport (BEST), Brihanmumbai Suburban Electric Supply (BSES) and Tata Power.

“I have asked energy ministry officials to submit a report in this regard in three months,” he told TOI.

A senior discom official told TOI on the condition of anonymity that there were 14 lakh consumers in Delhi whose consumption was less than 100 units. “However, in the state the figure is over 1.25 crore. A rough calculation done by us shows that state government will have to pay Rs8,000 crore to the MSEDCL every year to provide free power to the targeted group,” he said.

The official further said Delhi and Maharashtra could not be compared as far as power tariff was compared. “Delhi has no agricultural consumers whereas there are 42 lakh such users in the state. Other consumers have to pay a cross-subsidy of Rs9,000 crore to keep their tariff at less than Rs2 per unit. In addition, the state government has to pay a subsidy of Rs5,500 crore to us. Delhi government doesn’t have to pay any such subsidy,” he added.

“The state government is reeling under a debt burden of over Rs4 lakh crore. Recent crop loan waiver will cost it another Rs30,000 crore to Rs40,000 crore. How will the state pay Rs8,000 crore subsidy every year,” said the official adding that the government has already stopped funding to many development works citing cash crunch.

Ajit Pawar, deputy chief minister who handles finance portfolio, had publicly opposed Raut’s plan. He told the media that ministers should not make people habituated to such freebies. Unfazed, Raut told the media that he would talk to Pawar and chief minister Uddhav Thackeray to implement his scheme.

Balasaheb Thorat, revenue minister who hails from Congress, recently found it difficult to defend Raut. When asked about the contradictory statements of Pawar and Raut, he said the energy minister had merely asked MSEDCL to study the plan and a concrete announcement had not been made.

Power expert Ashok Pendse feels that such populist decisions can’t be sustained in the long run. “Delhi government has created regulatory assets worth hundreds of crore to keep power tariff in the state artificially low. The power companies have approached Appellate Tribunal of Electricity (ATE) and Supreme Court for recovering these assets. If the decisions go against the government, it will have to shell out hundreds of crores or allow the power companies to sharply increase the power tariff,” he told TOI.

Title: State asks mining cos for locations of non-royalty ore
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: The directorate of mines and geology (DMG) has written to mining companies asking for details of the locations where their non-royalty iron ore is being stored and the quantities.

This is to avoid mining companies from lifting government iron ore lying at jetties and plots. There is nearly 5 million tonne of government-owned ore lying at jetties and plots .

“Once we receive the details of the quantity and locations, we will send a file to the government for approval for collection of royalty,” a senior officer said.

Once the royalty is collected, the department will issue the mining companies transport permits for the same.

Details of the transportation route will also be submitted to the Goa State Pollution Control Board to enable it to monitor air pollution, the officer said. The senior officer also said that when mining in the state first came to a halt in 2012, the apex court had declared the ore lying at plots and jetties as illegal.

It had directed the state government to confiscate the ore and conduct e-auctions. The mines department had identified 15 million tonne of such ore, from which 10 million tonne was e-auctioned.

Between September 2014 and January 2015, the state conducted a second renewal of 88 mining leases.

Mining activities in Goa once again commenced in August 2015, but then came to a halt on March 15, 2018, after the Supreme Court quashed a second renewal of 88 mining leases. Recently, the apex court permitted the export of ore extracted before March 15, 2018.

Senior officers said from August 2015 to March 2018, mining companies extracted ore, but did not pay the royalty.

Title: Government stops pension of 6 retired officials for ‘graft’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Monday ordered senior officers to permanently stop the pension of six retired employees after charges of corruption were proved against them by vigilance. Naveen also ordered compulsory retirement for two other employees of doubtful integrity.

According to an official statement issued by the chief minister’s office ( CMO ), the action has been taken because of the chief minister’s policy of zero tolerance for corruption.

The retired officials whose pension has been stopped are former managing director of Odisha Bridge and Construction Corporation Ltd (OBCC) Sudhir Kumar Brajendra Narayan, former senior project manager of OBCC Arun Charan Parida, retired assistant engineer Pramod Kumar Behera , retired executive engineers Brajasundar Patnaik and Khageswar Swain and retired superintending engineer Bibekananda Mohanty, said the CMO statement.

Two revenue inspectors — Eswari Prasad Purohit from Kalahandi district and Arun Kumar Purohit from Sonepur district — have been given compulsory retirement according to the state government’s premature retirement policy.

In a crackdown against corrupt officials, the state government has sacked 74 government officials since August last year.

Similarly, 15 officials of doubtful integrity have been given forced retirement since September 26, 2019.

Title: Chopper rides to start before monsoon
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: After repeated delays, Goa tourism expects to start helicopter rides from Ela, Old Goa, before the monsoon starts. A new helipad is under construction at Ela.

“Construction of the helipad should be completed in March. We should be able to start the helicopter rides before monsoon,” J Ashok Kumar, tourism secretary, told TOI on Tuesday.

Pawan Hans Ltd, a Delhi-based helicopter service company, was originally appointed when Goa introduced helicopter rides in early 2016 with Aguada helipad as the take-off point.

The chopper rides will also continue during the monsoon period since they shall be only covering a short distance, said the tourism secretary. Some tourism-related services are closed during the monsoon months keeping safety in mind, and also because tourist footfalls usually decrease during the rainy months— though, in the last few years, the state has seen an icreasing trend of visitors during extended weekends despite the rain.

In 2016, GTDC was compelled to discontinue the ten-minute joyrides from Aguada, within a few days of the launch, following objection from some villagers, who were supported by local politicians. The service was then shifted to South Goa, and the helipad owned by a starred hotel was used, but the service was discontinued at the end of the season that year due to logistical problems.

Title: Tiwari blames confusion for unrest, Maken asks Kejriwal to take the lead
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

New Delhi: Referring to the anti-CAA protests in the city, Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari on Monday said that people were still “confused” about the amendment made to the law and were creating an “atmosphere of unrest”.

While urging protesters to practice restraint and maintain peace, Tiwari, who is a Member of Parliament from North East Delhi where violent clashes erupted on Sunday between those favouring and opposing CAA , said lakhs of people were being “harassed” due to the agitations.

“Under the guise of peaceful demonstration, miscreants are harassing millions of Delhiites by protesting on roads and committing violent activities. It is now important that they be controlled as soon as possible,” Tiwari said.

Former Delhi Congress chief Ajay Maken , however, urged chief minister Arvind Kejriwal to not appear “helpless” and take the “lead” in bringing the situation firmly in control.

In a series of tweets, Maken suggested setting up of a helpline to take complaints of violence or police inaction, calling an all-party meet to take suggestions from functionaries across party lines and formation of peace committees in troubled areas.

Maken, who was junior home minister in the UPA-II government between 2009-11, said he was making the suggestions to deal with Delhi riots on the basis of his experience in dealing with numerous administrative responsibilities.

In his tweets, Maken suggested: “Establish a helpline directly under your office to receive complaints of violence or police inaction. This should be monitored and further passed on to police and the local SDM. Immediately call an all-party meeting, take suggestions and work across political parties to restore normalcy in troubled areas. Form peace committees with social influencers, including MLAs, councillors, district magistrate, local SHO and SDM. Make each minister of your cabinet in chargeof such committees and ask them to hit the ground.”

The senior Congress functionary also asked the chief minister to establish a hotline with the lieutenant governor and talk to him every hour to take stock of the situation. “Take a lead and don’t sit back blaming others. As a CM, please do not appear to be helpless. This would badly erode a much-needed credibility of our democratic institutions to protect atrocity/violence against innocent citizens,” he added.

Senior BJP functionary and Rajya Sabha MP Vijay Goel said he will start a campaign against Shaheen Bagh protests on March 1 from Delhi University’s Bonta Park. He added he will visit parks across the city every morning to talk about Shaheen Bagh.

“Women at Shaheen Bagh are being exploited as shields by Opposition parties. This is a very well-thought conspiracy to instigate riots,” the MP claimed.

Title: HC rejects bail plea by woman maoist
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has dismissed the bail plea filed by a woman maoist stating that trial in her case is prolonging, and directed the trial court in Dindigul to complete the trial within March 31. The court further said that it would not hesitate to grant relief to the petitioner, if this timeline is not strictly adhered to.

Sivasakthi alias Shenbagavalli alias Rama alias Kanimozhi, a resident of Krishnagiri district in her petition stated that police officials received information on April 19, 2008 that maoists were conducting arms training camp inside the forest areas of Kodaikanal. When the police officials went to the spot, the maoists opened fire. When the police officials retaliated a maoist was shot dead. There were total seven accused in the case registered by the Kodaikanal police and it was alleged that she was also one of the participants in the camp.

When she filed a bail petition before the high court Madurai bench in 2019, the court on November 25, 2019, dismissed her bail plea taking into consideration the state government’s submission that examination of witnesses was not concluded. She stated that the court had also directed the Dindigul principal district and sessions court to complete the trial by January 31.

However, as police officials are not cooperating with the trial, it is still prolonging before the trial court. Since she has been in judicial custody for the past two years, she moved the high court Madurai bench seeking bail.

When the case was heard on Monday, the state government submitted that the process of examination of witnesses was under way and sought time for complete the same.

Taking note of the submissions, justice G R Swaminathan dismissed the bail petition and directed the trial court to complete the trial within March 31. The judge observed that the petitioner had filed this bail petition as the earlier timeline fixed by the court was not adhered to.

Title: Plea to form panel to remove stray cattle from roads
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: The state government has been directed to file a counter on a plea moved by an advocate seeking to constitute a committee to remove stray cattle from the roads in Madurai district.

K Gandhiyammal, an advocate from Madurai, in her petition before the Madras high court stated that people who own cattle let them loose on the roads as they do not bother about taking care of them. Due to this, the cattle are roaming on the roads causing difficulty to vehicular movement.

She said that stray cattle roaming on the roads are also a reason for causing accidents. Recently, when she was travelling from her house to the high court, she sustained injuries as two cattle which were running amok pushed her down from her two-wheeler.

Even though she submitted a representation to the authorities concerned in this regard, no steps were taken.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking for a direction to constitute a coordination committee comprising district administration officials and police officials with adequate vehicles to remove the stray cattle from the roads and impose heavy penalty on the owners who allow their cattle to roam on the roads.

When the petition was heard on Monday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran gave the direction.

Title: Students showcase their talent in IIIT Nagpur’s Abhivyakti 2020 inter-college fest
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: The Indian Institute of Information Technology (IIIT-Nagpur) completed the fourth edition of its National Level Cultural Fest, Abhivyakti-2020, on Sunday, with a two-day inter-college fest.

The fest had a slew of thrilling events which witnessed participation from a multitude of colleges from all over Nagpur.

The inauguration ceremony was followed by ‘Talk Masters’ — the public speaking event. Personality contest Vyaktitva and singing competition Antara summed up day one. The second day kick-started with the poetry competition ‘Kavyanjali’ and debate contest ‘Big Roar’. The other events like ‘To the beat’ and ‘Abhivyakti’s got talent’ kept the audience enthralled.

The ceremony was flagged off by chief guest Sanjay Kumar, director (personnel), WCL, in the presence of dean AG Kothari, director OG Kakde, registrar Kalilas N Dakhale and faculty in charge Kirti Dorshetwar. The closing event was graced by Vishram Jamdar, chairman of VNIT.

In the end, everyone’s emotions were mixed; partly high from the dance, partly sad as the event was nearing its completion and partly contented as the event was a huge success.

Title: Kitco seeks KIIFB’s nod on tourism circuit project
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kozhikode: Kitco (Kerala Industrial and Technical Consultancy Organisation), on Monday, submitted a detailed project report (DPR) on Koyilandy-Vadakara tourism circuit project to Kerala Infrastructure Investment Fund Board (KIIFB), which is the funding agency for the project, and sought their approval.

The plan is to link tourism destinations in Koyilandy and Vadakara legislative assembly constituencies with Sargalaya Craft Village at Iringal. The report envisages the development of Sargalaya, which already is a centre of attraction with the presence of artisans and scenic beauty of Moorad River, in the first phase of the project.

“We hope KIIFB will give nod the project and it will take off soon,” said K Dasan MLA of Koyilandy. DPR is prepared in a way to develop all minor and major tourism destinations in Koyilandy and nearby areas to attract tourists, he said.

As per the project report, beach destinations with exclusive features and riverside tourism spots will be linked to develop them into a major tourism project. The plan is to link Sargalaya Craft Village at Iringal, Kolavippalam beach, Thikkodi beach and Govindan Kettu on the bank of Akalapuzha River. It is expected that the project would benefit other destinations including Urupunyakvu beach at Moodadi and Koyilandy Mangrove Park also. “The tourism circuit project was initiated with an aim to develop all tourism destinations and bring them under a single project in the backdrop of the fact that there are many destinations in the district which could be developed into major destinations,” said K Dasan. The tourism circuit project would enable us to popularize our destinations, he said.TNN

Title: Head-constable held taking bribe of Rs 10,000 in Kota
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kota: An Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) team of Jhalawar arrested a head constable posted at Chechat police station in Kota district on Monday for allegedly accepting a bribe of Rs 10,000.

Accused Ajit Singh had demanded the amount for allowing illegal transportation of Bajri by a tractor in his area.

Singh was arrested from Chechat police station premises after he had accepted the bribe from one Brijmohan Yadav, a resident of Alod village under Chechat police station area, ASP (ACB) Jhalawar Bhawani Shankar Meena said.

The constable had demanded the amount for allowing illegal transportation of Bajri by a tractor following which Yadav approached ACB, Jhalawar last week and lodged a complaint.

The constable, at the time of verification of the complaint on Friday last week, asked Yadav to hand him over full amount on Monday following which the ACB laid a trap to nab him, the ASP said.

The constable will be produced before the ACB court in Kota on Tuesday, he added.

Title: Rane orders lab test of PWD water at Keri
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: Health minister Vishwajit Rane on Monday met officials of public works department, water resources department and Keri panchayat to look into complaints of high iron content in potable water.

“Latest reports suggests the iron content is within permissible limits. I have instructed PWD officials to send water samples to a laboratory for evaluation. I request Keri locals to not have any apprehensions,” the minister said.

Rane said it also needs to be seen if water from dams can be directly pumped into tanks and sent for further filtration.

Title: CM Kamal Nath lashes out at Modi govt for failure on job front
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madhaya Pradesh chief minister Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Monday continued his tirade against Prime Minister Narendra Modi-led NDA government at the Centre for its failure to provide employment to the youth.

Nath said PM Modi never talked about youth and tribal welfare, but MP government will chalk out a scheme to check migration of tribals and provide them employment and justified price of their produce.

“PM Modi never talks about youth and farmers. He only talks about Pakistan and nationalism to distract people from real issues. The Congress government will restart all welfare schemes closed by the BJP government so that tribals get work and do not migrate,” said Nath, while addressing a tribal convention in Dindori to mark Shabari Jayanti.

The chief minister also assured that after Chhindwara, tribal dominated districts of Dindori and Mandla would be on the priority list for development. The government is committed to overall development of the tribals.

“We will mobilise the economic activity. The state government will chalk out a scheme to provide jobs and justified price of farmers’ produce. The government will also review all the old schemes dumped by the previous government,” said Nath, hinting at the revival of Rs 10,000 crore Narmada water supply scheme for Dindori.

Nath's tribal convention holds significance amid efforts by the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) that has recently launched its most important campaign on social equality and harmony among tribals and other backward classes.

The chief minister said during last 15 years of BJP rule in MP all the promises made to the tribals remained incomplete. The Congress government will fulfill these tasks without much propaganda.

He said, “Mata Shabari is a symbol of humanity and simplicity which is why tribals have great reverence and faith towards her. They should resolve to preserve their culture and history. Tribals have always supported the truth, the Congress government will not disappoint them. The previous government had left empty coffer for the new government. Former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan made 21,000 announcements but, none of them was fulfilled,” he said.

Title: Bhubaneswar: Football tourney in tribal districts to find, nurture hidden talents
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

BHUBANESWAR: The authorities of the special development council (SDC) of the state government is organising the SDC Cup football tournament in nine tribal-dominated districts with an aim to explore and nurture the sporting talents among the tribal youths.

The tourney is being organized in association with the Football Association of Odisha. Altogether 10 teams have been formed to participate in the sporting event.

Official sources said more than 6,000 tribal boys and girls had registered their names to participate in the tournament. The district-level selection was held separately for boys and girls to shortlist the players for various teams. Accordingly, 10 teams have been formed. These include Baripada, Rairangpur, Keonjhar, Sundargarh, Gajapati, Malkangiri, Rayagada, Koraput, Nabarangpur and Kandhamal.

“There are many hidden sporting talents in our tribal areas who do not get a proper platform to showcase their talents. The SDC Cup is a unique platform to explore the hidden talents and nurture them through better training and other facilities,”Sujeet Kumar, advisor of SDC, said.

The league matches of the SDC Cup were played at Baripada and Phulbani on Monday. These will continue till February 28, while the semi-final matches will be played on March 2 at Keonjhar and Sundargarh. Similarly, the final match will be played at Barabati Stadium on March 5, which is scheduled to be attended by chief minister Naveen Patnaik.

Kumar said the SDC will soon sign a memorandum of understanding with the All India Football Federation to facilitate better training for potential sportspersons.

“All the matches are being conducted in a professional manner. The tribal boys and girls with better football skills will be trained in some of the best football clubs of the country,” Kumar said.

Officials said a tribal cultural extravaganza with the participation of tribal boys and girls will also be held on March 5 to mark the final event of the tournament.

The state government had constituted the special development councils (SDC) in nine districts where tribals comprise about 50% of the total population of the district. The SDCs were formed with the objectives of preservation and development of tribal art and culture, recognition of indigenous knowledge and development of tribal youths.
