Title: Goa: Governor worried fewer boys win honours in higher education
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Over 55% of students awarded degrees on Monday were women

PANAJI: Of the 10,670 students who were awarded various degrees at the 32nd annual convocation of the Goa University (GU) on Monday, over 55% were female students, said GU’s vice-chancellor Varun Sahni at the event on Monday. Of the 15 medals awarded for outstanding academic performances, only one awardee was a male. Following this, governor and chancellor of the university Satya Pal Malik said that it is worrisome that boys have been left so far behind in higher education.

“I congratulate all the students who were awarded medals, especially the female students. There was only one male student. It brings us happiness that so many girls have won medals. But it is sad to think where have the boys gone. I want to request them that now girls are winning medals even in wrestling, weightlifting and in every other sport. Now they can enter the Army too,” Malik pointed out.

“Now you need to tighten the belt and try to do some good work. Otherwise you cannot even cook like them. Take inspiration from girls and try to change this situation the next time around,” Malik said.

Sahni said that of the 10,670 students who received their degrees at the 32nd GU convocation, 8,569 are graduates, 1,894 are postgraduates, 130 PG diplomas and 78 PhDs.

“Most pleasing of all, over 55% of the students receiving their degrees today are women. As the only university in our lovely state, we are extremely proud of this statistic in particular,” Sahni said.

Vice-President of India M Venkaiah Naidu, who was the chief guest at the convocation, said that the trend is the same in universities across India. Where ever he is called to attend convocations, 65% to 70% of the gold medalists and honour awardees are women, he said.

“We should feel happy that more girls are getting awards because it is a trend that needs to be encouraged. Women constitute 50% of the population of the country and they are not being given adequate encouragement because of the feeling that what will the girl child do, they have to get married and have children. They feel that is our tradition. But that is not our tradition,” Naidu said. “In the Indian tradition, women always used to be in the forefront,” he added.

Sahni said that the university is now working towards making the varsity campus a green one.

“Goa University is very fortunate to possess a beautiful campus of 403 acres with enough land for development of the university over future generations. We are determined to create a green campus, which is second to none. Our campus is plastic-free,” said Sahni.

Title: TEDxPanaji to stimulate ‘rush’ of ideas
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: An inventor, a street artist and a cancer survivor, among others, are some of the speakers who will showcase stimulating ideas at the fourth edition of TEDxPanaji, an independently organised TED event, will be held on March 8 from 3 to 8pm, at Kala Academy, Panaji.

The theme for this year’s event is ‘rush’, which signifies the emotional unrest that precedes powerful action.

This year, eleven speakers will deliver talks on diverse topics such as protest through art, robotics, waste management, body building, and drones, among others. tnn

Title: ICAR sees potential in local cow breed Shweta kapila
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: An indigenous dairy cow of Goa has shown prominent presence of A2 milk, beleived to have better health benefits when compared to A1 milk. Called Shweta kapila, this local breed has been registered by Old Goa-based ICAR-CCARI.

“The A2 milk is beneficial to health over A1 milk,” said ICAR-CCARI director E B Chakurkar. He said that the institute has collected blood samples and extracted DNA of the cow breed. “It was found that the DNA samples from these cows showed prominent presence of A2 milk protein genes of size 172bp,” he said, adding that further study is required of the breed.

Of the various stray cattle found on the streets of Goa, many are local breeds left by owners due to their low productivity. Their genetic make-up, however, is largely unknown. ICAR-CCARI, during its survey on indigenous cattle breeds of Goa, discovered few local breeds with characteristic features of true breed, one of which was the Shweta kapila.

“This breed has been around in Goa for many years, which is unlike the coloured breed of cows. It is spotless, white in colour, and of medium size. Moreover, it can sustain adverse climatic conditions owing to its genetic make-up,” said Sanjay Udharwar, animal scientist at ICAR-CCARI, Old Goa.

Shweta kapila cows are prevalent in Valpoi and Saakeri regions of the Satari taluka in North Goa as well as in some parts of South Goa. Based on the institute’s findings through farmer interviews, approximately 5,000 animals of this breed are estimated to be in Goa.

“Many farmers believe that the milk from Shweta kapila cows has medicinal properties and is being used to treat gastrointestinal disorders and other health problems. The milk yield of these cows may vary from two to six litres under grazing with minimum feeding inputs,” animal scientist Shivasharanappa N has stated in his report on the breed.

Looking at the tremendous potential of this distinct cow breed in Goa, the institute’s team of scientists has begun work on documentation of this breed based on its phenotypic characteristics. They have also started working on characterisation of A1/A2 milk protein gene from indigenous dairy cattle in this region by molecular biotechnological tests.

“There is an urgent need for proper documentation and registration of the Shweta kapila. The conservation of elite germplasm of the cattle will help farmers shift from cross breed cows to local cows as they produce A2 milk with medicinal properties and which further significantly enhances the milk production of Goa,” the scientists stated.

Title: Recover Rs74.87 lakh from RFO for wrongdoings: Probe panel
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: In an unprecedented decision, a range forest officer (RFO) from Yavatmal has been asked to deposit Rs74.87 lakh for irregularities committed by him in plantation and nursery development works under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS).

Sources said based on information received under RTI, a complaint was lodged by one Sachin Kukkulwar from Jodmoha in Kalamb tehsil with Yavatmal collector alleging financial irregularities by RFO SG Hatkar.

Hatkar was RFO, Hiwri, under Yavatmal forest division in 2017-2018. After the complaint, a committee was set up in March 2019 under Yavatmal collector to probe the matter. The committee found glaring irregularities committed by Hatkar in purchases for raising 6.95 lakh saplings in eight nurseries under Hiwri range. The report was submitted to Yavatmal conservator of forests (CF) Ravindra Wankhede in November 2019.

The committee charged Hatkar with financial bunglings in purchases of material from various parties by violating prescribed procedure. These purchases relate to green nets, teak root stumps, bamboo sticks, sand, soil, manure, polybags, watering of plants among other things.

Some of the works were carried out despite lack of provision in the budget. These irregularities in purchases and other works amounted to over Rs74.87 lakh.

Based on its findings, the committee not only directed to recover entire amount from Hatkar but also recommended action against him under Maharashtra Civil Services (Discipline & Appeal) Rules, 1979, and MGNREG Act, 2005.

“On the recommendation of the collector-led committee, we have issued a challan to Hatkar on January 2, 2020, and asked him to deposit the money in government treasury in 30 days. However, Hatkar has moved Maharashtra Administrative Tribunal (MAT) against the decision,” said Yavatmal deputy conservator of forest (DyCF) Dr BN Pingle.

Hatkar, who has been posted in social forestry department (SFD) in Yavatmal now, has contended that the committee’s recommendation is one-sided as he was not allowed to submit his say.

“The forest department and collector have been asked to file reply in three weeks,” Pingle added.

cracking the whip

* RFO of Hiwri SG Hatkar charged with purchasing material worth Rs74.87 lakh without following rules

* A Jodmoha resident files complaint with collector

* As works pertained to EGS, Yavatmal collector orders inquiry

* Committee found allegations to be true and asked Yavatmal CF to recover amount from RFO

* Bhandara DFO with social forestry was suspended in December on similar charges

Title: Bhubaneswar: Feb 25 deadline for centres to install CCTV for +2 exam
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Tuesday is the deadline to fix cameras

BHUBANESWAR: The Council of Higher Secondary Education (CHSE) has issued an ultimatum (February 25) to all examination centres to install CCTV cameras for higher secondary examination. The higher secondary schools or junior colleges , which will fail to install CVTVs by the deadline, will not be allowed to conduct the annual plus two exam, an official source said. The exam will begin from March 7.

“All 1,142 exam centres have been asked to install CCTV cameras to ensure free and fair exam. But it came to our notice that many college authorities have not yet installed the cameras. We will tag the centres without CCTVs with nearby colleges having such surveillance system. By February 25, the colleges have to inform whether they have completed the process or not,” said CHSE controller of examinations Bijay Kumar Sahu.

Despite several reminders, some junior colleges in the state did install CCTVs. The CHSE decided to put all examination centres under CCTV surveillance to ensure free and fair Plus Two exam in 2019.

Meanwhile, the CHSE has appointed centre superintendents for exam centres. The headmasters of higher secondary schools, which have become exam centres, will be the centre superintendents. If relatives of the principals are engaged in the exam duty, the latter would hand over the charge to senior teaching staff. Besides, a deputy superintendent will also be engaged in examination duty, Sahu said.

To ensure security of question papers, the CHSE has set up examination management hubs (EMHs) across the state. Question papers will be kept in strong rooms in these EMHs with 24x7 security arrangement. Question papers will be sent to the EMHs this week for first-phase exam.

“The district administrations will declare these strong rooms as temporary treasury and ensure security. These strong rooms will operate till the answer sheets of the region reach CHSE office,” he added.

The process of handing over of question papers to hub supervisers must be recorded on the CCTV. Besides, a police van will pilot when question papers will be transferred from the EMHs to the examination centres, an official said.

Title: No respite, fresh heat warning in four districts
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kochi: The heat warning for the state continues with temperatures expected to soar by at least 2-3 Celsius in central districts of Kottayam and Alappuzha and northern districts of Kannur and Kozhikode . These districts have been recording high temperatures of more than 35C since several days.

Dry weather prevailed in many places while Cial Kochi, Karipur airport, Kottayam and Punalur reported the lowest minimum temperature of 23C. Kannur recorded the highest of 37C on Monday while Cial Kochi and Punalur in Kollam district recorded more than 36 Celsius.

The Kerala state disaster management authority (KSDMA) has asked people to avoid direct exposure to sun rays between 11am and 3pm, especially in districts where the warning has been issued.

The labour department has also issued warning to farm workers and construction workers toiling in open against exposure to sunlight during these hours. They have advised people to look out for symptoms indicating heat exhaustion, sun burns. If the symptoms indicate heat stroke, it needs medical intervention. Schools have been asked to ensure plenty of clean drinking water for students during exams.

Title: MLA seeks law to sack govt staff over bribery
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Jaipur: A Congress legislator on Monday demanded the enactment of a law to dismiss government servants caught accepting bribe by the Anti-Corruption Bureau.

Raising a special mention during the Zero Hour in the assembly, Sangod constituency MLA Bharat Singh cited a 2019 Transparency International report to say that Rajasthan ranks first in the country in terms of corruption and those caught taking bribe rejoin their duty "with pride after serving a jail term".

Singh urged the House Chair to allow a day-long discussion to know the views of other assembly members. In the present arrangement, the state government's resolution to eliminate corruption seems impossible, he said.

It is necessary an arrangement is made to dismiss those from service who are caught taking bribe by the ACB.

The MLA said 2,067 government employees and public representatives were caught taking bribe by the ACB in last five years. However, challans were issued only in 986 cases and the rest were still under consideration, he said, adding some of the accused are absconding.

He claimed that those caught taking bribe include officers at the level of the chief secretary, IAS, IPS and village sarpanchs. PTI

Title: DMC to clean up Sahastradhara dumping ground
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Dehradun: Officials of the Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) on Monday inspected its old trenching ground at Sahastradhara road and announced a plan to remove the trash that still lies at the site. The DMC stopped using the dumping ground in 2017, but the garbage was never removed.

“We inspected the site today and tried to analyse its condition. Soon, the tonnes of waste lying there will be removed. Our aim is to remove all the waste there and level the ground. However, we have not decided what to convert the site into once it is cleaned up,” said DMC commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey.

A source indicated that the site might be converted into a martyrs’ memorial public park once the waste is shifted.

Interestingly, the Supreme Court had directed the local administration to treat the waste in Sahastradhara and convert the site into a public park back in May, 2014. If the apex court orders had been followed, the facility would have been ready by now.

The municipal corporation is currently dumping waste at the Shishambara Waste Management Plant. Local residents there have been protesting for months to shift the dumping ground to the city’s outskirts as it is causing health complications among those living in the vicinity.

Title: Authentication of beneficiary accounts with Aadhaar starts
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nashik: The process of authenticating the accounts of the beneficiaries of loan waiver schemes with their Aadhaar number has started in the district.

“The process of authenticating the accounts has started in Chandori village in Niphad taluka and Sonambe village in Sinnar taluka,” said deputy district registrar, Nashik, Gautam Balsane.

Balsane was in the two villages to see if the authentication process was being conducted as per proces and if farmers were facing any issues. Over 778 farmers were identified from the two villages as beneficiaries for the loan waiver scheme.

“Once we verify the accounts of the beneficiaries with their Aadhaar cards, the loan amount will be waived from their bank accounts,” said Balsane. According to the state government’s loan waiver scheme, farmers having total outstanding loan worth Rs 2 lakh are to benefit from the scheme. Around 1.47 lakh farmers from the district are expected to benefit from the loan waiver scheme.

Various nationalized, private and cooperative banks, which had provided loans to the farmers, were asked to upload the Aadhaar number associated with every account. Thereafter, the process of clubbing all the loans linked to one Aadhaar number was carried out.

“The banks have come up with the list of farmers who fit the criteria for loan waiver. Farmers will have to look for their names in the list and then go either to the Aaple Sarkar Seva Kendra, consumer facilitation centre, private and nationalized banks or the Nashik District Central Cooperative Bank to authenticate their Aadhaar number with the unique number allotted to them,” said Balsane.

All the banks across the district are expected to publish the list of beneficiaries by February 28. The district administration is taking efforts to complete the authentication process in a week, so that the loan disbursement process begins soon.

Once the verification is complete, the beneficiaries receive a government letter stating that their account will be credited with the amount they had taken as loan. Farmers will then be able to obtain loan for crops to be cultivated in the kharif season starting from June or with the onset of rainfall.

“After the farmer’s account is credited with the aid from the government, he can proceed to obtain a new loan that will be given to him in April / May or as and when required,” said Madhukar Tarle, a farmer.

Title: Pvt agency chosen to develop Santa Monica jetty
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: Goa Tourism Development Corporation (GTDC) has finalised a vendor to develop the Santa Monica jetty in Panaji. An area of 1,000sqm will be leased out to a private player while the government will earn Rs 1.2 crore annually.

Tourism, secretary J Ashok Kumar confirmed to TOI that the vendor has been finalised through a tender. GTDC will proceed with the formal appointment of the vendor after approval is received from the government.

The vendor will build facilities like restrooms for tourists visiting the jetty and also construct a restaurant and host other commercially-viable activities.

The jetty was reconstructed over three years ago, but hardly offers any facilities for tourists though footfalls even during non-peak tourist season are impressive.

During season time, the crowd at the jetty is maddening and leads to traffic chaos in the evenings— and there are no traffic policemen posted there to ensure the safety of pedestrians, complain tourism stakeholders.

In 2016, GTDC’s plans for development of the jetty were halted, when the government did not approve its plan to lease the entire area – jetty plus multi-level car park— to a single party.

While it wanted to float a fresh tender, it could not, owing to construction of the Atal Sethu as some building material was stored there.

Title: Ratan Lal: Head constable Ratan Lal who always took up tough challenges
Content:
Head constable Ratan Lal who died on Monday during clashes over CAA in Maujpur, northeast Delhi. (PTI Photo)

NEW DELHI: On February 27 last year, head constable Ratan Lal was the talking point among his colleagues and seniors because his moustache was similar to Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman, who had shot down a Pak F-16 fighter jet that day.Exactly a year later, the 42-year-old policeman died a heroic death while bravely fighting rioters in northeast Delhi. He had joined Delhi Police in 1998 as a constable.Lal was currently posted in Gokulpuri. The ACP he reported to was also injured in the riots. Known to be a confident and brave cop, Lal led many raids conducted by Gokulpuri police in the last few years because of his strong built.“An outstanding policeman with indefatigable attitude and tremendous positive energy,” recalled additional DCP Brijender Yadav to whom Lal reported to a few years ago. Yadav, in his profile as ACP (Gokulpuri), had given many citations to Lal for his excellent performance.Born in a middle-class family in Sikar, Rajasthan, Lal was the eldest among three brothers and a sister. He lived with his wife and three children — two girls aged 11 and 12 and a boy aged 8 — in north Delhi’s Burari. He had promised his children that they would celebrate Holi at their village in Tihawali. He had lost his father a decade ago. His mother has not been informed of his death as yet.“My brother-in law informed us about his death and we immediately switched off the TV so that our mother does not see anything. She knows we are hiding something from her as people are coming to meet us more than usual. She doesn’t know how to use social media, so she cannot get to know of his death online,” said a family member.Speaking to TOI, Lal’s younger brother Dinesh said, “He was a patriot. He wanted to don the uniform from the very beginning. He had immense patience. We never saw him scream or shout at people. He last came over a month ago when a relative had passed away.”Dinesh appealed to people not to be violent. “I lost my brother today, but tomorrow it could be anyone else,” he added.Lal’s colleagues said he would always volunteer for difficult and dangerous assignments. “He was instrumental in nabbing the accused in a gruesome rape of two tribal women in 2013 and in an act of vandalism committed by a group of wrestlers at a restaurant in Seemapuri,” said an officer.His villagers have demanded a “martyr” status for him and that he be consigned to flames with full state honours. They have also demanded that the government school in Tihawali be named after Lal.

Title: Six cobras with mouths stitched and glued rescued from Madhya Pradesh's Betul
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The snakes were rescued from a mela in Betul

BHOPAL: Six cobras were rescued by an NGO – People for Animals, from Mahashivaratri mela near Ranipur area in Betul district. Their mouths were either sealed with glue or stitched with nylon threads.

Young mechanical engineer Adil Kahn, who is working with this NGO informed SDO, Sarni, Vijay Kumar about snake charmers and raided the mela.

His team was able to catch six snakes from a group of young boys. Five were cobras and one was a sand boa. Officials found that the cobra's were weak and in molting period. Charmers had broken their fangs (teeth responsible for venom movement). “They had used strong glue to seal their mouth besides stitching their mouths with nylon thread,” said Khan adding snakes were tortured.

Ranipur range forest officer Sachin Gupta and his team decided to take the snakes to the nearest veterinary hospital (Betul) with Adil Khan.

Dr M Sinha operated upon and treated those snakes. All six have been kept under observation. They would be released in the wild after are cured.

Read this story in Bengali

Title: Erode: 2 Russel’s vipers rescued from well
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

ERODE: Fire and rescue services personnel rescued two Russell ’s vipers, a species of venomous snake, from a 50-ft deep well near Bhavani in Erode district on Monday.

Villagers, who found the snakes floating in the well owned by Anil Rathinam , 50, of Thottipalayam village near Bhavani, initally thought they were pythons and informed the fire and rescue department in Bhavani.

On reaching the spot, a group of rescue personnel entered into the well and caught one of the snakes using hooks and rods. “When we brought the snake out of the well, we realised that it was a Russell’s viper,” a rescue personnel said. Later, they rescued another snake too. The snakes were released in a reserve forest in the Andhiyur forest division. tnn

Title: YCMOU to certify jail inmates’ skill projects
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nashik: The Yashwantrao Chavan Maharashtra Open University (YCMOU) has decided to recognise the skill-based projects done by jail inmates so that the convicts can get employment in industries or begin their own work after their release from prisons.

The inmates usually prefer to learn mobile repairing, plumbing, making Paithani sarees, bedsheets, Ganesh idols, soaps, bakery products etc. Some of them also cook in the central kitchen.

“The projects undertaken by the convicts in our jails are efficient and skill-based. They will help the inmates build on their confidence and reform their lives once they are out of the prison,” said E Vayunandan, the YCMOU vice-chancellor. The varsity was approached by an Aurangabad-based NGO called Samta Foundation that has been working on reformation of convicts over the past three years.

Deepak Loya, the head of prisoner reform project, told TOI: “There are several convicts who work hard and take part in skill-based projects. They hope to get back on their feet once out of jail. Our objective is to ensure that they do not commit another crime after serving their sentence.”

There are 45 prisons in Maharashtra, but they do not provide any certificate to the convicts, added Loya. The certificates that will be provided to the convicts will be from the YCMOU and Samta Foundation.

Title: Annual income stipulation of prospective parents relaxed
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The social justice department has brought out some amendments in the guidelines for adoption . The major change that has been brought is that annual income of the prospective parents has been brought down to Rs 2.5 lakh from Rs 3 lakh.

The governing body of the state adoption resource agency has decided to bring down the annual income stipulation since people who had come forward for adoption had alleged that their applications were rejected since they could not prove the annual income.

Health minister K K Shailaja said after the meeting that “if the parents cannot produce the income certificate then they should produce certificates to prove that they have assets worth Rs 50 lakh without any liabilities”. The income limit had adversely affected adoptions in the state and hence it was decided to bring down the annual income limit, she added.

The district adoption committees have been asked to scrutinize the applications once again as per the new amendment.

Title: Punjab: IAF officer killed, NCC cadet hurt in Patiala microlight plane crash
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Remains of the NCC aircraft, which crashed after take-off

PATIALA: An IAF officer was killed and a trainee pilot injured when a microlight aircraft crashed in the Army area, immediately after take-off from the Patiala Aviation Club airstrip on Monday afternoon.

Group Captain Gurpreet Singh Cheema, commander of the 3rd Punjab Air Squadron of National Cadet Corps (NCC), was killed while trainee cadet Vipan Yadav was seriously injured. Group Captain Cheema was on deputation to the NCC unit.

The aircraft, which was used to teach flying to NCC cadets, lost flight after its engine stalled immediately after take-off at around 2 pm. The left-wing of the aircraft hit an eucalyptus tree along the Patiala-Sangrur highway before it fell inside the Army unit fence.

Group Capt Cheema, a former MiG-21 pilot, and Yadav were pulled out of the aircraft and taken to the Military Hospital, where Cheema reportedly succumbed to a head injury. Yadav was later shifted to Command Hospital, Chandigarh.

Title: ‘India, US are united in fight on Islamic terror’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

US President Donald Trump. (AFP)

NEW DELHI: US President Donald Trump on Monday reaffirmed cooperation with India in the fight against radical Islamic terrorism , underlining a key area unaffected by ups and downs over trade and tariffs as security agencies collaborate closely on counter-terrorism.

“The United States and India are also firmly united in our ironclad resolve to defend our citizens from the threat of radical Islamic terrorism,” Trump said at Motera Stadium with US agencies often playing a crucial role in assisting terrorism investigations in India as after major terror strikes like 26/11.

“Both of our countries have been hurt by the pain and turmoil of terrorism and that terrorism brings. Under my administration, we unleashed the full power of the American military on bloodthirsty killers of Islamic State in Iraq and in Syria. Today, the IS territorial caliphate has been 100% destroyed. And the monster known as Al Baghdadi , the founder and leader of IS, is dead,” Trump said.

In addition, he defended the US’s measures to secure its borders. “In the United States, we have also made clear that while our country will always welcome newcomers who share our values and love our people, our borders will always be closed to terrorists and terrorism and to any form of extremism,” he said.

PM Narendra Modi repeated the sentiment. “We are together in our fight against terror. We are inspired by a long-term vision. Our cooperation will grow and we will fulfil the dreams of our nations,” he said. The cooperation has also found voice in military joint exercises and sharing of logistics.

Title: 2 more Indian crew on cruise ship test positive for Covid-19
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: Two more Indian crew on board quarantined cruise ship Diamond Princess at Yokohama in Japan tested positive for Covid-19 positive on Monday, taking the number of Indians infected by the virus in the ship, to 14.

After disembarking passengers, the mandatory test for all crew members on board was conducted on February 20 and results of the PCR test is being released in a phased manner. Four Indians tested positive two days ago and two more names were added on Monday.

Indian crew members on board complained that proper quarantine measures were not carried out inside the ship. A couple of those who were later quarantined after they tested positive were having food with the other crew members in the common mess area.

There is fear of the numbers climbing as the official Twitter handle of the Indian Embassy in Japan has stated that the results of all crew members will be out by February 25 or 26. In a series of tweets and messages on Twitter and Facebook, the Indian embassy confirmed that all 14 Indians who tested positive for Covid-19 are responding well to treatment.

“Indian Embassy is awaiting test results and is coordinating with Japanese authorities and ship management company for safe return of all Indian nationals who do not test positive for Covid-19,” they stated on their Facebook page.

It received strong replies from the crew on board Diamond Princess.

“Many of us have already completed quarantine and tested negative. Are you waiting for all of us to test positive?” asked a crew. “Why is the embassy not replying to our mails. You are saying that you are in touch with us but when we mail you with our concerns, we are not getting any response from anybody,” said another.

Responding to the messages, the embassy thanked the crew for their patience and reassured that they are working on their early and safe return.

Stating that there has been no official announcement on crew members affected by Covid-19, the crew said that 64 have tested positive till Monday.

Princess Cruises, the parent company of the ship that provided daily updates on the status of the quarantine on their official website has not given any update after February 20, raising concern among crew members.

“On Monday the (ship) captain announced that Philippines will evacuate its crew members on Tuesday and asked Philippines crew to be ready with their baggage. We await a similar message for the Indian crew members. It’s a week since we filled up the forms sent by the Indian Embassy in Japan asking interest to prematurely leave the ship if the government arranged a chartered flight,” Anbalagan, 41, a chef from Madurai said.

Title: 2 woman corporators upset after party snub
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nashik: Two woman corporators — Priyanka Ghate of the BJP and the Shiv Sena’s Poonam Mogre — lashed out their respective party leaderships in the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) for ignoring their names for the new member positions on the standing committee.

Both corporators questioned their senior party functionaries outside the House before the general body meeting started. Ghate also tendered her resignation to the municipal commissioner, party MLAs and city president of the party.

She also staged sit-in agitations along with her supporters at the mayor Satish Kulkarni’s official residence, but the mayor was not home. After half-an-hour Ghate called off her agitation.

Speaking to reporters, Ghate said the new corporators are being sidelined within the party. “We never worked against the party, but we have not been given any opportunity or any posts in the NMC in the past three years. Therefore, I have given my resignation to the municipal commissioner, the party MLAs as well as the BJP city president,” she said.

Meanwhile, Shiv Sena corporator Poonam Mogre said that though she was not disappointed in her party, she felt that the new corporators were being ignored while opportunities for various NMC posts were given. The party leadership should give an opportunity to the new members and consider their names while appointing members to various committees and posts, Mogre said.

The mayor had called a special meeting of the NMC general body on Monday to appoint new members on the standing committee. Sensing trouble, he hurriedly announced the names of the eight new standing committee members and concluded the House proceedings.

The mayor announced the names of eight of 16 members, which included four members from BJP, two from Sena and one each from Congress and NCP.

The eight new members are Hemant Shetti, Supriya Khode, Rakesh Donde, Varsha Bhalerao, Satyabhama Gadekar, Sudhakar Badgujar, Rahul Dive and Samina Meman.

BJP corporator Dinkar Patil said BJP is a disciplined party and no injustice is done on anyone. Hence, there is no chance that the party is ignoring new members.

Title: Sriram, Wafa fail to appear before court
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Sriram Venkitaraman IAS and Wafa Firoz , the accused in the road accident that led to the death of journalist K M Basheer , failed to appear before the chief judicial magistrate court here on Monday.

The advocate of both the accused gave a leave application citing personal reasons for not appearing before the court. The court later posted the case for April 16.

On February 15, the CJM-3 had served summons notice on the IAS officer to appear before it on February 24 for the hearing in the case. Venkitaraman is facing charges of culpable homicide not amounting to murder along with other charges of drunk driving, damaging public property and destroying evidence.

Notice was also served to Venkitaraman’s friend Wafa, who is arraigned as the second accused. Venkitaraman was allegedly driving the car owned by Wafa when the accident occurred. She was sitting in the passenger’s seat. She has been charged with the offence of abetment of crime as she allowed Venkitaraman to drive the car though he was allegedly drunk.

Police had failed to take Venkitaraman for blood alcohol test immediately after the accident and delayed it by more than 10 hours. The state government had placed Venkitaraman under suspension after the opposition raised questions on his act.

Title: Fireworks unit blast: 3 more dead
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: The death toll in the blast at a fireworks unit near Sattur in Virudhunagar district last week has risen to six, as three more people, who were undergoing treatment at the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) in Madurai, succumbed on Monday.

Those who died on Monday have been identified as V Vijayakumar from Chinnakamanpatti, K Muthulakshmi and S Valliammal from Mettamalai. Meanwhile, police had registered a case against five people based on a complaint from the village administrative officer, S Senthilkumar. The accused were identified R Prabakaran, owner of the unit, his relatives Dharmaraj, his wife and son D Padmavathi and D Rajkumar and foreman Dhanasekaran. Prabakaran had entrusted his relatives to run the unit.tnn

Title: Complaints by GFP, Cong sent to collector
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Panaji: The state election commission (SEC) has forwarded the complaint filed by the Goa Forward Party ( GFP ) to the North Goa collector for an inquiry.

GFP on Sunday filed a complaint alleging violation of the code of conduct by chief minister Pramod Sawant and some cabinet ministers. Congress also filed complaints with SEC and the chief secretary over the alleged violation by the chief minister who flagged off the carnival parade and delivered a speech along with tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar and town and country planning (TCP) minister Chandrakant Kavalekar.

Congress referred to SEC’s letter to the director of tourism which states that “no political functionary should inaugurate or close the function or deliver speech throughout the event”. “The chief minister of Goa has not only flagged off the parade, but has also given a speech which was political and targeting a certain section of society,” general secretary of Goa Congress Pradesh Committee (GPCC), Amarnath Panjikar, stated in a letter to the SEC.

In the letter addressed to the chief secretary, Panjikar complained that the director of tourism, under alleged political pressure, did not follow instructions of the SEC and allowed political functionaries to directly participate and use the carnival at Panaji and Margao for political propaganda. “Strict action needs to be initiated against the tourism department,” stated the Congress’ letter to the chief secretary.

Title: Refrain from submitting forged data, warns FRA
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Aurangabad: The Fee Regulatory Authority ( FRA ) has warned colleges against submitting fake information, especially those related to the availability of teachers while submitting the fee proposal.

The warning came after a section of institutions were found to have submitted incorrect information regarding the staff approval and their continuation.

In the latest directive, the FRA has asked colleges to recheck and re-verify the authenticity of all information including staff data while submitting the proposal for the academic year 2020-21.

The authority has also brought it to the notice to institutions the provision of six-month jail term for furnishing wrong information as per the Maharashtra Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions (Regulation of Admission and Fees) Act, 2015.

“After cross-checking, it has come to the notice of the authority that information particularly related to approval of staff and their continuation till the relevant period till March 31, 2019 is prima-facie wrong/incorrect. Please note that along with fees proposal, the college/institute has submitted affidavit certifying that information is true and correct,” the FRA said.

While asking for re-verification of proposals submitted for the academic year 2020-21, the FRA has said the latest order is applicable to those proposals that have been decided or disposed as well as along for those awaiting approval.

As per section 20(2) of the act, whoever, provides incorrect information, fabricated and fake books of accounts, fraudulent documents, and such other evidence to the authorities whether or not the act is done for profit or gain, is said to have committed an offence and shall, on conviction be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months.

Title: Official on the run in molestation case skips panel hearing
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Indore: A local complaints committee (LCC) under Vishaka Guidelines on Monday recorded statements of witnesses including the complainant in a case filed against suspended deputy commissioner of cooperative department.

Accused Rajesh Kumar Kshatri, who is absconding since an FIR lodged against him at MG Road police station, failed to appear before the committee prompting it to complete ex-parte proceedings.

A government employee had last month filed molestation complaint against Kshatri and taking cognizance of it, the state government suspended him. On January 28, MG Road police lodged an FIR against him and also raided his house to arrest him but he was not there.

According to LCC members, Kshatri was not receiving notices and summon was pasted at his house giving him last chance to appear before the committee to file his reply on allegations made against him. On Monday, the committee had asked the complainant and other witnesses to record their statements and furnish proof including mobile recordings and messages while Kshatri was issued a notice to challenge the same.

The complainant has alleged that Kshatri had been harassing her for the past one year, used to send text messages to her late in night. He also tried to molest her in his cabin on pretext of meeting for an official work.

“Kshatri failed to appear before the committee as he was given chance first to challenge the allegations made against him and second to present his side against the statements and other proof furnished by the witnesses. The committee then carried out the proceedings one-sided,” an LCC member said.

Sources said the committee has completed entire proceedings related to the case and is likely to deliver its verdict within a week.

Title: ‘CAB wouldn’t have been passed if AIADMK, PMK had oppossed it’’
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: Stating that Citizenship (Amendment) Act would not have been passed if the AIADMK and PMK had opposed it, CPI(M) politburo member G Ramakrishnan questioned “If welfare of the people or their alliance dharma with the BJP is important for AIADMK and PMK?” Ramakrishnan was addressing reporters after releasing a booklet titled ‘Kudiurimai Thirutha Sattama allathu Kudi Kedukkum Thittama’ (CAA or scheme for citizenship destruction) that was prepared by the CPI(M) state council.

The 16-page Tamil booklet released was received by representatives from Tamilnadu Muslim Munnetra Kazhagam, Manithaneya Makkal Katchi and Madurai mavatta Aikkiya Jamath Peravai. “The booklet is to support the ongoing strong protests across the State and India against CAA,” the former CPI(M) state secretary said. He stated that the CAA, NRC and NPR are tactics of the BJP to implement the RSS ideology of ‘Hindu Rashtra’.

Stating that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah are determined to implement CAA, NRC and NPR despite a losing streak in the assembly elections in Bihar Odisha, Andhra, Telangana and Delhi, he added that the CPI(M) and those opposing it will continue protesting till the three initiatives are defeated. “It is not too late,” he said and added that the meeting to be conducted by the party in Chennai on Wednesday will serve as such a platform.

Ramakrishnan said that many poor villagers from rural Tamil Nadu migrated to cities like Kolkata, Mumbai, Delhi, Bengaluru and Chennai many years ago for their livelihood. “What certificate would they be carrying? Their children and grandchildren may know the place of birth of their ancestors who migrated but not the date. In that case they will be marked as doubtful citizens and detained in detention camps like the ones in Assam,” he said.

Saying so, he claimed that 25 persons lodged in detention camps in Assam have died and it includes Hindus. “These acts are not against Muslims alone. They are against the poor,” he added. He said that CAA, NRC and NPR will destroy the vision of a secular, democratic and economically independent India that our forefathers had when the country got independence. The government of Tamil Nadu should pass resolutions against CAA and NPR, he reiterated.

He accused the AIADMK government of contradictory stands on NPR. Stating that revenue minister R B Udhayakumar had replied the DMK that they have written to the Centre seeking clarification on three questions (10, 13 and 14) out of 21 questions in the NPR, he pointed out that without getting the clarifications AIADMK has announced that NPR will be conducted in June. He asked the government not to cheat people with their drama.

Title: Defence land now encroachment-free, 28 structures razed
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Mhow: A total of 28 illegal structures encroaching upon defence land were brought down in an anti-encroachment drive at Mhow on Monday. Defence estate officer (DEO) Neha Gupta led her team assisted by the team of Mhow Cantonment Board, police and administration in demolishing the 28 shops constructed in the premises of Bungalow no. 86 (also called Barwani Bungalow) situated near government high school at Mhow.

A large police force reached Mhow on two buses from Indore in early morning hours and all policemen were positioned between Hariphatak square and the school.

As soon as the magistrate naib tehsildar Ritesh Joshi arrived at the spot, DEO Neha Gupta ordered her team to start the action on the illegal construction. The residents and shop owners reached there on getting information that their shops were being razed. They tried to hamper the action but were restricted by the troops.

Mhow MLA Usha Thakur reached there as half of the shops had been flattened. Thakur asked Gupta to give some time to the residents to evict and remove the structures but Gupta told her that they had already been given time of more than a year. On this, they both had a heated exchange of words for over 15 minutes.

Gupta agreed to give two hours to the shop owners for removing their own constructions but by then all structures had been razed.

Usha Thakur raised the issue of Khan Colony where a large number of multistorey houses have been constructed on defence land and asked Gupta that why doesn’t the department take action in that area.

Title: 6 minors held for vandalizing cars in Mhow
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Mhow: Kishanganj police have arrested six minors in connection to the vandalism incident which had rocked Kishanganj on Sunday. Seven have been booked in the case so far who were identified on the basis of CCTV footage.

Accused Appa alias Rahul Lodhi, 20, is on the run. A scooter and a bike have been recovered from the accused that were used in the crime.

Kishanganj police station in charge Shashikant Chorasiya told TOI that the accused revealed all of them had consumed bhang and under its influence, they drove through colonies hurling stones on cars and houses.

Chorasiya said that the CCTV cameras installed in about half a dozen houses in all three colonies led to the arrests.

Residents of three colonies at Mhowgaon had their worst nightmare when bike-borne youths damaged their cars and window panes by pelting it with stones on the intervening night of Friday and Saturday. The miscreants riding on five to six two-wheelers broke the windshields of over 80 cars in Jawaharnagar, Shantinagar and Supercity. Some of them had their faces covered.

Residents were worried as some of them were of the view that if the miscreants are not arrested, they could attempt even more harmful acts in the colonies.

Title: Survey on number of damaged cycles
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nashik: The fate of the smart city development corporation’s rent-a-cycle project hangs in the balance as besides the significant drop in the number of people opting for the rides, the cycles are either missing from the stands or are damaged beyond repair.

CEO of Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL) Prakash Thavil said, “When the project was initiated, there were around 900 takers for the cycles. Now, hardly 100 people opt for the cycle rides. We are creating awareness among the residents about the project. We have also joined hands with Nashik Cyclists Foundation to create awareness.”

Thavil said they would conduct a survey to find out how many cycles have been damaged. A senior official from HYPL said, “It is really unfortunate that over 100 cycles have been damaged. After all, it is public property. The government should have taken some steps to keep a check on miscreants damaging cycles.”

“There is no question of winding up the project. We need to brand and market the rent-a-cycle project properly to evoke interest among citizens,” said the official. tnn

Title: New team visits site, to submit report soon
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Thrissur: A new team led by Thrissur deputy transport commissioner M Suresh, on Monday, visited the accident site at Avinashi in Tamil Nadu , where a container truck collided with a KSRTC bus. The team was appointed on the directive of transport minister A K Saseendran.

The team inspected the site in detail. An inspection report will be submitted to the transport commissioner, officials said. Allegations rose that the report by the Palakkad enforcement RTO had no scientific facts. The transport minister then appointed a new team led by Suresh and enforcement RTOs Shaji Madhavan and P Sivakumar. Motor vehicle inspectors Appu P M, Padmalal P T, N Vinod Kumar, Tamil Nadu RTO and police officers also joined the inspection. The RTO enforcement report found that the truck driver may have fallen asleep or while negotiating a curve at high speed, he may have lost control of the vehicle.

The container truck had collided into the KSRTC bus on the Salem-Kochi national highway near Avinashi on February 20 at 3.30am. The accident killed 19 people and many were injured.

LIC expedites claims

Kochi: In a humane gesture, the Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) has processed insurance claims of six persons who lost their lives in the Avinashi bus mishap. A total of 32 claims were processed disregarding holidays, and cheques were handed over to the families of the deceased. The policies of KSRTC employee V R Baiju and others including Sivakumar, Joffy Paul, Gopika T G, Emcy Mathew, Jismon Shaju were cleared while that of the deceased KSRTC driver V D Gireesh’s is being processed and will soon be cleared.

Title: Junk food continues to be sold on school campuses
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: While most of the schools in the city have stopped sale of junk food items and restricted its consumption by students inside their campuses, few schools continue to sell junk food items on their campuses.

Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) recently has made draft regulations titled Food Safety and Standards (Safe food and healthy diets for school children) Regulations, 2019, which bans sales of food items containing salt, sugar and fats in high levels, in school campuses. Junk food cannot even be displayed or sold within 50 metres of the school campuses, according to the draft regulations.

Some of the private schools continue to sell junk food in campuses despite recent circulars sent to schools by food safety officials from Madurai district restricting them to do so. Recently, junk food items were sold in large quantities in a popular private school near Koodalpudur during an event, which saw a participation of students and parents from various other schools. Students purchased high caloric drinks, fried food and packed food consisting high salt level.

M Senthil Nathan, president of matriculation schools in Madurai district, said that most of the schools have stopped selling junk food in campuses. However, they could not check sales of junk food in shops outside their schools. “Consumption of junk food has come down due to the increased awareness among parents and students in higher standards like IXth and Xth. However, children in lower classes continue to consume junk food items outside the campus as they are not aware of the risk,” he said.

A food safety official said that apart from sending circulars, they also conducted awareness meeting involving private and government school teachers in Madurai district. They will soon conduct inspections in school premises and areas around the schools to ensure that junk food items are not sold.

“Teachers can inform them if they come across traders near schools selling junk food items. We will take appropriate action against the trader,” he said.

Title: Licences of over 55k drivers suspended
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: More than 55,000 licences have been suspended/cancelled by the transport department based on recommendations made by police units across nine southern districts in 2019. The action was taken for not following traffic rules and causing accidents due to negligence.

Transport department officials said that 76,554 recommendations were made by nine police units, of which action was taken on 72% of the recommendations.

Madurai district police unit has made the highest number of recommendations for suspension/cancellation in 2019, while the lowest number was recorded in Kanyakumari district.

More than 15,000 licences were cancelled/suspended in Madurai district, while it was around 1,000 in Kanyakumari.

An official from Madurai district said that they are recommending cancellation/suspension only in cases of extreme negligence, causing deaths and repeated violations. While all drivers faced such action, bike riders faced the maximum recommendations. “No one is deterred by penalty as most of the common offences attract only Rs 100. But, when they realise that licences will be suspended for a few months and they cannot ride/drive their vehicles, it creates a strong deterrence,” he said.

The official added that details of suspended licences is updated online by transport authorities.

Every single recommendation made by Kanyakumari and Sivaganga districts was accepted by the concerned road transport officials, whereas 99.95% recommendations made by the Ramanathapuram police was accepted. But, in Dindigul and Tuticorin districts, only around 50% of the recommendations were accepted.

Police officials say that action on licence helps deter erring motorists as the recent rule by the road transport department increasing penalty for traffic violation has not been implemented in Tamil Nadu so far. The enhanced penalty is only followed in cases of drunk and drive, since the cases are directly dealt by courts, they say.

Title: Deolali cantonment board to fix defunct streetlights, install new ones
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nashik: The Cantonment Board, Deolali (CBD), has kicked off the process to repair 3,000 defunct streetlights in the entire cantonment area.

The CBD officials said that apart from repairing the defunct lights they would also erect more than 250 new LED streetlights with poles at various places.

“We have started identifying the obsolete streetlights and repairing them in the cantonment area. This will ease commuting at night,” said Ajay Kumar, the board’s chief executive officer.

According to the officials, the Cantonment Board, Deolali has decided to use more than Rs 40 lakh for the repair of the old and installation of the new streetlights.

“There are 3,314 existing streetlight poles that we are examining during the night and repairing during the day in case they are faulty,” the officials added.

The repair and new installations will take about a month.

“We are making provisions for over 250 new fixtures that will be spread across the cantonment area. The whole project should get over by March 31,” the officials said.

Sushil Chavan, a resident of the Deolali cantonment area, appreciated the board’s actions.

“I finish my work only after dark every day and my residence is in the interiors. If the streetlights are repaired, it will be very helpful for me. The LED lights will be more efficient. Also, there is still the lurking danger of leopards,” he said.

Another resident of the cantonment area applauded the installation of new streetlights.

“I work as a night watchman in one of the housing societies. I have to commute late at night to work. There are many areas along the way that do not have any streetlights. Since the board is putting up more poles, my problem will be resolved,” said Viraj.

Title: Communal violence erupts after years, few black spots
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

A man pushes his scooter after violence errupts in Trilokpuri

NEW DELHI: Minor flare-ups involving two communities are not that uncommon in the capital but full-fledged communal riots are not frequent. It was in 2014 that the city witnessed large-scale violence in the Trilokpuri riots. Seven years later, communal violence has come back to haunt the capital as the anti-CAA protests taken a violent turn.

There had been no casualties in the Trilokpuri riots though over three dozen people were injured in the clashes and subsequent police action. At that time, a mata ki chowki was organised near a mosque in the area on the night of Diwali. What started off as arguments between two groups over playing of loudspeaker turned into a scuffle and led to stone-pelting. The cops managed to control the situation but violence erupted yet again and this time it was fierce and led to instances of firing.

TOI spoke to seasoned policemen who said that apart from the 1984 riots, there was one instance of large-scale violence during a riot which took place a decade prior to that in west Delhi. “Around a dozen people were killed after two communities clashed,” an officer recalled.

In recent times, the police have been often able to control the situation before it spun out of control. After the Trilokpuri riots, Delhi Police had formed Aman committees, comprising elderly members and religious preachers from different communities. They have often been police’s troubleshooters and helped defuse tension after the police contained the violence.

Members of two communities had clashed in north-west Delhi’s Sangam Park area in June 2018. Around six people were injured in the stone-pelting leading to tension in the area. The locality was a volatile one with a history of communal tension.

In 2016, two communities had clashed after a minor girl from the Valmiki community was molested by a man from another religion. The cops were vigilant and moved swiftly to control the situation when they clashed again in 2018.

Another cop narrated a recent incident in which a temple was vandalised in central Delhi last year but cops managed to defuse the situation. In both incidents, elderly members of both communities played a pivotal role in restoring peace.

Title: Magnificent MP needs infra push to leap to tourism top 5
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Indore: Madhya Pradesh, eyeing spot in top five tourist destinations in the country, has less than 500 hotels having 25 rooms capacity while top 34 tourist destinations lack any form of recreational activities, showed a survey.

Khajuraho is the only tourist destination with presence of branded hotels with last one to come up in 2008 since then there has been no influx of branded chains at any tourist destinations in the state, the survey showed.

First-of-its-kind hospitality survey by Madhya Pradesh Tourism Board has revealed a wide infrastructure gap in tourism sector and stressed on urgent need to bring in more branded hotels at tourist destinations and promote recreational activities to attract footfall.

“The survey was done to look into all aspects where we are doing good and where we have failed to perform. This will give us a line to work and improve to achieve the desired target in promoting tourism,” said a senior official from tourism department.

A total of 1,480 hotels were surveyed, of which just 33 per cent were found to have minimum 25 rooms. Indore followed by Ujjain has the highest number of standard hotels, the survey showed.

State tourism board in association with the government of India conducted a hospitality survey to ascertain tourism infrastructure and measures to bridge the gap, a move seen promoting tourism and aiming to scale up to top five tourist destinations in the country.

Aiming to attract investors, the state tourism department has picked up land parcels and notified water bodies to bring in new players and branded hotels with slew of subsidies and promotional sops.

The department claimed that in past 4-5 years, an average of 80-100 hotels are coming up in the state every year looking at untapped potential.

The official said, “We are also working to promote scenic and outskirt places as wedding destinations owing to encouraging enquires and feedback from hoteliers. Space constraints in cities have led people move to outskirts and rural areas for hosting functions.”

The survey also included detailed study of 34 tourist destinations and found them having negligible recreational activities such as ropeway, amusement park, museum and theme parks among others to attract footfall.

The state has tweaked the tourism policy to incorporate water and adventure activities at notified water bodies with attractive sops.

Title: Rs2cr to conduct exam of Class 5, 8 smoothly
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Indore: An estimated budget of over Rs two crore has been designated by the school education department to conduct the board examination of over 16 lakh enrolled students of class five and eight across the state.

As from this academic session the students of class five and eight will be appearing for their annual examination in board pattern, the department has been trying to ascertain that the examination is conducted smoothly for all the 322 development blocks.

Out of the 16,83,615 enrolled students of MP, 7,98,934 students are of class five and 8,84,681 students are of class eight.

The allotted budget to conduct the examination for the six blocks of Indore district is over Rs 3 lakh.

“The department has decided to upload the exam procedure for students online and has issued an Annual Examination Management System (AEMS) timeline for students appearing for the exams. At present the distribution of admit cards has been taking place and it will continue till February 28,” Indore division education department joint director Manish Verma told TOI.

All the districts have been allotted a separate budget. The schools have been conducting extra classes on weekends and off days for the students to fare well in the exam which will begin from March 3, he said.

A total of 13,583 students of class five and 14,360 students of class eight will be appearing from Indore district.

BOX:

The budget amount includes Rs 5 per student of class eight for answer sheet, Rs 6 per student of class five for question paper cum answer sheet, Rs 3 per supplementary copy and Rs 5 per student for question paper of class eight and Rs 3 per student of class five and eight for printing.

Title: Court closes case on DGP’s assurance
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kochi: The high court on Monday disposed of a petition challenging an order issued by state police chief for allegedly granting access to ‘ crime data ’ to a labour cooperative society for handling police clearance for passport verification.

Justice Anu Sivaraman disposed the petition by KPCC secretary Jyothikumar Chamakkala through senior advocate George Poonthottam after state police chief informed the court that the order granting access to Uralungal Labour Contract Cooperative Society (ULCC) was a typo and that ‘crime data’ is not being shared. A revised order was subsequently issued, the court was told.

It was contended by the petitioner that the state police chief’s order allows sharing of confidential details of citizens to a private entity, which is impermissible as per law. It affects the right to privacy of citizens and amounts to failure of constitutional functions of the State, he had alleged.

As per the petition, the state police chief’s order directed for granting ULCC access to ‘crime data’, which consists particulars of every crime registered in the state, by permitting access to Crime and Criminal Tracking Network and Systems (CCTNS) production API, CCTNS master data, firewall access to CCTN production, API, etc.

Title: Ileana D'Cruz's comment on Malaika Arora's stunning picture just summed-up what everyone wants to say to the 'Chaiya Chaiyya' girl
Content: Not one to bow out of a social media battle, Kangana Ranaut claimed that she was the first "in the history of Hindi cinema" to bring “Maratha Pride”. She went on to claim that she put her life and career on the line in an “Islam dominate industry” to make a film on Shivaji Maharaj and Rani Laxmibai.

Title: Book sugar mill for not paying FRP: HC
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Aurangabad: The Bombay high court bench at Aurangabad has directed the police to register a case against the management of a sugar factory from Majalgaon in Beed for alleged non-payment of fair and remunerative price ( FRP ) to growers within the stipulated 14 days of supply.

The court has directed that the case be registered under sections 3 and 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 on the basis of Sugarcane (Control) Order, 1966, in respect to the FRP.

The bench, comprising Justices T V Nalawade and M G Sewlikar, observed on on February 17 that it was “unfortunate, but a fact that most sugar factories from Maharashtra are not paying FRP to farmers, who are at their mercy as they have no alternative than to supply sugarcane to the nearest sugar factory. This problem of the sugarcane growers is used by the persons in the management of the sugar factory and the farmers are virtually exploited.”

Pawan Ramkisan Chandak (31), an agriculturist from Talkhed in Majalgaon taluka of Beed district, had approached the court seeking directions to register offences against the chairman, vice-chairman of the sugar mill. He had earlier approached different police authorities in Beed district about the non-payment of FRP for the crushing season 2018-19 within 14 days of delivering the sugarcane and even till April 23, 2019, when he filed the complaint.

The court noted that Chandak was paid FRP after he filed the petition. “Admittedly, the price of sugarcane was not paid within 14 days of the date of supply and interest is not paid till today,” the court observed.

The bench noted that the farmers face all kinds of problems due to “such late payment of FRP and non-payment of interest. They cannot repay the loan taken from banks and societies for cultivation purpose. Due to their inability to make payment of the previous loan, the banks and societies are not sanctioning new loans for subsequent crop seasons to the farmers. Due to these circumstances, the incidents of farmers suicides have increased to an alarming extent.”

The high court also observed “though, these circumstances are within the knowledge of sugar commissioner and all the concerned, including the police, actions are not taken against the concerned. This is mainly due to circumstance that the factory owners or the persons managing factory are influential persons and most of them are in politics.”

“In the present matter also, it can be said that the police station has tried to shirk the responsibility by submitting a report that money of the farmers is now paid and the sugar factory has supplied an information that FRP is paid. On the basis of such police report or the payment of FRP, after so many months, the things cannot be closed. They (sugar factories) need to learn a lesson, otherwise these things will be repeated,” it noted.

Title: Two attempt to kill selves on collector office premises
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: In two separate incidents, an elderly man and a woman along with her two children, attempted suicide inside Madurai district collector office premises during grievance day meet on Monday.

One Muthulakshmi from N Kovilpatti near Melur, who came to district collector office along with her two blind daughters, poured kerosene on her children and herself. Police personnel stopped her from setting herself on fire. She said that they have been pushed to live on street as her husband has deserted them. She had petitioned the collector three times seeking help and action against her husband. However, as mo action was taken, she decided to end their lives. In another incident, Perumal, 72, from Karuvelampatti attempted suicide, by pouring kerosene on himself as his sons abandoned him after taking his house and retirement benefits of his wife, who had worked in TNSTC. He was stopped by the policemen there. He said that he had petitioned the collector a few times seeking action against his sons. However, he said that he is yet to get any relief.

Title: Dog bites six Gujarat National Law University students
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Gujarat National Law University

AHMEDABAD: At least six students of Gujarat National Law University (GNLU) were bitten by a suspected rabid dog on Sunday evening and night at the campus. The students were taken to a nearby private hospital for vaccination.

GNLU authorities said that none of the students were in any danger.

According to sources at GNLU, the stray dog was a pet of a few students living on the campus. The dog went on a biting spree near the residential areas as the students brought the incident to notice of the university authorities. “All the students were provided necessary vaccines and all are back on the campus,” said a senior GNLU official.

Sources said the dog was later removed from the campus and the students, who keep stray dogs as pets, have been reprimanded. “Keeping a pet on the campus is not allowed. However, a few students had raised objection to the policy and removal of stray dogs on humanitarian grounds. After the incident, it’s likely that the no pet policy could be implemented more stringently,” said the official.

Title: On lunch menu: High-powered business meet
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

NEW DELHI: Several ministers, bureaucrats and leading industrialists have been invited to the lunch hosted by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in honour of US President Donald Trump.

The ministers who have been invited include foreign minister S Jaishankar, commerce, industry and railways minister Piyush Goyal, petroleum and natural gas minister Dharmendra Pradhan and civil aviation, housing and urban affairs minister Hardeep Singh Puri .

Principal secretary to the PM P K Mishra and national security advisor Ajit Doval are also in the list of invitees. Foreign secretary Harsh Vardhan Shringla, home secretary Ajay Bhalla, Chief of Defence Staff General Bipin Rawat and Niti Aayog CEO Amitabh Kant will also be there.

Indian ambassador to the US Taranjit Singh Sandhu and commerce and industry secretary Anup Wadhawan also figure in the list.

A strong contingent from the private sector will be present for the high profile lunch. Chairman and managing director of Reliance Industries Mukesh Ambani , Mahindra Group CMD Anand Mahindra, Bharat Forge CMD Baba Kalyani, Adani Group chairman Gautam Adani, Tata Sons executive chairman N Chandrsekharan, CEO and managing director if Larsen and Toubro S N Subrahmanyan, Bharti Enterprises chairman Sunil Mittal and Arcelor Mittal chairman and CEO L N Mittal will be present.

Other prominent industrialists on the list include Aditya Birla Group chairman Kumar Mangalam Birla, Vedanta chairman Anil Agarwal , Infosys CEO and MD Salil Parekh, and Hindustan Unilever CEO Sanjiv Mehta.

Sources said the presence of top industrialists will help foster closer economic and trade ties. Among the CEOs are those whose companies have made investment commitments in the US.

Title: HC sitting judges to teach at Nuals
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Kochi: The National University of Advanced Legal Studies (Nuals) has made arrangements with high court sitting judges to give lectures for law students at Nuals as adjunct professors .

Seven sitting judges — Justices A Hariprasad, A Muhammed Musthaque, AK Jayasankaran Nambiar, Anil K Narendran, Sunil K Thomas, B Sudheendra Kumar, Devan Ramachandran — have been appointed as adjunct professors of Nuals.

Besides, retired chief justice of Sikkim high court Pious Kuriakose, justice and former director of Kerala Judicial Academy K T Sankaran, senior advocates like K B Muhammed Kutty, TPM Ibrahim Khan, S Radhakrishnan, Dr Pauly Mathew Murikkan, Nagaraj Narayanan and former legislative secretary M C Valson have also been appointed as adjunct professors.tnn

Title: Proposal sent to divide city police jurisdiction
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Madurai: Newly-appointed additional director general of police (ADGP) and Madurai city police commissioner, S Davidson Devasirvatham has petitioned the higher authorities to divide Madurai city police jurisdiction into two and to bring each under a deputy commissioner of police in order to effectively maintain law and order and crime prevention.Devasirvatham told this to reporters after assuming charge as ADGP on Monday. The posting, which is at the level of an inspector general was upgraded to ADGP paving way for Devasirvatham to continue as commissioner. Devasirvatham said the proposal was sent a few weeks ago for consideration of higher officials. Once it is implemented policing can be done more effectively as officials will be concentrating their area in a much better way.

At present, crime and law and order is being handled separately by two deputy commissioners respectively by K Palanikumar and E Karthick. There are some grey areas. For instance, four newly-added stations like Thirupparankundram, Thirunagar, Avaniyapuram and Koodalpudur do not have a separate crime station, while the remaining police stations have law and order and crime. DC law and order takes care of crime incidents in such stations. tnn

Title: Gold price breaches Rs 45,000-mark in Ahmedabad
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Experts also said that the rise in prices will adversely impact demand of gold

AHMEDABAD: Continuing its upward rally riding on global factors, gold price breached the Rs 45,000-mark in the Ahmedabad market on Monday, touching a new record-high price. Pure gold price settled at Rs 45,050 per 10 gram in Ahmedabad on Monday, including 3% goods and services tax (GST), increasing by Rs 900 against Thursday’s price.

Analysts said that the increase in price can be attributed to the rise in international price of gold, owing to spike in cases of coronavirus infections in China and other countries and consequent concerns over its impact on the global market.

“Gold prices rose to $1,689 per ounce in the international market amid rising concerns over impact of the spread of coronavirus not just in China but other countries as well. Concerned over adverse fallouts of this situation on the global markets, investors have begun moving towards safe-haven investments in gold as a result of which prices have gone up. Consequently, gold prices touched a new record high in the Ahmedabad market as well,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers’ Association (IBJA).

“The restrictions imposed by Singapore on movement of passengers has also fuelled rise in prices,” Acharya added.

Experts said that prices are expected to rise further in the days to come. “Throughout the year, gold prices will continue to rise and this is because of rapidly changing global scenario. Big investors across the world have turned to safe-haven investments in gold,” said Sudhish Nambiath, head, India Gold Policy Centre (IGPC), Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad (IIMA).

Experts also said that the rise in prices will adversely impact demand of gold. “Gold imports in Gujarat for January already plunged to 0.92 metric tonne in anticipation of customs duty cut in the Union Budget announcement. Currently, the demand has sustained only due to the ongoing wedding season and after mid-March, if prices continue to remain high, this will further come down,” said a gold analyst.

Title: Gujarat high court orders double-sided printing to save paper, planet
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court has ordered its registry to ensure double-sided print on paper so that “substantial saving of paper and thereby the environment can be achieved,” said its registrar.

In the green initiatives, Chief Justice Vikram Nath has issued instructions to HC’s registry to adopt the method of printing on both the sides of a paper and do away with one-sided printing in at least 15 areas of working on administrative side. In preparing cause lists for judges, agenda notes of meetings of various committees, submission notes placed at all levels, Paybills, annexures of notices and writs, correspondence with district courts and government bodies, internal communications in the registry, RTI replies and order in RTI appeals, circular, guidelines etc. The registrar’s statement said that the agenda notes of the highest level of meetings will be circulated in PDF ebook format with index and bookmarks. The HC has also instructed the district judiciary heads to take initiatives for paper saving as much as possible.

HC’s move has been welcomed by lawyers and some even said that this liberty should be given to the litigants too that the petition’s papers should also be printed double sided. “This will reduce the burden on poor litigants,” a lawyer said.

Title: Donald Trump cites Dandi, Ahmedabad marches for him
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

PM Narendra Modi and US President Donald Trump wave the crowd at ‘Namaste Trump’ event (ANI Photo)

AHMEDABAD: A group of 25 traders had the challenging task of performing ‘Gair-Naach’, a Rajasthani folk dance performed mainly by the Bhil community, for six long hours on Monday morning. But the troupe comprising all men were not complaining as they danced away enthusiastically showcasing their native state Rajasthan at the roadshow of US President Donald Trump and Indian PM Narendra Modi.

"Our troupe played the dhol non-stop and danced to its beats with gunghroos tied to our feet almost non-stop," said a businessman Bhimji Chaudhary, one of the troupe members.

All along the 22km roadshow, tableaux, folk dancers and musicians rolling out the cultural tapestry from 28 states of India lined the roadsides, making it a sight to behold. At least 50 stages were set up with some bearing unique names like Lilliput and Michael Jackson.

Young, old and children alike thronged the roads to watch Trump. "I have come to watch Trump with my eight months old baby," said a housewife Meena Bharwad.

There was unprecedented curiosity over Trump’s bulletproof limousine ‘The Beast’ as large crowds bent over the railings to click picture of the vehicle. Unlike Japanese PM Shinzo Abe and wife Akie Abe, who participated in the 8km roadshow from airport to Gandhi Ashram in an open vehicle, the fact that Trump was in a closed vehicle was a bit of a dampener.

"It would have been great if we have caught a glimpse of Trump and Modi together. But we understand the security concerns," said Madhav Patel, a professional.

At many places, cops were seen having a tough time to restrain the enthusiastic crowds behind the makeshift barricades as they clamoured to get pictures in their mobile phones. Policemen were also seen enjoying the roadshow on TV sets in shops in Motera. The Trump euphoria at Motera had attracted salesmen from cities as far as Kolkata to sell their wares.

Subrato Paul and Riddhan Sarkar who travelled from Kolkata hoping to sell Team India t-shirts and tricolours failed to make brisk sales but were happy to witness history of a different kind at the world’s biggest cricket stadium.
