“The iVEIN network will facilitate high-quality research among the academic fraternity in India and create avenues for dissemination of relevant knowledge through conferences and journals,” he said.

According to Prof Venkatesh Panchapagesan, chair at NSRCEL, the innovation and entrepreneurship cell of IIM-B, iVEIN aims at playing a larger, strategic role in the startup ecosystem by looking beyond incubating startups.

“The network, backed by the academic rigour of premier institutions, would help formulate knowledge in the fast-evolving entrepreneurial ecosystem in the country,” said Keyoor Purani, professor IIM-K and executive director, IIMK LIVE.

Objectives of the network include creating an interdisciplinary body of knowledge synthesizing multiple perspectives, which would meet the requirements of policymakers, academic researchers, students, innovators, entrepreneurs, investors and all those interested in innovation and ventures

The immediate activity that would be taken up by iVEIN would be to publish the India Innovation, Venture and Entrepreneurship Report. Conceptualized as a biennial publication, the first report would be published in 2020 with the theme ‘Creating Successful Ventures’.

END

Title: 1000 excellence schools to multiply in Indore division
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Indore: Over 1000 primary and middle schools of Indore division may soon get ‘school of excellence’ tag.

The school education department has selected 524 primary and 524 middle government schools from Indore division and after physical verification they may become schools of excellence . “We have decided to cross check and physically verify the conditions and availability of basic infrastructure to go ahead with it. We are planning complete verification in two days,” school education joint director Indore division Manish Verma told TOI.

The project is part of the initiative to ensure that government schools are at par with private institutions and those that already have all required basic infra, amenities and services are put in the bracket of school of excellence. The decision was taken in a division-level meeting of school education department on Monday.

These schools will have to maintain the facilities with the funds that they have already been getting, they will not be given any additional funds.

Ideally, school of excellence consist of facilities such as good infrastructure, separate washrooms for boys and girls, drinking water facility and even boundary wall of school campus apart from experienced principal, well-qualified faculty of subjects, office staff, equipped laboratories etc.

The department has decided to conduct physical verification of all primary and middle schools of the division that have been put up on the list.

The verification process will begin from Tuesday and the procedure will have to be completed by February 26 before forwarding the list to Bhopal office, he added. TNN

Title: We are heirs of MGR, Anna and Amma, EPS tells cadre
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Chennai: AIADMK joint coordinator and chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Monday asserted that AIADMK cadres were the true heirs of former chief ministers C N Annadurai , M G Ramachandran and J Jayalalithaa .

Speaking at a public rally in his native town of Salem on the occasion of Jayalalithaa’s 72nd birth anniversary, Palaniswami said the cadres were successors of the leaders, who had no direct heirs. “The All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam is a historic movement. The leaders had delivered a number of welfare schemes for the people. If MGR realized the dreams of Anna, Amma fulfilled the dreams of both. Can anyone refute that?” Palaniswami said. He said his government continued her welfare schemes and enhanced the benefits and cost as well.

Flaunting the recently passed legislation to protect the Cauvery delta region, the CM said, “DMK chief M K Stalin did not expect we would announce the Cauvery delta as protected agricultural zone.”

The AIADMK celebrated Jayalalithaa’s birth anniversary with great frenzy across the state by garlanding the statue of the leader, cutting cakes and distributing sweets. Palaniswami launched a drive to plant 72 lakh saplings across the state and distributed welfare measures benefitting girl children to commemorate the Girl Children Safety Day, announced by him last week. In a three-minute video, the CM exhorted cadres to vow to destroy fake propaganda of opponents.

At R K Nagar, deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam said Jayalalithaa had established the rights of the state in inter-state water disputes. “On her advice and along the path laid down by her, the party is moving without getting derailed. She steered the party for 28 years and took the cadre force to 1.5 crore from 18 lakhs when MGR passed away,” the AIADMK coordinator said.

Palaniswami distributed welfare measures to 47,072 beneficiaries in Salem, and Panneerselvam to 18,000 beneficiaries in R K Nagar and others in other districts.

Title: A month gone, varsity fails to allot guides to PhD scholars
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Indore: Allotment of research guides for PhD candidates, who cleared Devi Ahilya Vishwavidyalaya’s (DAVV) doctoral entrance test (DET) is not over even after a month.

Over 800 PhD candidates also have to wait till March for varsity’s research advisory committee (RAC) to begin the process.

The varsity had declared result of entrance test on January 21. Since then, candidates have been running pillar to post to get acquainted with allotted guide to begin their course work.

The entrance test was scheduled in May which kept getting delayed and after seven months, it was conducted on December 22. The result, which was expected on January 5, was delayed too by a fortnight, said a PhD candidate on condition of anonymity.

The varsity hasn’t put up list of guides and process of RAC has also not begun, he added.

Over 2900 out of 4406 candidates had appeared for the exam and only 28% had cleared the test.

Chairman of DET Dr VB Gupta said that he will soon write a letter to heads of university teaching departments (UTD) to prepare for RAC. However, the process is likely to begin next week.

Title: Northeast Delhi News: Shrine, petrol pump and much more in flames
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Many shops on the main road towards Bhajanpura and Karawal Nagar were vandalised as the violence spread

NEW DELHI: Till Monday afternoon, an uneasy calm prevailed in northeast Delhi’s Karawal Nagar and nearby localities of Khajuri Khas and Bhajanpura — the epicentre of Sunday’s violence where cars, motorcycles and three-wheelers were set ablaze by rioters.

Things took a turn for the worse after 1pm. It started with pro- and anti-CAA protesters pelting stones at each other at Khajuri Khas Chowk. It all went downhill pretty quickly as the violence spread to the main road in Wazirabad. Eyewitnesses said a mazaar (shrine) on the main road was set ablaze and, a little later, a petrol pump went up in flames, barely 100 metres away.

By 1.30pm, stones were flying like rockets. Police and Rapid Action Force personnel, who were on the spot, were unable to subdue the crowd. TOI was witness to some people even using molotovs, which eventually led to the fire spreading. Police fired several rounds of teargas shells to contain the crowd, but things had spiralled way out of control by then.

Those approaching east Delhi from Signature Bridge and Wazirabad flyover were met with thick, black plumes of smoke. Around 2pm, policemen barricaded the road to prevent any incoming traffic from getting caught in the violence. Several motorists were turned back.

Many shops on the main road towards Bhajanpura and Karawal Nagar were vandalised in the process. Locals alleged that police did little to control the damage. “If the cops had taken timely action, the crowd could have dispersed. People from nearby areas joined in, but the policemen simply waited and watched,” claimed Saurav Jain, whose brother runs a garment store on Wazirabad main road towards Bhajanpura.

Jain said they had no inkling of what was to follow, as till 12:30pm, everything was peaceful. “I even had lunch at a stall on the main road. Around 1pm, some people started throwing stones,” he said. Many shopkeepers downed their shutters and women were quickly transported to safety, Jain said.

Vishal Jha, another local, claimed tension worsened after the mazaar was set ablaze. “All of a sudden, a group emerged on the road and started chanting inflammatory slogans. After the mazaar was burned down, stones, sticks and lathis rained,” Jha said.

TOI saw several people being injured in the melee, with one individual brutally attacked by a group of at least 10 people. Towards Karawal Nagar, another man was severely wounded. People could be seen taking the injured away in e-rickshaws.

Further ahead towards Chand Bagh in New Mustafabad, vehicles and buildings had caught fire. Thick plumes of smoke billowed, but fire trucks were unable to go in for over an hour. Locals said over a hundred people were injured in the clashes.

Delhi University’s Dr Bhim Rao Ambedkar College in Wazirabad said it had cancelled its cultural festival scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday. “The college cultural festival is being postponed till further notice because of circumstances beyond the college’s control (sic),” it stated.

Title: Uttarakhand: Two dead as speeding car plunges into Bhimtal lake
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: Two persons died after their speeding car fell into the Bhimtal lake on Monday.

The incident, according to police, occurred around 6:30 am in Bhimtal area of Nainital district when the speeding car hit the parapet, skidded off the road and plunged into the lake.

Speaking to TOI, Arvind Kumar, an eyewitness, said the car was speeding when it lost control and fell into the lake. “We were going there for a walk when we saw the car coming towards us. It, however, went out of control and hit the parapet after which it fell in the lake. We soon informed the police but by the time they could reach the spot, the car had already submerged,” Kumar said.

Police officials, meanwhile, informed that the SDRF as well as the police team recovered the bodies and the car from the lake. However, both the men had already died by then. “We used a crane to recover the bodies and the car from the water. Both the men were found dead,” said Anushka Badola, circle officer, Bhimtal.

The police said that the deceased have been identified as 20-year-old Lalit and 22-year-old Kuldeep Sah. “We have sent their bodies for postmortem and their families have also been informed. The bodies will be handed over to their family members for last rites once the postmortem is complete,” Badola added.

The locals claimed that there was a long delay in the rescue work as neither the police nor the SDRF could reach on time. “The police were informed soon after the incident. But, it took them over an hour to reach the spot. In fact, the rescue work started late when the SDRF came and the crane was then deployed to retrieve the car,” said another local.

Title: VACB: 56 docus seized from Sivakumar’s house
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The vigilance and anti-corruption bureau ( VACB ) officials have submitted a report at a vigilance special court here regarding the search conducted in the house of former minister and Congress MLA V S Sivakumar .

It is reliably learned that the vigilance sleuths have seized as many as 56 documents from his house that can throw light into the financial transactions and receipts of luxury tax and fee paid for his daughter.

The vigilance also reported before the court that it seized as many as 72 documents, including 13 documents relating to properties, and six bank passbooks from the residence of Rajendran, who is suspected to be the benami of Sivakumar. The vigilance also said that it received proof that Rajendran had financial dealings abroad as well. The vigilance also seized 25 and 15 documents from the residences of Harikumar and Shyjuharan, respectively. The sleuths also seized two bank locker keys from the residence of Harikumar.

The vigilance team probing the case has also directed the bank where Sivakumar holds account not to open the locker of Sivakumar in the absence of vigilance officials.

However, sources said that the sleuths are yet to find any documents to prove the benami link between Sivakumar and the three others. “Though there is credible information that money has been collected mostly in the names of transfers for doctors and from medical companies, there are no documents to prove them. The agency is waiting to find some person who can vouch that he or she had paid the money for getting a favour. This would be enough even though there is no document to establish direct financial transactions between the suspects,” sources said.

The vigilance probe could not reveal disproportionate assets to the known source of income of Sivakumar during the period from May 18, 2011 to May 20, 2016 when he was the health and devaswom minister in the former UDF ministry.

Title: Indore model in limelight at nat’l Smart City conclave
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Indore: To work things out for Indore Smart City’s largest venture — the ambitious MOG Lines redevelopment project — officials have decided to change terms and conditions of tender worth Rs 800 crore to find an agency to assign the work. “We have issued tenders twice for assigning redevelopment works worth Rs 800 crore for MOG Lines, which is spread in around 40 acre. But no agency showed interest. Therefore, some changes in terms and conditions of the tender have been proposed,” said Indore Smart City Development Limited (ISCDL) CEO Sandeep Soni. He discussed the same with Smart City Mission director Rahul Kapoor during a conference here on Monday.

In the conference, CEOs of 23 Smart City Projects of six states were invited to share their knowledge and discuss challenges in implementation of different development works to share possible solutions. “We are making required changes in tender of MOG Line redevelopment project including construction of residential and commercial complexes and arranging modern amenities to attract agencies to assign work,” Soni said.

During the workshop, senior officials learnt about ‘Indore-model’ for road widening in congested old city areas, waste management and resettlement. The CEOs of different cities will visit CP Shekhar Nagar on Tuesday, which has been converted into a public garden by shifting slum dwellers to highrise apartments near Gandhi Nagar under resettlement policy. Kapoor said that are the challenges are different for each Smart City. These works have been selected on parameters of quality of life, economic potential and sustainability. “The main challenges are population, limited budget and resources and failing to find contractors in implementation of Smart City projects,” he said.

He added that to ensure sustainability of Smart City works, departments using the facilities including civic body, police and traffic should pay service fee to the agency.

“In conference, difficulties and hurdles in implementation of different works in 23 Smart Cities were discussed by their CEOs. They tried to find best possible solutions. The participants also shared their knowledge for better handling of challenges in similar projects in respective cities,” divisional commissioner Akash Tripathi said.

Title: Maharashtra: Ahead of summer, Osmanabad and Latur stare at water shortage
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

As per official data of the State Water Resources Department (WRD), a total of 11 major irrigation projects in... Read More

AURANGABAD: Major irrigation projects in Marathwada currently hold twice the amount than the average from the past five years, but many parts in the region, including Latur, Osmanabad and certain areas of Parbhani, are faced with a scarcity this summer.

Summer hasn't officially started but reservoirs, one each from Latur and Osmanabad, have already hit dead storage levels. One project in Parbhani is already showing single-digit storage.

Irrigation projects in Aurangabad, Beed, Hingoli and Nanded districts, however, hold sufficient stock. The Jayakwadi irrigation project - a lifeline for Aurangabad and parts of Marathwada - was at 81%.

The Manjra irrigation project in Latur and Sina Kolegaon project from Osmanabad currently show no live storage, whereas Lower Dudhna in the district of Parbhani, district is showing only 6% live storage.

As per official data of the State Water Resources Department (WRD), a total of 11 major irrigation projects in Marathwada were holding a combined 69% live storage as of Monday. The region has 75 medium irrigation projects that were showing 40% live storage; 749 small irrigation projects have been showing 32% live stock. Another 13 barrages built over Godavari currently have 71% live storage, whereas such structures built on the Terna, Manjra and Rena rivers were having 18% live storage.

A senior WRD official said Latur and Osmanabad will have to rely on medium or small irrigation projects besides barrages for their water needs this summer.

“A judicious use of water will have to be norm right from the start of summer. District administrations have already taken note of depleting water reservoirs in both the districts. The available water will be reserved for drinking on a priority basis,” an official from the WRD said.

Latur district disaster management officer Saqueb Osmani said residents were receiving tap water after a gap of 10 days since the monsoon and added that there was no immediate plan to reduce the frequency. “The Manjra dam has around 1.4 TMC of water. Other reservoirs also hold some amount of water that can be put to judicious use this summer,” he said.

Residents of Beed, a district in Marathwada known for water scarcity in the summers, have some relief as the Majalgaon major irrigation project currently has a stock of 79%.

The Jayakwadi dam had received heavy inflow from upstream areas, especially Nashik, during Monsoon 2019. It witnessed heavy periodic discharge, which in turn filled the Majalgaon dam despite its catchment areas receiving weak rainfall.

Marathwada overall had a deficient monsoon last year, with below average levels during the first three months of rain.

The region reported the lowest - 65% average rainfall - in June, followed by 72% in August and 75% in July. In September, Marathwada reported 124.5% rainfall, followed by considerable showers in October.

Title: Woman power: Four receive Eashwari Bai Memorial Award
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

(From left) Dr Manisha Bangaru, B Vijaya Bharathi Tarakam, Kondaveeti Sathyavathi, and K Bharathi after receiv... Read More

HYDERABAD: Four women from the state, hailing from different spheres of life, received the Smt J Eashwari Bai Memorial Award at an event organised in the city on Monday. The department of language and culture and the Eashwari Bai Memorial trust had organised the event to mark the death anniversary of Eashwari Bai.

B Vijaya Bharathi Tarakam, writer and former filmmaker, Kondaveeti Sathyavathi, editor of a magazine, Dr Manisha Bangaru, social activist and K Bharathi, state president of the Telangana Organ Donors Association received the award for their contribution towards the cause of women and child welfare and their work for the backward classes.

The ceremony was attended by Union minister G Kishan Reddy, state minister Srinivas Goud, head of department of language and culture Mamidi Hari Krishna, government of Telangana advisor Dr KV Ramana Chary and MLA and chairperson of Eashwari Bai Memorial Trust Dr J Geetha Reddy. “This year we awarded women from the state to inspire and motivate others to work towards social welfare of the state,” said Dr Geetha Reddy. She added that despite the political differences among the various parties, it was Eashwari Bai’s work that brought everybody on the same stage.

Commemorating Eashwari Bai and Dr BR Ambedkar’s work for SCs and STs, Kishan Reddy said, “We belong to different political parties, but we need to work together on the path laid by Dr Ambedkar.”

Title: Lucknow high court: Didn’t ban trains in Dudhwa
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative Image

LUCKNOW: The high court has expressed serious displeasure on railways for stopping plying of trains on the Mailani-Nanpara route passing through Dudhwa National Park. The court clarified that it did not pass any order to stop the operation of trains on the said route. It has sought clarifications from DRM and GM railways in this regard.

A bench of Justice MN Bhandari and Justice VK Srivastava passed the order on two PILs filed by Rajiv Gupta and Terai Development Institute. The petitioners alleged that due to stoppage of the trains, lakhs of passengers from nearby villagers would face serious difficulty.

The court then asked the petitioners to show the order which directed stoppage of the trains but the parties could not produce the order. This irked the bench which summoned clarification from railways.

The court also directed the railways to change the alignment of the track instead of stopping the operation so that passengers would not suffer.

Title: Rajasthan: Leopard injures 3 in Amber, tranquillised
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The leopard, which was rescued from Rundal village, at Jaipur zoo

JAIPUR: A leopard attacked three persons in Rundal village of Amber tehsil in Jaipur district on Monday after some people threw a stone at it in an attempt to shoo it away from the village.

The victims have been identified as Deepak, Raju and Mohan. Two of them were rushed to Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital.

Around 9am three women were working in a field when they spotted a leopard hiding in between wheat crops in Rundal village. They rushed back to their homes and within a few minutes people from the entire village reached the spot. Some climbed to the trees and others pulled out sticks to take on the leopard. It was the first time the villagers spotted the animal.

Few days ago, Rundal villagers had come to know that a leopard was seen at Manpura Macheri village, close to Rundal, had killed some goats.

Miscalculating that the leopard will run away if it was stoned, some youths stepped in the agriculture field where the leopard was hiding and started pelting stones. Immediately, the leopard jumped at them and injured at least three youths.

The villages then called police and forest department officials. “Some forest department officials were already in the village as I had called them to rescue a Nilgai from a water tank. But, they did not have cape and the tranquilising dart gun. A team of forest department reached at the spot around 3pm with all their equipment and tranquilised the leopard,” said Dilip Singh Shekhawat, a resident of Rundal village.

Chandwaji SHO Vikrant Sharma said, “The leopard might have come in search of food or he might have gone astray. It injured three persons, who are fine now.”

After the leopard was caged by the forest department officials, villagers celebrated it and chased the vehicle carrying the feline to take videos.

Title: Rajasthan: Budget session of assembly to conclude on March 13
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Mahesh Joshi

JAIPUR: The state budget will be passed in the assembly on March 13. Presenting the report of the business advisory committee in the House, Congress chief whip Mahesh Joshi said the budget will be debated in the House from February 24 to 27.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot will reply to the budget debate at 5pm on February 27. The debate on demands for grants and voting will begin in the House from February 28. On February 29 and March 1, there will be holidays. Demands for grants will be debated and passed from March 2 to March 6.

The assembly will function on March 7(Saturday) as wel when two bills will be passed. The Municipal Amendment Bill and the Advocates Welfare Amendment Bill will be passed after debate.

March 8 to 11 are holidays on account of Holi. On March 12, the House will take up the remaining demands for grants. On March 13, the budget and finance bill and appropriation bill will be passed.

Title: FB hacker threatens woman to post her ‘semi-nude’ photos, demands money; booked
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Bareilly: A communication on your Facebook messenger from your friend offering you help in shedding weight and asking for the photos of your specific body parts or full body so that s/he can chalk out a weight-loss plan for you may lead you to unforeseen trouble if you fall in its trap, warns police while cautioning Facebook users, especially women, not to fall prey if they encountered with such messages.

Sambhal police has, in a similar case, booked an unidentified person under IPC section 384 (extortion) and sections 66C (punishment of identity theft) and 66D (cheating by personation by using computer resource) of the Information Technology Act at Chandausi police station. The case has been transferred to the cyber cell and the investigation is on.

The complainant told police, “Many women have fallen prey to the hackers inadvertently. Many victims shared their experience with me on Facebook when I shared a post educating users on how to protect their accounts from being hacked. Hackers attempted to hack my account, too, but I acted sensibly. Since most of the victims are married and don’t want their life to be affected by this, I lodged an FIR.”

Explaining the modus operandi of the blackmailers, additional superintendent of police (ASP) Alok Kumar Jaiswal said, “They hack Facebook accounts of women after they click on a link sent to them. Thereafter, the hackers send messages from the hacked Facebook accounts to the account holders’ women friends, offering help in reducing their body weight and asking pictures of fatty portions of their bodies or full body. The women who share their pictures are later blackmailed by the hackers, who threatened them to post their semi-nude photos.”

The ASP added, “This is a serious issue and our cybercrime team is working to track down the hacker. As the hackers have targeted many women and young girls here, the cybercrime team has sent a message to Facebook users, asking them to block their account — if hacked — so that it can’t be misused.”

Meanwhile, a complaint was lodged at Powayan police station in Shahjahanpur district, where the Facebook account of a lawyer’s wife was hacked and the hacker was sending messages to her friends, demanding money.

Shahjahanpur senior superintendent of police (SSP) Shivasimpi Channapa said he forwarded the complaint to the cyber cell and an FIR would be registered after verification of the complaint.

Title: Cast in stone: Growing feeling of distrust
Content:
Protesters can be seen pelting stones at cops in Maujpur area of Delhi. (Photo: Anindya Chattopadhyay)

NEW DELHI: The arterial Jafrabad-Maujpur Road in northeast Delhi yet again witnessed a clash between pro and anti-CAA protesters on Monday. The opposite camps set up base at two metro stations — Jafrabad for anti-CAA protesters and Maujpur-Babarpur station for supporters of the Act.Tension remained high in Jafrabad after stone-pelting incidents with the violence spreading to inner lanes of the colonies along the main road. Schoolchildren complained of facing trouble in trying to reach their homes. The railings of the road median were broken by the agitators and several walls were also damaged. The bricks from these walls were used by the mob to pelt at policemen trying to control the situation.The situation flared up after sloganeering between the two groups with one shouting “Hum kya chaahe, NRC” and the other replying “Hum kya chaahe, Azadi”. Soon, anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protesters residing in Kabir Nagar came on the road only to face a rain of bricks and stones.The cemented railings of the central median of 66-Foota Road near Maujpur-Babarpur metro station were broken by the protesters and the debris pelted at police. The security personnel fired tear gas shells, but it didn’t serve the purpose for long as clashes broke out in the interior lanes.In lane number 4 at Vijay Park, both opposing camps started pelting stones at each other. Worried residents waiting for their children to return after the Board exams peeped through their doors to check on them. Gayatri Devi, who lives in one of the lanes, said, “Since morning, they have been throwing stones and hurling abuses. I was scared, so I didn’t send my daughter to school. We are a family of six. How can we live here with people randomly pelting stones at each other?”Around 5pm, Jafrabad-Maujpur Road was found covered with half-broken pieces of glass, bricks and stones. Most of the shops had been vandalised. Windowpanes had been shattered and CCTV cameras damaged. The owner of a furniture house said the entire façade of his shop had been broken. “We were caught in the crossfire when the two groups started pelting stones. We are now being protected by police,” he added.Bricks stacked at a construction site in Vijay Park V-2 Block became ammunition for the mob. Barricades had been put up at Seelampur Chowk even as police and central forces battled to push the stone-pelters away from the arterial road.Till dusk, central forces could be seen tackling protesters near Kadampuri. Stones and bricks were thrown at them from the rooftops across Shahadra drain that divides the region. Broken bottles, Molotov cocktails and pouches filled with liquid were tossed on the mob.A senior police officer leading the charge said that situation was comparatively under control as the two groups had been separated by the nullah. “We are more concerned about people throwing stones from the roofs,” he added. In the evening, ambulances were rushed to the inner lanes of Kadampuri to ferry the injured to hospitals.Loudspeakers could be heard blaring religious songs at Maujpur-Babarpur Metro Station. A youth donning a vermillion tilak said they will not vacate the place until the anti-CAA protesters leave Jafrabad. “How can blocking our roads be called a peaceful protest?” he countered.Several youngsters carrying rods and sticks were seen mixing with the crowd where a langar was being prepared. The agitators objected to being photographed and made appeals to boycott the media.With darkness setting in, plumes of smoke could still be seen rising from the inner lanes with police stationed on the main Maujpur road. As the forces changed shifts, some locals could be seen serving the tired security personnel refreshments. Harish Thakur, a rickshaw driver whose daughters were serving tea, said, “They are protecting our homes. The least we can do is show solidarity.” Late in the night, violence was reported from Noor-e-Ilahi near Ghonda Chowk where protesters set several shops on fire.

Title: Expedite SRDP works: KT Rama Rao to GHMC
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: Municipal Administration and Urban Development (MA&UD) minister KT Rama Rao instructed GHMC officials to ensure that agencies deploy additional manpower and machinery to execute works under the Strategic Road Development Plan (SRDP) at a review meeting held at the GHMC head office on Monday.

He directed the GHMC officials to take up multiple SRDP works simultaneously.

The minister reviewed 18 works being undertaken under the SRDP.

“Line departments including water board and electricity department officials were asked to shift utilities so that SRDP works are executed on a war footing. SRDP workers will work round-the-clock in shifts,” said a GHMC official.

Officials said traffic will be diverted at important places in consultation with the traffic police.

Mayor Bonthu Rammohan, MA&UD principal secretary Arvind Kumar and GHMC officials attended the meeting.

Title: Michael B. Jordan will kill it as James Bond, says Billie Eilish
Content: Grammy-winning singer Billie Eilish has batted for 'Black Panther' star Michael B Jordan as best suited actor to take forward the James Bond franchise. Fans have been vouching for stars such as Richard Madden , James Norton and Idris Elba to play the fictional British spy after the exit of Daniel Craig with 'No Time to Die'.Eilish, who has crooned the theme song for the upcoming film, said Jordon would be perfect as the suave spy."Honestly, Michael B Jordan would kill that s***. I think he'd kill it," Eilish said during an appearance on a show.Craig has already announced that he will be bidding adieu to the role after starring in 'Casino Royale', 'Quantum Of Solace', 'Skyfall', 'Spectre' and the latest one, directed by Cary Joji Fukunaga 'No Time to Die' will release in April this year and also stars Oscar-winning actor Rami Malek

Title: Civic body may struggle to meet revenue target for 2019-20 fiscal
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) is working hard to meet its target of collecting Rs 359 crore as property tax, including tax on vacant land, this fiscal. As of Sunday, the civic body has realised Rs 221 crore with hardly a month left before the end of the financial year.

In the 2018-19 fiscal, the GVMC had collected more than Rs 300 crore in taxes. Following that, the civic body proposed a collectible demand of Rs 350 crore this fiscal by bringing new tax assessments into the tax net of the corporation. Now, the GVMC is yet to collect Rs 138 crore, within the next month, to meet the target it had set for itself.

Speaking to TOI, MVD Phani Ram, deputy commissioner ( revenue ) of GVMC said that the civic body could add around 24,000 tax assessments, both through revision of existing assessment and by getting new assessments. “We are making all efforts to achieve 100% of our tax collection target. The civic body has started issuing notices, warrants and property sealing notices to tax defaulters,” Ram added.

He further said the civic body could collect Rs 20 crore water tax out of the collectible demand of nearly Rs 69 crore. “We have launched a special tax drive to reach our target,” Phani Ram informed.

In the last fiscal, the civic body had managed to collect Rs 50 crore more on property tax than the previous fiscal by conducting aggressive tax collection drives. The 2018-19 financial year was the first time that the civic body earned more than Rs 300 crore, making it a record of sorts.

Now, the GVMC wants to continue the momentum and reach its Rs 359crore target. The civic body has been trying to bolster its tax system to ensure the smooth functioning of the civic body for the last few years. Additionally, with the city expanding from all sides, GVMC is faced with the challenge of creating additional infrastructure. The GVMC mostly relies on its own funds for creation of infrastructure.

Title: GVMC official reviews waste mgmt system
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Thameem Ansariya, additional commissioner of GVMC , visited several colonies in the 11th ward of the city along with zonal-level officials on Monday. During the course of her visit, the additional commissioner reviewed the newly-introduced facial recognition system for sanitation workers and the garbage collection through online waste management system.

Ansariya interacted with locals in the Gandhinagar slum wherein she enquired about the state of water supply, underground drainage system, street lighting and sanitation services being offered by GVMC. She also inspected two under-construction buildings in TPT Colony. Further, Ansariya appealed to locals to segregate waste before handing it over the the GVMC sanitation staff.

The GVMC is currently installing QR code-embedded radio frequency identification (RFID) tags on walls of every household to implement the online waste management system. Sanitation workers will have to scan these codes with devices provided by GVMC, which will then make an entry into the online database. Further, the GVMC has also introduced facial recognition-based attendance system for workers.

Title: Visakhapatnam: Rushikonda boat control room to open soon
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

The boat control room under construction at Rushikonda in Visakhapatnam

VISAKHAPATNAM: The boat control room , which is coming up at the Rushikonda beach, is likely to be inaugurated ahead of the tourist season.

Confirming this to TOI, Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation (APTDC) Visakhapatnam divisional manager DVM Reddy said it is the first of its kind in the state that has been exclusively designed to check mishaps.

“For Visakhapatnam city, Rushikonda Beach was chosen to get a control room. Everything is ready. We are waiting for the inauguration of the facility. It will be operational by the beginning of the summer season, which usually witnesses heavy crowd at the beach,” Reddy told TOI.

Explaining how the officials will work, Reddy said it will be operated by13 officials from various government departments, such as revenue, fire, police, irrigation, fisheries, tourism, medical, meteorological and health. Each will their own set of responsibilities. For instance, an irrigation officer will provide updates on route clearance, water levels; a meteorological department officer will provide updates on weather; a team of police will be there to check the boat and the passengers.

The control room at Rushikonda is one of the nine such boat control rooms, which are being built across nine tourist destinations across the state including Kakinada, Mummidivaram, and Vijayawada. The government had announced these control rooms following a major boat mishap at Devipatnam along the Godavari in neighbouring East Godavari district last year.

The government allocated Rs 1.7 crore for the control rooms, which will be equipped with required technical tools, infrastructure and manpower.

Title: Four-day workshop on energy research begins at IIPE
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: A four-day workshop on ‘Research Opportunities in Petroleum, Energy and Natural Gas’— ReOPEN 2020 was inaugurated at the Indian Institute of Petroleum and Energy ( IIPE ) on Monday.

MK Surana, chairman and managing director of Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited (HPCL) was the chief guest.

The focus of the workshop will be on technologies that can improve energy efficiency, reduce carbon emissions and bring renewable energy closer to implementation.

Speaking on the occasion, Surana said that India is one of the few countries in the world to adopt BS-VI norms from BS-IV at par with, or even ahead of several developed countries and that India has taken a giant leap in emission norms by directly migrating from BS-IV to BS-VI. “India has made a name for itself in the refining sector. While consumption of India’s crude oil stands at about 225 million tonnes per annum, the refining capacity of the country is much higher at 249 million tonnes.”

Surana further said that under BS-IV norms, the fuel sulphur content will come down to 10ppm, which was 5,000ppm nearly 25 years ago.

Explaining research opportunities in petroleum, energy and natural gas, Surana said that researchers can explore opportunities in converting agricultural waste to fuel. “This can reduce import bills, take care of energy requirements and solve the pollution problem. India is currently importing about 83% of its total energy requirements from. This can be a key research area,” Surana said.

Title: Navigation training for Andhra Pradesh fishermen
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: Fishermen’s associations in the state have decided to impart navigation and safety training to fishermen across the state following last year’s incident, when eight local fishermen drifted into Bangladesh waters and spent more than three months in the neighbouring country’s jail before being released last month.

“It has happened twice now when fishermen from the state entered the waters of neighbouring countries and got caught. We have therefore decided to hold a workshop on vessel safety and navigation for fishermen of the state,” Arjilli Dasu, executive director of Fisherfolk Foundation, told TOI. The foundation is a community organisation which works for the interests of fishermen in AP.

The workshop is scheduled to be held on March 28 in Visakhapatnam. Fishermen would be given a basic training on navigation and taught how to use vehicle monitoring system (VMS). “We want all boats involved in deep sea fishing to be fitted with VMS. The cost of installation for such system is around Rs 1 lakh. We have requested the state government to give a 30% subsidy to fishermen to install the system,” added Dasu.

The Union government is already giving a subsidy of 50% to install VMS through the Marine Products Exports Development Authority (MPEDA).

If the state government agrees to the 30% subsidy proposal put forward by the associations, fishermen will have to spend only 20% of the installation cost.

“With fish population reducing along the Andhra coastline, we have to travel to as far as Bengal for a good catch. Such a system would definitely shield us from entering the water of neighbouring countries,” said N Buallaya, a fisherman.

Title: AMRC gets govt nod to call for quotations
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state government issued an order on Monday authorising the Amaravati Metro Rail Corporation ( AMRC ) to call for quotations for the detailed project report (DPR) for modern tram corridors for a length of 60.2km.

The 60km tram corridor will be developed in the second phase of the 140 km Visakhapatnam light metro rail project. The AMRC has also been authorised to avail transaction advisory from the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation, RITES Limited and Urban Mass Transit Company Limited.

The state government has already given its nod to AMRC to invite bids for preparation of the DPR of the first phase 80 km project around two weeks ago. The four tram corridors of the second phase project include NAD Junction-Pendurthi (10.2 km), Steel Plant-Anakapalli (18.2 km), Old Post Office-Rushikonda beach (15.4 km) and Rushikonda beach-Bheemili beach (16.4 km). The trams, which run on virtual tracks on the road, work based on ‘autonomous rail rapid transit system’.

Title: 6 months on, NIT yet to hand over 1L files to NMC
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Nagpur: Despite the state government making the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) sole planning authority of the city six months ago, the Nagpur Improvement Trust ( NIT ) is yet to hand over over 1 lakh files to the civic body.

Citing this and other reasons, municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe has stressed the need for total abolition of NIT and handing over of open spaces, public utility (PU) lands, funds, staff etc to the NMC.

In a letter to the state urban development department (UDD) on February 18, Mundhe, also one of the trustees in NIT, blamed the agency for non-implementation of city’s development plan (DP) in a planned manner.

On August 27, 2019, the BJP government had made the NMC sole planning authority of the city. But the government did not complete the process of abolishing the NIT totally and handing over its properties and liabilities to the NMC.

Immediately after becoming minister in the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government, guardian minister Nitin Raut requested CM Uddhav Thackeray to give back planning authority status of seven schemes and Gunthewari areas to the NIT. Accordingly, the UDD had sought opinion of NMC and NIT.

Mundhe said it will not be appropriate to again give back planning authority status to the NIT. “The question of reconsideration of NIT does not arise at all. Also, there is no need to change the government’s decision,” he said.

The municipal commissioner said, “The NMC has started regularizing unauthorized plots and disposing off applications received by it as well as NIT after the government’s decision. There is delay from NMC’s side in disposing off applications as NIT is yet to hand over all files. Also, wrong message about NMC is spreading in public about the NMC only due to NIT. In fact, the NMC has taken up cases in a speedy manner. The NIT is yet to transfer its staff despite repeated reminders from the NMC,” he said.

An NIT official said, “The NMC has not taken away all files. We have time and again asked NMC to take possession of all files at a time. But the NMC is taking whichever file it requires. The decision on NIT’s staff is pending at government level,” he said.

In his letter, Mundhe also state, “The NIT did not hand over all regularized layouts to the NMC despite being mandatory. The NIT regularized 2,084 of total 3,822 unuathorized layouts. As many as 1.11 lakh plots have been regularized whereas demand notes were issued to 1.27 lakh. Only 126 layouts have been handed over to the NMC. Hence, the NMC is unable to execute works. People are upset with NMC over recovering property tax and NIT not executing developmental works,” he said.

Mundhe said, “The city’s DP could not be implemented in a planned manner. The NIT made itself planning authority for maximum reservations while preparing DP. It was supposed to acquire reserved lands, but did nothing leaving people without any facilities. The NIT even deleted various types of reservations and regularized unauthorized layouts and plots on it. It was also made the planning authority under the Gunthewari Act. Land owners were supposed to submit applications within six months. It did not regularize all plots despite passing of 18 years. Also, it did not take possession of all PU lands,” he said.

Mundhe also talked about the NMC’s general body passing a resolution unanimously to maintain NMC as the sole planning authority. “The mayor requested the government to direct NIT to transfer properties, liabilities and staff to the NMC,” he added.

Title: Macho Man & Elton John songs play for Potus
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

AHMEDABAD: The Trump-Modi bonhomie at Motera had an interesting soundtrack. As the US President, accompanied by PM Modi, appeared on stage at the newly constructed stadium, ‘ Macho Man’ by the American disco group Village People rang out on the loudspeakers as the crowd burst into loud applause.

Maria Abi-Habib, a reporter for The New York Times, tweeted: “I never thought I’d be listening to ‘Macho Macho man’ in Gujarat, let alone with a crowd of 120,000 people anywhere in this world.

The gala ended with the strains of The Rolling Stones’ number, ‘Ýou Can’t Always Get What You Want’, a song that often plays at his campaign rallies in the US. The band has repeatedly asked Trump to stop playing their music, but clearly haven’t had much success.

Another of Trump’s rally favourites is Elton John though the British singer-songwriter politely declined to play at his inauguration. At Motera, the Elton songs that played were Rotten Peaches and Tiny Dancer and Indian Sunset.

The English songs played after Trump’s entry were selected by his team, said sources in Gujarat Cricket Association, which owns the cricket stadium.

The audience was also regaled with Gujarati folksongs like ‘Kasumbi no rang' and Bollywood medleys including ‘It happens only in India’ and ‘Desh mera rangrez hai babu’. Kailash Kher and other Indian artists performed. Composer AR Rahman shared his new track Ahimsa on Twitter. “Here’s a track to welcome President Donald Trump ,” he tweeted.

Title: Visakhapatnam: Newly-married woman kills self
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

VISAKHAPATNAM: A woman committed suicide by hanging herself from a ceiling fan at her home in Sekuvanaipalem area under New Port police station limits in Visakhapatnam on Monday.

The woman, identified as 26-year-old K Priya, got married to K Gowtham nearly four months ago after a prolonged romantic association. The couple had settled down together at Peda Gantyada.

Priya used to a work as a beautician while Gowtham was an auto-driver. Local sources said that Priya and Gowtham entered into a heated argument on Monday following which Priya rushed into the bedroom and hanged herself to the ceiling fan.

Upon receiving information, police rushed to the spot and sent the body for post-mortem at King George Hospital. A case has been registered and the husband, Gowtham, has been taken into custody for

interrogation. tnn

Title: Middlemen out: Farmers in mini-vans are reaching out to consumers directly
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

A farmer-turned-fruit vendor with his mini-van in Visakhapatnam on Monday

Visakhapatnam: Mini-vans have played a major role in transforming farmers into fruit vendors. Many small and medium farmers, instead of selling their orchard produce to wholesalers, are now directly selling their produce to customers within the city.

This phenomena is not a new one. About three decades ago, women carrying vegetable baskets on their heads would roam the streets of residential areas in the city, selling their vegetable produce directly to households. However, there was a sharp decline in such direct selling, mainly due to rapid urbanisation, which had engulfed much of the agriculture and horticulture area around the city. Farmers used to produce vegetables in fields, on which we have the massive townships of Madhurawada, Yendada and Rushikonda.

Today thanks to the introduction of mini-vans and large autos, farmers are back with a bang. Many of them come from as far as Yelamanchili-Narsipatnam belt, which are 70 to 80 kms away. “Selling in the city has a major advantage, the difference is the price factor. If I sell my vegetables in the local shandies or to wholesalers, the rewards are little. Take for example, drumsticks, in the city, depending on the size and quality of the sticks, I can make up to Rs 4 per stick. However, in rural shandies and the wholesale market, I cannot make more than one and half rupees, which is not more than Rs 15 per bundle often as against Rs 40,” observed, Y V Chalapathi, a farmer from Chodavaram.

Chalapathi is just one of the many farmers selling their produce directly, instead of going through the cumbersome process of selling them in rythu bazaars or wholesale markets.

P Latcha Reddy a wholesale merchant from Tuni mango market stated, “Small farmers who have mixed mango orchards, prefer to sell directly in the city. High-end mango varieties such as Banganapalli and Suvarnarekha sell for Rs 100 a kilo (roughly four to five units), the small farmers, whose orchards have mixed plantations sell mangoes for Rs 70 a kilo. They usually park at the main residential area junctions in the city and from 0700 am to 1100 am, they sell their produce, which in case of a mini-van or auto does not exceed a tonne.”

According to estimates made by sources in the rythu bazaars, the volumes of some vegetables and most fruits sold this way, equals the volumes sold through the rythu bazaars. In case of mangoes alone, the estimate is 500 tonnes, which would roughly translate into 30 large truck loads.”

Title: Polls coming up, Trump woos Gujarati diaspora
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

AHMEDABAD: US President Donald Trump ’s bonhomie with Gujarati-origin Indian PM Narendra Modi was unmissable on Monday. Trump in his speech said that the four million strong Indian diaspora has contributed immensely to the development of US. He also acknowledged the strong Gujarati diaspora by mentioning that one in four NRIs has roots in Gujarat.

NRGs in particular and NRIs at large are known to have affinity towards Democrats. But Trump’s stance on India and support for the country on global arena might swing votes in his favour, believe some diaspora members.

However, the NRGs who were part of the event on Monday, saw it as a reciprocation of love which was on display during Howdy Modi event last year. “I am sure the Namaste Trump event will leave a deep impression on the US President who termed himself as a friend of India and Indians,” said Haribhai Patel, a resident of Chicago and vice-president of Republican Hindu Coalition. Patel said that 50-odd NRGs had come on their own to the event as there was no official contingent of NRIs with Trump on his two-day India visit.

Madhu Patel, another NRG who was at the event, said that he did not see it as a political event. “It was homecoming of a friend — it’s personal relationship between Indian PM and US President which was on show. I don’t know how it would pan out politically for the duo, but it would build a stronger image for India globally and would also help NRIs in the US,” said Patel, adding that with Trump’s stance on India, many NRGs are supporting the Republicans in the US.

Title: Loudest 'Namaste' President will hear
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

AHMEDABAD: When 1.2 lakh people said 'namaste', all at the same time, the sound travelled across the world's largest cricket arena here - the Motera stadium - from the galleries to the ground, and the VVIP zone on the stage.

On Monday, when US President Donald Trump began his speech with 'namaste,' the entire stadium returned the greeting together.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi 's call, 'Long Live Indian-American Friendship', received a similar response. And, the sheer size of the stadium inspired awe.

The stadium was packed much before Modi and Trump arrived at noon as people waited for hours despite the scorching heat.

They received a spectacular ovation as they strode onto the stage. Groups from several districts of Gujarat were spread across the stadium. The loudest roar of approval came when Modi and Trump addressed each other as 'friends'. The US President's allusion to Bollywood blockbusters, his 'chaiwala' reference about Modi, and his appreciation of the contribution of NRIs in the US drew spirited cheers from the crowd.

For the police, it was a big task. People were frisked by two policemen simultaneously. "This allowed us to frisk each person in just five seconds. Still, it took about three-and-a-half hours for the stadium to fill up," said a city police official.

Those at the stadium were provided specially-designed white T-shirts and caps to ensure uniformity. A few groups entered the stadium with saffron jackets with 'Namaste Trump' logo them. Many put on Modi and Trump masks.

A participant from Khokhra in Ahmedabad, who did not wish to be named, said that the corporators took him and others in the neighourhood to the venue in buses. "We were provided breakfast before we started for Motera at 8.30am. At the stadium, we were served boondi-ganthiya and buttermilk," said the participant . Corporators were asked to click photographs of groups of people they had brought to the ground.

The stadium began to fill up from 7.30am and a host of performers kept the people entertained before Trump and Modi arrived. As Kailash Kher , Veena Saxena , Kinjal Dave, Kirtidan Gadhvi and Sairam Dave performed, people broke into a dance.

Title: All of India on display in 22km roadshow
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

AHMEDABAD: A group of 25 traders had been dancing for six hours since early Monday morning. The 'Gair-Naach', a Rajasthani folk dance performed by the Bhil community, was a tough feat but the all-men troupe was not complaining.

"Our troupe played the dhol and danced to its beats with gunghroos tied to our feet without a break," said Bhimji Chaudhary, one of the troupe members. Chaudhary was happy they could showcase Rajasthani culture at the roadshow of US President Donald Trump and PM Narendra Modi .

All along the 22-km stretch from the airport to Motera stadium, tableaux, folk dancers and musicians from 28 states of India lined the roadsides, rolling out the country's cultural tapestry. At least 50 stages were set up with some bearing unique names like Lilliput and Michael Jackson.

Young, old and children alike thronged the roads to watch Trump. Home-maker Meena Bharwad was there with her eight-month-old son . There was unprecedented curiosity over Trump's bulletproof limousine 'The Beast' as large crowds bent over the railings to click photographs of the vehicle. Unlike Japanese PM Shinzo Abe and wife Akie Abe, who participated in an 8-km roadshow from airport to Gandhi Ashram in an open vehicle, the fact that Trump was in a closed vehicle was a bit of a dampener .

"We wanted to catch a glimpse of Trump and Modi together. But we understand the security concerns," said Madhav Patel, a professional. Subrato Paul and Riddhan Sarkar, who travelled from Kolkata hoping to sell Team India t-shirts and tricolours failed to make brisk sale but were happy to be there at the world's largest cricket stadium.

Title: 'India gives hope to humanity'
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

AHMEDABAD: Emphasising that the US military had been "rebuilt" and that Washington was quickly revitalising its alliances and friendships all around the world, US President Donald Trump on Monday referred to India-US land, air and sea military exercise while announcing a joint commitment to a "free and open" the Indo-Pacific.

"It is faith in free society, confidence in your own people, your trust in your own citizens and respect for dignity of every person that makes the US and India such a natural, beautiful and enduring friendship," Trump said in his speech at Motera .

In fulsome praise, Trump said, "The story of the Indian nation is a tale of astounding progress and a miracle of democracy, extraordinary diversity and above all a strong and noble people. India gives hope to all of humanity. It has become an economic giant, largest democracy and one of the most amazing nations anywhere in the world."

Referring to PM Modi's humble beginnings, he cited him as living proof of what Indians could achieve through hard work. Trump said Modi was a leader who worked for India night and day and who he was proud to call his "true friend".

"We will always remember this remarkable hospitality. From this day on, India will hold a special place in our hearts," Trump said. Referring to the PM, he said, "Everybody loves him but I will tell you this, he is very tough" and chuckled at his observation, adding Modi won a landslide in the largest democratic election to be held anywhere in the world.

The speech came against the backdrop of criticism of India over alleged rise of intolerance and erosion of inter-faith amity. But Trump showed no sign that the charges had resonated with him yet as he launched into fulsome praise for "one great Indian nation" despite diversity of faiths and beliefs. "Your unity is an inspiration to the world," he said.

"All Indians - Hindus, Muslims, Christians and Jews, rich and poor - must take pride in glories of the past, and a bright future," the American president said. Emphasising India's democratic traditions, he said there was a difference between a nation that rose by coercion and one that rose by setting people free, and added that India would soon be home to the biggest middle class anywhere.

Trump struck an emotional connect when he expressed warm approval for people of Indian origin in the US who he said were contributing to American life in every field. "They are titans of business, the biggest, the best, pioneers of science, masters of arts," he said.

The president took on opposition at home and spelt out why he thought there was great potential in India-US ties, and said US unemployment was low and the economy was booming. "A booming America is a great thing for the world," he said, adding that he had shown how reduced taxes and regulatory burdens had worked and that Modi was also carrying out reforms at a record pace.

Title: Thane: 'Dummy', student held in one of five HSC exam malpractice cases
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Shahapur police arrested a 21-year-old man for posing as an HSC student and appearing for his English exam at a centre in Khardi, Thane district. The student was arrested as well. This case was among the five malpractices reported on Monday in the Maharashtra State Board's Mumbai division, which consists of Mumbai, Thane, Raigad and Palghar.

Teacher Hirve Butha, supervisor at Primary and Secondary High School, Khardi found an examinee's behaviour suspicious and checked his hall ticket during the first HSC exam on February 18. The photo on the hall ticket was not the same as the one in their records, and Butha informed Dattatray Mahajan, the chief exam conductor at the centre.

On questioning the accused, Mahajan found that he was a dummy student identified as Nitesh Dhapte, who was giving the exam on behalf of student Rahul Ghavat (19). Talking to TOI, Mahajan said, "After getting confirmation that he was a dummy, we informed the local Shahapur police to file an FIR." Police sources said Ghavat had failed twice in two subjects, and had hired Dhapte to give all his exams on his behalf.

School authorities informed the board about the incident only on Monday. "We will seek a clarification from the centre about the case," said Sandeep Sangave, Mumbai division secretary.

Another incident reported on Monday was at Nutan Vidyalaya in Goregaon, where a student tore his own answersheet. According to the state board's daily report of malpractices, a student was using a mobile phone and a Bluetooth device to copy at a centre in Bhiwandi. "The centres will send a detailed report soon. The student is expected to only write his paper. If he tears the answersheet, he destroyed the board's property and hence it is considered to be a malpractice," said Sangave.

Other malpractices included students copying from each other at Borivli and Bandra centres. In such cases, students are allowed to appear for the rest of the papers and the board decides on action to be taken after students explain themselves before a committee. Students may be barred from appearing for the examination for one to five attempts.

Across the division, 94,973 students took the physics exam on Monday. Another 1.42 lakh students appeared for the secretarial practice paper and 29,231 students took the political science paper. No malpractices were reported in these papers. In the state, 119 cases of malpractices were recorded on Monday. The highest number of cases-30, was in Aurangabad, during the political science paper.

Title: Chief Sonia not invited, all Cong netas to skip Prez banquet
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

NEW DELHI: Congress is set to give a complete miss to President Kovind’s banquet for US President Donald Trump , with all three party principals deciding to skip the dinner at Rashtrapati Bhavan on Tuesday — alleging that the government had kept party chief Sonia Gandhi out of Trump’s visit.

Leader of opposition in Rajya Sabha Ghulam Nabi Azad and former PM Manmohan Singh decided to follow the lead of Congress leader in Lok Sabha Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury, who said on Saturday that he would not attend the dinner.

Chowdhury said he was offended that the Congress chief had been completely ignored for the US president’s visit and no meeting had been arranged with the opposition leader. He claimed it was contrary to the practice followed by past governments when interactions were arranged with principal opposition functionaries. Azad is learnt to have conveyed his “thank you” to President’s House but expressed inability to attend. He regretted that Sonia, who is chairperson of the Congress parliamentary party, was not invited. Azad and Singh are learnt to have accepted the invite before turning it down on Monday. It is believed that Chowdhury’s public announcement forced the hands of his colleagues. The decision of complete boycott came after nearly 36 hours of silence.

Title: Agusta case: CBI, ED oppose Michel’s bail plea
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

NEW DELHI: The CBI and ED have opposed in the Delhi HC the bail plea of Christian Michel, the alleged middleman arrested in connection with the AgustaWestland VVIP helicopter scam cases.

These agencies said last week he must not be granted bail as he has connections to influential people. Opposing any relief, the agencies have contended he was extradited to India with great difficulty and there was every likelihood he would flee from justice if allowed to come out on bail as he had no roots in India.

Michel, who was arrested in 2018 and has been in judicial custody since January 5, 2019, had been denied bail in both the CBI and ED cases by the trial court. He has now approached the HC against the lower court’s decision.

They added that he had successfully evaded the entire investigation and trial in Italy , which despite being a European Union member could not successfully bring him to face the judicial process. The agencies argued that Michel cannot claim parity with other co-accused.

Title: Announce allocation for Mahadayi project in budget, HK Patil tells CM
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Hubballi: Notwithstanding the stance adopted by the Goa government with regard to the Supreme Court ’s verdict on the orders of the Mahadayi Water Dispute Tribunal – Goa chief minister Pramod Sawant has expressed his government’s wish to seek a stay on the apex court’s order – MLA and senior Congress member HK Patil on Monday urged Karnataka CM BS Yediyurappa to allocate a sum of Rs 2,000 crore in the state budget for the project.

In its recent order, the apex court asked the Centre to issue a gazzete notification ratifying the award of the Mahadayi tribunal. While the order, which gives Karnataka sanction to divert the waters of the river to arid regions in North Karnataka, was greeted with glee in the region, neighbouring Goa expressed its displeasure over the same.

Urging the central government to issue the notification at the earliest, Patil said, “The state government must start the groundwork for the Kalasa-Banduri Nala project. The state government must exert pressure on the Centre to ensure that no time is lost in the issuance of the notification and work can start at the earliest.”

Patil called on Yediyurappa to lead an all-party delegation from the state to New Delhi to meet the Union minister for water resources.

Meanwhile, the former minister expressed displeasure over the number of files pending for clearance across departments. He said that more than one lakh government files had not been cleared. “This proves that the government is not active, and attests to corruption having spread to all levels of the administration. The common people are struggling to get justice,” Patil alleged.

Pointing out that Karnataka had a reputation for transparency and accountability, Patil said, “Various departments have been feted for transparency. In fact, people could track the movement of files on their fingertips. But they have not been able to do this for the past few months.”

Tourism minister’s suggestion draws flak

The senior Congress member did not pull any punches in criticising tourism minister CT Ravi, who mooted giving permission to operate casinos in Karnataka as a means of generating revenue and employment. “The BJP leaders are very fond of talking about culture in public. But in their implementation of projects they think very differently. Ravi’s statements highlight the gap between their real objectives and what they preach in public,” Patil added.

Making it clear that the Congress was opposed to starting casinos in the state, the former minister said, “Is the minister trying to turn Karnataka into Thailand? The government must drop this idea right here, and the CM must announce that no casino will be opened in the state. The Congress will fight against the implementation of such a proposal.”

MLC Srinivas Mane and AM Hindasgeri were among those in Patil’s company at the media interaction.

Title: 60 years on, this co-op society keeps party politics at bay
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Haveri: Notwithstanding their size, squabbles and disagreements between numerous factions within cooperative societies often turn out to be their collective Achilles’s Heel. Often, most members are caught up in the pursuit of their personal goals or furthering of their party agenda to be bothered by the needs of the public. Administrative positions in these societies are the subject of hotly contested elections. The purpose of such societies, which is to act as a conduit between the grassroots and the higher echelons of the government, is often defeated as a result.

However, the agriculture produce marketing cooperative society of Hirekerur taluk appears to have been, and continues to remain, immune to the problems that political squabbles inevitably bring in their tow. Since its inception 60 years ago, the functioning of the society has not been interrupted by elections and all the organisational problems that they entail. All members of the society adhere to a set of principles, and all of them have reaped the dividends of efficient administration as a result.

The cooperative society has six branches and a head office, and has been supplying fertilisers and seeds to farmers across Hirekerur taluk since it was founded in 1959. The four fuel stations that the society owns offer petrol and diesel to farmers on credit. In addition to these services, the society owns a rice mill in Chikkerur and a ginning factory in Hirekerur. In all, the society has as many as 60 people in its employ.

President of the society SS Patil said that the organisation had been founded on June 3, 1959 by BG Banakar with just 117 members. The present strength of the society – it currently boasts 4,800 members on its rolls – attests to its growth over the years, he said. “We have an investment budget of Rs 15 crore, and last year we purchased a total of 1,000 tonnes of cotton from our farmers. This year, that figure rose to 1,060 tonnes. Our society has consistently been working for the welfare of the farmers. As a result, there is no scope for party politics here,” Patil said.

Former MLA UB Banakar and chairman of the Karnataka State Agriculture Produce Processing and Exporting Corporation Ltd UB Banakar was lavish in his praise of the society’s accomplishments and its insulation from politics. “The record of the society in Hirekerur is noteworthy particularly because of the pathetic condition of other such bodies. With the support of its members, it has managed to work for the welfare of farmers, the economic condition of whom has improved as a result,” said the former MLA.

Golden jubilee celebrations today

The Hirekerur taluk agriculture produce marketing cooperative society will celebrate its golden jubilee on Tuesday, along with the Taluk Vidyavardaka Souharda Cooperative Society. Panditaradya Shivacharya Swamiji, Karnataka minister Basavaraj Bommai, agriculture minister BC Patil are expected to participate in the event. The Dr Abdul Kalam Science Hall, built at a cost of Rs 5 crore, will be inaugurated on the occasion.

Title: Villager lynched in Bastar over black magic rumour
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

A 53-year-old man in Bastar has been lynched by a mob in his village — some of them neighbours — on the rumour that he was casting “murderous black magic spells”.

Victim Mancheet Kashyap of Charagaon village was beaten until he died on Saturday night. His terrified family, who spent all night cradling his body, could reach out to police only on Sunday after which 10 suspects have been arrested for murder and rioting under IPC and sections 4 and 5 of Chhattisgarh Witchcraft Atrocities (Prevention) Act, 2005.

The lynching was allegedly triggered by a ‘witchdoctor’, with whom villagers discussed their troubles. Cops found that a family in the village was distraught after two deaths for unknown reasons.

Title: Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Bahrain... virus cases soar in W Asia
Content: SEOUL: The new virus took aim at a broadening swath of the globe on Monday, with officials in West Asia and Europe scrambling to limit the spread of an outbreak that showed signs of stabilising at its Chinese epicentre but posed new threats far beyond.Clusters of the virus continued to emerge, including a possible one in Qom , an Iranian city where the country’s semiofficial ILNA news agency cited a lawmaker in reporting a staggering 50 people had died of Covid-19. Iran’s health ministry rejected that, insisting toll remained at 12. Five neighbouring countries —Iraq, Kuwait , Bahrain, Oman and Afghanistan — reported their first cases, with those infected all having links to Iran.Italy has locked down 50,000 people in 10 towns to contain the first major virus outbreak in Europe, as fears grow of a spread across the continent. On Monday, the number of cases in Italy rose to 219 from at least 152 on Sunday.Across the world, stock markets and futures dipped on fears of a global slowdown due to the virus spread, with the Dow down more than 800 points. The number of people sickened by the coronavirus topped 79,000 globally.WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said using the word “pandemic” did not fit the facts. “We must focus on containment while preparing for a potential pandemic,” he said in Geneva.

Title: Illegal Indian migrant shot dead in US store
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

Maninder Singh, an illegal immigrant into the US hailing from Karnal district , was shot dead in a California town on Saturday. The 29-year-old from Uplana village worked at a departmental store in Whittier , southern California, and is survived by his elderly parents, wife, eight-year-old daughter, and five-year-old son.

Maninder, who had gone to the US in June 2019, was shot dead by a robber who barged into the store and fled after committing the crime.

Title: Accidents due to bad roads: Madras High Court warns NHAI
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020

NHAI may be held responsible for accidents due to bad roads and signage, the Madras high court has said

CHENNAI: If any accident happens due to bad condition of roads or signages, the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) may be held responsible and made to pay compensation, Madras high court has warned.

A division bench of Justice M Sathyanarayanan and Justice R Hemalatha, making the remarks during PIL proceedings taken up on Monday, said: "It is made clear that at some point of time this court also may take the call that if any accident takes place on account of the bad condition of the road, signage, NHAI may also be held liable and responsible for compensating the victims of the road accident.

The judges issued the caution as an advocate-commissioner appointed by the court to monitor the progress made by NHAI on the Maduravoyal- Walajahpet stretch of NH4, submitted in his report that it appeared that the patch works done recently and lighting on the entire stretch were extremely poor and that they were a matter of 'grave concern'.

The report also pointed out the absence of proper traffic signals and restrooms along the stretch and the poor frequency of highway patrols. Noting down the submissions, the bench made it clear that the stretch of road should be relaid be strictly in conformity with the Indian Road Standard Congress.

The judges also suggested that it is high time a single window agency is created by the state government to enable the NHAI to get clearances from various stakeholders expeditiously. They also suo motu impleaded the chief secretary to government of Tamil Nadu as a party to the case.

Earlier, the NHAI authorities submitted that high mast lighting will be provided at toll plaza locations and at 17 major junctions along the Sriperumbudur-Walajahpet stretch.

Already, the assistant solicitor-general had informed the court that the six-laning of the 34km stretch between Sriperumbudur and Karaipettai section was to be completed by May 2019. However, the contractor has achieved a progress of 2.4 % against the target of 15.47 % as of January 31, 2020. It was further submitted that the appointed date for six laning of Karaipettai to Wallajapet section of NH4 was fixed as February 11 last year and the contractor achieved a physical progress of 5.80% against the target of 31.95% as on January 31, 2020.

To a query by the bench as to why there is delayed by the contractors, the ASG submitted that NHAI has to approach several agencies in the state government to get clearances and sought a single window agency so that NHAI projects in the state could be completed on time.

Title: Sensex tanks 807 pts, gold at lifetime high of Rs 44,472
Content: MUMBAI: The sensex recorded its second-biggest fall this year on Monday in line with global markets as the coronavirus infection spread to Italy, Iran and South Korea. Riskaverse investors turned to gold, which hit a lifetime high of Rs 44, 472 per 10 gram in Delhi and Rs 43,250 in Mumbai.The 30-share index fell 807 points, or nearly 2%, to close at 40,363. The fall in equities was led by stocks of automobiles, pharmaceuticals and consumer durables over fears of disruption of supplies from China, which accounts for 14% of India’s imports.In the foreign currency markets, the rupee fell 34 paise to close at a more than threemonth low of 72 against the dollar, as there was flight to safety.In Europe, early trades saw Britain’s FTSE 100 fall nearly 3.5%, while the CAC 40 in Paris as well as Germany’s DAX lost almost 4%. The Dow Jones was down nearly 3% after opening on Monday but slipped further by over 1,000 points (see graphic). South Korea’s Kospi fell 3.9% with 231 new cases of the virus being reported on Monday. Earlier in the day, Hong Kong ’s Hang Seng dropped 1.8%.Auto companies, represented in the BSE auto index, were hit the most with the index declining 3.3% on fears of disruption of supplies from China. Tata Motors and Eicher Motors were down 5%, and so were Maruti Suzuki (4.2%), Hero Moto-Corp (2.5%) and Mahindra & Mahindra (2.2%).“Headline indices are down around 2% across all market cap categories, suggesting that the broad-based sell-off is largely in response to weakness in sentiment across the region and spilling over into European trading,” said Emkay Global Financial Services head (sales trading) S Hariharan.“News around the spread of the coronavirus and its concomitant impact on trade and activity levels have been the strongest driver of daily moves in the last few sessions and would continue to be a major factor. The auto sector has been the worst hit over the last two weeks, driven primarily by concerns on supply chain disruptions,” he added. Banks were hit hard over fears of fresh non-performing assets with the government digging in its heels over its demand for adjusted gross revenue dues from telecom companies. ICICI Bank was down 3% and Axis Bank 2.4%. “We believe new forms of stress are emerging (for banks). On the retail side, we have stress from agriculture and commercial vehicle space, and on the corporate side there is stress in real estate, telecom and small and medium enterprises/mid-corporate space,” said Macquarie Capital Securities research analyst (financials) Suresh Ganapathy.

Title: Build own tech capability: Satya Nadella to companies
Content:
This story is from February 25, 2020
